SENTENCES AND THEIR PERPLEXITY


1. the fulton county grand jury said friday an investigation	of atlanta's recent primary election produced no evidence that	any irregularities took place.	5.574729405097006
2. the jury further said in term-end	presentments that the city executive committee which had over-all	charge of the election deserves the praise and thanks of the	city of atlanta for the manner in which the election was conducted.	9.277958118439836
3. the september-october term jury had been charged by fulton	superior court judge durwood pye to investigate reports of possible	irregularities in the hard-fought primary which was won by	mayor-nominate ivan allen jr.	4.264604519874985
4. only a relative handful	of such reports was received the jury said considering the	widespread interest in the election the number of voters and the size	of this city.	11.535635330350408
5. the jury said it did find that many of georgia's	registration and election laws are outmoded or inadequate	and often ambiguous.	8.11095184530014
6. it recommended that fulton legislators	act to have these laws studied and revised to the end of modernizing	and improving them.	13.752744159583582
7. the grand jury commented on a number	of other topics among them the atlanta and fulton county purchasing	departments which it said are well operated and follow generally	accepted practices which inure to the best interest of both governments.	6.691416081109971
8. however the jury said it believes these	two offices should be combined to achieve greater efficiency and reduce	the cost of administration.	11.533427862790573
9. the city purchasing department	the jury said is lacking in experienced clerical personnel	as a result of city personnel policies.	8.503256313167215
10. it urged that the city take	steps to remedy this problem.	16.515179662724922
11. implementation of georgia's	automobile title law was also recommended by the outgoing jury.	5.674119473116242
12. it urged that the next legislature provide enabling funds	and re-set the effective date so that an orderly implementation of	the law may be effected.	9.316922262203818
13. the grand jury took a swipe at the	state welfare department's handling of federal funds granted for	child welfare services in foster homes.	6.176780722512161
14. this is one of the	major items in the fulton county general assistance program the	jury said but the state welfare department has seen fit to distribute	these funds through the welfare departments of all the counties	in the state with the exception of fulton county which receives	none of this money.	11.241221466696059
15. the jurors said they realize a proportionate	distribution of these funds might disable this program in our less	populous counties.	7.854570662151386
16. nevertheless we feel that in the	future fulton county should receive some portion of these available	funds the jurors said.	9.162437629872713
17. failure to do this will continue to place	a disproportionate burden on fulton taxpayers.	9.933670217503357
18. the jury	also commented on the fulton ordinary's court which has been under	fire for its practices in the appointment of appraisers guardians and	administrators and the awarding of fees and compensation.	7.570548843052115
19. the jury said it found the court has incorporated into	its operating procedures the recommendations of two previous grand	juries the atlanta bar association and an interim citizens committee.	7.948023932695558
20. these actions should serve to protect in fact and in effect the court's wards from undue costs and its appointed and elected servants from unmeritorious criticisms the jury said.	7.728599247157923
21. regarding atlanta's new multi-million-dollar airport the jury recommended that when the new management takes charge jan 1 the airport be operated in a manner that will eliminate political influences.	5.645924244229191
22. the jury did not elaborate but it added that there should be periodic surveillance of the pricing practices of the concessionaires for the purpose of keeping the prices reasonable.	10.789386896525306
23. fulton legislators work with city officials to pass enabling legislation that will permit the establishment of a fair and equitable pension plan for city employes.	7.132680191015796
24. the jury praised the administration and operation of the atlanta police department the fulton tax commissioner's office the bellwood and alpharetta prison farms grady hospital and the fulton health department.	8.172517924529995
25. mayor william b hartsfield filed suit for divorce from his wife pearl williams hartsfield in fulton superior court friday.	5.715209322347487
26. his petition charged mental cruelty.	11.263731156544116
27. the couple was married aug 2 1913.	9.826195600480325
28. they have a son william berry jr and a daughter mrs j m cheshire of griffin.	11.635535812806213
29. attorneys for the mayor said that an amicable property settlement has been agreed upon.	8.631509613778968
30. the petition listed the mayor's occupation as attorney and his age as 71.	8.251220222760594
31. it listed his wife's age as 74 and place of birth as opelika ala.	6.66891696435036
32. the petition said that the couple has not lived together as man and wife for more than a year.	12.942321443397773
33. the hartsfield home is at 637 e pelham rd ne.	7.373098374826277
34. henry l bowden was listed on the petition as the mayor's attorney.	8.350114122530668
35. hartsfield has been mayor of atlanta with exception of one brief interlude since 1937.	6.560932860516071
36. his political career goes back to his election to city council in 1923.	11.583913269744295
37. the mayor's present term of office expires jan 1.	5.39045382628722
38. he will be succeeded by ivan allen jr who became a candidate in the sept 13 primary after mayor hartsfield announced that he would not run for reelection.	13.583751923638069
39. georgia republicans are getting strong encouragement to enter a candidate in the 1962 governor's race a top official said wednesday.	7.876281220466513
40. robert snodgrass state gop chairman said a meeting held tuesday night in blue ridge brought enthusiastic responses from the audience.	8.306436403633366
41. state party chairman james w dorsey added that enthusiasm was picking up for a state rally to be held sept 8 in savannah at which newly elected texas sen john tower will be the featured speaker.	6.820297823452111
42. in the blue ridge meeting the audience was warned that entering a candidate for governor would force it to take petitions out into voting precincts to obtain the signatures of registered voters.	10.741291077955138
43. despite the warning there was a unanimous vote to enter a candidate according to republicans who attended.	9.038193424478628
44. when the crowd was asked whether it wanted to wait one more term to make the race it voted no- and there were no dissents.	9.990273095195713
45. the largest hurdle the republicans would have to face is a	state law which says that before making a first race one of two alternative	courses must be taken:  five per cent of the voters	in each county must sign petitions requesting that the republicans be	allowed to place names of candidates on the general election ballot	or  the republicans must hold a primary under the county unit	system- a system which the party opposes in its platform.	6.103618644627902
46. sam caldwell state highway department public relations director	resigned tuesday to work for lt gov garland byrd's	campaign.	10.501520820889438
47. caldwell's resignation had been expected for some	time.	7.2514301962043
48. he will be succeeded by rob ledford of gainesville who has	been an assistant more than three years.	11.618329243743469

50. the georgia legislature will wind up its 1961 session monday	and head for home- where some of the highway bond money it approved	will follow shortly.	8.569574226279641
51. before adjournment monday afternoon the	senate is expected to approve a study of the number of legislators	allotted to rural and urban areas to determine what adjustments should	be made.	7.742540308452936
52. gov vandiver is expected to make the traditional	visit to both chambers as they work toward adjournment.	10.758838407516802
53. vandiver likely	will mention the $100 million highway bond issue approved earlier	in the session as his first priority item.	4.9025691668804035
54. meanwhile	it was learned the state highway department is very near	being ready to issue the first $30 million worth of highway reconstruction	bonds.	7.895762167785033
55. the bond issue will go to the state courts for a	friendly test suit to test the validity of the act and then the sales	will begin and contracts let for repair work on some of georgia's	most heavily traveled highways.	7.288400354431515
56. a highway department source	said there also is a plan there to issue some $3 million to $4 million	worth of rural roads authority bonds for rural road construction work.	7.066275295625535
57. the department apparently intends to make	the rural roads authority a revolving fund under which new bonds would	be issued every time a portion of the old ones are paid off by tax	authorities.	7.758385459392727
58. vandiver opened his race for governor in 1958 with	a battle in the legislature against the issuance of $50 million worth	of additional rural roads bonds proposed by then gov marvin	griffin.	8.438029042751838
59. the highway department source told the constitution	however that vandiver has not been consulted yet about the plans	to issue the new rural roads bonds.	6.845706253556006
60. schley county rep b d pelham will offer a resolution	monday in the house to rescind the body's action of friday in	voting itself a $10 per day increase in expense allowances.	6.649331166255972
61. pelham	said sunday night there was research being done on whether the	quickie vote on the increase can be repealed outright or whether	notice would have to first be given that reconsideration of the action	would be sought.	7.136953987188732
62. while emphasizing that technical details were	not fully worked out pelham said his resolution would seek to set	aside the privilege resolution which the house voted through 87-31.	8.20779977568832
63. a similar resolution passed in the senate by a vote of 29-5.	8.640923619893442
64. as of sunday night there was no word of a resolution being offered	there to rescind the action.	13.5349816171356
65. pelham pointed out that georgia	voters last november rejected a constitutional amendment to allow legislators	to vote on pay raises for future legislature sessions.	5.972488566401542
66. a veteran jackson county legislator will ask the georgia house	monday to back federal aid to education something it has consistently	opposed in the past.	9.517627729516795
67. rep mac barber of commerce is	asking the house in a privilege resolution to endorse increased federal	support for public education provided that such funds be received	and expended as state funds.	6.15791068460756
68. barber who is in his 13th	year as a legislator said there are some members of our congressional	delegation in washington who would like to see it	passed.	11.163501695339638
69. but he added that none of georgia's congressmen specifically	asked him to offer the resolution.	8.51547410063695
70. the resolution which	barber tossed into the house hopper friday will be formally read	monday.	10.276974943225541
71. it says that in	the event congress does provide this increase in federal funds the	state board of education should be directed to give priority	to teacher pay raises.	7.975160750658859

88. committee approval of gov price daniel's	abandoned property act seemed certain thursday despite the adamant	protests of texas bankers.	7.067835314200581
89. daniel personally led the fight	for the measure which he had watered down considerably since its	rejection by two previous legislatures in a public hearing before	the house committee on revenue and taxation.	6.149201200243353
90. under committee	rules it went automatically to a subcommittee for one week.	10.322033154957222
91. but	questions with which committee members taunted bankers appearing as witnesses	left little doubt that they will recommend passage of it.	7.490651482294354
92. daniel termed extremely conservative his estimate that it would	produce 17 million dollars to help erase an anticipated deficit of	63 million dollars at the end of the current fiscal year next aug	31.	9.950965799888067
93. he told the committee the measure would merely provide means	of enforcing the escheat law which has been on the books since	texas was a republic.	7.757404615437187
94. it permits the state to take over bank accounts	stocks and other personal property of persons missing for seven	years or more.	10.187983095698378
95. the bill which daniel said he drafted personally	would force banks insurance firms pipeline companies and other	corporations to report such property to the state treasurer.	7.428503411409267
96. the escheat	law cannot be enforced now because it is almost impossible to locate	such property daniel declared.	11.316600556365234
97. dewey lawrence a tyler	lawyer representing the texas bankers association sounded the opposition	keynote when he said it would force banks to violate their contractual	obligations with depositors and undermine the confidence of bank	customers.	7.000970795121097
98. if you destroy confidence in banks you do something	to the economy he said.	13.025025798481973
99. you take out of circulation many	millions of dollars.	10.31572994989087
100. rep charles e hughes of sherman	sponsor of the bill said a failure to enact it would amount to	making a gift out of the taxpayers' pockets to banks insurance	and pipeline companies.	7.584584459954743
101. his contention was denied by several	bankers including scott hudson of sherman gaynor b jones	of houston j b brady of harlingen and howard cox of austin.	5.130553283655718
102. cox argued that the bill is probably unconstitutional	since he said it would impair contracts.	13.281709704883754
103. he also complained	that not enough notice was given on the hearing since the bill was	introduced only last monday.	7.530717546599467

2703. there's a lot of talk about the problem of education in america	today.	5.699618349564688

2706. it seems like only last year that we watched them set out up the	hill hand in hand on a rainy day in their yellow raincoats to finger-paint	at the grammar school.	9.444773875674127

2760. here's an idea for a child's room that is easy to execute	and is completely charming using puppets for lamp bases.	5.010252031759538
2761. most children	love the animated puppet faces and their flexible bodies and	they prefer to see them as though the puppets were in action rather than	put away in boxes.	6.798166555963068
2762. displayed as lamps the puppets delight the children	and are decorative accent.	8.045964676280578
2763. to create such a lamp order	a wired pedestal from any lamp shop.	6.9602287455990615
2764. measure the puppet to determine	the height of the light socket allowing three to four inches above the	puppet's head.	9.022653548356015
2765. make sure that the metal tube through which the wire	passes is in the shape of an inverted l the foot of the	l about three inches long so that the puppet can hang directly	under the light.	8.191051594247362
2766. using the strings that manipulate	the puppet suspend him from the light fixture by tying the	strings to the lamp base.	9.314959286435936
2767. in this way you can arrange his legs and arms	in any desired position with feet or one foot barely resting on	the pedestal.	8.095205252393283
2768. if the puppets are of uniform size you can change them	in accord with your child's whims.	9.657363156617283

3066. the u s and	soviet heads of government have met three times since sir winston	churchill in 1953 introduced a new word into international diplomacy	with his call for a fresh approach to the problem of peace at the	summit of the nations.	10.343180919318913

3141. there can	be no doubt that the american catholic accomplishment in the field	of higher education is most impressive: our european brethren never	cease to marvel at the number and the size of our colleges and universities.	8.26069230274092
3142. the deeper wonder is how this miracle was accomplished in decades	rather than in centuries and by immigrant minorities at that.	8.673319563693832
3143. by way of explanation we ourselves are prone to imagine that this achievement	stems from the same american catholic zeal and generosity which	brought the parochial school system into existence.	6.912966878298424
3144. there	is however one curious discrepancy in this broad and flattering picture.	9.319682857288738
3145. viewing the american catholic educational achievement in retrospect	we may indeed see it as a unified whole extending from grade school	to university.	6.313397129208867
3146. but the simple truth is that higher education has	never really been an official american catholic project; certainly	not in the same sense that the establishment of a parochial school	system has been a matter of official policy.	10.342871226256065
3147. official encouragement	is one thing but the down-to-earth test is the allocation of diocesan	and parochial funds.	5.231082729636129
3148. american catholics have responded generously	to bishops' and pastors' appeals for the support necessary to	create parochial schools but they have not contributed in a similar	fashion to the establishment of institutions of higher learning.	8.10501636636711
3149. they	have not done so for the simple reason that such appeals have hardly	ever been made.	7.16245784687459
3150. diocesan authorities generally have not regarded this	as their direct responsibility.	8.377682622354797
3151. all of this may be understandable	enough: it is however in fact difficult to see how diocesan	authorities could have acted otherwise.	8.165473310881005
3152. yet for better or for worse	the truth of the matter is that most american catholic colleges do	not owe their existence to general catholic support but rather to	the initiative resourcefulness and sacrifices of individual religious	communities.	10.62517661112568
3153. community esprit de corps has been the protective	shell which has made the achievement possible.	9.608785456244341
3154. to understand	the past history- and the future potential- of american catholic	higher education it is necessary to appreciate the special character	of the esprit d' corps of the religious community.	7.178231987601147
3155. it is something	more than the arithmetical sum of individual totals of piety and	detachment.	9.518619422726305
3156. a religious community with a vital sense of mission achieves	a degree of group orientation and group identification seldom found	elsewhere.	10.008554997825522
3157. the fact that the group orientation and group identification	are founded on supernatural principles and nourished by the well-springs	of devotion simply give them a deeper and more satisfying dimension.	7.629961523682329
3158. the net result is a uniquely satisfying sense of comradeship	the kind of comradeship which sparks enthusiasm and blunts the cutting	edge of sacrifice and hardship.	9.3429452025571
3159. american catholic colleges	and universities are in a very real sense the product of private	enterprise- the private enterprise of religious communities.	7.667773041382036
3160. had it not been for such private enterprise diocesan authorities	might of course have been goaded into establishing institutions subsidized	by diocesan funds and parish collections and staffed by religious	as paid employees.	9.05614657125685
3161. there is however no point in speculating about such	a possibility: the fact of the matter is that our institutions of	higher learning owe their existence to a spirit not unlike that which	produces the family business.	8.51431168333991
3162. this family-community spirit	is the real explanation of the marvel of our achievement.	9.439598829365151
3163. it is this spirit which explains some of the anomalies of american	catholic higher education in particular the wasteful duplication	apparent in some areas.	8.68712954601904

3167. apart however from the question of wasteful duplication	there is another aspect of the family business spirit	in american catholic higher education which deserves closer scrutiny.	9.589551679368471
3168. for while the past needs of the church in this country may have	been adequately met by collegiate institutions which in temper and tone	closely resembled junior colleges and finishing schools it would	seem that today's need is for the college which more closely resembles	the university in its pursuit of excellence.	8.897433392082458
3169. at the earlier	pre-academic excellence stage of catholic education the operation	could be conducted on an intra-mural community basis.	5.813019514224829

3175. in the above mentioned report of	the notre dame chapter of the american association of university	professors the basic outlook of the new breed of lay faculty emerges	very clearly in the very statement of the problem as the members see	it: even with the best of intentions he	is loath to delegate such authority and responsibility to	a group the membership of which considered in	individual terms is inhomogeneous mortal and of extremely varying	temperament interests and capabilities.	7.1002763446587265

3183. word spreads rapidly in the tightly knit academic profession	much given to attending meetings and conferences.	6.52796464360239
3184. expressions	of even low-key dissatisfaction by a catholic college faculty member	has the effect of confirming the already existing stereotype.	6.982774276936797
3185. in	the academic world there is seldom anything so dramatic as a strike or	a boycott: all that happens is that the better qualified teacher declines	to gamble two or three years of his life on the chance that conditions	at the catholic institution will be as good as those elsewhere.	6.897952582225188
3186. to appreciate the nature of the gamble it should be realized	that while college teaching is almost a public symbol of security	that security does not come as quickly or as automatically as it does	in an elementary school system or in the civil service.	10.635011603586795
3187. much has	been made of the fact that major catholic institutions now guarantee	firm tenure.	11.433975734860725
3188. this is a significant advance but its import should not	be exaggerated.	14.345619928249592
3189. when a man invests a block of his years at a university	without gaining the coveted promotion not only is he faced with the	problem of starting over but there is also a certain depreciation in	the market value of his services.	7.793813726735458
3190. a man does not make that kind of	gamble if he suspects that one or more of the limited number of tenure	positions is being reserved for members of the family.	13.289252475096541
3191. just	as it is possible to exaggerate the drawing power of the new	tenure practices it is also possible to exaggerate the significance	of the now relatively adequate salaries paid by major catholic institutions.	8.350432116648756
3192. yet adequate compensation-	and particularly merely adequate compensation is no substitute	for those intangibles which cause a man to sacrifice part of his	earning potential by taking up college teaching in the first place.	7.968050333548122
3193. broadly	speaking the total catholic atmosphere is such an intangible	but the larger demand is for a sense of creative participation and mature	responsibility in the total work of the university.	6.784764875540547
3194. religious who	derive their own sense of purpose through identification with the religious	community rather than the academic community are prone to underestimate	both the layman's reservoir of idealism and his need for this	identification.	7.72497151213527
3195. there is no need here to spell out the conditions	of creative teaching except to point out that at the college	level the sense of community and of community responsibility is even	more necessary than it is at other levels.	11.226752112190193
3196. the college teacher needs	the stimulus of communication with other faculty members but he also	needs to feel that such communication even informal debates over the	luncheon table are a contribution to the total good of the institution.	9.325166780438073
3197. but this in turn means that decisions are not merely imposed from	the top but that there be some actual mechanism of faculty participation.	7.897213099998587
3198. the second reason for being concerned with the dichotomy	between faculty members who are part of the in-group that owns and	operates the institution and those who are merely paid employees is	therefore the baneful effect on the caliber of the teaching itself.	10.15110526538132
3199. this is a problem that goes considerably beyond questions of salary	and tenure.	12.138808051392996
3200. yet though it may seem difficult to envision any definitive	resolution of the problem of ownership and control there are nevertheless	certain suggestions which seem to be in order.	12.616525899651966
3201. the first	is a negative warning: there is no point in the creation of faculty	committees and advisory boards with high-sounding titles but no real	authority.	6.197822190427274
3202. in the case of academic personnel the feeling of	participation can hardly be faked.	16.974195136713
3203. competent teachers are well	versed in the technique of leading students to pre-set conclusions without	destroying the students' illusion that they are making their own	decisions.	5.003077186712575
3204. those who have served as faculty advisers are too familiar	with the useful but artificial mechanisms of student government to	be taken in by busy-work and ersatz decision making.	8.309486559397754

3207. in itself there is nothing wrong	with this form of participation: the only difficulty on the	catholic campus is that those faculty members who are in a position	to implement policy ie members of the religious community which	owns and administers the institution have their own eating arrangements.	6.956030210211303
3208. sen john l mcclellan of arkansas and rep david	martin of nebraska are again beating the drums to place the unions	under the anti-monopoly laws.	7.158476623153288
3209. once more the fallacious equation is advanced	to argue that since business is restricted under the anti-monopoly	laws there must be a corresponding restriction against labor unions:	the law must treat everybody equally.	5.486719080791055
3210. or in the words of anatole	france the law in its majestic equality must forbid the rich	as well as the poor from begging in the streets and sleeping under	bridges.	10.243389597965674

3220. the	recent publicity attending the successful federal prosecution	of a conspiracy indictment against a number of electrical manufacturers	has evoked a new respect for the anti-trust laws that is justified	neither by their rationale nor by the results they have obtained.	6.579845863471484
3221. the	anti-trust laws inform a business that it must compete but along completely	undefined lines; it must play a game in which there never is	a winner.	5.817809321445392
3222. the fact is that any business that wants to operate successfully	cannot follow the law.	18.49978082697061
3223. hypocrisy thus becomes the answer to a	foolish public policy.	7.712753244768429
3224. let us look at the heavy-electrical-goods	industry in which general electric westinghouse and a number of	other manufacturers were recently convicted of engaging in a conspiracy	to rig prices and allocate the market.	9.096894582326396
3225. the industry is so structured	that price-setting by a multi-product company will vary with the way	overhead charges are allocated- whether marginal or average pricing	is applied.	4.178787370316771
3226. the problem becomes even more complex where an enterprise	is engaged in the manufacture of a wide variety of other goods	in addition to the heavy electrical equipment.	13.346217755046897
3227. accounting procedures	can be varied to provide a rationale for almost any price.	6.816358779812407
3228. naturally	enterprises of the size of general electric are in a position to	structure their prices in such a way that the relatively small competitors	can be forced to the wall in a very short time.	11.445868932477916
3229. should these giants	really flex their competitive muscles they would become the only	survivors in the industry.	6.560512753379273
3230. uncle sam would then accuse them of creating	a monopoly by unfair competition.	10.116603133062979
3231. but if they show self-restraint	they don't get the orders.	6.443498660516824
3232. under the circumstances	the only protection for the relatively small manufacturers is to engage	in exactly the kind of conspiracy with the giants for which the latter	were convicted.	10.197816509576011
3233. engaging in such a conspiracy was an act of mercy	by the giants.	7.925025990008774

3235. in other words	the anti-trust laws designed to reduce prices to the consumer on monday	wednesday and friday become a tool to protect the marginal manufacturer	on tuesday thursday and saturday.	6.255537461124528
3236. and which theory would	govern the enforcers of the law on sunday?	12.197717175052087

3240. he wrote:  h the anti-trust	laws were the answer of a society which unconsciously felt the need	of great organizations and at the same time had to deny them a place	in the moral and logical ideology of the social structure.	7.867005165619132

3941. confronted with this situation most libraries	either endure the severe limitations of their budgets and do what they	can with what they have or else depend on the bounty of patrons and	local governments to supplement their annual funds.	6.246988155568219
3942. in some parts of	the country however a co-operative movement has begun to grow under	the wing of state governments whereby with the financial help of the	state libraries share their book resources on a county-wide or regional	basis.	7.417976174737661
3943. new york state has what is probably the most advanced	of these co-operative systems so well developed that it has become	a model for others to follow.	7.021864215721914
3944. because it is so large a state with	marked contrasts in population density the organization of the new	york co-operative offers a cross-section of how the plan works.	8.776975957013372
3945. at	one extreme are the systems of upper new york state where libraries	in two or more counties combine to serve a large sparsely populated	area.	6.853318947427573
3946. at the other are organizations like the newly formed nassau library	system in a high-density area with ample resources and a rapidly	growing territory to serve.	8.782325242656398
3947. both these types and those	in between are in existence by reason of a legislative interest in libraries	that began at albany as early as 1950 with the creation by the	legislature of county library systems financed by county governments	with matching funds from the state.	6.289660838096941
3948. it was a step in the right direction	but it took an additional act passed in 1958 to establish fully	the thriving systems of today.	12.192921678042364
3949. under this law annual grants are	given to systems in substantial amounts.	7.622879841199637
3950. an earlier difficulty was	overcome by making it clear that individual libraries in any area might	join or not as they saw fit.	10.850047572646607
3951. some library boards are wary of the	plan.	7.871112120131343
3952. a large well-stocked library surrounded in a county by smaller	ones may feel that the demands on its resources are likely to be too	great.	10.135999036517179
3953. a small library may cherish its independence and established	ways and resist joining in a cooperative movement that sometimes seems	radical to older members of the board.	6.364239119945874
3954. within a system however	the autonomy of each member library is preserved.	12.168208774801572
3955. the local community	maintains responsibility for the financial support of its own library	program facilities and services but wider resources and additional	services become available through membership in a system.	6.746851968602881
3956. all	services are given without cost to members.	10.172622445289814
3957. so obvious are these advantages	that nearly 95 per cent of the population of new york state	now has access to a system and enthusiastic librarians foresee the day	not too distant when all the libraries in the state will belong to	a co-op.	8.051992537471863
3958. to set up a co-operative library system the law	requires a central book collection of 100000 nonfiction volumes as	the nucleus and the system is organized around it.	8.427688486457859
3959. the collection may	be in an existing library or it may be built up in a central collection.	9.352828119162737
3960. each system develops differently according to the area it serves	but the universal goal is to pool the resources of a given area for	maximum efficiency.	9.38301466602579
3961. the basic state grant is thirty cents for each	person served and there is a further book incentive grant that provides	an extra twenty cents up to fifty cents per capita if a library spends	a certain number of dollars.	6.818584379272753

3965. the	need is for reference works of a more specialized nature than individual	libraries adequate to satisfy everyday needs could afford.	6.1417083188979245

3972. it is connected	by teletype with the state library in albany which will supply any	book to a system that the system itself cannot provide.	12.837910798318227

6004. one of the inescapable realities	of the cold war is that is has thrust upon the west a wholly new	and historically unique set of moral dilemmas.	12.042844243031213

7356. only	once in a very long while comes a book that gives the reader a magic	sense of sharing a rare experience.	9.41738935455222

7358. he has married me with h a ring of bright	water	begins the kathleen raine poem from which maxwell takes his title	and it is this mystic bond between the human and natural world that the	author conveys.	8.587067220691196

7384. the performances of the comedie francaise are the	most important recent events in the new york theater.	12.262964014298438
7385. they	serve to contradict a popular notion that the comedie merely repeats	as accurately as possible the techniques of acting the classics that	prevailed in the 17th century.	6.721335938647602
7386. on the contrary the old plays are continually	being reinterpreted and each new production of a classic has	only a brief history at the comedie.	9.690985838609217
7387. of course the well-received	revivals last longer than the others and that further reminds	us that the comedie is not insensitive to criticism.	8.072897435778431
7388. the directors of	the comedie do not respond to adverse notices in as docile and subservient	a manner as the broadway producers who in two instances this	season closed their plays after one performance.	8.241296100481128
7389. but they are aware	of the world outside they court public approval they delight in full	houses and they occasionally dare to experiment in interpreting a dramatic	classic.	7.131963283211937
7390. in france novel approaches to the classic french	plays are frequently attempted.	11.829784675239175
7391. the government pays a subsidy	for revival of the classics and this policy attracts experimenters who	sometimes put moliere's characters in modern dress and often achieve	interesting results.	5.890514310265451
7392. so far as i know the comedie has never	put moliere's people in the costumes of the 20th century but	they do reinterpret plays and characters.	11.155934908060877
7393. last season the comedie's	two principal experiments came to grief and in consequence we can	expect fairly soon to see still newer productions of racine's phedre	and moliere's school for wives.	4.604607206377327
7394. the new	phedre was done in 17th century setting instead of ancient greek;	perhaps that is the comedie's equivalent for thrusting this	play's characters into our own time.	6.430007852013022
7395. the speaking of the lines seemed	excessively slow and stately possibly in an effort to capture the	spirit of 17th century elegance.	8.041642294122743
7396. a few literary men defended what they	took to be an emphasis on the poetry at the expense of the drama but	the response was mainly hostile and quite violent.	9.388900728297028
7397. the new school	for wives was interpreted according to a principle that	is becoming increasingly common in the playing of classic comedy- the	idea of turning some obviously ludicrous figure into a tragic character.	5.77137023524078
7398. among the moliere specialists of some years ago louis	jouvet tried to humanize some of the clowns while fernand ledoux	often performing at the comedie made them more gross than moliere may	have intended.	10.109668297214478

7489. it was quite an evening!	a year ago today when the democrats were fretting and frolicking	in los angeles and john f kennedy was still only an	able and ambitious senator who yearned for the power and responsibility	of the presidency theodore h white had already compiled masses	of notes about the presidential campaign of 1960.	6.443916575418916

7623. a tribe in ancient india believed the earth was a huge tea tray	resting on the backs of three giant elephants which in turn stood	on the shell of a great tortoise.	6.607001794870853

7628. in	the autumn of 1959 the british broadcasting corporation presented	a series of talks by four scientists competent in cosmology.	8.181974067955997
7629. three	of these men discussed major theories of the universe while the other	acted as a moderator.	6.828029139855866
7630. the participants were professor h bondi	professor of mathematics at king's college london; dr w	b bonnor reader in mathematics at queen elizabeth college	london; dr r a lyttleton a lecturer at st john's	college cambridge and a reader in theoretical astronomy at the	university of cambridge; and dr g j whitrow reader	in applied mathematics at the imperial college of science and technology	london.	5.676756617951268
7631. dr whitrow functioned as moderator.	8.68257491245581
7632. the	programs were so well received by the british public that the arguments	have been published in a totally engrossing little book called rival	theories of cosmology.	8.23301498851955
7633. dr bonnor begins with	a discussion of the relativistic theories of the universe based on	the general theory of relativity.	7.532408823897036
7634. first of all and this has been calculated	by observation the universe is expanding- that is the galaxies	are receding from each other at immense speeds.	10.508599623194776
7635. because of this	dr bonnor holds that the universe is becoming more thinly populated	by stars and whatever else is there.	8.744246489088969
7636. this expansion has been going	on for an estimated eight billion years.	10.733649384974553
7637. dr bonnor supports the idea that the universe both expands and contracts	that in several billion years the expansion will slow up and	reverse itself and that the contraction will set in.	7.105454331721512
7638. then after many	more billions of years when all the galaxies are whistling toward a	common center this movement will slow down and reverse itself again.	9.704389896938858
7639. professor bondi disagrees with the expansion-contraction theory.	6.631310470376089
7640. he supports the steady-state theory which holds that matter is continually	being created in space.	8.574290037510266
7641. for this reason he says the density	of the universe always remains the same even though the galaxies are	zooming away in all directions.	9.857037284999139
7642. new galaxies are forever being formed	to fill in the gaps left by the receding galaxies.	10.263159615607922

7645. he contends this idea doesn't conflict with experiments on	which the principle of conservation of matter and energy is based because	some slight error must be assumed in such experiments.	5.773809861681148

7648. the charges of the electron	and proton are believed to be exactly equal and opposite but dr	lyttleton is not so sure.	9.7669750400522
7649. suppose says dr lyttleton the proton	has a slightly greater charge than the electron	.	6.708010131336902
7650. this would give the hydrogen atom a slight	charge-excess.	15.050028510321539
7651. now if one hydrogen atom were placed at the surface	of a large sphere of hydrogen atoms it would be subject both to the	gravitation of the sphere and the charge-excess of all those atoms	in the sphere.	7.143180110599957
7652. because electrical forces are far	more powerful than gravitation the surface hydrogen atoms would shoot	away from the sphere.	9.515084742312895

8033. it contains large amounts of protein vitamins	and minerals.	10.791024918367663
