8035. but keys worries that the	metrecal drinker will never make either the psychological or physiological	adjustment to the idea of eating smaller portions of food.	6.72413610944792
8036. despite his personal distaste for obesity	dr keys has only an incidental interest	in how much americans eat.	8.740409290577412
8037. what concerns him much more is the relationship	of diet to the nation's no 1 killer: coronary artery disease	which accounts for more than half of all heart fatalities and kills	500000 americans a year- twice the toll from all varieties of	cancer five times the deaths from automobile accidents.	5.150634297750153
8038. cholesterol	the cornerstone of dr keys's theory is a mysterious	yellowish	waxy substance chemically a crystalline alcohol.	6.052272952419241
8039. scientists	assume that cholesterol	is somehow necessary for the formation of	brain cells since it accounts for about 2% of the brain's total	solid weight.	4.6371604856691855
8040. they know it is the chief ingredient in gallstones.	16.102447141327573
8041. they	suspect it plays a role in the production of adrenal hormones and	they believe it is essential to the transport of fats throughout the	circulatory system.	8.093010083041142
8042. but they cannot fully explain the process of its	manufacture by the human liver.	13.474257411316193
8043. although the fatty protein molecules	carried in the blood and partly composed of cholesterol are water soluble	cholesterol itself is insoluble and cannot be destroyed by the	body.	7.337092269813467
8044. a remarkable substance says dr keys quite apart	from its tendency to be deposited in the walls of arteries.	10.443964000617358
8045. when thus deposited keys says that cholesterol is mainly responsible	for the arterial blockages that culminate in heart attacks.	6.450066792084764
8046. explains	keys: as the fatty protein molecules travel in the bloodstream	they are deposited in the intima or inner wall of a coronary artery.	7.299185856296672
8047. the proteins and fats are burned off and the cholesterol is left	behind.	8.646415123408081
8048. as cholesterol piles up it narrows irritates and damages the	artery encouraging formation of calcium deposits and slowing circulation.	8.080591352810032
8049. eventually says keys one of two things happens.	8.44901741695294
8050. a clot forms	at the site seals off the flow of blood to the heart and provokes	a heart attack.	13.111274463960202
8051. or the deposits themselves	get so big that they choke off the artery's flow to the point that	an infarct occurs: the heart muscle is suffocated cells supplied	by the artery die and the heart is permanently perhaps fatally injured.	5.657817410661288
8052. ordinarily the human liver synthesizes	only enough cholesterol to satisfy the body's needs- for transportation	of fats and for production of bile.	7.400807778526613
8053. even eggs and other cholesterol-rich	foods eaten in normal amounts says dr keys do not materially	affect the amount of cholesterol in the blood.	6.942772790353365
8054. during world war 2 doctors in the netherlands	and scandinavia noted a curious fact: despite the stresses of nazi	occupation the death rate from coronary artery disease was slowly dropping.	9.201008492397087
8055. not until long after the war- 1950 in fact- did they get	a hint of the reason.	6.171051822576264
8056. that year sweden's haqvin malmros showed	that the sinking death rate neatly coincided with increasingly severe	restrictions on fatty foods.	7.194727747805062
8057. that same year the university of california's	dr laurance kinsell timing oxidation rates of blood	fats stumbled onto the discovery that many vegetable fats cause blood	cholesterol levels to drop radically while animal fats cause them to	rise.	5.84679939812425
8058. here keys and others such as dr a e ahrens of	the rockefeller institute took over to demonstrate the chemical difference	between vegetable and animal fats- and even between different	varieties of each.	7.345517128213803
8059. all natural food fats fall into one of three	categories- saturated mono-unsaturated and poly-unsaturated.	5.601498548237698
8060. the	degree of saturation depends on the number of hydrogen atoms on the	fat molecule.	11.106933339232157
8061. saturated fats can accommodate no more hydrogens.	7.085404632188788
8062. mono-unsaturated	fats have room for two more hydrogens on each molecule	and the poly-unsaturated fat molecule has room for at least four hydrogens.	6.770610842895149
8063. the three fats have similar caloric values	but each exerts a radically different influence on	blood cholesterol.	6.3032983871001
8064. as a result although we still make use of this distinction there is	much confusion as to the meaning of the basic terms employed.	15.399024646164209
8065. just what	is meant by spirit and by matter?	8.770373913177687
8066.  the terms are generally	taken for granted as though they referred to direct and axiomatic	elements in the common experience of all.	10.967030473655347
8067. yet in the contemporary	context this is precisely what one must not do.	10.069917615942103
8068. for in the modern world	neither spirit nor matter refer to any generally agreed-upon	elements of experience.	10.951061110092704
8069. we are in a transitional stage in which	many of the connotations of former usage have had to be revised or rejected.	8.815173485959564
8070. when the words are used we are never sure which of the traditional	meanings the user may have in mind or to what extent his revisions	and rejections of former understandings correspond to ours.	9.964215165418159
8071. one of the most widespread features of contemporary thought is the	almost universal disbelief in the reality of spirit.	10.490474541686178
8072. just a few centuries	ago the world of spirits was as populous and real as the world of	material entities.	13.096791073932202
8073. not only in popular thought but in that of the highly	educated as well was this true.	10.01737599721236
8074. demons fairies angels and a host	of other spiritual beings were as much a part of the experiential	world of western man as were rocks and trees and stars.	9.91746467430966
8075. in such a world	the words matter and spirit both referred to directly	known realities in the common experience of all.	9.080671100265839
8076. in it important elements	of christianity and of the biblical view of reality in general	which now cause us much difficulty could be responded to quite naturally	and spontaneously.	9.353214004832592
8077. the progress of science over these last	few centuries and the gradual replacement of biblical by scientific	categories of reality have to a large extent emptied the spirit world	of the entities which previously populated it.	7.013484435771585
8078. in carrying out this	program science has undoubtedly performed a very considerable service	for which it can claim due credit.	9.781911999709097
8079. the objectification of the world	of spirit in popular superstition had certainly gone far beyond what the	experience of spirit could justify or support.	6.726992328623042
8080. science is fully competent	to deal with any element of experience which arises from an object	in space and time.	9.794117207951974
8081. when therefore it turned its attention to the	concrete entities with which popular imagination had peopled the world	of spirit these entities soon lost whatever status they had enjoyed	as actual elements of external reality.	6.189750403637941
8082. in doing so science has unquestionably	cleared up widespread misconceptions removed extraneous	and illusory sources of fear and dispelled many undesirable popular	superstitions.	10.60531861277468
8083. there have been indeed many important and valuable gains	from the development of our present scientific view of the world	for which we may be rightly grateful.	8.765916894141302
8084. all this has not however	been an unmixed blessing.	13.680978846160713
8085. the scientific debunking of the spirit world	has been in a way too successful and too thorough.	9.126748196713336
8086. the house has	been swept so clean that contemporary man has been left with no means	or at best with wholly inadequate means for dealing with his experience	of spirit.	8.945602707679205
8087. although the particular form of conceptualization which	popular imagination had made in response to the experience of spirit	was undoubtedly defective the raw experience itself which led to such	excesses remains with us as vividly as ever.	7.153361217055732
8088. we simply find ourselves	in the position of having no means for inquiring into the structure	and meaning of this range of our experience.	10.384079708809251
8089. there is no framework	or structure of thought with respect to which we can organize it and	no part	of reality as we know and apprehend it with respect to which we	can refer this experience.	10.448374634520778
8090. science has simply left us helpless and powerless	in this important sector of our lives.	9.14897700106683
8091. the situation in	which we find ourselves is brought out with dramatic force in arthur	miller's play the crucible which deals with the salem witch	trials.	6.3077136100812625
8092. as the play opens the audience is introduced to the community	of salem in puritan america at the end of the eighteenth century.	14.07086496296003
8093. aside from a quaint concern with witches and devils which provides	the immediate problem in the opening scene it is a quite normal community.	7.759954725074153
8094. the conversation of the characters creates an atmosphere suggesting	the usual mixture of pleasures foibles irritations and concerns	which would characterize the common life of a normal village in any	age.	8.371957238195167
8095. there is no occasion to feel uneasy or disturbed about these people.	12.807952765863194
8096. instead the audience can sit back at ease and from the perspective	of an enlightened time which no longer believes in such things	enjoy the dead seriousness with which the characters in the play take	the witches and devils which are under discussion.	10.334244033655253
8097. a teenage girl abigail	williams is being sharply questioned by her minister uncle	the reverend samuel parris about a wild night affair in the woods	in which she and some other girls had seemed to have had contact with	these evil beings.	6.044152449976617
8098. for all involved in this discussion the devil is	a real entity who can really be confronted in the woods on a dark night	the demon world is populated with real creatures and witches actually	can be seen flying through the air.	8.948162743181383
8099. as the play unfolds however	the audience is subtly brought into the grip of an awful evil	which grows with ominously gathering power and soon engulfs the community.	7.133866930616662
8100. everyone in salem saint and sinner alike is swept up by it.	9.196391104895504
8101. it is like a mysterious epidemic which starting first with abigail	and parris spreads inexorably with a dreadfully growing virulence through	the whole town until all have been infected by it.	6.935800484939843
8102. it grows terribly	and unavoidably in power and leaves in its wake a trail of misery	moral disintegration and destruction.	9.499059132393885
8103. the audience leaves the play	under a spell it is the kind of spell which the exposure to spirit	in its living active manifestation always evokes.	7.70100746252646
8104. if one asks	about this play what it is that comes upon this community and works	within it with such terrible power there is no better answer to give	than spirit.	11.784425963244502
8105. this is not to attempt to say what spirit is but	only to employ a commonly used word to designate or simply identify a	common experience.	9.570289877406987
8106. in the end the good man john proctor expresses	what the audience has already come to feel when he says a fire	a fire is burning! i hear the boot of lucifer i see his filthy	face! the tragic irony of the play is that the very belief in and	concern with a devil who could be met in the woods and combatted with	formulae set out in books was the very thing that prevented them from	detecting the real devil when he came among them.	8.912076398900547
8107. we marvel at their	blindness for not seeing this.	9.128210153408487
8108. yet are not we of the mid-twentieth	century who rightly do not believe there is any such thing as the	devil just as bad off as they- only in a different way?	8.658406760954998
8109.  in our	disbelief we think that we can no longer even use the word and so are	unable to even name the elemental power which is so vividly real in	this play.	8.018251181921208
8110. we are left helpless to cope with it because we do not dare	speak of it as anything real for fear that to do so would imply a commitment	to that which has already been discredited and proved false.	11.540660088703557
8111. even mr miller himself seems uncertain on this score.	8.449426466165553
8112. in	a long commentary which he has inserted in the published text of the	first act of the play he says at one point: however that experience	never raised a doubt in his mind as to the reality of the underworld	or the existence of lucifer's many-faced lieutenants.	8.89502104922755
8113. and his	belief is not to his discredit.	12.064249099310658
8114. better minds than hale's were-	and still are- convinced that there is a society of spirits beyond	our ken.	7.781580429633792
8115. on the other hand a little later on he says:	since 1692 a great but superficial change has wiped out god's	beard and the devil's horns but the world is still gripped between	two diametrically opposed absolutes.	5.812451644841371
8116. the concept of unity in which	positive and negative are attributes of the same force in which good	and evil are relative ever-changing and always joined to the same phenomenon-	such a concept is still reserved to the physical sciences	and to the few who have grasped the history of ideas h.	8.27503304500424
8117. when we see	the steady and methodical inculcation into humanity of the idea of man's	worthlessness- until redeemed- the necessity of the devil may	become evident as a weapon a weapon designed and used time and time	again in every age to whip men into a surrender to a particular church	or church-state.	5.872004814911531
8118. apparently he does not intend	that those who read or view this play should think of the devil as being	actually real.	11.090266383589361
8119. yet such is the dramatic power of his writing that	the audience is nevertheless left in the grip of the terrible power and	potency of that which came over salem.	7.631678593859151
8120. it casts a spell upon them	so that they leave with a feeling of having been in the mysterious presence	of an evil power.	12.982375977744967
8121. it is not enough in accounting for this feeling	to analyze it into the wickedness of individual people added together	to produce a cumulative effect.	9.254244524899878
8122. for this does not account for the	integral elemental power of that which grows with abounding vigor as	the play unfolds nor does it explain the strange numinous sense of presentness	which comes over those who watch the play like a spell.	9.387865700683482
8123. the	reality of spirit emerges in this play in spite of the author's convictions	to the contrary.	6.279047250572346
8124. there is	nothing in the whole range of human experience more widely known and	universally felt than spirit.	12.981574961979913
8125. apart from spirit there could be no community	for it is spirit which draws men into community and gives to any	community its unity cohesiveness and permanence.	7.48104806173053
8126. think for example	of the spirit of the marine corps.	15.297901786291858
8127. surely this is a reality we	all acknowledge.	8.74153916905672
8128. we cannot of course assign it any substance.	13.353398297583137
8129. it	is not material and is not a thing occupying space and time.	10.230763407333205
8130. yet	it exists and has an objective reality which can be experienced and	known.	10.056316963531911
8131. so it is too with many other spirits which we all know: the	spirit of nazism or communism school spirit the spirit of a street	corner gang or a football team the spirit of rotary or the ku klux	klan.	6.675860400908966
8132. every community if it is alive has a spirit and that spirit	is the center of its unity and identity.	13.023554068314803
8133. in searching for clues	which might lead us to a fresh apprehension of the reality of spirit	the close connection between spirit and community is likely to prove	the most fruitful.	7.56248413999189
8134. for it is primarily in community that we know and	experience spirit.	17.364180917572433
8135. it is spirit which gives life to a community and	causes it to cohere.	12.509475198243395
8136. it is the spirit which is the source of a community's	drawing power by means of which others are drawn into it from	the world outside so that the community grows and prospers.	12.503139554088198
8137. yet the	spirit which lives in community is not identical with the community.	7.955633489695482
8138. the idea of community and the idea of spirit are two distinct and separable	ideas.	15.697727350598889
8139. one characteristic of the spirit in community is	its givenness.	12.737237829447333
8140. the members of the community do not create the spirit	but rather find it present and waiting for them.	13.056492018588918
8141. it is for them a given	which they and they alone possess.	13.04606634820278
8142. the spirit of the marine corps	was present and operative before any of the present members of it came	into it.	14.021019584144016
8143. it is they of course who keep it alive and preserve it	so the same spirit will continue to be present in the corps for future	recruits to find as they come into it.	9.577110282387412
8144. if the content of faith is to be presented today in a form that can be	understanded of the people- and this it must not be forgotten	is one of the goals of the perennial theological task- there is	no other choice but to abandon completely a mythological manner of	representation.	9.029148868132445
8145. this does not mean that mythological language as	such can no longer be used in theology and preaching.	11.547445801465933
8146. the absurd notion	that demythologization entails the expurgation of all mythological	concepts completely misrepresents bultmann's intention.	7.382560162815788
8147. his point	is not that mythology may not be used but that it may no longer be regarded	as the only or even the most appropriate conceptuality for expressing	the christian kerygma.	7.95362932459729
8148. when we say that a mythological mode	of thought must be completely abandoned we mean it must be abandoned	as the sole or proper means for presenting the christian understanding	of existence.	9.550869387952341
8149. mythological concepts may by all means still be used	but they can be used responsibly only as symbols or ciphers	that is only if they are also constantly interpreted in nonmythological	terms.	6.951165194263815
8150. the statement is often made	that when bultmann argues in this way he overestimates the intellectual	stumbling-block which myth is supposed to put in the way of accepting	the christian faith.	10.860452982034419
8151. but this statement is completely unconvincing.	13.3149610992168
8152. if bultmann's own definition of myth is strictly adhered	to	the evidence is overwhelming that he does	not at all exaggerate the extent to which the mythological concepts of	traditional theology have become incredible and irrelevant.	8.622424059497387
8153. nor is	it necessary to look for such evidence in the great urban centers of our	culture that are admittedly almost entirely secularized and so profoundly	estranged from the conventional forms in which the gospel has been	communicated.	6.6270443910555485
8154. on the contrary even in the heart of the bible	belt itself as can be attested by any one who is called to work there	the industrial and technological revolutions have long been under	way together with the corresponding changes in man's picture of himself	and his world.	9.727336337523989
8155. in fact it is in just such a situation	that the profundity of bultmann's argument is disclosed.	9.457936183232455
8156. although	the theological forms of the past continue to exist in a way they do	not in a more secularized situation the striking thing is the rapidity	with which they are being reduced to a marginal existence.	10.791361918741849
8157. this is	especially in evidence among the present generation of the suburban middle	class.	9.07308860773403
8158. time and again in counseling and teaching one encounters	members of this group whose attempts to bring into some kind of unity	the insubstantial mythologies of their fundamentalist heritage	and the stubborn reality of the modern world are only too painfully obvious.	9.214251967285007
8159. the same thing is also evidenced by the extreme culture-protestantism	so often observed to characterize the preaching	and teaching of the american churches.	6.952259762161874
8160. in the absence of a truly adequate	conceptuality in which the gospel can be expressed the unavoidable	need to demythologize it makes use of whatever resources are at	hand- and this usually means one or another of the various forms of	folk religion current in the situation.	9.71199445303942
8161. this is not to say that	the only explanation of the present infatuation with norman vincent	peale's cult of reassurance or the other types of a purely	cultural christianity is the ever-present need for a demythologized	gospel.	7.632248448615035
8162. but it is to say that this need is far more important for such	infatuation than most of the pundits seem to have suspected.	19.023401543679814
8163. however even if the latent demand for demythologization is not nearly	as widespread as we are claiming at least among the cultured elements	of the population there tends to be an almost complete indifference	to the church and its traditional message of sin and grace.	7.306136527792916
8164. to be	sure when this is pointed out a common response among certain churchmen	is to fulminate about the little flock and the great crowd	and to take solace from paul's castigation of the wisdom of	the wise in the opening chapter of first corinthians.	8.199594384308643
8165. but can	we any longer afford the luxury of such smug indigation?	9.354518678978495
8166.  can the church	risk assuming that the folly of men is as dear to god as their	wisdom or as is also commonly implied that the foolishness	of god and the foolishness of men are simply two ways	of talking about the same thing?	9.077681842329971
8167.  can we continue to alienate precisely	those whose gifts we so desperately need and apart from whose co-operation	our mission in the world must become increasingly precarious?	5.950623291380903
8168. 	there is an ancient and venerable tradition in the church	derives however from the heritage of the greeks rather than from	that god is completely independent of his creation and	so has no need of men for accomplishing his work in the world.	8.857766556909052
8169. by analogy	the church also has been regarded as entirely independent of the	world in the sense of requiring nothing from it in order to be	the church.	8.55415593891083
8170. but as scripture everywhere reminds us god does	have need of his creatures and the church a fortiori can ill afford	to do without the talents with which the world by god's providence	presents it.	9.218607418618857
8171. and yet this is exactly the risk we run when	we assume as we too often do that we can continue to preach the gospel	in a form that makes it seem incredible and irrelevant to cultured	men.	8.703536451947357
8172. until we translate this gospel into a language that enlightened	men today can understand we are depriving ourselves of the very resources	on which the continued success of our witness most certainly depends.	8.144867925808345
8173. in arguing in this way we are obviously taking for granted	that a demythologized restatement of the kerygma can be achieved;	and that we firmly believe this will presently become evident when	we set forth reasons to justify such a conviction.	5.973105389663379
8174. but the main point	here is that even if such a restatement were not possible the	demand to demythologize the kerygma would still be unavoidable.	10.66004329921192
8175. this is what we mean when we say this demand must be accepted without	condition.	12.507400476507003
8176. if to be a christian means to say yes where i otherwise	say no or where i do not have the right to say anything at all then	my only choice is to refuse to be a christian.	12.911721177161109
8177. expressed differently:	if the price for becoming a faithful follower of jesus christ	is some form of self-destruction whether of the body or of the mind-	sacrificium corporis sacrificium intellectus- then there is	no alternative but that the price remain unpaid.	4.867659416975825
8178. this must be	stressed because it is absolutely essential to the argument of this concluding	chapter.	13.67920946608397
8179. modern man as dietrich bonhoeffer has told us has	come of age; and though this process by no means represents	an unambiguous gain and is in fact marked by the estrangement from	the depths that seems to be the cost of human maturation it is still	a positive step forward; and those of us who so richly benefit from	it should be the last to despise it.	6.641320621869472
8180. in any event it is an irreversible	step and if we are at all honest with ourselves we will know we	have no other alternative than to live in the world in which god has	seen fit to place us.	14.464560629307764
8181. to say this of course is to take up a	position on one side of a controversy going on now for some two hundred	years or at any rate since the beginning of the distinctively modern	period in theological thought.	10.27105490429483
8182. we have aligned ourselves with that	liberal tradition in protestant christianity that counts among	the great names in its history those of schleiermacher ritschl	herrmann harnack and troeltsch and more recently schweitzer and	the early barth and in part at least bultmann.	8.083913689787174
8183. it is to this same	tradition that most of the creative figures in the last century and	a half of american theology also belong.	11.002271397905949
8184. for we must number here not	only the names of bushnell clarke and rauschenbusch not to mention	those of the chicago school and macintosh but those of	the brothers niebuhr and tillich as	well.	8.723473161605868
8185. finally we may also mention the several members of the self-consciously	neoliberal movement that developed at the university	of chicago and is heavily indebted philosophically to the creative work	of alfred north whitehead.	6.533519774797182
8186. what makes this long and diverse	tradition essentially one is that those who have belonged to it	have been profoundly in earnest about being modern men in a distinctively	modern world.	10.087124794196905
8187. although they have also been concerned to stand squarely	within the tradition of the apostolic church they have exhibited	no willingness whatever to sacrifice their modernity to their christianity.	7.044856546240403
8188. they have insisted rather on living fully and completely	within modern culture and so far from considering this treason to god	have looked upon it as the only way they could be faithful to him.	10.463612455118064
8189. when we say then that today in our situation the demand for	demythologization must be accepted without condition we are simply	saying that at least this much of the liberal tradition is an enduring	achievement.	8.752248365641119
8190. however much we may have to criticize liberal theology's	constructive formulations the theology we ourselves must strive	to formulate can only go beyond liberalism not behind it.	8.373981429497233
8191. in affirming this we have already taken the decisive step in breaking	the deadlock into which bultmann's attempt to formulate such a	theology has led.	5.88839143125723
8192. for we have said in effect that of the two alternatives	to his position variously represented by the other participants	in the demythologizing discussion only one is really an alternative.	10.866969690822582
8193. if the demand for demythologization is unavoidable and so must be	accepted	by theology unconditionally the position of the right is	clearly untenable.	10.800426516530978
8194. whereas bultmann's center position is structurally	inconsistent and is therefore indefensible on formal grounds	alone the general position of the right as represented say	by karl barth involves the rejection or at least qualification of	the demand for demythologization and so is invalidated on the material	grounds we have just considered.	8.12810996090035
8195. it follows then provided	the possibilities have been exhausted that the only real alternative	is the general viewpoint of the left which has been represented	on the continent by fritz buri and to some extent at least	is found in much that is significant in american and english theology.	7.44801944184701
8196. in order to make the implications of our position as clear	as possible we may develop this argument at greater length.	13.29459201883199
8197. we	may show first that there cannot possibly be an alternative other	than the three typically represented by bultmann barth and buri.	7.188478395159444
8198. to do this it is sufficient to point out that if the principle in terms	of which alternatives are to be conceived is such as to exclude more	than two then the question of a third possibility is a meaningless	question.	11.50496045530036
8199. thus if what is at issue is whether all s	is p it is indifferent whether some s is not p	or no s is p since in either case the judgment in question	is false.	7.338150637226299
8200. hence if what is in question is whether in a given theology	myth is or is not completely rejected it is unimportant whether	only a little bit of myth or a considerable quantity is accepted;	for in either event the first possibility is excluded.	10.034256394541814
8201. therefore	the only conceivable alternatives are those represented on the one hand	by the two at least apparently self-consistent but mutually exclusive	positions of buri and barth and on the other hand by the third	but really pseudo position of bultmann.	6.425373292989998
8202. a second point requires more extended comment.	11.974735453515434
8203. it will be recalled	from the discussion in section 7 that the position of the right	as represented by barth rests on the following thesis: the	only tenable alternative to bultmann's position is a theology that	rejects or at least qualifies his unconditioned demand for demythologization	and existential interpretation; accepts instead a	special biblical hermeneutics or method of interpretation; and	in so doing frees itself to give appropriate emphasis to the event jesus	christ by means of statements that from bultmann's point of	view are mythological.	4.947791716978071
8204. one hundred years ago there existed in england the association	for the promotion of the unity of christendom.	15.84449443336292
8205. representing	as it did the efforts of only unauthorized individuals of the roman	and anglican churches and urging a communion of prayer unacceptable	to rome this association produced little fruit and in fact was	condemned by the holy office in 1864.	6.1088127664542275
8206. now again in 1961 in	england there is perhaps nothing in the religious sphere so popularly	discussed as christian unity.	9.412714754887201
8207. the church unity octave january	18-25 was enthusiastically devoted to prayer and discussion by the various	churches.	7.667885087548503
8208. many people seem hopeful yet it is difficult to predict	whether or not there will be any more real attainment of christian	unity in 1961 than there was in 1861.	12.98314232564725
8209. but it must be readily seen	that the religious picture in england has so greatly changed during these	hundred years as to engender hope at least on the catholic side.	8.0794758034637
8210. for the tide is well on the turn as the london catholic weekly	universe has written.	11.048824340642778
8211. i came to england last summer to	do research on the unpublished letters of cardinal newman.	9.82359848431133
8212. as an	american catholic of irish ancestry i came with certain preconceptions	and expectations; being intellectually influenced by newman	and the general 19th-century literature of england i knew only a	protestant-dominated	country.	6.639393982846011
8213. since arriving here however i have formed	a far different religious picture of present-day england.	5.963258565189593
8214. in representing	part of this new picture i will be recounting some of my	own personal experiences reactions and judgments; but my primary aim	is to transcribe what englishmen themselves are saying and writing	and implying about the roman and anglican churches and about the	present religious	state of england.	7.604034862680947
8215. since the protestant clergy for the	most part wear gray or some variant from the wholly black suit my roman	collar and black garb usually identify me in england as a roman	catholic cleric.	6.182509142293398
8216. in any case i have always been treated with the	utmost courtesy by englishmen even in devonshire and cornwall where	anti-catholic feeling has supposedly existed the strongest and longest.	8.44469083078573
8217. nowhere have i seen public expression of anti-catholicism.	8.18116241274294
8218. on my first guy fawkes day here i found catholics as well	as non-catholics celebrating with the traditional fireworks and bonfires	and was told that most englishmen either do not know or are not	concerned with the historical significance of the day.	8.701652661471853
8219. a birmingham	newspaper printed in a column for children an article entitled the	true story of guy fawkes which began:   when you	pile your	guy on the bonfire tomorrow night i wonder how much of the	true story of guy fawkes you will remember?	5.902467919390852
8220.  in the 355 years since	the first guy fawkes night much of the story has been forgotten	so here is a reminder.	12.532417769743978
8221. the article proceeded to give an inaccurate	account of a catholic plot to kill king james 1.	7.3841005422235355
8222. in	spite of the increase in numbers and prestige brought about by the	conversions of newman and other tractarians of the 1840's and 1850's	the catholic segment of england one hundred years ago was a very	small one which did not enjoy a gracious	hearing from the general public.	8.278197445576659
8223. the return of the catholic hierarchy	in 1850 was looked upon with indignant disapprobation and in fact	was charged with being a gesture of disloyalty.	7.766790883209616
8224. in 1864 newman professedly	had to write his apologia with his keenest feelings in	order to be believed and to command a fair hearing from english readers.	9.28486381084273
8225. now in 1961 the catholic population of england is still	quite small; yet it represents a very	considerable percentage of the churchgoing population.	6.756283536402677
8226. a protestant	woman marveled to me over the large crowds going in and out of the birmingham	oratory church on sunday mornings.	10.971669975308664
8227. she found	this a marvel because as she said only six per cent of english people	are churchgoers.	8.982147997425145
8228. she may not have been exact on this number but	others here feel quite certain that the percentage would be less than	ten.	11.906783101412975
8229. from many sides come remarks that protestant churches are badly	attended and the large medieval cathedrals look all but empty during	services.	6.705798297456342
8230. a catholic priest recently recounted how in the chapel of	a large city university following anglican evensong at which there	was a congregation of twelve he celebrated mass before more than a	hundred.	7.843455902279242
8231. the protestants themselves are the first to admit the	great falling off in effective membership in their churches.	7.6501369586319665
8232. according	to a newspaper report of the 1961 statistics of the church of england	the total of confirmed members is 9748000 but only 2887671	are registered on the parochial church rolls and over 27 million	people in england are baptized into the church of england but	roughly only a tenth of them continue.	9.91277111556254
8233. an amazing article in the	manchester guardian of last november entitled fate of redundant	churches states than an archbishops' commission reported	last month that in the church of england alone there are 790	churches which are redundant now or will be in 20 years' time.	6.291535179199725
8234. a further	260 anglican churches have been demolished since 1948.	10.480751749782208
8235. and	in the last five years the methodist chapel committee has	authorized	the demolition or more often the sale of 764 chapels.	7.173612030752086
8236. most of	these former churches are now used as warehouses but neither anglicans	nor	nonconformists object to selling churches to roman catholics	and have done so.	8.848855843562127
8237. while it must be said that these same	protestants have built some new churches during this period and that	religious population shifts have emptied churches a principal reason	for this phenomenon of redundancy is that fewer protestants are	going to church.	6.651755266487741
8238. it should be admitted too that there is a good	percentage of lapsed or nonchurchgoing catholics	.	16.939924120577565
8239. still it is clear from such reports and apparently clear	from the remarks of many people that protestants are decreasing and	catholics increasing.	7.83863131900158
8240. an anglican clergyman in oxford sadly	but frankly acknowledged to me that this is true.	11.63087287807988
8241. a century ago	newman saw that liberalism would	gradually but definitely make its mark on english protestantism and	that even high anglicanism would someday no longer be a serviceable	breakwater against doctrinal errors more fundamental than its own.	5.605543681067952
8242. that day is perhaps today 1961 and it seems no longer very meaningful	to call england a protestant country.	9.578229230263307
8243. one of the ironies	of the present crusade for christian unity is that there are not relatively	speaking many real christians to unite.	11.426589375350247
8244. many english	catholics are proud of their catholicism and know that they are	in a new ascendancy.	10.464833704245635
8245. the london universe devoted its centenary	issue	last december 8 to mapping out various aspects of catholic progress	during the last one hundred years.	6.391566163405857
8246. with traditional nationalistic spirit	some englishmen claim that english catholicism is catholicism	at its best.	8.625870067539255
8247. i have found myself saying with other foreigners here	that english catholics are good catholics.	8.892759754292829
8248. it has been my experience	to find as many men as women in church and to hear almost everyone	in church congregations reciting the latin prayers and responses	at mass.	10.718207283934749
8249. they hope of course to reclaim the non-catholic	population to the catholic faith and at every sunday benediction	they recite by heart the prayer for england:   o blessed	virgin mary mother of god and our most gentle queen and mother	look down in mercy upon england thy dowry and upon us	all who greatly hope and trust in thee h.	5.181346077301476
8250. intercede for our separated	brethren that with us in the one true fold they may be united to the	chief shepherd the vicar of thy son h.	8.116581656463973
8251. a hymn often to be	heard in catholic churches is faith of our fathers which glories	in england's ancient faith that endured persecution and which	proclaims: faith of our fathers: mary's prayersshall win	our country back to thee.	4.498932907016714
8252. the english saints are widely venerated	quite naturally and now there is great hope that the forty martyrs	and cardinal newman will soon be canonized.	10.752110509695232
8253. because they	have kept the faith of their medieval fathers english catholics have	always strongly resented the charge of being un-english.	7.456612321208743
8254. i	have not seen this charge made during my stay here but apparently it	is still in the air.	9.167766110430996
8255. for example a writer in a recent number of the	queen hyperbolically states that of the myriad imprecations the	only one which the english catholics really resent is the suggestion	that they are 'un-english'.	7.293461869129174
8256. in this connection it has been	observed that the increasing number of irish catholics priests and	laity in england while certainly seen as good for catholicism	is nevertheless a source of embarrassment for some of the more nationalistic	english catholics especially when these irishmen offer to remind	their christian brethren of this good.	9.241341047509087
8257. one of the	more noteworthy changes that have taken place since the mid-19th century	is the situation of catholics at oxford and cambridge universities.	7.803911655537888
8258. at oxford one hundred years ago there were very few catholics	partly because religious tests were removed only in 1854.	14.360889807449526
8259. moreover	for those few there was almost no ecclesiastical representation in the	city to care for their religious needs.	6.45962638299349
8260. now not only are there considerably	more laity as students and professors at oxford but there	are also numerous houses of religious orders existing in respectable	and friendly relations with the non-catholic members of the university.	7.645557073163752
8261. some catholic priests lecture there; catholic seminarians attend	tutorials and row on the cherwell with non-catholic students.	4.733761391342129
8262. further evidence that roman catholicism enjoys a more favorable	position today than in 1861 is the respectful attention given to it	in the mass media of england.	9.016094894520279
8263. the general tone of articles appearing	in such important newspapers as the manchester guardian and the	sunday observer implies a kindly recognition that the catholic	church is now at least of equal stature in england with the protestant	churches.	6.415042921835098
8264. on successive sundays during october 1960 paul ferris	wrote articles in the observer depicting	clergymen of the church of england the church of rome and the nonconformist	church.	12.209328015483973
8265. the catholic priest though somewhat superficially	drawn easily came out the best.	7.657156065707981
8266. there were many letters of strong	protest against the portrait of the anglican clergyman who was indeed	portrayed as a man not particularly concerned with religious matters	and without really very much to do as clergyman.	11.262490573393857
8267. such a series of	articles was certainly never printed in the public press of mid-victorian	england.	8.086954922325663
8268. there was so much interest shown in this present-day	venture that it was continued on bbc where comments were	equally made by an anglican parson a free church minister and a catholic	priest.	9.59165568965248
8269. catholic priests have frequently appeared on	television programs sometimes discussing the christian faith on an equal	footing with protestant clergymen.	6.067859606934685
8270. a notable example of this was	the discussion of christian unity by the catholic archbishop of liverpool	dr heenan and the anglican archbishop of york dr	ramsey recently appointed archbishop of canterbury.	8.777119343876892
8271. the good	feeling which exists between these two important church figures is now	well known in england.	7.021091045771775
8272. the holy sacrifice of the mass with commentary	has been televised several times in recent months.	9.509835326783428
8273. and it was	interesting to observe that bbc's television film on christmas	eve was the bells of st mary's.	6.977417371539014
8274. of course	the crowning event that has dramatically upset the traditional pattern	of english religious history was the friendly visit paid by dr	fisher then anglican archbishop of canterbury to the vatican	last december.	9.246150865875418
8275. it was the first time an english primate has done	this since the 14th century.	11.755001697180779
8276. english catholics reacted to this event	with moderate but real hope.	8.84291539982784
8277. almost daily something is reported	which feeds this catholic hope in england: statistics of the increasing	numbers of converts and irish catholic immigrants; news of	a protestant minister in leamington who has offered to allow a catholic	priest to preach from his pulpit; a report that a catholic nun	had been requested to teach in a non-catholic secondary school during	the sickness of one of its masters; the startling statement in a	respectable periodical that catholics if the present system is still	in operation will constitute almost one-third of the house of lords	in the next generation; a report that 200 protestant clergymen	and laity attended a votive mass offered for christian unity at	a catholic church in slough during the church unity octave.	4.657541801274573
8278. the death of a man is unique and yet it is universal.	22.967928665571
8279. the straight	line would symbolize its uniqueness the circle its universality.	7.08282385665725
8280. but	how can one figure symbolize both?	9.401575356806818
8281.    christianity declares that	in the life and death of jesus christ the unique and the universal	concur.	9.714423608119441
8282. perhaps no church father saw this concurrence of the unique	and the universal as clearly or formulated it as precisely as irenaeus.	8.45553815601911
8283. to be the savior and the lord jesus christ has to be a historical	individual with a biography all his own; he dare not be a cosmic	aeon that swoops to earth for a while but never identifies itself	with man's history.	6.78883406057712
8284. yet this utterly individual historical person	must also contain within himself the common history of mankind.	9.05263227932366
8285. his	history is his alone yet each man must recognize his own history in	it.	7.550564042635688
8286. his death is his alone yet each man can see his own death in the	crucifixion of jesus.	11.210556395467533
8287. each man can identify himself with the history	and the death of jesus christ because jesus christ has identified	himself with human history and human death coming as the head of a	new humanity.	8.398540956718342
8288. not a circle then nor a straight line but a spiral	represents the shape of death as irenaeus sees it; for a spiral has	motion as well as recurrence.	10.351671364139168
8289. as represented by a spiral history may	in some sense be said to repeat itself; yet each historical event	remains unique.	6.822943168947579
8290. christ is both unique and universal.	10.989487874118836
8291. the first	turn of the spiral is the primeval history of humanity in adam.	7.9369519389588
8292. as	origen interprets the end of history on the basis of its beginning	so irenaeus portrays the story of adam on the basis of the story of	christ.	13.707355353143262
8293. whence then comes the substance of the first man?	8.571350931282232
8294.  from	god's will and wisdom and from virgin earth.	7.7741268865296576
8295. for 'god had	not rained' says the scripture before man was made 'and there	was no man to till the earth'.	4.582308696570202
8296. from this earth then while it was	still virgin god took dust and fashioned the man the beginning of humanity.	11.216660033881123
8297. irenaeus does not regard adam and eve merely as private	individuals but as universal human beings who were and are all of humanity.	7.627510447469115
8298. adam and eve were perfect not in the sense that they possessed	perfection but in the sense that they were capable of development	toward perfection.	17.95737306480793
8299. they were in fact children.	17.620940254123337
8300. irenaeus does not	claim pre-existence for the human soul; therefore there is no need for	him as there is for origen to identify existence itself with the	fall.	8.657327332251825
8301. existence is created and willed by god and is not the consequence	of a pre-existent rebellion or of a cosmic descent from eternity	into history.	6.183126737723943
8302. historical existence is a created good.	10.582598031109338
8303. the biblical	symbol for this affirmation is expressed in the words: so	god created man in his own image; in the similitude of god he created	him.	6.441851308713628
8304. there are some passages in the writings of irenaeus where	the image of god and the similitude are sharply distinguished so	most notably in the statement: if the holy spirit is absent	from the soul such a man is indeed of an animal nature; and being	left carnal he will be an imperfect being possessing the image	of	god in his formation but not receiving the similitude of god	through the spirit.	8.819272306805725
8305. thus the image of god is that which makes	a man a man and not an oyster; the similitude of god by contrast	is that which makes a man a child of god and not merely a rational creature.	9.006744290964187
8306. recent research on irenaeus however makes it evident that	he does not consistently maintain this distinction.	8.736960947611912
8307. he does not mean	to say that adam lost the similitude of god and his immortality through	the fall; for he was created not exactly immortal nor yet exactly	mortal but capable of immortality as well as of mortality.	8.077351643895987
8308. therefore irenaeus describes man's creation as follows:	so that the man should not have thoughts of grandeur and become lifted	up as if he had no lord because of the dominion that had been	given to him and the freedom fall into sin against god his creator	overstepping his bounds and take up an attitude of self-conceited arrogance	towards god a law was given him by god that he might know	that he had for lord the lord of all.	8.117219301665516
8309. and he laid down for him certain	conditions: so that if he kept the command of god then he would	always remain as he was that is immortal; but if he did not he	would become mortal melting into earth whence his frame had been taken.	6.578270954371569
8310. these conditions man did not keep and thus he became mortal;	yet he did not stop being human as a result.	8.868854745114618
8311. there is no justification	for systematizing the random statements of irenaeus about the image	of god beyond this nor for reading into his imprecise usage the	later theological distinction between the image of god and	the similitude of god.	8.593164139162148
8312. man was created with the	capacity for immortality but the devil's promise of immortality	in exchange for disobedience cost adam his immortality.	7.429203619704669
8313. he was in the	words of irenaeus beguiled by another under the pretext of immortality.	8.792278221052259
8314. the true way to immortality lay through obedience but man	did not believe this.	9.696416238787693
8315. eve was disobedient; for she did	not obey when as yet she was a virgin.	5.616820786460667
8316. and even as she having indeed	a husband adam but being nevertheless as yet a virgin h having	become disobedient was made the cause of death both to herself and	to the entire human race; so also did mary having a man betrothed	to her and being nevertheless a virgin by yielding obedience become	the cause of salvation both to herself and the whole human race.	8.322116616882322
8317. because he interprets the primitive state of man as one of mere	potentiality or capacity and believes that adam and eve were created	as children irenaeus often seems inclined to extenuate their disobedience	as being due no doubt to carelessness but still wicked.	7.2793490521682
8318. his interpretation of the beginning on the basis of the end prompts	him to draw these parallels between the virgin eve and the virgin	mary.	12.842242007096301
8319. that parallelism affects his picture of man's disobedience too;	for as it was christ the word of god who came to rescue man	so it was disobedience to the word of god in the beginning that brought	death into the world and all our woe.	9.219757806753131
8320. with this act of disobedience	and not with the inception of his individual existence man	began the downward circuit on the spiral of history descending from	the created capacity for immortality to an inescapable mortality.	8.585346391108725
8321. at	the nadir of that circuit is death.	8.425872565976173
8322. along with the fruit they did	also fall under the power of death because they did eat in disobedience;	and disobedience to god entails death.	9.69715289731152
8323. wherefore as they became	forfeit to death from that moment they were handed over to it.	7.327610752864967
8324. this leads irenaeus to the somewhat startling notion that adam	and eve died on the same day that they disobeyed namely on a friday	as a parallel to the death of christ on good friday; he sees	a parallel also to the jewish day of preparation for the sabbath.	9.011493056578486
8325. in	any case though they had been promised immortality if they ate of	the tree they obtained mortality instead.	6.47874230788756
8326. the wages of sin is death.	18.011573980451907
8327. man's life originally shaped for immortality and for communion with	god must now be conformed to the shape of death.	4.8855991903684055
8328. nevertheless	even at the nadir of the circuit the spiral of history belongs	to god and he still rules.	9.620723538700455
8329. even death therefore has a providential	as well as a punitive function.	8.162176303089373
8330. wherefore also he god	drove him man out of paradise and removed him far from the tree	of life not because he envied him the tree of life as some venture	to assert but because he pitied him and did not desire that	he should continue a sinner for ever nor that the sin which surrounded	him should be immortal and evil interminable and irremediable.	8.189229617992838
8331. but	he set a bound to his state of sin by interposing death and thus	causing sin to cease putting an end to it by the dissolution of the	flesh which should take place in the earth so that man ceasing at	length to live in sin and dying to it might live to god.	7.642666937631228
8332. this	idea which occurs in both tatian and cyprian fits especially well	into the scheme of irenaeus' theology; for it prepares the way for	the passage from life through death to life that is achieved in christ.	6.977216454558633
8333. as man can live only by dying so it was only by his dying that	christ could bring many to life.	8.189509105746064
8334. it is probably fair to say	that the idea of death is more profound in irenaeus than the idea of	sin is.	13.99855346755407
8335. this applies to his picture of adam.	12.693771277433864
8336. it is borne out also	by the absence of any developed theory about how sin passes from one generation	to the next.	11.410743471967649
8337. it becomes most evident in his description of	christ as the second adam who does indeed come to destroy sin but	whose work culminates in the achievement of immortality.	7.370267387825848
8338. this emphasis	upon death rather than sin as man's fundamental problem irenaeus	shares with many early theologians especially the greek-speaking ones.	6.255987161114152
8339. they speak of the work of christ as the bestowal of incorruptibility	which can mean deliverance from	time and history.	10.47877189968513
8340. death reminds man of his sin but it reminds	him also of his transience.	10.37420811589553
8341. it represents a punishment that he knows	he deserves but it also symbolizes most dramatically that he lives	his life within the process of time.	8.278402761437116
8342. these two aspects of death cannot	be successfully separated but they dare not be confused or identified.	10.794975313466493
8343. the repeated efforts in christian history to describe death as	altogether the consequence of human sin show that these two aspects of	death cannot be separated.	7.380192592299091
8344. such efforts almost always find themselves	compelled to ask whether adam was created capable of growing old and	then older and then still older in short whether adam's life was	intended to be part of the process of time.	8.567281209866996
8345. if it was then it must	have been god's intention to translate him at a certain point from	time to eternity.	8.411192585960395
8346. one night so some of these theories run adam would	have fallen asleep much as he fell asleep for the creation of eve;	and thus he would have been carried over into the life eternal.	10.892884554117177
8347. the	embarrassment of these theories over the naturalness of death is an	illustration of the thesis that death cannot be only a punishment for	some termination seems necessary in a life that is lived within the	natural order of time and change.	7.018079867367519
8348. on the other hand christian	faith knows that death is more than the natural termination of temporal	existence.	17.34456987107292
8349. it is the wages of sin and its sting is the law.	15.250218570858765
8350. if	this aspect of death as punishment is not distinguished from the idea	of death as natural termination the conclusion seems inevitable that	temporal existence itself is a form of punishment rather than the state	into which man is put by the will of the creator.	10.127563727207654
8351. this seems to have	been the conclusion to which origen was forced.	10.46034962087898
8352. if death receives	more than its share of attention from the theologian and if sin receives	less than its share the gift of the life eternal through christ	begins to look like the divinely appointed means of rescue from temporal	ie created existence.	10.999660059034406
8353. such an interpretation of death radically	alters the christian view of creation; for it teaches salvation	from not salvation in time and history.	6.679565831447957
8354. because christianity	teaches not only salvation in history but salvation by the history of	christ such an interpretation of death would require a drastic revision	of the christian understanding of the work of christ.	11.453914839250944
8355. furthermore as an encouragement to revisionist thinking it manifestly	is fair to admit that any fraternity has a constitutional right	to refuse to accept persons it dislikes.	6.220371181813971
8356. the unitarian clergy were	an exclusive club of cultivated gentlemen- as the term was then understood	in the back bay- and parker was definitely not a gentleman	either in theology or in manners.	6.404121694996986
8357. ezra stiles gannett an honorable	representative of the sanhedrin addressed himself frankly to the	issue in 1845 insisting that parker should not be persecuted or calumniated	and that in this republic no power to restrain him by force	could exist.	5.597311859782103
8358. even so gannett judiciously argued the association could	legitimately decide that parker should not be encouraged nor	assisted in diffusing his opinions by those who differ from him in regard	to their correctness.	9.67202615628995
8359. we today are not entitled to excoriate	honest men who believed parker to be downright pernicious and who	barred their pulpits against his demand to poison the minds of their	congregations.	6.501093394994195
8360. one can even argue- though this is a delicate matter-	that every justification existed for their returning the public lecture	to the first church and so to suppress it rather than let parker	use it as a sounding board for his propaganda when his turn should	come to occupy it.	7.710355577689794
8361. finally it did seem clear as day to these clergymen	as gannett's son explained in the biography of his father	they had always contended for the propriety of their claim to the title	of christians.	5.577249525845629
8362. their demand against the calvinist orthodoxy for	intellectual liberty had never meant that they would follow free inquiry	to the extreme of proclaiming christianity a natural religion.	7.980004060783905

8590. but again we have no real evidence on this from that quarter until	the close of the ninth century ad when an arabic scholar tabit	ibn korra is said to have discussed the magic square of	three.	10.76918712994111
8591. thus while it remains possible that the babylonians andor	the pythagoreans may perhaps have had the magic square of three before	the chinese did more definite evidence will have to turn up from	the middle east or the classical world before china can lose her	claim to the earliest known magic square by more than a thousand years.	6.582782737645341
8592. the	concept of the middle kingdom at peace strong and united under a	forceful ruler which had been only a longed-for ideal in the time of	the	warring states was finally realized by the establishment of a chinese	empire under the ch'in dynasty.	8.474305045534164
8593. but this	was only accomplished by excessive cruelty and extremes of totalitarian	despotism.	7.944429280156753
8594. among the many severe measures taken by the first emperor	shih huang-ti in his efforts to insure the continuation of	this hard-won national unity was the burning of the books in 213 bc	with the expressed intention of removing possible sources for	divergent thinking; but as he had a special fondness for magic and	divination he ordered that books on these subjects should be spared.	7.131099080537934
8595. many of the latter were destroyed in their turn during the burning	of the vast ch'in palace some ten years later; yet some must have	survived because the old interest in number symbolism divination	and magic persisted on into the han dynasty which succeeded in reuniting	china and keeping it together for a longer period	.	6.105124492230673
8596. in fact during	the first century bc an extensive literature sprang up devoted	to these subjects finding its typical expression in the so-called	wei books a number of which were specifically devoted to	the lo shu and related numerical diagrams especially in connection	with divination.	8.207276867391343
8597. however the wei books were also destroyed	in a series of orthodox confucian purges which culminated in a final	proscription in 605.	6.472195379159268
8598. after all this destruction of old literature	it should be obvious why we have so little information about the	early history and development of the lo shu which was already	semisecret anyhow.	10.725218234306165
8599. but in spite of all this enough evidence remains	to show that the magic square of three must indeed have been the object	of a rather extensive cult- or series of cults- reaching fullest	expression in the han period.	7.066623302707542
8600. although modern scholars have	expressed surprise that the simple magic square of three a mere	mathematical puzzle was able to exert a considerable influence	on the minds and imaginations of the cultured chinese for so many centuries	they could have found most of the answers right within the square	itself.	8.740241843659652
8601. but up to now no one has attempted to analyze its inherent	mathematical properties or the numerical significance of its numbers-	singly or in combination- and then tried to consider these in	the light of old chinese cosmological concepts.	5.7944839013530824
8602. such an analysis	speedily reveals why the middle number of the lo shu 5	was so vitally significant for the chinese ever since the earliest hints	that they had a knowledge of this diagram.	11.114621696307305
8603. the importance of this	5 can largely be explained by the natural mathematical properties of	the middle number and its special relationship to all the rest of the	numbers- quite apart from any numerological considerations which is	to say any symbolic meaning arbitrarily assigned to it.	6.507600895920527
8604. indeed mathematically	speaking it was both functionally and symbolically the most	important number in the entire diagram.	8.76299412891438
8605. if one takes the middle	number 5 and multiplies it by 3	the result is 15 which is also the constant sum of	all the rows columns and two main diagonals.	7.556956391516311
8606. then if the middle number	is activated to its greatest potential in terms of this square through	multiplying it by the highest number 9	the result is 45; and the latter is the total sum	of all the numbers in the square by which all the other numbers are	overshadowed and in which they may be said to be absorbed.	11.516343660444925
8607. furthermore	the middle number of the lo shu is not only the physical	mean between every opposing pair of the other numbers by reason of	its central position; it is also their mathematical mean since it	is equal to half the sum of every opposing pair all of which equal 10.	7.053836915462284
8608. in fact the neat balance of these pairs and their subtle equilibrium	would have had special meaning in the minds of the old chinese.	12.280702647652056
8609. for they considered the odd numbers as male and the even ones as female	equating the two groups with the yang and yin principles in nature;	and in this square the respective pairs made up of large and	small odd numbers and those composed of large and small even	numbers were all equal to each other.	6.100592971095702
8610. thus all differences were	leveled and all contrasts erased in a realm of no distinction and	the harmonious balance of the lo shu square could effectively	symbolize the world in balanced harmony around a powerful central axis.	9.822245365676812
8611. the tremendous emphasis on the 5 in the lo shu square-	for purely mathematical reasons- and the fact that this number so	neatly symbolized the heart and center of the universe could well explain	why the old chinese seem to have so revered the number 5 and	why they put so much stress on the concept of centrality.	7.6673239943210945
8612. these twin	tendencies seem to have reached their height in the han dynasty.	11.773328083980559
8613. the existing reverence for centrality must have been still further	stimulated toward the close of the second century bc when	the han emperor wu ti ordered the dynastic color changed to yellow-	which symbolized the center among the traditional five directions-	and took 5 as the dynastic number believing that he would thus	place himself his imperial family and the nation under the most auspicious	influences.	5.624570454134648
8614. his immediate motive for doing this may not have	been directly inspired by the lo shu but this measure must inevitably	have increased the existing beliefs in the latter's efficacy.	9.168159503577924
8615. after this time inscriptions on the han bronze mirrors as well	as other writings emphasized the desirability of keeping one's	self at the center of the universe where cosmic forces were strongest.	8.012991322270542
8616. later we shall see what happened when an emperor took this idea too	literally.	12.457390379027762
8617. all this emphasis on centrality and on the number	5 as a symbolic expression of the center which seems to have begun	as far back as 400 bc also may conceivably have led to the development	of the five-elements school and the subsequent efforts to	fit everything into numerical categories of five.	7.138170862493579
8618. we find for example	such groupings as the five ancient rulers the five sacred mountains	the five directions the five metals five	colors five tastes five odors five musical notes five	bodily functions five viscera and many others.	7.86201435536644
8619. this trend has	often been ascribed to the cult of the five elements itself as though	they had served as the base for all the rest; but why did the old	chinese postulate five elements when the ancient near east-	which may have initiated the idea that natural elements exerted influence	in human life and activities- recognized only four?	5.797146521397663
8620.  and why	did the chinese suddenly begin to talk about the five directions	when the animals they used as symbols of the directions designated only	the usual four?	9.232999594558795
8621.  obviously something suddenly caused them to start	thinking in terms of fives and that may have been the workings of	the lo shu.	7.943660165308266
8622. this whole tendency had an unfortunate effect	on chinese thinking.	10.92141878781183
8623. whereas the primary meanings of the lo shu	diagram seemed to have been based on its inner mathematical properties-	and we shall see that even its secondary meanings rested on	some mathematical bases- the urgent desire to place everything into	categories of fives led to other groupings based on other numbers until	an exaggerated emphasis on mere numerology pervaded chinese thought.	5.445450256638245
8624. scholars made numbered sets of as many things as possible in nature	or assigned arbitrary numbers to individual things in a fashion that	seems to the modern scientific mind as downright nonsensical and	philosophical ideas based upon all this tended to stifle speculative thought	in china for many centuries.	7.577307426507605
8625. square	although the primary mathematical properties of the middle	number at the center of the lo shu and the interrelation	of all the other numbers to it might seem enough to account for the deep	fascination which the lo shu held for the old chinese philosophers	this was actually only a beginning of wonders.	9.215539471807341
8626. for the lo	shu square was a remarkably complete compendium of most of the chief	religious and philosophical ideas of its time.	10.830367067978772
8627. as such one cannot	fully understand the thought of the pre-han and han periods without	knowing the meanings inherent in the lo shu; but conversely	one cannot begin to understand the lo shu without knowing something	about the world view of the old chinese which they felt they	saw expressed in it.	6.73647583660719
8628. the chinese world view during the han dynasty	when the lo shu seems to have been at the height of its	popularity was based in large part on the teachings of the yin-yang	and five-elements school which was traditionally founded by tsou	yen.	9.871932338518185
8629. according to this doctrine the universe was ruled by heaven	t'ien- as a natural force or in the personification of a supreme	sky-god- governing all things by means of a process called the	tao	which can be roughly interpreted as the order of the universe	or the universal way.	6.585961634353067
8630. heaven acting through the tao	expressed itself by means of the workings of two basic principles	the yin and the yang.	9.049472492433141
8631. the yang or male principle was the source	of light heat and dynamic vitality associated with the sun; while	the yin or female principle flourished in darkness cold and quiet	inactivity and was associated with the moon.	5.8722562693076314
8632. together these two	principles influenced all things and in varying combinations they were	present in everything.	10.530647992763642
8633. we have already seen that odd numbers	were considered as being yang while the even numbers were yin so	that the eight outer numbers of the lo shu represented these two	principles in balanced equilibrium around the axial center.	6.7951356960834195
8634. during	the han dynasty another yin-yang conception was applied to the lo	shu considering the latter as a plan of ancient china.	8.531730369398199
8635. instead	of linking the nine numbers of this diagram with the traditional nine	provinces as was usually	done this equated the odd yang numbers	with mountains and the even numbers	with rivers; taking the former	from the five sacred mountains of the han period and the latter from	the principal river systems of old china.	6.151500848037283
8636. thus the middle	number 5 represented sung-shan in honan central china; the	3 t'ai-shan in shantung east china; the 7 hwa-shan in shensi	west china; the 1 heng-shan in hopei north china	; and the	9 huo-shan in anhwei which was then the south sacred mountain.	3.9745722372668566
8637. for the rivers the 4 represented the huai to the southeast;	the 2 the san kiang southwest;	the 8 the chi in the northeast; and the 6 the yellow river	in the northwest.	4.8960866623845005
8638. note that by western standards this	plan was upside down as it put north at the bottom and south	at the top with the other directions correspondingly altered; but in	this respect it was merely following the accepted chinese convention	for all maps.	7.9004308235259755
8639. the same arrangement was used when the lo shu was	equated with the nine provinces; and whenever the lo shu	involved directional symbolism it was oriented in this same fashion.	6.462433881556584

8703. the worship service is the natural and logical	time to receive new members into the church.	7.585365681228651
8704. the atmosphere for	this momentous experience can be created most effectively through the	worship experience.	9.823598022493226
8705. psychologically the reception should be the	_ ask the new members to meet thirty	minutes before the service to complete talent sheets and pledge	cards.	6.316356923305896
8706. some denominations ask new members to sign personally the	chronological membership register.	10.451278062102931
8707. provide a name card for each	_ arrange a	reserved section in the sanctuary where all new members may sit together.	5.49120898696987
8708. _ invite sponsors or fellowship	friends to stand back of the new members in the reception service.	9.489047653203398
8709. _	introduce each new member to the congregation asking him to face	_ lead the congregation in a response of	_ have a reception for new members in the parlor or	_ take a picture of	the group of new members to be put in the church paper or placed on the	_ have a fellowship luncheon or dinner with	new members as guests.	5.8614414122291105
8710. growth of new members	the church is the family of god.	12.035473320634077
8711. the members of the family are drawn together by a common love	for christ and a sincere devotion to his kingdom.	9.313047091001822
8712. every member	of the family must have a vital place in its life.	11.862213059405681
8713. this is no spectator-type	experience; everyone is to be a participant.	11.158481281643198
8714. yet the	most difficult problem in the church's program of evangelism is right	at this point- helping new members to become participating growing	parts of the fellowship.	6.9710277571264125
8715. very easily they may be neglected and eventually	join the ranks of the unconcerned and inactive.	7.837789998883765
8716. a study	of major denominational membership statistics over a twenty-year period	revealed the appalling fact that nearly 40 per cent of those who	joined the church were lost to the church within seven years.	8.853228732756907
8717. one	denomination had a membership of 1419833 at the beginning of the	period under study and twenty years later its membership stood at 1541991-	a net growth of only 122158.	6.803601876573696
8718. yet during the same period there	were 1080062 additions.	12.904025293187104
8719. another major church body had 4499608	members and twenty years later its membership stood at 4622444.	8.114899422311574
8720. during	this time 4122354 new members were brought into the fellowship.	11.165074099586699
8721. still another denomination had 7360187 members twenty years ago.	8.446450243924435
8722. during	this period 7484268 members were received yet the net membership	now is only 9910741.	9.95753761492229
8723. these figures indicate that we are losing	almost as many as we are receiving into membership.	9.147561066410603
8724. this problem	is illustrated by the fact that many local churches drop from the	active membership rolls each year as many as they receive into the fellowship.	10.541845783201227
8725. studies of membership trends even in some areas where population	is expanding show that numbers of churches have had little net	increase though many new members were received.	7.026761219193432
8726. something is wrong when	these things happen.	11.303124045535519
8727. the local family of god has failed its	new members through neglect and unconcern for their spiritual welfare.	7.986488495396639
8728. new members can become participating growing	members.	12.93768549210487
8729. but this will not happen merely through the natural process	of social life.	9.81835090462367
8730. it must be planned and carefully developed.	18.940214867978593
8731. the	entire membership of the local church must be alerted to their part	in this dynamic process.	7.268624256222957
8732. if the church has followed the plan	of cultivation of prospects and carried through a program of membership	preparation as outlined earlier in this book the process of assimilation	and growth will be well under way.	10.621280150214561
8733. those who enter the front	door of the church intelligently and with christian dedication will	not so easily step through the back door because of lost interest.	7.507408062208605
8734. however it is not enough to bring persons to christian commitment	and train them in the meaning of christian discipleship.	16.096507357868862
8735. when	they unite with the church they must find in this fellowship the satisfaction	of their basic spiritual needs or they will never mature into	effective christians.	6.738035944528748
8736. the church expects certain things of	those who become members.	12.483519738427777
8737. the new members justifiably expect some things	from their church family:  - welcome into the fellowship	- sincere christian love and understanding  - inspiring	and challenging worship experiences  - social and recreational	activities  - opportunities for christian service	- opportunities for study of the christian faith and the bible	- creative prayer experiences  - guidance in christian	social concerns	men need unity and they need god.	3.539715293595778
8738. care must be taken neither	to confuse unity with uniformity nor god with our parochial ideas	about him but with these two qualifications the statement stands.	8.472930429526567
8739. the statement also points to a classic paradox: the more men turn	toward god who is not only in himself the paradigm of all unity but	also the only ground on which human unity can ultimately be established	the more men splinter into groups and set themselves apart from one	another.	6.350528581632319
8740. to be reminded of this we need only glance at the world map	and note the extent to which religious divisions have compounded political	ones with a resultant fragmentation of the human race.	9.853431658151276
8741. massacres	attending the partition of india and the establishment of the state	of israel are simply recent grim evidences of the hostility such	divisions can engender.	6.792382446413984
8742. the words of cardinal newman come forcibly	to	mind: oh how we hate one another for the love of god!	the source of this paradox is not difficult to identify.	8.115666327401913
8743. institutions require structure form and definition	and these in turn entail differentiation and exclusion.	5.926280425435951
8744. a completely	amorphous institution would be a contradiction in terms; to escape	this fate it must rule some things out.	7.69511388207312
8745. for every criterion which	defines what something is at the same time proclaims- implicitly if	not openly- what that something is not.	6.8475040225568105
8746. some persons are so sensitive	to this truth as to propose that we do away with institutions altogether;	in the present context this amounts to the advice that while	being religious may have a certain justification we ought to dispense	with churches.	8.644895638348352
8747. man is at once a gregarious	animal and a form-creating being.	11.94025290817219
8748. having once committed himself to	an ideal which he considers worthwhile he inevitably creates forms	for its expression and institutions for its continuance.	7.771115636187354
