8749. to propose that	men be religious without having religious institutions is like proposing	that they be learned without having schools.	6.272363721540763
8750. both eventualities	are possible logically but practically they are impossible.	9.484618897350305
8751. as much	as men intrinsically need the unity that is grounded in god they instrumentally	require the institutions that will direct their steps toward	him.	6.685285331703009
8752. yet the fact remains that such institutions do set men	at odds with their fellows.	11.828680197980272
8753. is there any way out of the predicament?	18.084859613592613
8754. 	the only way that i can see is through communication.	10.61817879486361
8755. interfaith	communication need not be regarded as an unfortunate burden visited	upon us by the necessity of maintaining diplomatic relations with our	adversaries.	8.077905955269545
8756. approached creatively it is a high art.	12.98721741876323
8757. it is the art	of relating the finite to the infinite of doing our best to insure that	the particularistic requirements of religious institutions will not	thwart god's intent of unity among men more than is minimally necessary.	6.222029882757766
8758. in a certain sense interfaith communication parallels diplomatic	communication among the nation-states.	12.065032185160991
8759. what are the pertinent	facts affecting such communication at the present juncture of history?	8.829785873638745
8760. 	i shall touch on three areas: personal national and theological.	6.43911664212233
8761. by personal factors i mean those rooted in personality	structure.	7.543191035628483
8762. some interfaith tensions are not occasioned by theological	differences at all but by the need of men to have persons they	can blame distrust denounce and even hate.	10.082259605645298
8763. such needs may rise	to pathological proportions.	8.481670166652743
8764. modern psychology has shown that paralleling	the authoritarian personality is the bigoted personality	in which insecurity inferiority suspicion and distrust combine	to provide a target for antagonism so indispensable that it will be manufactured	if it does not exist naturally.	8.384003048048447
8765. fortunately the number of	pathological bigots appears to be quite small but it would be a mistake	to think that more than a matter of degree separates them from the	rest of us.	8.839930694664682
8766. to some extent the personal inadequacies that prejudices	attempt to compensate for are to be found in all of us.	14.639770062126983
8767. interfaith	conflicts which spring from psychological deficiencies are the most	unfortunate of all for they have no redeeming features whatsoever.	6.571170693758822
8768. it is difficult to say what can be done about them except that we must	learn to recognize when it is they rather than pretexts for them	that are causing the trouble and do everything possible to nurture the	healthy personalities that will prevent the development of such deficiencies.	12.429534971475046
8769. while the personality factors that aggravate interfaith	conflict may be perennial nationalism is more variable.	7.079332452263473
8770. the	specific instance i have in mind is the afro-asian version which	has gained prominence only in this second half of the twentieth century.	10.472489673401196
8771. emerging from the two centuries of colonial domination the	afro-asian world is aflame with a nationalism that has undone empires.	5.5036265631299885
8772. no less than twenty-two nations have already achieved independence	since world war 2 and the number is growing by the year.	11.169238421219115
8773. as	an obvious consequence obstacles to genuine interfaith communication	have grown more formidable in one important area: relations between	christians and non-christians in these lands.	4.730633994950466
8774. colonialism alone would	have been able to make these difficulties serious for christianity	is so closely tied to colonialism in the minds of these people that	repudiation of the one has tended automatically toward the repudiation	of the other.	9.073812522622985
8775. actually however this turns out to be only part of	the picture.	10.50854094767597
8776. nationalism has abetted not only the repudiation of foreign	religions but the revival of native ones some of which had been lying	in slumber for centuries.	9.058208544421975
8777. the truth is that any revival of traditional	and indigenous religion will serve to promote that sense of identity	and volksgeist which these young nations very much need.	7.635229657596672
8778. insofar	as these nations claim to incarnate traditions and ways of life	which constitute ultimate trans-political justifications for their existence	such people are inevitably led to emphasize the ways in which	these traditions and ways are theirs rather than someone else's.	7.69149645643918
8779. all this works severely against the kind of cross-cultural	communication for which christian missions stand.	6.942730360024325
8780. africans and asians	tend to consider not only missions but the local churches they have	produced as centers and agents of western culture and ideology if not	of direct political propaganda.	7.726599223002726
8781. the people hardest hit by this suspicion	are of course christians on the mainland of china.	8.223346925977872
8782. but the	problem extends elsewhere.	16.374682657648634
8783. for example in burma and ceylon many buddhists	argue that buddhism ought to be the official state religion.	9.1434281324499
8784. in 1960 ceylon nationalized its sectarian- preponderantly christian-	schools to the rejoicing of most of its 7000000 buddhists and	the lament of its 800000 roman catholics.	7.341662301350356
8785. again india has imposed	formidable barriers against the entrance of additional missionaries	and fanatical hindu parties are expected to seek further action against	christians once the influence making for tolerance due to nehru	and his followers is gone.	6.191435825717363
8786. the progressive closing of afro-asian	ears to the christian message is epitomized in a conversation	i had three years ago while flying from jerusalem to cairo.	8.471734639366348
8787. i was	seated next to the director of the seventh day adventists' world	radio program.	9.38310943319654
8788. he said that on his tour the preceding year a considerable	number of hours would have been available to him on japanese radio	networks but that he had then lacked the funds to contract for them.	11.16260671831008
8789. after returning to the united states and raising the money he	discovered on getting back to japan that the hours were no longer available.	9.47396443804756
8790. it was not that they had been contracted for during the interval;	they simply could no longer be purchased for missionary purposes.	11.408294482773906
8791. it is not unfair to add on the other side that the crude and almost	vitriolic approach of certain fundamentalist sects toward the cultures	and religions among which they work has contributed measurably to this	heightening of anti-christian sentiment.	7.789459252992862
8792. ironically these are the	groups which have doubled or tripled their missionary efforts since	world war 2 while the more established denominations are barely	maintaining pre-war staffs.	6.919310363071189
8793. although i have emphasized the	barriers which an aroused nationalism has raised against relations between	christians and non-christians in asia the fact is that this development	has also widened the gulf between certain afro-asian religions	themselves.	6.6132875706580085
8794. the partition of india has hardly improved relations	between hindus and muslims; neither has the establishment of the	state of israel fostered harmony between muslims and jews.	8.16113058927607
8795. i turn finally to several theological developments.	9.435729076807798
8796. the modern world has been marked by progressive	disaffection with claims to divine sanction for the state whatever	its political form.	10.776939391634
8797. the american constitution was historic at	this point in providing that congress shall make no law respecting	an establishment of religion or prohibiting the free exercise thereof.	6.3315360360582496
8798. one of our foremost jurists david dudley field has gone so	far as to call this provision the greatest achievement ever made in	the course of human history.	9.604030733246313
8799. the trend throughout the world's	religions has been toward a recognition of at least the practical	validity of this constitutional enactment.	6.763979387464178
8800. pakistan was created in	1947 expressly as a muslim state but when the army took over eleven	years later it did so on a wave of mass impatience which was directed	in part against the inability of political and religious leaders to think	their way through to the meaning of islam for the modern political	situation.	8.9391060160524
8801. what is the point charles adams reports the pakistanis	as asking in demanding an islamic state and society if no	one not even the doctors of the sacred law themselves can say clearly	and succinctly what the nature of such a state and society is?	7.82431855151331
8802. 	the current regime of president mohammad ayub khan is determinedly	secular.	7.683459220362503
8803. and while the nation was formerly named the islamic	republic of pakistan it is now simply the republic of pakistan.	9.41537882146715
8804. comparable trends can be noted elsewhere.	10.555668197651205
8805. the new regime	in turkey is intentionally less muslim than its predecessor.	7.407279409403219
8806. the	religious parties in israel have experienced a great loss of prestige	in recent months.	8.914258299385423
8807. during the years when israel was passing from	crisis to crisis- the sinai campaign the infusion of multitudes of	penniless immigrants- it was felt that the purpose of national unity	could be best served if the secular majority were to yield to the religious	parties.	5.6357017670925735
8808. now that israel enjoys relative prosperity and a reduction	of tensions the secularists are less disposed to compromise.	9.445120428971958
8809. and in this country gustave weigel's delineation of the line between	the sacral and secular orders during the last presidential campaign	served to provide a most impressive roman catholic defense of the	practical autonomy of both church and state.	6.825953626087082
8810. the failure at that time	of the puerto rican bishops to control the votes of their people added	a ring of good sense to father weigel's theological argument.	8.801557787009777
8811. everywhere there seems to be a growing recognition of the fact that	governments and religious institutions alike are too fallible and corruptible-	in a word too human- to warrant any claim of maintaining	partnership with the divine.	6.503520921499627
8812. my	father went as a missionary to china in a generation that responded	to student volunteer movement speakers who held watches in their hands	and announced to the students in their audiences how many chinese	souls were going to hell each second because these students were not	over there saving them.	7.524104183249097
8813. that mention of this should bring smiles to	our lips today is as clear an indication as we could wish of the extent	to which attitudes have changed.	6.838085094331686
8814. i do not mean to imply that christians	have adopted the liberal assumption so prevalent in hinduism	that all religions are merely different paths to the same summit.	11.403227776347414
8815. leslie	newbiggin reflects the dominant position within the world council	of churches when he says we must claim absoluteness and finality	for christ and his finished work but that very claim forbids	us to claim absoluteness and finality for our understanding of it.	6.771359497538354
8816. newbiggin's qualification on the christian claim is of considerable	significance.	7.9210077261597505
8817. the roman catholic church has excommunicated one of	its priests father feeney for insisting that there is no salvation	outside the visible church.	8.368792423139679
8818. in mentioning this under salvation	reconsidered i do not mean to imply that roman catholic doctrine	has changed in this area but rather that it has become clearer to the	world community what that doctrine is.	11.675220547196975
8819. when they say that under no circumstances would it ever be right to permit	the termination of the human race by human action because	there could not possibly be any proportionate grave reason to justify	such a thing they know exactly what they mean.	8.179467424219517
8820. of course in prudential	calculation in balancing the good directly intended and done against	the evil unintended and indirectly done no greater precision can	be forthcoming than the subject allows.	8.986442346306513
8821. yet it seems clear that there	can be no good sufficiently great or evil repelled sufficiently grave	to warrant the destruction of mankind by man's own action.	6.4731800957929195
8822. i mean however that the moral theologian knows what he means by permit.	12.768122725900104
8823. he is not talking in the main about probabilities risks	and danger in general.	9.81323814110054
8824. he is talking about an action which just as efficaciously	does an evil thing	as it efficaciously does some good.	11.028116407401724
8825. he	is talking about double effects of which the specific action causes	directly the one and indirectly the other but causes both;	of which one is deliberately willed or intended and the other not intended	or not directly intended but still both are done while the	evil effect is with equal consciousness on the part of the agent foreknown	to be among the consequences.	6.152755192661877
8826. this is what in a technical sense	to only permit an evil result means.	13.161752281053712
8827. it means to do it	and to know one is doing it but as only a secondary if certain effect	of the good one primarily does and intends.	8.851717544782503
8828. of course grave guiltiness	may be imputed to the military action of any nation or to the action	of any leader or leaders which for any supposed good permits	in this sense the termination of the human race by human action.	10.505553475561307
8829. certainly in analyzing an action which truly faced such alternatives	it is never possible that no world would be preferable to	some worlds and there are in truth no circumstances in which the	destruction of human life presents itself as a reasonable alternative.	6.939732291747171
8830. naturally where one or the other of the effects of an action	is uncertain this has to be taken into account.	14.371857977679877
8831. especially is this	true when because the good effect is remote and speculative while	the evil is certain and grave the action is prohibited.	6.818197606719262
8832. presumably	if the reverse is the case and the good effect is more certain than the	evil result that may be forthcoming not only must the good and the	evil be prudentially weighed and found proportionate but also calculation	of the probabilities and of the degree of certainty or uncertainty	in the good or evil effect must be taken into account.	9.418687849073939
8833. there must	not only be greater good than evil objectively in view but also greater	probability of actually doing more good than harm.	7.0692172891083
8834. if an evil which	is certain and extensive and immediate may rarely be compensated for	by a problematic speculative future good by the same token not every	present certain and immediate good that may have	to be done will be outweighed by a problematic speculative and future	evil.	7.907353164647632
8835. nevertheless according to the traditional theory a man begins	in the midst of action and he analyzes its nature and immediate cosequences	before or while putting it forth and causing these consequences.	6.56892784627634
8836. he does not expect to be able to trammel up all the future consequences	of his action.	16.776557466091127
8837. above all he does not debate mere contingencies	and therefore if these are possibly dreadful find himself forced	into inaction.	8.007036396386265
8838. he does what he can and may and must without regarding	himself as lord of the future or on the other hand as covered with	guilt by accident or unforeseen consequences or by results he did not	permit in the sense explained.	12.846380148910947
8839. by contrast a good deal of nuclear	pacifism begins with the contingencies and the probabilities and	not with the moral nature of the action to be done; and by deriving	legitimate decision backward from whatever may conceivably or possibly	or probably result whether by anyone's doing or by accident	it finds itself driven to inaction to non-political action in politics	and non-military action in military affairs and to the not very surprising	discovery that there are now no distinctions on which the defense	of justice can possibly be based.	5.399414814363572
8840. mr philip toynbee	writes for example that in terms of probability it is surely as	likely as not that mutual fear will lead to accidental war in the near	future if the present situation continues.	10.162540326455035
8841. if it continues indefinitely	it is nearly a statistical certainty that a mistake will	be made and that the devastation will begin.	9.19085651145026
8842. against such a termination	of human life on earth by human action he then proposes as an	alternative that we negotiate at once with the russians and get the	best terms which are available that we deliberately negotiate	from comparative weakness.	9.706727080067354
8843. he bravely attempts to face this alternative	realistically ie by considering the worst possible outcome	namely the total domination of the world by russia within a few	years.	7.288650251009446
8844. this would be by far the better choice when it is a question	of allowing the human race to survive possibly under the domination	of a regime which most of us detest or of allowing it to	destroy itself in appalling and prolonged anguish.	10.483880961970176
8845. nevertheless the	consequence of the policy proposed is everywhere subtly qualified:	it is a possible result however improbable; the worst and	least probable result; if it didn't prevail mankind would	still be given the opportunity of prevailing; for surely	anything is better than a policy which allows for the possibility	of nuclear war.	4.419238472340994
8846. if we have not thought and made a decision entirely	in these terms then we need to submit ourselves to the following	simple test: have we decided how we are to kill the other	members of our household in the event of our being less injured than	they are?	9.725383787793065
8847.  thus moral decision must be entirely deduced backward	from the likely eventuality; it is no longer to be formulated in terms	of the nature of present action itself its intention and proximate	effect or the thing to be done.	6.979329103140577
8848. several of the replies	to mr toynbee without conscious resort to the traditional terminology	with regard to the permission of evil succeed in restoring the	actual context in which present moral and political decisions must be	made by distinguishing between choosing a great evil and choosing in	danger of this evil.	7.929867159736758
8849. it is worse for a nation to give in to evil	h than to run the risk of annihilation.	11.057681512466257
8850. i am consciously prepared	to run the continued risk of 'race suicide by accident' rather	than accept the alternative certainty of race slavery by design.	7.2734456546405575
8851. but	i can only make this choice because i believe that the risk need	not increase but may be deliberately reduced by precautions against	accidents or by limiting war?	6.747132910340661
8852.  quoting mr kennan's	phrase that anything would be better than a policy which led inevitably	to nuclear war he toynbee says that anything is better than a	policy which allows for the possibility of nuclear war.	9.21577041766703
8853. if	asked to choose between a terrible probability and a more terrible possibility	most men will choose the latter.	6.624696015203257
8854. if h philip toynbee	is claiming that the choice lies between capitulation and the risk	of nuclear war i think he is right.	10.476575715651965
8855. i do not accept that the choice	is between capitulation and the certainty of nuclear war.	10.557233103059595
8856. even	professor arnold toynbee agreeing with his son does so in these	terms: compared to continuing to incur a constant risk of	the destruction of the human race all other evils are lesser evils h.	8.052204403598797
8857. let us therefore put first things first and make sure of preserving	the human race at whatever the temporary price may be.	7.311043946608728
8858. mr	philip toynbee affirms at one point that if he shared the	anticipations of orwell in nineteen eighty-four if he believed	communism was not only evil but also irredeemably evil then	he might think it right to do anything rather than to take the	risk of a communist world.	8.365634850089242
8859. even a nuclear holocaust is a little less	frightful to contemplate than a race of dehumanised humans occupying the	earth until doomsday.	7.431357631341555
8860. no political order or economic system is	so clearly contrary to nature.	9.60325521710285
8861. but one does not have to affirm the existence	of an evil order irredeemable in that sense or a static order	in which no changes will take place in time to be able truthfully to	affirm the following fact: there has never been justitia imprinted	in social institutions and social relationships except in the context	of some pax-ordo preserved by clothed or naked force.	6.982316326707109
8862. on their	way to the heavenly city the children of god make use of the pax-ordo	of the earthly city and acknowledge their share in responsibility	for its preservation.	9.76312923350759
8863. not to repel injury and uphold and improve	pax-ordo means not simply to accept the misshapen order and injustice	that challenges it at the moment but also to start down the steep	slope along which justice can find no place whereon to stand.	6.8631858539668675
8864. toynbee	seems to think that there is some other way to give justice social	embodiment.	18.243792417512005
8865. i would far rather die after a russian occupation of	this country- by some deliberate act of refusal- than die uselessly	by atomisation.	5.0873469534246265
8866. would such an act of refusal be useful?	18.37386126834212
8867.  he does	not mean in fact he addresses himself specifically to reject the	proposition that if we took the risk of surrendering a new generation	in britain would soon begin to amass its strength in secret in order	to reverse the consequences of that surrender.	6.8701365864785595
8868. he wants to be	brutally frank and say that these rebellions would be hopeless-	far far more hopeless than was the hungarian revolution of 1956.	9.80521591286063
8869. this is not a project for regaining the ground for limited war by	creating a monopoly in one power of the world's arsenal of unlimited	weapons.	6.5933704617221345
8870. it is a proposal that justice now be served by means other	than those that have ever preconditioned the search for it or preconditioned	more positive means for attaining it in the past.	11.0353280256642
8871. it is	no good recommending surrender rather than nuclear warfare with the proviso	that surrender could be followed by the effective military resistance	by occupied peoples.	7.200759096878629
8872. hope for the future h would lie in the	natural longing of the human race for freedom and the right to develop.	12.154653414249706
8873. this is to surrender in advance to whatever attack may yet be mounted	to the very last; it is to stride along the steep slope downward.	6.933109426938385
8874. the only contrary action in the future as in the past runs the	risk of war; and now and in the future unlike in the past any	attempt to repel injury and to preserve any particular civilized attainment	of mankind or its provisional justice runs some risk of nuclear	warfare and the danger that an effect of it will by human action render	this planet less habitable by the human race.	9.571720680903814
8875. that is why it is	so very important that ethical analysis keep clear the problem of decision	as to permitted effects and not draw back in fright from	any conceivable contingency or suffer paralysis of action before possibilities	or probabilities unrelated or not directly morally related	to what we can and may and must do as long as human history endures.	7.090695849013665
8876. finally just as no different issues are posed for thoughtful	analysis by the foreshortening of time that may yet pass before the end	of human life on this earth but only stimulation and alarm to the imagination	the same thing must be said in connection with the question	of what we may perhaps already be doing by human action to accelerate	this end.	9.264132476278673
8877. we should not allow the image of an immanent end brought	about indirectly by our own action in the continuing human struggle	for a just endurable order of existence to blind us to the fact that	in some measure accelerating the end of our lease may be one consequence	among others of many other of mankind's thrusts toward we know	not what future.	7.229372419780303
8878. much more than shelter housing symbolizes social status	a sense of belonging acceptance within a given group or neighborhood	identification with particular cultural values and social institutions	feelings of pride and worth aspirations and hopes basic to	human well-being.	7.72486691176796
8879. for almost one-sixth of the national population discrimination	in the free selection of residence casts a considerable shadow	upon these values assumed as self-evident by most americans.	5.0928094948199
8880. few business groups in recent years have come under heavier pressure	to face these realities than real estate brokers and home builders.	9.229227765351919
8881. this pressure has urged re-evaluation of the assumptions underlying	their professional ethics; it has sought new sympathy for the human	aspirations of racial minority groups in this country.	5.739884180002967
8882. it is not surprising	that as spokesman for real estate interests the national association	of real estate boards and its local associations	have sought to limit and often ignore much of this pressure.	10.549923525639054
8883. how does the local realtor see himself in the context of housing	restrictions based on race religion or ethnic attachment?	8.565808500233102
8884.  what	does he conceive his role to be in this area of social unrest?	12.674842295805801
8885.  what	ought to be what is his potential role as a force for constructive social	change?	6.789538537804253
8886.  what social ethical and theological insights can the	church and university help him bring to bear upon his situation?	9.907752657981291
8887. 	recently a group of the faculty at wesleyan university's public	affairs center sought some answers to these questions.	5.4345981036232205
8888. several	new england realtors were invited to participate in a small colloquium	of property lawyers political scientists economists social psychologists	social ethicists and theologians.	7.321407450184151
8889. here in an atmosphere	of forthrightness and mutual criticism each sought to bring his particular	insights to bear upon the question of discrimination in housing	and the part each man present played in it.	7.501401262813303
8890. for a number of years	wesleyan has been drawing varied groups of political and business	leaders into these informal discussions with members of the faculty	and student body attempting to explore and clarify aspects of their	responsibility for public policy.	9.503939980588896
8891. this article presents our observations	of that session of the realtors as they saw themselves and as the	faculty and students saw them.	7.5824844766731685
8892. such conversation quickly reveals	an ethically significant ambivalence in the self-images held by most	realtors.	7.3209825159578115
8893. within the membership of this group as has been found true	of men in other professional or trade associations the most ready	portrayal of oneself to the public is that of a neutral agent simply	serving the interests of a seller or buyer and mediating between	them.	7.851796042001269
8894. professional responsibility is seen to consist largely in serving	the wishes of the client fairly and in an efficient manner.	9.116711702104237
8895. but as	conversation goes on particularly among the realtors themselves another	image emerges that of considerable power and influence in the community.	7.316859971315862
8896. obviously much more than customer expectation is determining	the realtor's role.	9.739587017371228
8897. judgments are continually rendered regarding	the potential buyers' income educational level and above all racial	extraction; and whether these would qualify them for congenial	happy relations to other people in certain community areas.	4.6491806880621915
8898. how explicit such factors have been	historically is evident in any chronology of restrictive covenant cases	or in a review of nareb's code of ethics article 34 in	the code adopted in 1924 states that a realtor should never be	instrumental in introducing into a neighborhood a character of property	or occupancy members of any race or nationality or any individuals	whose presence will clearly be detrimental to property values in that	neighborhood.	7.102809680279514
8899. though the reference to race was stricken by the association	in 1950 being an agent of such detrimental influences	still appears as the cardinal sin realtors see themselves committed to	avoid.	6.388005978409778
8900. the rationale for this avoidance was most frequently	expressed in economic terms; all feared the supposed stigma they believed	would inevitably attach to any realtor who openly introduced non-white	particularly negro peoples into all-white restricted areas.	5.565312643113165
8901. they would become tagged as men not interested in being purely real	estate professionals but agitators for some kind of cause	or reform and this was no longer to be a pro.	7.928300040966711
8902. obviously	what we are confronted with here is the identification of professional	with narrow skills and specialization the effective servicing	of a client rather than responsiveness to the wider and deeper	meaning and associations of one's work.	6.818457010138962
8903. these men- for the most	part educated in our best new england colleges well established	financially and socially in the community- under kindly but insistent	probing reveal little or no objective or explicit criteria or data	for their generalizations about the interests and attitudes of the	people they claim to serve or about the public responses that actually	follow their occasional breach of a client-service relationship.	4.753367216270999
8904. this narrow professionalism does not even fit the present	realities of their situation as the pressure of minorities and the	power and respectability of the realtors increase.	9.192781229152075
8905. as our discussion	continued the inadequacy of the client relationship as an interpretation	of their way of operating became evident.	8.073794773306833
8906. realtors	live in their communities as specialists in a given area of work as	members of social and professional organizations as citizens and civic	leaders as church laymen as university alumni as newspaper readers	etc.	8.015255524864454
8907. from such communal roles the realtor finds the substance that	shapes his moral understanding.	6.808239772856556
8908. it seems to us that choices exercised	by realtors in moral situations center in at least three areas:	the various ways in which they interpret a particular social	issue; their pattern of involvement in the regular legal and political	processes; and most pervasively their interpretation of	who is a real pro of what it means to be a professional man in	a technical fragmented society.	8.684328249457884
8909. most of the realtors minimized	their own understanding of and role in the racial issue pleading	that they only reflect the attitudes and intentions of their society.	8.51468703526203
8910. there is some reality to this; the commission on race and housing	concluded that there is no reason to believe that real estate	men are either more or less racially prejudiced on the whole than any	other segment of the american population.	13.224316903086365
8911. but such a reaction obscures	the powerful efforts made in the past by both nareb and	its local boards for the maintenance of restrictive clauses and practices.	7.744944720741813
8912. also it does not recognize the elements of choice and judgment	continually employed.	11.917004180448332
8913. like business and university groups generally	these men had very limited knowledge of recent sociological and	psychological studies and findings that might illumine the decisions	they make.	5.761983419583011
8914. realtors both generally and in this group have invariably	equated residential integration with a decline in property values	a circumstance viewed with considerable apprehension.	8.202197808023666
8915. recent	studies by the commission on race and housing and others however	point to a vast complex of factors that often do not warrant this conclusion.	6.768951962214033
8916. there are increasing numbers of neighborhoods that are integrated	residentially without great loss of property values the white population	having taken the initiative in preparing the areas for an appreciation	of the negroes' desire for well-kept housing privacy etc.	8.704017937450677
8917. data on the decline of property values in an area after a new racial	group enters it has to be assessed in terms of the trends in property	values before the group comes in.	8.948437282969117
8918. often they are able to get in	only because the area is declining economically.	12.562826114846057
8919. significantly	no realtor and few of the faculty present were familiar with any of	the six volumes	that present the commission's findings.	5.9499744578887235
8920. no one anticipates any radical	shift in this situation but questions concerning reading habits	the availability of such data and the places where it is discussed must	surely be raised.	9.128746756091573
8921. the role of both church and university as sources	of information and settings within which the implications of such information	may be explored needs consideration.	8.040163594934995
8922. relevant facts	however	extend beyond considerations of property values and maintenance	of harmonious neighborhoods.	9.145081018155972
8923. discussion of minority housing necessarily	involves such basic issues as the intensity of one's democratic	conviction and religious belief concerning equality of opportunity	the function and limitations of government in the securing of such	equality and the spotlight that world opinion plays upon local incidents	of racial agitation and strife.	4.436730985977461
8924. realtors realize of course that they are involved in an	increasingly complex legal and political system that is opening up opportunities	for leverage on their relation to clients as well as opportunities	for evasion of their responsibility for racial discrimination	in housing.	8.955321708025025
8925. on the positive side recent federal action has largely	undermined the legal sanction so long enjoyed by the segregationist position;	anti-discriminatory statutes in housing have now been adopted	by thirteen states and while specific provisions have varied the	tendency is clearly toward expanding coverage.	5.778781086848755
8926. realtors in attendance	at the colloquium expressed interest for example in connecticut's	new housing law as setting standards of equity that they would	like to have to obey but in support of which none had been willing	to go on public record.	8.69247693735297
8927. as far as they were aware the connecticut	association of real estate boards had not officially opposed	the bill's passage or lobbied in its support.	7.406169154034309
8928. in 1957 the real estate boards of new york city	actively opposed the then pending private housing anti-discrimination	law.	11.455401067535897
8929. official reasoning: the bill was a wanton invasion	there are sins of omission as	well as commission; the attitude adopted by realtors and their associations	either negative or positive plays a large part in the public	acceptance of such measures and the degree to which they may be effectively	enforced.	6.198384275140745
8930. judicial opinion since the supreme court decision	on shelley v kraemer has rendered racial restrictive	covenants unenforcible.	8.05131272355703
8931. such a decision should have placed a powerful	weapon in the hands of the entire housing industry but there is little	evidence that realtors or at least their associations have repudiated	the principle in such clauses.	8.559439167921354
8932. in the states that have passed	laws preventing discrimination in the sale or rental of housing	support by real estate associations for compliance and broadened coverage	through additional legislation could help remove the label of social	reformism that most realtors individually seem determined to	avoid.	9.24944815238382
8933. but as yet no real estate board has been willing officially	to support such laws or to admit the permissibility of introducing minority	buyers into all-white neighborhoods.	6.270426419346002
8934. one of the roles of	the social scientist ethicist or theologian in our discussions with	the realtors became that of encouraging greater awareness of the opportunities	offered by the legal and political processes for the exercise	of broad social responsibilities in their work.	9.745508700987527
8935. but responsiveness to	these opportunities presumes that all of us judge the good as a human	good and not simply as a professional white american good.	8.145836722560762
8936. such	judgments are meaningful only	in so far as persons are members of a world	let us say a community that embraces scarsdale or yonkers but is	also infinitely richer since it is all-inclusive.	8.816617864256155
8937. that community	of all creation is then the ultimate object of our loyalty and	the concrete norm of all moral judgment.	6.728422008961423
8938. racial discrimination is wrong	then not because it goes against the grain of a faculty member trying	to converse with a few realtors but because it goes against the	grain of creation and against the will of the creator.	11.018181597156541
8939. thus moral issues	concerning the nature of the legal and political processes take	on theological dimensions.	10.554855420252917
8940. over the years	individuals engaged in the sale of real estate have developed remarkable	unity in the methods and practices employed.	13.552705520048999
8941. most realtors and	real estate brokers talk of themselves as professional people	with the cultural and moral values held by the traditional professions.	7.507872521200461
8942. but what significance attaches to professional beyond the narrow	sense of skillfulness in meeting a client's stated needs as already	noted?	7.904077705725467
8943.  our faculty and students pressed this issue more than	any other.	6.911332891840832
8944. as a theologian in the group pointed out a professional	was before the modern period of technical specialization one who	professed to be a bearer and critic of his culture in the use	of his particular skills.	11.142924839708702
8945. if we look about the world today we can see clearly that there	are two especially significant factors shaping the future of our civilization:	science and religion.	7.730015310668533
8946. science is placing in our	hands the ultimate power of the universe the power of the atom.	14.991119759490143
8947. religion	or the lack of it will decide whether we use this power to build	a brave new world of peace and abundance for all mankind or whether	we misuse this power to leave a world utterly destroyed.	7.744980776611012
8948. how can we	have the wisdom to meet such a new and difficult challenge?	12.556766887778743
8949.    we	may feel pessimistic at the outlook.	8.274582368518889
8950. and yet there is a note of	hope	because this same science that is giving us the power of the atom is	also giving us atomic vision.	14.007688883577265
8951. we are looking inside the atom and seeing	there a universe which is not material but something beyond the material	a universe that in a word is not matter but music.	8.298899250582608
8952. and it is	in this new vision of the atom that we find an affirmation and an invigoration	of our faith.	11.291140662846075
8953. to see this vision in perspective	we need first of all a clear idea of the magnitude of this new	power from the atom.	8.784029274197458
8954. you know that i could hold right here in my	hand the little chunk of uranium metal that was the heart of the bomb	that dropped on hiroshima.	12.473052588637481
8955. it was only about the size of a baseball;	but packed in that metallic ball there was the explosive force of	20000 tons of tnt.	8.9835602281936
8956. that is enough tnt to fill the tower	of the empire state building; and with the availability of bombs	of that size war became a new problem.	9.452749999164336
8957. now we might have restricted	the use of uranium bombs by controlling the sources of uranium	because it is found in only a few places in the world.	8.79628775783826
8958. but we had hardly	started to adjust our thinking to this new uranium weapon when we	were faced with the hydrogen bomb.	11.020390193080804
8959. hydrogen is just as plentiful as	uranium is scarce.	7.816322636343856
8960. we know that we have hydrogen in water; water is	f and the h stands for hydrogen; there is also hydrogen in wood	and hydrogen in our bodies.	8.674747457468715
8961. i have calculated that if i could snap	my fingers in one magic gesture to release the power of all the hydrogen	in my body i would explode with the force of a hundred bombs of	the kind that fell on hiroshima.	9.158208291470332
8962. i won't try the experiment but	i think you can see that if we all knew the secret and we could all let	ourselves go there would be quite an explosion.	10.293212371471911
8963. and then think how	little hydrogen we have in us compared with the hydrogen in delaware	bay or in the ocean beyond.	9.451944666988076
8964. salt water is still f the same hydrogen	is there.	10.63973281742861
8965. and the size of the ocean shows us the magnitude of the	destructive power we hold in our hands today.	9.81757606931465
8966. of course there	is also an optimistic side to the picture.	13.248297972260739
8967. for if i knew the secret	of letting this power in my body change directly into electricity	i could rent myself out to the electric companies and with just the power	in my body i could light all the lights and run all the factories	in the entire united states for some days.	7.378241192913506
8968. and think if we all knew	this secret and we could pool our power what a wonderful public utility	company we would make.	9.922261322781
8969. with just the hydrogen of our bodies we	could run the world for years.	9.15992887256205
8970. then think of delaware bay and the	ocean and you see that we have a supply of power for millions of years	to come.	11.992687149556755
8971. it is power with which we can literally rebuild the world	provide adequate housing food education abundant living for everyone	everywhere.	8.575338469734238
8972. now let us see where this power	comes from.	10.802614815174564
8973. to grasp our new view of the atom we have to appreciate	first of all how small the atom is.	8.62520279531899
8974. i have been trying to make this	clear to my own class in chemistry.	14.607706382135323
8975. one night there were some dried	peas lying on our kitchen table and these peas looked to me like a little	group of atoms; and i asked myself a question: suppose i	had the same number of peas as there are atoms in my body how large an	area would they cover?	6.325840888497786
8976.    i calculated first that there are	about an octillion atoms in the average human body; that is a figure	one with 27 ciphers quite a large number.	8.992586445502077
8977. then i calculated that a	million peas would just about fill a household refrigerator; a billion	peas would fill a small house from cellar to attic; a trillion peas	would fill all the houses in a town of about ten thousand people;	and a quadrillion peas would fill all the buildings in the city of philadelphia.	5.982897178568758
8978. i saw that i would soon run out of buildings at	this rate so i decided to take another measure- the whole state of	pennsylvania.	9.627537709434362
8979. imagine that there is a blizzard over pennsylvania	but instead of snowing snow it snows peas; so we get the whole state	covered with peas about four feet deep.	6.744763121708702
8980. you can imagine what it would	look like going out on the turnpike with the peas banked up against	the houses and covering the cars; pennsylvania thus blanketed would	contain about a quintillion peas.	8.587840515093793
8981. but we still have a long	way to go.	12.519864627587195
8982. next we imagine our blizzard raging over all the land areas	of the entire globe- north america south america europe asia	and africa all covered with peas four feet deep; then we have	sextillion peas.	6.801508868974564
8983. next we freeze over the oceans and cover the whole	earth with peas then we go out among the neighboring stars collect	250 planets each the size of the earth and also cover each of these	with peas four feet deep; and then we have septillion.	7.379475958948021
8984. finally we	go into the farthest reaches of the milky way; we get 250000 planets;	we cover each of these with our blanket of peas and then at last	we have octillion peas corresponding in number to the atoms in the body.	7.203009146770151
8985. so you see how small an atom is and how complicated you are.	10.037226085933773
8986. speck- and space	now although an atom is small we can still in	imagination have a look at it.	8.663700254911687
8987. let us focus on an atom of calcium from	the tip of the bone of my finger and let us suppose that i swallow	a magic alice in wonderland growing pill.	7.597663547080582
8988. i start growing rapidly	and this calcium atom grows along with me.	10.136541842658323
8989. i shoot up through the	roof into the sky past the clouds through the stratosphere out beyond	the moon out among the planets until i am over a hundred and	fifty million miles long.	6.645724537595254
8990. then this atom of calcium will swell to something	like a great balloon a hundred yards across a balloon big enough	to put a football field inside.	9.088532295391698
8991. and if you should step inside of such	a magnified atom according to the physics of forty years ago you	would see circulating over your head down at the sides and under your	feet some twenty luminous balls about the size of footballs.	8.077105957530378
8992. these	balls are moving in great circles and ellipses and are of course the	electrons the particles of negative electricity which by their action	create the forces that tie this atom of calcium to the neighboring	atoms of oxygen and make up the solid structure of my finger bone.	7.917986259499561
8993. since these electrons are moving like planets you may wonder whether	there is an atomic sun at the center of the atom.	10.026621643039654
8994. so you look down	there and you see a tiny whirling point about the size of the head	of a pin.	14.354431816675916
8995. this is the atomic sun the atomic nucleus.	13.745400407058032
8996. even if the	atom were big enough to hold a football field this nucleus is still	only about the size of a pinhead.	12.900245825613998
8997. it is this atomic nucleus that contains	the positive charge of electricity holding these negatively charged	electrons in their orbits; it also contains nearly all the mass	and the atomic energy.	6.717881285001127
8998. you may ask what else there is and the	answer is nothing- nothing but empty space.	10.498328240900648
8999. and since you are made	of atoms you are nothing much but empty space too.	8.880790881839744
9000. if i could put	your body in an imaginary atomic press and squeeze you down squeeze	these holes out of you in the way we squeeze the holes out of a sponge	you would get smaller and smaller until finally when the last hole	was gone you would be smaller than the smallest speck of dust that you	could see on this piece of paper.	10.208562266707903
9001. someone has remarked that this is	certainly the ultimate in reducing.	8.181159883358882
9002. at any rate it shows us how immaterial	we are.	14.232105024746968
9003. now this 1920 view of the	atom was on the whole a discouraging picture.	8.288917944044087
9004. for we believed that the	electrons	obeyed the law of mechanics and electrodynamics; and therefore	the atom was really just a little machine; and in mechanics the	whole is no more than the sum of the parts.	8.631470379130413
9005. so if you are made of	atoms you are just a big machine; and since the universe is also made	of atoms it is just a supermachine.	8.079716389746388
9006. and this would mean that we	live in a mechanistic universe governed by the laws of cause and effect	bound in chains of determinism that hold the universe on a completely	predetermined course in which there is not room for soul or spirit	or human freedom.	10.73387965368769
9007. and this is why so many scientists a half a century	ago were agnostics or atheists.	9.999215675323146
9008. then came the scientific revolution	in the late 1920's.	12.550862197387438
9009. a suggestion from louis de broglie a	physicist in france showed us that these electrons are not point particles	but waves.	6.339293666291469
9010. and to see the meaning of this new picture imagine	that you can put on more powerful glasses and go back inside the atom	and have a look at it in the way we view it today.	15.325922495014192
9011. now as you step	inside instead of seeing particles orbiting around like planets you	see waves and ripples very much like the ripples that you get on the surface	of a pond when you drop a stone into it.	6.735698518033924
9012. these ripples spread	out in symmetrical patterns like the rose windows of a great cathedral.	9.21003040484368
9013. and as the waves flow back and forth and merge with the waves from	the neighboring atoms you can put on a magic hearing aid and you hear	music.	8.57257877457087
9014. it is a music like the music from a great organ or a vast orchestra	playing a symphony.	13.315641630935536
9015. harmony melody counterpoint symphonic structure	are there; and as this music ebbs and flows there is an antiphonal	chorus from all the atoms outside in fact from the atoms of	the entire universe.	5.3557767254741
9016. and so today when we examine the structure of our	knowledge of the atom and of the universe we are forced to conclude	that the best word to describe our universe is music.	11.675408693298682
9017. the island of nantucket part of the state of massachusetts	lies about thirty-one miles southeast of its mother state.	8.376419299615904
9018. some of	the island is sand and is not suitable for living.	11.846341503612901
9019. the island folk	have their living almost entirely from summer visitors; the rest is	obtained from harbor scallops.	5.5329301347147934
9020. during about three and a half months	of the year in the summer there are three boats that run from the mainland	to the island carrying passengers food and cars; but the	rest of the year only one boat is needed which ties up at the mainland	nights and makes the trip down to nantucket in the daytime.	9.938986892515437
9021. this	is a fine trip too on a good day.	10.262807946454558
9022. with martha's vineyard on one	side and the open sea on the other it makes an excellent trip of about	three hours.	8.755704882912687
9023. to what extent and in what ways did christianity affect	the united states of america in the nineteenth century?	11.754698954709049
9024.  how far	and in what fashion did it modify the new nation which was emerging	in the midst of the forces shaping the revolutionary age?	10.549101682927335
9025.  to what	extent did it mould the morals and the social economic and political	life and institutions of the country?	7.857118799881864
9026.    a complete picture is	impossible- partly because of the limitations of space partly because	for millions of individuals who professed allegiance to the christian	faith data are unobtainable.	8.741741433131724
9027. even more of an obstacle is the difficulty	of separating the influence of christianity from other factors.	8.653314725335205
9028. although a complete picture cannot be given we can indicate	some aspects of life into which the christian faith entered as at	least one creative factor.	10.550129391915355
9029. at times we can say that it was the major	factor.	16.13006364214808
9030. what in some ways was the most important aspect was the	impact individually on the millions who constituted the nation.	11.826504135304674
9031. as	we have seen a growing proportion although in 1914 still a minority	were members of churches.	6.805696331996166
9032. presumably those who did not have a formal	church connexion had also felt the influence of christianity to a greater	or less extent.	10.326139725307142
9033. many of them had once been members of a church	or at least had been given instruction in christianity but for one or	another reason had allowed the connexion to lapse.	8.57736657877442
9034. the form of christianity	to which they were exposed was for some the protestantism of	the older stock for others the protestantism of the nineteenth-century	immigration; for still others mostly of the nineteenth-century	immigration it was roman catholicism and for a small minority it was	eastern orthodoxy.	9.033304193507334
9035. upon all of them played the intellectual social	political and economic attitudes institutions and customs of the	nation.	7.422637167283205
9036. upon most of these christianity had left an impress and through	them had had a share in making the individual what he was.	10.0158439955906
9037. yet	to determine precisely to what extent and exactly in what ways any individual	showed the effects of christianity would be impossible.	7.656536878185347
9038. at	best only an approximation could be arrived at.	9.001082994450293
9039. to generalize for the	entire nation would be absurd.	9.455720007798085
9040. for instance we cannot know whether	even for church members the degree of conformity to christian standards	of morality increased or declined as the proportion of church members	in the population rose.	9.318151160898834
9041. the temptation is to say that as the percentage	of church members mounted the degree of discipline exercised	by the churches lessened and the trend was towards conformity to the general	level.	7.823736417700156
9042. yet this cannot be proved.	14.800496504513374
9043. we know that in the early part	of the century many protestant congregations took positive action	against members who transgressed the ethical codes to which the majority	subscribed.	8.432604055865452
9044. thus baptist churches on the frontier took cognizance	of charges against their members of drunkenness fighting malicious	gossip lying cheating sexual irregularities gambling horse racing	and failure to pay just debts.	7.331268618263893
9045. if guilty the offender might be excluded	from membership.	8.958205807370456
9046. as church membership burgeoned such measures	faded into desuetude.	11.724091870976082
9047. but whether this was accompanied by a general	lowering of the moral life of the membership we do not know.	10.640183256256693
9048. what	we can attempt with some hope of dependable conclusions is to point	out the manner in which christianity entered into particular aspects	of the life of the nation.	9.530678782372743
9049. we have already hinted at the fashion in	which christianity contributed to education and so to intellectual life.	9.322033246729303
9050. we will now speak of the ways in which it helped shape the ideals	of the country and of the manner in which it stimulated efforts to attain	those ideals through reform movements through programmes for bringing	the collective life to the nation to conformity to christian standards	and through leaders in the government.	12.606064766928275
9051. throughout the	nineteenth century christianity exerted its influence on american	society as a whole primarily through the protestantism of the older stock.	8.470644313973963
9052. by the end of the century the roman catholic church was beginning	to make itself felt mainly through such institutions as hospitals	but also through its attitude towards organized labour.	11.493638909776852
9053. in the twentieth	century its influence grew as did that of the protestantism of	the nineteenth-century immigration.	8.885369006550205
9054. the ideals	of the country were deeply indebted to the protestantism of the	older stock.	13.292985728234349
9055. thus america the most widely sung of the patriotic	songs was written by a new england baptist clergyman samuel francis	smith while a student in andover theological	seminary.	6.469632756953519
9056. with its zeal for liberty and its dependence on god it	breathed the spirit which had been nourished on the evangelical revivals.	10.251278520846633
9057. the great seal of the united states was obviously inspired by	the christian faith.	12.35985042672508
9058. here was what was called the american dream namely	the effort to build a structure which would be something new in	history and to do so in such fashion that god could bless it.	12.132621541976672
9059. later	in the century the dream again found expression in the lines of katherine	lee bates daughter and granddaughter of new england	congregational ministers in her widely sung hymn written in	1893 america the beautiful with the words o beautiful	for pilgrim feet whose stern impassioned stress a thoroughfare for freedom	beat across the wilderness.	5.388495237126969
9060. america america god mend	thy every flaw confirm thy soul in self control thy liberty in law	h.	8.258579094939316
9061. o beautiful for patriot dream that sees beyond the years thine	alabaster cities gleam undimmed by human tears.	7.162739330347597
9062. america america	god shed his grace on thee and crown thy good with brotherhood from	sea to shining sea.	8.2015316056709
9063. the american dream was compounded of	many strains.	10.340917336717848
9064. some were clearly of christian origin among them the	great awakening and other revivals which helped to make christian	liberty christian equality and christian fraternity the passion of	the land.	7.601016388314115
9065. some have seen revivalism and the search for christian perfection	as the fountain-head of the american hope.	6.928290705989776
9066. here too must	be placed unitarianism and less obviously from christian inspiration	emerson transcendentalism and the idealism of walt whitman.	8.644983642492713
9067. we	must also remember those who reacted against the dream as a kind of	myth- among them melville hawthorne and henry james the elder	all of them out of a christian background.	6.575817667574045
9068. with	such a dream arising at least in part from the protestant heritage	of the united states and built into the foundations of the nation	it is not surprising that many efforts were made to give it concrete	expression.	10.337133396310273
9069. a number were in the nature of movements to relieve or	remove social ills.	11.807053207272112
9070. significantly the initiation and leadership	of a major proportion of the reform movements especially those in	the first half of the nineteenth century came from men and women of	new england birth or parentage and from either trinitarian or unitarian	congregationalism.	10.26974023087806
9071. several of the movements were given a marked	impetus by revivalism.	9.228025413328078
9072. quakers some from new england had a larger	share than their proportionate numerical strength would have warranted.	8.009960029638966
9073. we do well to remind ourselves that from men and women of new england	ancestry also issued the church of jesus christ of latter	day saints the seventh day adventists christian science the	american board of commissioners for foreign missions the american	home missionary society the american bible society and new	england theology.	7.585034228782525
9074. the atmosphere was one of optimism of confidence	in human progress and of a determination to rid the world of its ills.	12.227699681258535
9075. the hopkinsian universal disinterested benevolence although holding	to original sin and the doctrine of election inspired its adherents	to heroic endeavours for others looked for the early coming of the	millennium and was paralleled by the confidence in man's ability	cherished by the unitarians emerson and the transcendentalists.	5.043574925407774
9076. we should recall the number of movements for the service of mankind	which arose from the kindred evangelicalism of the british isles	and the pietism of the continent of europe- among them prison	reform anti-slavery measures legislation for the alleviation of conditions	of labour the inner mission and the red cross.	7.695312569552225
9077. we	cannot take the space to record all the efforts for the removal or alleviation	of collective ills.	7.654184333497386
9078. a few of the more prominent must serve	as examples of what a complete listing and description would disclose.	11.86897946439372
9079. several were born in the early decades and persisted throughout the	century.	8.744776694557274
9080. some disappeared with the attainment	of their purpose.	11.102627930595927
9081. still others sprang up late in the century to meet	conditions which arose from fresh stages of the revolutionary age.	7.36883414569755
9082. anti-slavery movement	the movement to end negro slavery began	before 1815 and mounted after that year until as a result of the civil	war emancipation was achieved.	8.785886975284987
9083. long before 1815 the christian	conscience was leading some to declare slavery wrong and to act	accordingly.	6.816835312461095
9084. for example in 1693 the philadelphia yearly meeting	of friends declared that its members should emancipate their slaves	and in 1776 it determined to exclude from membership all who did not	comply.	8.836455803946992
9085. in the latter year samuel hopkins from whom the hopkinsian	strain of new england theology took its name asked the continental	congress to abolish slavery.	7.959896016633556
9086. as we have seen methodism early took	a stand against slavery.	13.157110894857553
9087. beginning at least as far back as 1789 various	baptist bodies condemned slavery.	7.971838089974791
9088. after 1815 anti-slavery	sentiment mounted chiefly among protestants and those of protestant	background of the older stock.	9.459510030015343
9089. the nineteenth-century immigration	whether protestant or roman catholic was not so much concerned	for very few if any among them held slaves: they were mostly in the	northern states where slavery had disappeared or was on the way out	or were too poverty-stricken to own slaves.	5.77612793966322
9090. the anti-slavery movement	took many forms.	7.114084654104681
9091. benjamin lundy a quaker was	a pioneer in preparing the way for anti-slavery societies.	6.557880096485472
9092. it was	he who turned the attention of william lloyd garrison	to the subject.	13.084633349213865
9093. garrison massachusetts born of nova scotian parentage	was by temperament and conviction a reformer.	5.807207516032287
9094. chiefly remembered	because of his incessant advocacy of immediate and unconditional	abolition he also espoused a great variety of other causes- among	them women's rights prohibition and justice to the indians.	6.022131677076559
9095. incurably	optimistic dogmatic and utterly fearless in his youth a devout	baptist in spite of his friendship for the quaker poet john	greenleaf whittier he eventually attacked the orthodox	churches for what he deemed their cowardly compromising on the slavery	issue and in his invariably ardent manner was emphatically unorthodox	and denied the plenary inspiration of the bible.	5.10393212025262
9096. a marked	impulse came to the anti-slavery movement through the finney revivals.	7.833049565288333
9097. finney himself while opposed to slavery placed his chief emphasis	on evangelism but from his converts issued much of the leadership of	the anti-slavery campaign.	5.915540544254146
9098. theodore dwight weld was	especially active.	9.363589305390176
9099. weld was the son and grandson of new england congregational	ministers.	8.786305185016182
9100. as a youth he became one of finney's band	of evangelists and gave himself to winning young men.	9.871129965176433
9101. a strong temperance	advocate through the influence of a favorite teacher charles	stewart another finney convert he devoted himself to the anti-slavery	cause.	7.2349329350380644
9102. a group of young men influenced by him enrolled in lane theological	seminary and had to leave because of their open anti-slavery	position.	12.977651980486119
9103. the majority then went to the infant oberlin.	10.644025054872957
9104. they and	others employed some of finney's techniques as they sought to win	adherents to the cause.	8.068889522445575
9105. weld contributed to the anti-slavery convictions	of such men as joshua r giddings and edwin m stanton	enlisted john quincy adams and helped provide ideas which underlay	harriet beecher stowe's uncle tom's cabin.	4.099974493107466
9106. he shunned	publicity for himself and sought to avoid fame.	13.586016417272603
9107. wendell phillips	from a prominent massachusetts family in his teens	was converted under the preaching of lyman beecher.	5.734892134194237
9108. although he	later broke with the churches because he believed that they were insufficiently	outspoken against social evils he remained a devout christian.	9.36745946337479
9109. he was remembered chiefly for his fearless advocacy of abolition	but he also stood for equal rights for women for opportunity for the	freedmen and for prohibition.	7.079640126200515
9110. the anti-slavery movement and	other contemporary reforms and philanthropies were given leadership	and financial undergirding by arthur tappan and his younger	brother lewis tappan.	5.76048083338347
9111. individuals possessing unusual gifts and great personal power	were transmuted at death into awesome spirits; they were almost immediately	worshipped for these newer even more terrible abilities.	4.65518677563441
9112. their	direct descendants inherited not only their worldly fortunes but also	the mandate of their newfound power as spirits in the other half of	the universe.	9.064064751715128
9113. royal lineages could be based on extraordinary worldly	achievements translated into eternal otherworldly power.	6.035134837415636
9114. thus	the emperor could draw on sources not available to those with less	puissant ancestors.	8.53678484799813
9115. but this eminence was not without its weighty	responsibilities.	11.164063944538361
9116. since he possessed more power in an interdependent universe	of living beings and dead spirits the emperor had to use it for	the benefit of the living.	11.12565846981593
9117. the royal ritual generated power into the	other world: it also provided the living with a way to control the	spirits and bring their powers directly to bear on the everyday affairs	of the world.	6.480867368553068
9118. proper ritual observance at any level of society was	capable of generating power for use in the spirit world; but naturally	the royal ritual which provided unusual control over already supremely	powerful divine spirits was held responsible for regulating the	universe and insuring the welfare of the kingdom.	8.08142944719992
9119. this is the	familiar system of cosmic government.	12.51315986615121
9120. the chinese emperor by	proper observance of ritual manifested divine powers.	9.926232411532684
9121. he regulated	the dualities of light and darkness yang and yin which are	locked in eternal struggle.	7.398666725082809
9122. by swaying the balance between them he	effected the alternation of the seasons.	10.760704358587637
9123. his power was so great that	he even promoted and demoted gods according to whether they had given	ear or been deaf to petitions.	6.384464512067959
9124. in this system no man is exempt	from obligations.	15.588268189140475
9125. failure in daily moral and ethical duties to one's	family outrages to community propriety any departure from rigid	standards of moral excellence were offenses against the dead.	5.164294485575273
9126. and to	offend the dead meant to incur their wrath and thus provoke the unleashing	of countrywide disasters.	8.878364919624401
9127. the family home was in fact a temple;	and the daily duties of individuals were basically religious in	nature.	7.427498340731885
9128. the dead spirits occupied a prominent place in every hope and	in every fear.	12.130766914128056
9129. the common belief was that there existed one	moral order which included everything.	8.345152351497386
9130. the dead controlled the material	prosperity of the living and the living adhered to strict codes of	conduct in order not to weaken that control.	10.08532996817878
9131. men believed they could	control nature by obeying a moral code.	6.84213560683905
9132. if the moral code were flouted	the proper balance of the universe would be upset and the disastrous	result could be floods plague or famine.	10.131240278974863
9133. modern westerners	have difficulty comprehending this fusion of moral and material	largely because in the west the historical trend has been to deny the	connection.	6.515046784903595
9134. living in urban conditions away from the deadweight of	village constraint and the constrictions of a thatched-roof world view	the individual may find it possible say to commit adultery not only	without personal misgivings but also without suffering any adverse	effects in his worldly fortunes.	7.011205524896947
9135. basing action on the empirical determination	of cause and effect provides a toughness and bravado that no	powerful otherworldly ancestor could ever impart- plus the added liberation	from the constraint of silent burial urns.	5.236167309771599
9136. in china	the magical system par excellence was taoism.	11.546387313909312
9137. the taoists were quietist	mystics who saw an unchanging unity- the tao- underlying	all phenomena.	4.64872747195005
9138. it was this timeless unity that was all-important and	not its temporary manifestations in the world of reality.	12.03028106236694
9139. the taoists	believed the unity could be influenced by proper magical manipulation;	in other words they were actually an organization of magicians.	6.024414782044076
9140. mahayana buddhism was no exception to these prevailing magical	concepts.	11.345375265854715
9141. after this form of indian buddhism had been introduced	into china it underwent extensive changes.	7.856342389141722
9142. during its flowering in	the sixth to the eighth centuries mahayana offered a supernatural package	to the chinese which bears no resemblance to the highly digested	philosophical zen morsels offered to the modern western reader.	8.879455987778583
9143. mahayana	had gods and magic a pantheon heavens and hells and gorgeously	appareled priests monks and nuns all of whom wielded power over	souls in the other world.	5.750149962459381
9144. the self-realized mahayana saint possessed	superhuman powers and magic.	8.227504108746977
9145. the mahayana that developed in the	north was a religion of idolatry and coarse magic that made the world	into a huge magical garden.	6.2108021594295
9146. in its monastic form mahayana was merely	an organization of magic-practicing monks who catered	to the chinese faith in the supernatural.	8.41896074276675
9147. nonmagical confucianism	was a secular rational philosophy but even with this different	orientation it could not escape from the ethos of a cosmic government.	6.417294856298913
9148. confucianism had its own magic in the idea that virtue had power.	10.607860289905773
9149. if a man lived a classical life he need not fear the spirits- for	only lack of virtue gave the spirits power over him.	7.345359232194953
9150. but let us not be	mistaken about confucian virtue; this was not virtue as we	understand the word today and it did not mean an abandonment of the belief	in magic manipulation.	9.862840024096322
9151. to the confucian virtue simply meant	mastery and correct observance of three hundred major rules of ritual	and three thousand minor ones.	6.940563771523749
9152. propriety was synonymous with ritual	observance the mark of a true gentleman.	8.935075235374413
9153. to live correctly in an	interdependent moral and material universe of living and dead was decisive	for man's fate.	6.450984405179288
9154. this in brief was the historical background	out of which zen emerged.	11.563937469340683
9155. promoters of zen to the west record	its ancestry and recognize that zen grew out of a combination of	taoism and indian mahayana buddhism.	7.373770972760217
9156. but the marvelous person	that is supposed to result from zen exhibits more chinese practicality	than indian speculation- he possesses magical powers and can	use them to order nature and to redeem souls.	8.143849607311598
9157. proponents of zen to	the west emphasize disproportionately the amount of mahayana buddhism	in zen probably in order to dignify the indisputably magical taoist	ideas with more respectable buddhist metaphysic.	5.753584422198943
9158. but in the chinese	mind there was little difference between the two- the bonzes	were no more metaphysical than a magician has to be.	9.535214643543712
9159. actually	zen owes more to chinese quietism than it does to mahayana buddhism.	7.5364971053181495
9160. the ch'an sect may have derived its metaphysic from	mahayana but its psychology was pure early taoist.	7.05755373251119
9161. this is well	evidenced	by the quietist doctrines carried over in zen: the idea of	the inward turning of thought the enjoinder to put aside desires and	perturbations so that a return to purity peace and stillness- a	union with the infinite with the tao- could be effected.	5.061374615677127
9162. in fact	the antipathy to outward ceremonies hailed by modern exponents as so	uniquely characteristic of the direct thinking zennist was a feature	of taoism.	8.646801086495138
9163. so too was the insistence on the relativity of the	external world and the ideas that language and things perceived by	consciousness were poor substitutes indeed for immediate perception by	pure indwelling spirit: the opposition of pure consciousness to ratiocinating	consciousness.	5.6187504889104565
9164. zen maintains that cognitive things	are only the surface of experience.	10.242090405005401
9165. one of its features attractive	to the west is its irreverence for tradition and dogma and for sacred	texts.	9.086763124624916
9166. one patriarch is supposed to have relegated sacred scriptures	for use in an outhouse.	12.573233229814829
9167. but this is not the spirit of self-reliant freedom	of action for which the westerner mistakes it.	10.606262560318447
9168. it is simply that	in taoist tradition- as in all good mysticisms- books words	or any other manifestations that belong to the normal state of consciousness	are considered only the surface of experience.	9.208423395808703
9169. the truth- the	eternal truth- is not transmittable by words.	4.752267283625065
9170. reality is considered	not only irrelevant to the acquisition of higher knowledge but	a positive handicap.	9.365253173231224
9171. the technique of reality confusion- the use of	paradox and riddles to shake the mind's grip on reality- originated	with fourth and third century bc chinese quietism: the	koan is not basically a new device.	4.310600556696363
9172. it is important for an	understanding of zen to realize that the esoteric preoccupations of	the select few cannot be the doctrine of the common man.	14.008278492860553
9173. in the supernatural	atmosphere of cosmic government only the ruling elite was ever	concerned with a kingdom-wide ordering of nature: popular religion	aimed at more personal benefits from magical powers.	5.630256389543487
9174. and this is only	natural- witness the haste with which modern man gobbles the latest	wonder drug.	9.448082249218624
9175. early chinese anchoritism was theoretically aimed	at a mystic pantheist union with the divine personal salvation being	achieved when the mystical recluse united with divine essence.	6.150650971640338
9176. but	this esoteric doctrine was lost in the shuffle to acquire special powers.	10.28939887735327
9177. the anchorite strove in fact to magically influence the world	of spirits in the same way that the divine emperor manifested his power.	8.526895976397276
9178. thus the mahayana metaphysic of mystical union for salvation was	distilled down to a bare self-seeking and for this reason the mystic	in asia did not long remain in isolated contemplation.	8.176224257860888
9179. as the zen	literature reveals as soon as an early zen master attained fame in	seclusion he was called out into the world to exercise his powers.	8.990744183412044
9180. the early anchorite masters attracted disciples because of their presumed	ability to perform miracles.	10.269142465228601
9181. exponents of zen often insist	that very early zen doctrine opposed the rampant supernaturalism	of china and proposed instead a more mature less credulous view of	the universe.	5.264044338700743
9182. in support of this stories from the early literature are	cited to show that zen attacks the idea of supernatural power.	12.73362590562246
9183. but	actually these accounts reveal the supernatural powers that the masters	were in fact supposed to possess as well as the extreme degree of	popular credulity: hwang pah one day going up mount	tien tai h which was believed to have been inhabited by arhats	with supernatural powers met with a monk whose eyes emitted strange light.	5.82402473657954
9184. they went along the pass talking with each other for a short while	until they came to a river roaring with torrent.	11.506151962596805
9185. there being no bridge	the master had to stop at the shore; but his companion crossed	the river walking on the water and beckoned to hwang pah to follow	him.	6.839791448508005
9186. thereupon hwang pah said: if i knew thou art an arhat	i would have doubled you up before thou got over there! the monk	then understood the spiritual attainment of hwang pah and praised	him as a true mahayanist.	6.111874917737688
9187. a second tale shows still	more clearly the kind of powers a truly spiritual monk could possess:	on one occasion yang shan saw a stranger monk flying	through the air.	5.582247820392485
9188. when that monk came down and approached him with a	respectful salutation he asked: where art thou from?	8.27874362917479
9189.  early	this morning replied the other i set out from india.	7.448745605328924
9190. why said the teacher art thou so late?	11.709870588347291
9191.  i stopped	responded the man several times to look at beautiful sceneries.	9.952358243755873
9192. thou mayst have supernatural powers exclaimed yang shan	yet thou must give back the spirit of buddha to me.	8.396929125832784
9193. then	the monk praised yang shan saying: i have come over to china	in order to worship manjucri and met unexpectedly with minor shakya	and after giving the master some palm leaves he brought from india	went back through the air.	4.979568574160275
