9194. in the popular chinese	mind ch'an was no exception to the ideas of coarse magic that	dominated.	11.204220783862368
9195. a closer look at modern zen reveals many magical	carryovers that are still part of popular zen attitudes.	7.337813402333589
9196. to the	zen monk the universe is still populated with spiritual beings	who have to be appeased.	10.637112138819061
9197. part of the mealtime ritual in the zendo consists	in offerings of rice to the spiritual beings.	10.301660332346263
9198. modern zen presentation	to the west insists on the anti-authoritarian highly pragmatic	nature of the zen belief- scriptures are burned to make fire	action is based on direct self-confidence and so on.	6.090454782202668
9199. this picture	of extreme self-reliant individuation is difficult to reconcile with such	zendo formulas as: o you demons and other spiritual beings	i now offer this to you and may this food fill up the ten quarters	of the world and all the demons and other spiritual beings be fed therewith.	6.262811825208333
9200. pope leo 13 on the 13th day of december 1898 granted	the following indulgences: an indulgence of three hundred days is	granted to all the faithful who read the holy gospels at least a	quarter of an hour.	7.688030514510616
9201. a plenary indulgence under the usual conditions	is granted once a month for the daily reading.	8.1051440026588
9202. pope pius the sixth	at rome in april 1778 wrote the following: the faithful	should be excited to the reading of the holy scriptures: for these	are the most abundant sources which ought to be left open to everyone	to draw from them purity of morals and of doctrine to eradicate	errors which are so widely disseminated in these corrupt times.	6.8020138767419756
9203. the	american bishops assembled at the third plenary council of baltimore	urged the catholic people to read the holy bible.	6.5737200166281475
9204. we hope	they said that no family can be found amongst us without a	correct version of the holy scriptures.	11.928239397891096
9205. they recommended also	that at a fixed hour let the entire family be assembled for night	prayers followed by a short reading of the holy scriptures.	7.166789155890907
9206. since the catholic church expresses such desire that the sacred	scriptures be read the following taken from the holy bible	will prove a means of grace and a source of great	spiritual blessing.	9.832006694176156
9207. do not wonder that	i said to thee you must be born again.	14.446202183650264

9212. all have gone	astray together; h all have sinned and have need of the glory of	the new birth is necessary because the	therefore as through	one man sin entered into the world and through sin death and thus death	has passed unto all men because all have sinned.	9.132187643056536

9680. the lyric beauties of schubert's trout quintet-	its elemental rhythms and infectious melodies- make it a source	of pure pleasure for almost all music listeners.	6.16436322061603

9723. must records always sound like records?	8.474032507650639
9724.    from the beginning	of commercial recording new discs purported to be indistinguishable	from the real thing have regularly been put in circulation.	9.435473961458575
9725. seen	in perspective many of these releases have a genuine claim to be milestones.	7.194584275473867
9726. although lacking absolute verisimilitude they supply the	ear and the imagination with all necessary materials for re-creation	of the original.	8.181027351485236
9727. on the basis of what they give us we can know how the	young caruso sang appreciate the distinctive qualities of parsifal	under karl muck's baton or sense the type of ensemble toscanini	created in his years with the new york philharmonic.	7.2062239893607805
9728. since	the concept of high fidelity became important some dozen years ago	the claims of technical improvements have multiplied tenfold.	8.515311045954887
9729. in many	cases the revolutionary production has offered no more than sensational	effects: the first hearing was fascinating and the second disillusioning	as the gap between sound and substance became clearer.	6.422517598615624
9730. other	innovations with better claims to musical interest survived rehearing	to acquire in time the status of classics.	8.77650806898038

9732. records sound like records because they provide	a different sort of experience than live music.	11.567737787171794
9733. this difference is	made up of many factors.	10.050192692400612
9734. some of them are obvious such as the fact	that we associate recorded and live music with our reponses and behavior	in different types of environments and social settings.	10.593140941851427
9735. sounds best to me when i can dress informally and sit in something	from the technical standpoint	records differ from live music to the degree that they fail to convey	the true color texture complexity range intensity pulse and pitch	of the original.	5.708307956401126
9736. any alteration of one of these factors is distortion	although we generally use that word only for effects so pronounced	that they can be stated quantitatively on the basis of standard tests.	10.232691756767348
9737. yet it is the accumulation of distortion the fitting together of	fractional bits until the total reaches the threshold of our awareness	that makes records sound like records.	8.26245768369914
9738. the sound may be good;	but if you know the real thing you know that what you are hearing	is only a clever imitation.	10.549630789023002
9739. command's new brahms second is	a major effort to make a record that sounds like a real orchestra rather	than a copy of one.	5.617407047449131
9740. like the recent scheherazade from london	it is successful because emphasis	has been placed on good musical and engineering practices rather than	on creating sensational effects.	8.303763657915603
9741. because of this only those with	truly fine equipment will be able to appreciate the exact degree of the	engineers' triumph.	9.645301496157
9742. the easiest way to describe this release	is to say that it reproduces an interesting and effective steinberg	performance with minimal alteration of its musical values.	10.158573974631175
9743. the engineering	as such never obtrudes upon your consciousness.	7.538474561709924
9744. the effect of	the recording is very open and natural with the frequency emphasis	exactly what you would expect from a live performance.	9.832026091895965
9745. this absence of	peaky highs and beefed-up bass not only produces greater fidelity but	it eliminates listener fatigue.	5.25957520540939
9746. a contributing factor is the perspective	the uniform aesthetic distance which is maintained.	10.090796474030672
9747. the orchestra	is far enough away from you that you miss the bow scrapes valve	clicks and other noises incidental to playing.	6.570072223789582
9748. yet you feel the orchestra	is near at hand and the individual instruments have the same firm	presence associated with listening from a good seat in an acoustically	perfect hall.	10.60866379240978
9749. command has achieved the ideal amount of reverberation.	9.578883012065875
9750. the music is always allowed the living space needed to attain its	full sonority; yet the hall never intrudes as a quasi-performer.	8.289997820286626
9751. the	timbre remains that of the instruments unclouded by resonance.	8.525205951531897
9752. all of this would be wasted of course if the performance lacked	authority and musical distinction.	14.06772903408318
9753. for me it has more of both elements	than the majority of its competitors.	11.046715036979943
9754. steinberg seems to have gone	directly back to the score discounting tradition and has built his	performance on the intention to reproduce as faithfully as possible exactly	what brahms set down on paper.	9.38432161155639
9755. those accustomed to broader	more romantic statements of the symphony can be expected to react	strongly when they hear this one.	8.047470748154383
9756. without losing the distinctive undertow	of brahmsian rhythm the pacing is firm and the over-all performance	has a tightly knit quality that makes for maximum cumulative effect.	7.080150826600271

9760. the	engineering provides exactly the support needed for such a result.	10.392550455915513
9761. too	many records seem to reduce a work of symphonic complexity to a melody	and its accompaniment.	6.9320275461760685

9902. when the automobile was in its embryonic	stage such roads as existed were pretty much open roads with the tacit	understanding that horses should not be unduly terrified being about	the only rule governing where when and how fast a car could go.	7.913301946392831

9931. as america on wheels was responsible	for an industry of motor courts motels and drive-in establishments	where you can dine see a movie shop or make a bank deposit	the ever-increasing number of boating enthusiasts have sparked industries	designed especially to accommodate them.	4.686659200183336
9932. instead of motels for	the boatman there are marinas.	14.428167492614126

9940. a recent survey disclosed there	are about 4000 commercially and municipally operated marinas and	boatyards in the united states the majority of which are equipped	to handle outboard boats.	10.390782032799954
9941. the design of a mechanical interlocking frame is much like a mechanical	puzzle but once understood the principles can be applied to	any track and signal arrangement.	7.728379271320698
9942. in the frame are two sets of bars	which interact with each other to prevent the operator from making dangerous	moves.	14.309166159690621
9943. the main set of bars are the tappets and one tappet	is connected to each lever.	8.022093873060083
9944. if the lever is pulled to clear a signal	or move a switch the tappet moves a short distance lengthwise at	the same time.	10.29367956434749
9945. close behind the plane of the tappets are the locking	bars.	10.918336969010891
9946. these can also move a short distance but at right angles	to the tappets.	10.75297308364297
9947. the number of locking bars required depends on how many	false moves must be prevented.	9.55752178243047
9948. in the sides of the tappets	are notches with sloping sides and connection between the tappets and	locking bars consist of cams called dogs.	10.449084170588009
9949. two or more dogs are	mounted on each locking bar.	8.723289982282555
9950. these slide into and out of the notches	in the tappets as the tappets are moved locking and unlocking them.	11.079978277137874
9951. here's how the scheme works: suppose the operator pulls	the lever to clear a particular signal.	4.148351416625082
9952. this also pulls the tappet connected	to the particular lever and forces any dogs seated in the notches	to the side thus moving one or more locking bars.	8.447197289232392
9953. the dogs on the	other ends of these locking bars are thus forced into notches in other	tappets.	8.37597188830024
9954. by this scheme pulling one signal to clear locks all the	other switch and signal levers in safe positions until the first signal	is again restored to normal.	8.416169315120257
9955. interlocking signals are normally	at stop or red position and a lever must be pulled to clear	the signal.	6.232758089210192
9956. this is not necessarily to green however for in	some situations only a yellow indication is given to a train to let it	into the plant.	11.983469410955042
9957. there are other basic rules.	18.910548845700152
9958. a turnout	may have two levers one to actually move the switch points the other	to lock the points.	8.80758588773232
9959. a signal cannot be cleared until all the related	turnouts are properly thrown and locked.	7.903336577273323
9960. such locks are nearly	always used where the switch points face oncoming traffic.	9.91757377709928
9961. the	lock insures that the points are thrown all the way with no chance that	a wheel flange will snag on a partly thrown point.	6.438457291400927
9962. if the points aren't	thrown all the way the turnout cannot be locked and in turn	the signal cannot be cleared.	10.605292529735307
9963. generally these locks on turnouts are	called facing point locks.	6.768356798132767
9964. figs 1-6 show typical arrangements	of track and signals.	7.1036836051263155
9965. each diagram is accompanied by a dog	chart a list of the levers that show which other levers any particular	lever will lock if pulled.	6.964833912978675
9966. the lines connecting the wedge-shaped	dogs represent the locking bars at right angles to the tappet bars.	9.175303784221912
9967. by studying the track-signal diagrams you'll note several	other details.	4.3417015116471145
9968. derails- mechanical track devices that actually guide	the wheels off the rails if a train passes a stop signal- are	used in many instances.	5.85577070230384
9969. home signals have two blades.	10.28958726932349
9970. the blacked-in	blades indicate a fixed aspect- the blade does not move.	6.589413320164942
9971. as	an engineer approaches the plant the position of the home signal	is seen in advance when he passes the distant signal located	beyond the limits of the interlocking plant.	7.639652996805564
9972. in some low-speed situations	the distant signal is fixed at caution.	10.051440973392918
9973. in other instances where	there is no automatic block signaling the distant has only green	and yellow aspects.	7.523292565024276
9974. so much for the prototype.	15.528161428988247
9975. the interlocking	frame we built at the model railroader workshop and then	installed on paul larson's railroad follows the fig 1 scheme	and is shown beginning in fig 7 page 65 and in the photos.	6.165665933243645
9976. here's	how it can be built.	8.92944618607499
9977. the sizes of pieces needed	for the interlocking frame are shown in the notes within fig 7 most	of the bars being 18'' brass in 14'' and 12'' widths.	4.881204240223201
9978. you may change the dimensions to suit a frame for more or fewer levers	and locks as you wish.	10.67227939388929
9979. our instructions assume you are building	this particular frame which is for a junction.	7.179888070798207
9980. when cutting	the pieces dress the ends smooth and square with a smooth file or sanding	disk.	10.207897691550233
9981. start with the right-hand piece b f soldering	it to the lower piece a of the same material but 12''	long.	7.312012152761405
9982. let exactly 1'' of a extend beyond b and	use a square to check your angle to exactly 90 degrees.	7.652235357863072
9983. now	lay 12 pieces of f cut 5-34'' long side by side but separated	by 12 pieces of the same material 12'' sq.	6.575506707956603
9984. this gives you the	spacing for locating the left-hand piece b.	12.287922325274259
9985. compress the assembly	when you make the mark to show the location for b.	7.477601345597643
9986. solder	this second b to a at right angles.	9.82652027362338
9987. there	should be 10'' between the two parallel members and each should be	1'' from an end of the long piece.	5.577138538737023
9988. cap this assembly	with a f bar.	10.555638181539077
9989. tack-solder all the 12''	sq pieces to the 10'' and 12'' members.	2.9371090583272172
9990. these will be drilled	and tapped later on.	12.50166008836441
9991. now cut five f locking bar spacers	.	10.036515537166414
9992. position these using six intermediate temporary	f spacers and locate the upper 12'' bar a.	6.714313432104116
9993. solder	it and the five locking bar spacers to the frame.	7.54475830540641
9994. now place 12 pieces	12'' sq on this edge as we did before and space them with	the 5-34'' long tappets as they are called.	7.289619572646048
9995. cap with a f	bar and tack-solder in place.	5.864436273812438
9996. cap the locking bar spacers with two	f directly under the first two b pieces.	10.414357609621995
9997. remove all the	loose spacing bars.	10.254412559661871
9998. mark and center-punch all the holes required	for screws to hold this assembly together.	7.5147253838304575
9999. placement	of these holes is not critical but they should be located so that	the centers are about 18'' from any edge.	5.3974580308841436
10000. drill all no 50 and	counter-drill all except the a pieces size 43.	9.000561803736195
10001. tap the a	pieces 2-56.	9.700058290985755
10002. now unsolder and disassemble the frame	except for the two 12'' and the first two 3-34'' bars	which are soldered together.	6.466546030927323
10003. either lay	the components aside in proper order or code them with numbers and letters	so they may be replaced in their proper positions.	6.884894887339783
10004. dress all surfaces	with a file cleaning off all solder and drilling burrs.	8.367356312277304
10005. drill 20 no 47 holes in the upper piece a as shown in	fig 7.	8.042748463331648
10006. tap these 3-48 for mounting the electrical contact later	on.	7.565065182236538
10007. note 6 and 8 lock levers don't require holes for contacts.	5.345829806000728
10008. now reassemble the frame using f roundhead steel screws and nuts.	9.423880339479451
10009. put the 12 tappets and some f locking bar spacers in the frame to	help align all the components before you tighten the screws.	7.7190401133924
10010. be sure	the tappets are not pinched by a twisted 12'' sq spacer.	8.508451843925952
10011. as	an anchor for the spring lock insert a f bar in the lower left corner	of the frame as shown in fig 7.	8.089455317520441
10012. drill a no 43 hole through	the pieces and secure with a 2-56 nut and screw.	9.284041645227447
10013. drill two no 50	holes one in the insert and one in the locking bar spacer directly	above it and tap 2-56.	8.143539893054054
10014. number all the tappet bars before removing them	so they can be replaced in the same slots.	11.965438185272918

10034. these	will serve as lifting pads for the electrical contacts.	9.611514760952513
10035. fitting	the locking bars and making the locking pieces is a rather tedious job	since stop screws tappets and locking bars must be removed and replaced	many times.	6.972425919012492
10036. as the work progresses the frame and moving parts become	a sort of chinese puzzle where several pieces must be removed before	the part you are working on is accessible.	9.565900627189937
10037. a little extra work	here will pay off with a smooth snug-fitting machine when you are finished.	6.921868846497069
10038. each completed locking bar should remain in place as the work	progresses to insure snug fitting.	9.45165822704882
10039. the order of fitting is not	too important.	13.252897374963602
10040. however we started with the first row of bars and worked	our way back.	11.113781201287695
10041. since the same method of shaping and fitting the dogs	and notches is used throughout we will only describe the construction	of one locking bar.	6.66967553547276
10042. figs 7 and 8 give all pertinent dimensions.	11.194705058099851
10043. all the bars are cut from f brass.	11.655165982269644

10069. scientists say that the world and everything in it are based on	mathematics.	10.987962896191352
10070. without math the men who are continually seeking the causes	of and the reasons for the many things that make the world go 'round	would not have any means of analyzing standardizing and communicating	the things they discover and learn.	9.19963369729894
10071. math and the formulas that	allow it to be applied to different problems are therefore essential	to any scientific endeavor.	7.146581495955655
10072. hot rodding is a science.	11.014405610253803
10073. it's	not a science as involved as determining what makes the earth rotate	on its axis or building a rocket or putting a satellite into orbit	but it is nevertheless a science.	5.1973263882634
10074. but because science is based on mathematics	doesn't mean that a hot rodder must necessarily be a mathematician.	10.586747946448357
10075. a guy can be an active and successful hot rodder for years	without becoming even remotely involved with mathematical problems;	however he will have a clearer understanding of what he is doing and	the chances are he will be more successful if he understands the few	formulas that apply to rodding.	6.244341344705362
10076. a mathematical formula is nothing	more than a pattern for solving a specific problem.	10.17522672344938
10077. it places the	various factors involved in the problem in their correct order in relation	to each other so that the influence of factors on each other can	be computed.	11.244087303977205
10078. the first step in using a formula is to insert the	numerical values of the factors involved in their correct positions	in the formula.	12.740269701152865
10079. this changes the formula to an equation.	10.424429816122545
10080. the	equation is used for the mathematical process of solving the problem.	11.070425670194599
10081. equations for rodding formulas are not complicated.	7.5146672982426646
10082. they involve	only simple mathematics that are taught in grammar school arithmetic	classes.	10.248498360529734
10083. however it is essential that the various mathematical symbols	used in the equations be understood so that the mathematical processes	can be done properly and in their correct order.	8.519005845260496
10084. they indicate	simple division multiplication subtraction and addition.	12.777733962025929
10085. the	symbol for division is a straight line that separates two numbers	placed one above the other.	6.900354553581217
10086. the lower number is always divided into the	upper number: f   the symbol for multiplication is .	8.569916582328023
10087. it is used to separate two or more numbers in a row.	20.146540071166033
10088. for example:	f numbers to be multiplied together may be multiplied in any	order.	8.833937597581695
10089. the result will be the same regardless of the order used.	17.554817362845018
10090. the symbol for subtraction is the standard minus sign.	14.057099447711387
10091. this is	nothing more than a dash.	11.007080783412263
10092. it separates two or more numbers.	20.557088453207776
10093. the number	on the right of the symbol is always subtracted from the number on	the left of the symbol.	10.439278394102647
10094. for example: f when more than two figures	are separated by subtraction symbols the subtraction must be carried	out from the left to right if the result is to be correct.	8.572742905423109
10095. for example	for the problem f 10 from 25 equals 15 then 6 from 15 equals	9.	6.973541730404112
10096. addition is indicated by the + symbol.	8.64845214219982
10097. the symbol is	used to separate two or more numbers.	11.274711028535757
10098. for example: f numbers separated	by addition symbols may be placed in any order.	7.619751719118117
10099. when solving	an equation that involves division as well as other steps do all	the division steps first	to reduce those parts of the equation to their	numerical value.	7.411808001312838
10100. multiplication subtraction and addition can then	be accomplished as they appear in the equation by starting at the left	end of the equation and working toward the right.	10.5175263928362
10101. completing the	division first also includes those division parts that require multiplication	subtraction or addition steps: f this would be reduced	by multiplying 8 times 6 and then dividing the product by 12.	5.21716416736054
10102. this part	of the equation would then become 4.	13.36843287346194
10103. for use in formulas fractions	should be converted to their decimal equivalents.	9.841519914811034
10104. the easiest	way to do this is with a conversion chart.	12.83704879677891
10105. charts for this purpose	are available from many sources.	7.2949904747434315
10106. they are included in all types of mathematical	handbooks and they are stamped on some types of precision	measuring instruments.	11.236989500733024
10107. the various mathematical processes can	be simplified by carrying the results to only two or three decimal places.	7.543737048293195
10108. shortening the results in this manner will not have any detrimental	effect on the accuracy of the final result.	11.47455746077156
10109. a constant is a number that remains the same	regardless of the other numbers used in the formula and the resultant	equation.	10.386584450723577
10110. it is a number without which the equation cannot be solved	correctly.	21.594586205903248
10111. rodding formulas apply to many phases of the sport.	8.885639840181192
10112. the answers they give can often pave the way to performance increases	and	quite often are necessary for completing entry blanks for different	events.	9.798672584270937
10113. when it is needed one formula is as important as another.	15.199748418523345
10114. however some formulas are used more than others.	12.078685424869935
10115. we'll take	them in the general order of their popularity.	5.127535365434798
10116. a rodder should be able to compute the displacement of his engine.	11.949371322803879
10117. displacement is sometimes referred to as swept volume.	8.277903991967294
10118. most	entry blanks for competitive events require engine displacement information	because of class restrictions.	7.908192277092596
10119. it is good to be able to compute	displacement so that changes in it resulting from boring and stroking	can be computed.	10.286762113539782
10120. factors involved in the displacement formula	are the bore diameter of the engine's cylinders the length of the	piston stroke the number of cylinders in the engine and a constant.	9.925140450924847
10121. 7854 which is one-quarter of 3.	5.914218763127433
10122. 1416 another constant	known as pi.	9.51828979249826
10123. pi is used in formulas concerned with the dimensions	of circles.	9.247456096291875
10124. actually the engine displacement formula is	the standard formula for computing the volume of a cylinder of any type	with an added factor that represents the number of cylinders in the	engine.	10.455843148885041
10125. the cross-sectional area of the cylinders is determined and	then the volume of the individual cylinders is computed by multiplying	the area by the stroke length which is the equivalent of the length	of the cylinders.	8.007610259732699
10126. multiplying the result by the number of cylinders	in the engine gives the engine's total displacement.	8.480697343150224
10127. dimensions in inches and fractions of inches will give	the displacement in cubic inches.	7.377164028503781
10128. dimensions in centimeters and fractions	of centimeters will give the displacement in cubic centimeters	.	10.559312922178517
10129. 54 centimeters: one cubic inch equals 16.	5.322750487150202
10130. for example let's consider a standard	283 cubic inch chevy v8.	8.971817203234178
10131. these engines have a cylinder diameter	of 3-78 inches and a stroke length of 3 inches.	6.411268383493361
10132. the formula with	the fractions converted to decimals becomes f.	10.312429762602429
10133. to arrive	at the answer multiply the numbers together by starting at the left of	the group and working to the right.	9.064342071822349
10134. the different steps will look like	this: f	a cylinder's compression ratio	is computed by comparing the cylinder's volume or its displacement	with the total volume of the cylinder and its combustion chamber.	6.855172972760118
10135. cylinder volume can be determined mathematically but combustion chamber	volume must be measured with a liquid.	7.230872750653363
10136. cylinder volume is	determined in exactly the same manner as for the displacement formula:	f.	15.299699854602691
10137. to measure the volume of one of the combustion chambers	in the cylinder head install the valves and spark plug in the chamber	and support the head so that its gasket surface is level.	9.146571188725902
10138. then pour	water or light oil from a graduated beaker into the chamber to fill	the chamber to its gasket surface.	9.22669504651572
10139. do not overfill the chamber.	12.882656516737265
10140. this	is possible with water and other liquids that have a high surface tension.	11.40487107156552
10141. such liquids will rise to a considerable height above the surface	around the chamber before they will flow out of the chamber.	7.67293285121822
10142. the amount of liquid poured into the chamber is determined by subtracting	the quantity still in the beaker when the chamber is full from	the original quantity.	12.799004623266208
10143. most beakers are graduated in cubic centimeters	making it necessary to convert the result to cubic inches.	7.7077922393551095
10144. however the displacement of the cylinder can be converted to cubic	centimeters.	15.826419014594837
10145. the compression ratio arrived at with the formula will	be the same regardless of whether cubic inches or cubic centimeters are	used.	7.735127314215895
10146. the only precaution is that all volumes used in the formula be	quoted in the same terms.	12.881634614691425
10147. the volume of the cylinder opening	in the head gasket must be computed by multiplying its area in square	inches by the gasket's thickness in thousandths of an inch.	6.730843392325641
10148. sometimes	it is necessary to roughly calculate the square inch area of the opening	but the calculation can usually be made with sufficient accuracy	that it won't affect the final computation.	6.737382605553043
10149. the volume of the opening	is added to the combustion chamber volume.	13.168915743339642
10150. another thing	that must be taken into consideration is the volume of the area between	the top of the piston and the top of the cylinder block when the piston	is in top dead center position.	15.92673766857294
10151. compute this volume by measuring	the distance from the top of the block to the piston head as accurately	as possible with a depth micrometer or some other precision measuring	device and then multiply the area of the cylinder by the depth.	7.699306443911464
10152. the	formula for this step is: f this volume is added to the total volume	of the combustion chamber and head gasket opening.	8.908678208602618
10153. the total of	these three volumes is the final combustion chamber volume.	8.7646738695098
10154. after the factors just described have been computed they are applied	to the following formula: f   for an example let's dream	up an engine that has a final combustion chamber volume of 5 cubic	inches and a cylinder volume of 45 cubic inches.	7.698311717221514
10155. applying these figures	to the formula we get the equation: f the compression ratio is	10 to 1.	5.47630599229847
10156. this method of computing compression ratio cannot be	used accurately for engines that have pistons with either domed or irregularly	shaped heads.	8.161550556370853
10157. any irregularity on the piston heads will make	it impossible with normal means to determine the final combustion	chamber volume because the volume displaced by the piston heads cannot	be readily computed.	6.8899590706455305
10158. the only way to determine the final combustion	chamber volume when such pistons are used is by measuring it with liquid	while the cylinder head is bolted to the cylinder block and the piston	is in top dead center position.	12.310141895211107
10159. there are four versions of the formula that involves the relationships	of car speed engine speed rear axle gear ratio and rear tire	size.	9.813166279899361
10160. by using the appropriate version any one of these factors can	be determined for any combination of the other three.	13.089955447796957
10161. to simplify	the formulas a representative symbol is substituted for each of	the factors.	8.047832027666166
10162. these are   mph for car speed   rpm	for engine crankshaft speed   r for rear axle gear ratio	w for tire size   tire size can be determined in	several ways but the one that is the easiest and as accurate as any is	by measuring the effective radius of a wheel and tire assembly.	8.596820800278822
10163. this	is done by measuring the distance from the surface on which the tire	is resting to the center of the rear axle shaft.	9.496350717559556
10164. a tire must be inflated	to its normal hot operating pressure and the car must be loaded to	its operating weight when this measurement is made.	7.937211153560436
10165. the measurement	must be in inches.	12.11163630983322
10166. any fraction of an inch involved in the measurement	must be converted to a decimal equivalent to simplify the mathematics.	11.64622906844718
10167. when tire size is measured in this manner a constant of 168 is used	in the formula.	7.599076770184413

10292. bill ruger's long-awaited deerstalker	is a new rifle action in a caliber that upsets all the	modern theory of high-velocity fans; it's a short light quick-handling	fast-firing little timber gun designed to push a heavy slug	at modest velocity but with lots of killing power and ample range for	our most popular big game- whitetail.	4.9831635479659155

10393. livery stable- j vernon prop coaching had declined	considerably by 1905 but the sign was still there near the old	wells fargo building in san francisco creaking in the fog as it	had for thirty years.	4.962074441743556

10399. the southward route	was the classic run in california and the most fashionable.	7.982589467143254

10435. the omelet named for ernest arbogast the palace's chef	was even more in demand.	5.433962957490287
10436. for decades it was the most popular dish	served in the ladies' grill at breakfast and it is one of the few	old palace dishes that still survive.	10.917570132060353
10437. native california oysters	salty and piquant as coppery as delawares and not much larger than a	five-cent piece went into it.	4.9079721184290435
10438. the original formula goes thus:	arbogast	fry in butter a small minced onion rub with a tablespoonful	of flour add half a cup of cream six beaten eggs pepper	celery salt a teaspoonful of minced chives a dash of cayenne and a	pinch of nutmeg.	7.144187561985731
10439. a jigger of dry sherry follows and as the mixture	stiffens in go a hundred of the little oysters.	7.47700226396046
10440. louis sherry	once stayed a fortnight at the palace and he was so pleased with omelet	arbogast that he introduced it at his restaurant in new york.	9.528242581704765
10441. j pierpont morgan had come in his private train to san francisco	to attend an episcopal convention and brought the restaurateur	with him.	5.89776744569911
10442. as things happened morgan was installed in the nob hill	residence of a magnate friend whose kitchen swarmed with cooks of approved	talent.	9.027380601102514
10443. sherry remained in his hotel suite where he amused himself	as best he could.	6.449793920344403
10444. twice he left everything to his entourage and	fled to make the santa cruz tour under vernon's guidance.	9.886589630997662
10445. in the grand court of the palace notable for its tiers of moorish	galleries that looked down on the maelstrom of vehicles below vernon's	station was at the entrance.	7.181232153942796
10446. it was a post of honor held inviolate	for him; he had the primacy among the coachmen.	11.170546806934361
10447. of majestic build	rubicund and slash-mouthed he resembled the late general winfield	scott who was said to be the most imposing general of his century	if not of all centuries.	6.7068299045735635
10448. vernon wore a gray tall hat a gardenia	and maroon wellington boots that glistened like currant jelly.	7.570004124553615
10449. promptly at seven he would clatter out of the court with twelve in	the tallyho.	8.275009853690984
10450. he had style: he held his reins in a loose bunch at the	third button of his checked epsom surtout and when the horses leaned	at a curve as if bent by the force of a gale he leaned with them.	8.157061731475391
10451. they cantered down the peninsula not slackening until the coach reached	woodside where the santa cruz uplands begin.	6.8010854044096485
10452. the road	maps of the region have changed since 1905; inns have burned down moved	elsewhere or taken other names.	7.359519754734403
10453. once on the road	the schedule meant	nothing.	11.020424522492746
10454. an agreeable ease suffused vernon and the passengers of	the tallyho from which there issued clouds of smoke.	9.232797029347193
10455. vernon would tilt	his hat over one ear as he lounged with his feet on the dashboard	indulging in a huge cigar.	6.284891205259477
10456. the horses moved at a clump; they were no	more on parade than was their driver; one fork of the road was as	good as another.	7.469971384125192
10457. the santa cruz mountains sprawl over three counties	and the roads twist through sky-tapping redwoods down whose furrowed	columns ripple streams of rain even when heat bakes the santa clara	valley below at the left.	5.234309044985687
10458. the water splashes into shoulder-high tracts	of fernery.	9.10532829272494
10459. you arrive there in seersucker and feel you were half-witted	not to bring a mackintosh.	7.1495288063773
10460. vernon kept an account book	with a list of all the establishments that he thought worthy of patronage.	11.077287721175308
10461. a number of them must have fallen into disfavor; they were	struck out with remarks in red ink denouncing both the cooks and the	management.	6.718372342802942
10462. he was copious in his praise of those that served food that	was good to eat.	11.787364797743669
10463. the horses seemed to know these by instinct he used	to say: such places invariably had stables with superior feed bins.	5.596240283727825
10464. there was wright's for one lost amongst trees its wide	verandas strewn with rockers.	10.114720477589607
10465. many of its sojourners were devoted	to seclusion and quiet and lived there to the end of their days.	11.256942689582027
10466. it	was	the haunt of writer ambrose bierce who admired its redwoods.	7.451120774553343
10467. acorns	from the great oaks fed the small black pigs	whose carcass sweepstakes were renowned.	5.690257311975986
10468. their ham butts cured	in oak-log smoke were also esteemed when roasted or boiled and served	with this original sauce:	put into	a saucepan a cupful of the baked ham gravy or of the boiled ham liquor	with a half stick of butter three teaspoonfuls of made mustard	and two mashed garlic cloves.	6.039793257782261
10469. contribute also an onion a peeled tomato	and two pickled gherkins and a mashed lime.	5.622778888055759
10470. after this has simmered	an hour add two tablespoons each of worcestershire catsup and	chutney two pickled walnuts and a pint of sherry.	9.059364893947844
10471. then simmer fifteen	minutes longer.	9.821516406722933
10472. every winter a kegful of this sauce was made	and placed at the end of a row of four other kegs in the cellar so	that when its turn came it was properly mellowed.	9.826161177622925
10473. vineyards	and orchards also grew around wright's and deer were rather a nuisance;	they leaped six-foot fences with the agility of panthers.	3.7640878284867507
10474. but	no one complained when they wound up regardless of season in venison	pies.	10.13491915633724
10475. no one complained of the white wine either: at this altitude	of two thousand feet grapes acquire a dryness and the tang of gunflint.	6.394867157576722
10476. apple	trees grew there also.	10.856153900407218
10477. though creeks in the santa cruz mountains	flow brimful the year round and it is forever spring the apples that	grow there have a wintry crackle.	8.74578100582755
10478. dwellers thereabouts preferred	to get their apple pies at the local bakery which had a brick oven	fired with redwood billets.	7.398404399474098
10479. the merit of the pie vernon believed	was due more to its making than to the waning heat of the oven.	7.5540981226980515
10480. the recipe	which he got from the baker and wrote down in his ledger is basically	this:	peel core and slice across	enough apples to make a dome in the pie tin and set aside.	7.752175466810923
10481. in a	saucepan put sufficient water to cover them an equal amount of sugar	a sliced lemon a tablespoonful of apricot preserve or jam a pinch each	of clove and nutmeg and a large bay leaf.	5.854520025417927
10482. let this boil gently for	twenty minutes then strain.	11.299570558327414
10483. poach the apples in this syrup for twelve	minutes drain them and cool.	6.929570799569572
10484. set the apples in the pastry-lined	tin spread over them three tablespoonfuls of softened butter	with as much brown sugar a sprinkling of nutmeg and a fresh bay leaf	then lay on a cover of pastry and gild it with beaten yolk of egg.	7.472511437465807
10485. those who have never traveled the width and length of this	land cannot conceive on the basis of textbook description alone the	overwhelming space and variety of this country held together under one	government.	7.891959004092686
10486. the miracle of democratic america comes home to one most	strongly only when one has seen the endless great plains of the	midwest; the sky-reaching peaks of the northwest mountains; the	smoke-filled art-filled drama-filled life of the great cities of the	east; the lush and historic charm of the south.	6.373613092211112
10487. now to add to the	already unbelievable extremes found in one nation we have the two	new states of hawaii and alaska.	8.529026497982104
10488. to hope to cover just one	region of this land and to enjoy all of its sights and events and of	course to bring back pictures of your experiences requires advance planning.	9.177777239358456
10489. for this reason us camera has prepared this special	usa vacation feature.	9.251522265305466
10490. we divided the country into five	regions plus hawaii and alaska and in each is included a general	description of the area plus specific recommendations of places and events	to cover.	9.406982032891491
10491. any special photographic requirements are also given.	7.612072186763525
10492. use this section to plan now to make the most of your vacation	in photogenic america.	13.196240025967475
10493. birthplace of the	nation the northeast offers historic battlefields; lovely old villages	and a rugged seashore among its many worthwhile sights.	5.429359918196512

10512. be careful here not	to overexpose this subject since they are extremely bright and	light-reflecting.	10.67725414109273

10514. the southern united	states extending from florida in the east to texas in the west	still maintains its unique flavor of gracious living and historical elegance.	9.657318748721561

10536. for example	the chamber of commerce of gatlinburg tennessee sponsors special	camera tours into the great smoky mountains to get pictures of the	profusion of wild flowers flourishing in these wooded regions.	9.017390251210147
10537. exposure problems may occur in these forest areas where uneven lighting	results from shafts of sunlight filtering through the overhead branches.	5.657303268821556

10571. a western vacation is practically	synonymous with a visit to at least one of the magnificent national parks	in this area.	9.312371508028344

10579. built upon seven hills istanbul like rome is one of	the most ancient cities in the world filled with splendor and contrast.	7.132366649597983
10580. it is an exotic place so different from the ordinary that the casual	tourist is likely to see at first only the contrast and the ugliness	of narrow streets lined with haphazard houses.	10.836044240010146
10581. at the moment many	of these are being pulled down.	12.348245730937652
10582. whole blocks are disappearing and more	are scheduled to vanish to make room for wide boulevards that will	show off its treasures to better advantage- the great domes and graceful	spires of its mosques the panorama of the bosphorus and the golden	horn.	6.875310885366586
10583. even when they are finished however the contrast will	remain for istanbul is the only city in the world that is built upon	two continents.	10.960545356244566
10584. for almost 3000 years europe and asia have rubbed	shoulders in its streets.	11.429654162749927
10585. founded in the ninth century bc	it was called byzantium 200 years later when byzas ruler of	the megarians expanded the settlement and named it after himself.	6.642929287354343
10586. about	a thousand years after that when the roman empire was divided	it became capital of the eastern section.	10.442125403264958
10587. on may 11 330 ad	its name was changed again this time to constantinople after its	emperor constantine.	8.462396738212673
10588. in 1453 when the last vestige of ancient roman	power fell to the turks the city officially shifted religions-	although the patriarch or pope of the orthodox church continued	to live there and still does- and became the capital of the ottoman	empire.	7.912414053706838
10589. when that was broken up after the first world war	its name was changed once more.	10.088917741996381
10590. rich in christian and moslem art	istanbul is today a fascinating museum of east and west that	recently	became a seaside resort as well with the development of new beaches on	the bosphorus and the sea of marmara only a short distance from the	center of town.	9.513117515332677
10591. easy to get to and becoming more popular every year	it is only fourteen hours from new york by pan american world	airways jet four hours from rome.	6.944720295649367
10592. most of the	sights lie in the old section across the golden horn from the modern	hotels.	13.451294127694114
10593. i started my tour of them at the turkish government tourist	office next to pan american's office on the left as you enter	the driveway that leads to the hilton hotel.	6.860181006097613
10594. from there i turned	left along cumhuriyet cadesi past more hotels and a park on the left	republic gardens and came in a few moments to taksim square one	of the hubs of the city with the monument of the republic erected	in 1928 in its center.	9.403521531883541
10595. directly across from the gardens i	found a bus stop sign for t 4 and rode it down to the bosphorus	with the sports center on my left just before i reached the water and	the entrance to dolmabahce palace immediately after that.	7.53723114971724
10596. there	the bus turned right along the bosphorus past ocean liners at anchor	to galata bridge over the entrance to the golden horn a brown sweep	of water that empties into the bosphorus.	8.484073327183257
10597. across the bridge on	the left i saw st sophia with its sturdy brown minarets and to the	right of them the slenderer spires of the blue mosque.	6.803928193590554
10598. on	the other side of the golden horn i rode through eminonu square	with yeni cami or the new mosque which dates from the seventeenth	century just across from the entrance to the bridge.	11.525495853200333
10599. passing it	the bus climbed a hill with the covered spice bazaar on the right and	pandelli's a famous and excellent restaurant above it.	5.393139724963861
10600. at the	top of the hill the buildings on the left gave way to a park.	15.075034116969965
10601. i got	off there crossed the street walked ahead with st sophia on my	left the blue mosque on my right and in a moment came to the entrance	of st sophia.	8.267889803740673
10602. erected on the site of pagan temples and	three previous st sophias the first of which was begun by constantine	this fourth church was started by justinian in 532 and completed	twenty years later.	8.958359750674235
10603. on his first trip to the finished structure	he boasted that he had built a temple grander than solomon's in jerusalem.	7.324241783469835
10604. a few years later the dome fell in.	17.66420067298266
10605. nevertheless it remained	one of the most splendid churches of the eastern empire where	the byzantine emperors were crowned.	9.020091853515806
10606. after the turks conquered the	city in 1453 they converted it to a mosque adding the stubby minarets.	9.76193477520454
10607. in the second half of the sixteenth century sinan the great architect	who is the michelangelo of the east designed the massive buttresses	that now help support the dome.	9.775245878249654
10608. with the birth of the turkish	republic after the first world war st sophia became a museum	and the ancient mosaics which were plastered over by the moslems	whose religion forbids pictures in holy places have been restored.	9.276585285555331
10609. inside over the first door i saw one of these which shows	constantine offering the city to the virgin mary and justinian offering	the temple.	7.495261916714966
10610. on the columns around the immense dome are round plaques	with arabic writing.	11.347699582518286
10611. the eight green columns i learned came	from the temple of artemis at ephesus the others red from the temple	of the sun at heliopolis.	6.472974056497496
10612. beneath the dome i saw the	spot where the byzantine emperors were crowned a bit of floor protected	now by a wooden fence.	9.734184813751718
10613. behind this is a minber or moslem pulpit	and near it a raised platform with golden grillwork where the emperors	and after them the sultans sat.	6.161271041379002
10614. directly opposite is the emperor's	door through which they entered the building.	8.716937731064643
10615. outside	st sophia i walked through the flower garden in front of it with	the blue mosque ahead on my left.	7.0611417730639445
10616. across the street on my right i	saw the hippodrome now a park.	11.966053457638669
10617. it was laid out in 196 for chariot	races and other public games.	10.484430283909433
10618. statues and other monuments that stood	there were stolen mostly by the waves of crusaders.	8.29508837333367
10619. at	the beginning of the hippodrome i saw the kaiser's fountain an	ugly octagonal building with a glass dome built in 1895 by the german	emperor and on my left directly across from it the tomb of sultan	ahmet who constructed the blue mosque more properly known by	his name.	6.742700919879317
10620. just before coming to the mosque entrance i crossed	the street entered the hippodrome and walked ahead to the obelisk	of theodosius originally erected in heliopolis in egypt about 1600	bc by thutmose who also built those now in new york	london and rome at the lateran.	7.8917337952535105
10621. this one was set up here in 390 ad	on a pedestal the faces of which are carved with statues of	the emperor and his family watching games in the hippodrome done so	realistically that the obelisk itself is included in them.	6.747302811967829
10622. beyond	it i noted a small green column about twelve feet below the present	ground level- the serpentine column three entwined serpents	which once stood at the temple of apollo at delphi greece.	7.284184488592426
10623. near	the end of the hippodrome i came upon the built column a truncated	obelisk of blocks all that remains of a monument that once rivalled	the colossus of rhodes.	7.238377791464623
10624. retracing my steps	to the mosque of sultan ahmet only one with six minarets i entered	the courtyard with a gallery supported by pointed arches running	around it and a fountain in the middle.	8.462635718506707
10625. one of the most beautiful	buildings in istanbul it was constructed in the early years of the seventeenth	century with a huge central dome two half domes that seem	to cascade down from it and smaller full domes around the gallery.	7.954344224161963
10626. the round minarets tall and graceful rise from rectangular bases and	have three platforms from which the muezzin can chant his call to prayer.	8.287860349352167
10627. inside the walls are covered with blue and white tile the floor	with red and cream carpets.	7.600414791785531
10628. back at the kaiser's fountain	i walked left to the streetcar stop and rode up the hill- any	car will do- past the column of constantine also known as the burnt	column at the top on my right.	6.796511738942404
10629. it stands in the middle of what	was once the forum of constantine who brought it from rome.	12.20546186812021
10630. i stayed on the car for a few minutes until turning right it entered	a huge square bayezit with the bayezit mosque on the right and	the gate to the university just beyond it.	10.270034529069493
10631. there i got off crossed	the square and on the side directly opposite the gate found a good	restaurant hard to come by in this part of the city.	10.14755898839182
10632. called the marmara	gazinosu it is on the third floor with signs pointing the way	there and has a terrace overlooking the sea of marmara.	11.063490370908491
10633. after lunch	in the arcade on my left just before reaching the street i found a	pastry shop that sells some of the best baklava- a sweet flaky cake-	in istanbul.	6.265491113827793
10634. it's a great favorite of the university students	and i joined them there for dessert.	4.4824904366260485
10635. taking the streetcar back	to kaiser's fountain i walked ahead then left down the street	opposite st sophia and just beyond the corner came to a small	one-story building with a red-tile roof which is the entrance to the	sunken palace.	5.489955890980297
10636. actually an underground cistern its roof supported	by rows and rows of pillars it was built by justinian in the sixth	century to supply the palace with water.	8.890418365459809
10637. there is still water in it.	22.31294660472296
10638. i found it fairly depressing and emerged almost immediately.	12.909314321730845
10639. outside i walked past the entrance to st sophia turned left at	the end of it and continued toward a gate in the wall ahead.	8.466751077052837
10640. just	before reaching it i came to a grey and brown stone building that looks	somewhat like an oriental pagoda with arabic lettering in gold and	colored tile decorations- the fountain of sultan ahmet.	6.97251277548774
10641. going through the imperial gate in the wall i entered the grounds	of topkapi palace home of the sultans and nerve center of the vast	ottoman empire and walked along a road toward another gate in the	distance past the church of st irene completed by constantine	in 330 ad on my left and then just outside the second	gate i saw a spring with a tap in the wall on my right- the executioner's	spring where he washed his hands and his sword after beheading	his victims.	5.681448849195101
10642. passing through the gate with towers on either	side once used as prisons i entered a huge square surrounded by	buildings and on the wall to my right found a general plan of the grounds	with explanations in english for each building.	8.732163668847367
10643. there are a	good many of them.	16.115387684367143
10644. at one time about 10000 people lived there.	19.689362590205494

10652. do start fires one or two hours ahead of time to obtain	a	lasting bed of glowing coals.	12.047321893849036
10653. keep ashes from one barbecue to the next	to sprinkle over coals if they are too hot and to stop flames that	arise from melting grease.	6.47993677927977
10654. do line barbecue fire bowl	with	heavy foil to reflect heat.	10.864497135158214
10655. don't forget to buy a plastic	pastry brush for basting with sauces.	3.216746914546581
10656. clean it meticulously in boiling	water and detergent rinse thoroughly.	8.438248050550651
10657. do build a wall	of glowing coals six to eight inches in front of meat that is barbecued	on an electric spit.	7.723724277015369
10658. make use of the back of the barbecue or of the	hood for heating vegetables sauces and such.	12.81300027521979
10659. don't	fail to shorten cooking time by the use of aluminum foil cut slightly	larger than the surface of steaks and chops.	6.542737509442191
10660. sear on both sides then	cover meat loosely with heat reflecting foil for juiciest results.	8.637283577278795
10661. do avoid puncturing or cutting into meats to test them.	7.979730237455581
10662. if doubtful	about a steak boldly cut it in half.	12.18481455252261
10663. if necessary to replace	both halves on grill sear cuts and allot extra time.	7.376445959547027
10664. for roasts insert	meat thermometer diagonally so it does not rest on bone.	11.165259443237792
10665. also make	sure thermometer does not touch the revolving spit or hit the coals.	6.571813478787193

10667. have a test-run	on the family first to be sure timing and seasoning are right.	8.253561480319217
10668. do buy meat the day or the day before you intend to cook it.	13.243850872995713

10670. don't	plan meals that are too complicated.	8.238001839407719

10674. when you start the outdoor performance	you can stay outdoors without a dozen running trips into the kitchen.	10.885096824075525

10715. a	story goes that a certain herr feuchtwanger of st louis around	1883 served his sausages and mustard to his fancy customers.	5.490540588630753

10768. directions are written for those who have had previous	experience in making pottery.	12.325954257413974
10769. instructions for preparing clay drying	glazing and firing are not given.	6.671001916212316
10770. wooden butter molds and cookie presses.	9.48963415842776
10771. ceramic modeling clay: red white or buff.	4.965414430966351
10772. glazes one-stroke ceramic colors stains cones as indicated	in the individual instructions.	6.43778505790055
10773. use	well-wedged clay	free of air bubbles and pliable enough to bend without	cracking.	5.528752877016092
10774. clean wooden molds and presses thoroughly; they must be	free of oil wax and dust.	7.023698862350184
10775. the size of wooden	mold will determine the amount of clay needed.	13.855347638910493
10776. roll clay to thickness	indicated in individual instructions.	10.63783232698963
10777. whenever possible use the	wooden mold as a pattern for cutting clay.	7.728218899318085
10778. when mold has more than one	design cavity make individual paper patterns.	11.541223069229089
10779. place mold or paper	pattern on rolled clay and cut clay by holding knife in vertical position	defects; experiment with defects for decoration techniques of glazes	.	5.632876526694328
10780. place the cut clay piece loosely over the carved cavity	design side of wooden mold.	10.394832864851827
10781. to obtain clear impression of mold press	clay gently but firmly into mold cavity starting at center and working	to outer edges.	7.005833663679408
10782. trim excess clay away from outer edges.	14.901956170539092
10783. check thickness	of clay and build up thin areas by moistening surface with a little	water and adding small pieces of clay.	5.995888777852015
10784. be sure to press the additional	clay firmly into place without locking in air bubbles.	12.968948463913343
10785. allow	project to stand for about five minutes	antique do not leave clay in too long as the dampness may cause mold	.	7.547679863508447
10786. to release clay from mold place hands in a cupped	position around project; gently lift the edge on far side then continue	to release edge completely around mold.	7.9650257471211825
10787. slight tapping on the	underside of mold will help release the clay but too much agitation will	cause the clay to become soft and will interfere with removal of clay	from mold.	5.9733874137142315
10788. place a piece of plaster wall board or plaster bat on	clay and reverse bat clay and mold in one action.	9.087784890141133
10789. this will prevent	the clay from twisting or bending causing warping when fired.	7.785838166752627
10790. place	project on table and carefully lift the mold off.	9.628494024404723
10791. study surface of clay	for defects or desired corrections.	6.764694290732687
10792. if clay is slightly out of shape	square straight sides with guide sticks or rulers pressed against	opposite sides or smooth round pieces with damp fingers.	8.091012956795652
10793. if the background	of design is too smooth or you wish to create a wood-grained effect	it may be added at this time with a dull tool such as the handle	of a fine paintbrush.	7.728854204293408
10794. make slight smooth grooves rather than cuts	for the texture	.	9.820667418406188
10795. leave the clay on	plaster board to dry slowly covered lightly with a loose piece of plastic	or cloth to prevent warping.	6.544159067866324

10906. hotei is 23 feet long with an 8-12-foot beam and every inch	a family boat.	7.2343147771369205
10907. menfolk can ride in the forward cockpit where the	helmsman has a clear view.	6.972004228480313
10908. youngsters can sleep or amuse themselves	safely in the large cabin which has 5-foot 11-inch headroom bunks for	three galley and marine toilet.	6.1129482386011516

10910. all are well distributed not crowded together near	the stern.	10.534753876792154

10912. the 80-hp motor drives	her at 25 mph with six aboard!   with only two aboard hotei	does better than 27	mph- and she gives a comfortable ride at this	speed even in a three-foot chop.	5.871242590674345
10913. she also banks into a turn like	a fine runabout- not digging in on the outside to throw passengers all	over the boat like many a small cabin cruiser.	6.338940820059555
10914. nor is she a wet boat.	14.043099821587818
10915. we've been out in five-foot waves and stayed dry.	3.4052304030519416
10916. a lot of	thought went into storage space construction.	11.150328798765925
10917. there's a large compartment	in the forward cockpit for charts and other items.	4.0060363662686855

10921. the well itself is designed to take two	merc 800's or 500's if you wish and there's room for a 25-gallon	long-cruise gas tank below it.	4.908582996635884
10922. needless to say you can't	build hotei in a couple of weeks.	8.501252843629276

10926. a	gator trailer model 565 is used to transport the boat to the waterways.	9.252635060633194
10927. this piece of equipment costs a little over $600 but it will save	you that in mooring and hauling fees in a few years.	6.974250190302712
10928. all framing	in hotei is one-inch mahogany which in the dressed state you	buy it is about the 1316-inch thickness specified in the drawings.	7.348616280321776
10929. therefore	the lumber is bought in planks and ripped to size for battens	etc on a table saw.	6.243459868805426
10930. besides flathead bronze screws silicon bronze	stronghold nails	are used extensively in assembly and weldwood	resorcinal glue is used in all the joints.	8.723298216878154
10931. follows a thorough study of the drawings.	10.229766805533108
10932. start by laying out the six	frames and the transom on a level floor.	12.038612724561954
10933. draw each outline in a different-color	chalk one on top of the other.	7.921757755695675
10934. in this way you will be	able to detect any obvious mistakes.	16.137995172070493
10935. the transom frame is made	first with the joints lapped glued and fastened with one-inch no	12 stronghold nails.	5.79040229408806
10936. after notching it for the keelson chines and	battens the half-inch plywood transom is secured to it with glue	and the same type	nails.	8.358119081271782
10937. all frames are butted at the joints and 38-inch plywood gussets	are glued and nailed on each side of each joint again using the one-inch	no 12 nails.	6.142495273752837
10938. the frames are notched only for the keelson	and the chines.	12.692408055352207
10939. if notched for the battens they would require more work	be weakened and limber holes would have to be bored so that bilge	water could flow through.	7.994039910142355
10940. nowhere in the boat do the frames come in	contact with the plywood planking.	9.662670282328643
10941. the jig is erected after the	frames and transom are complete.	7.49396414211318
10942. this is an important step because	any misalignment would cause progressively worse misalignment in the hull	as you advance in construction.	10.08886549009336
10943. be sure all members are parallel	vertical and level as required.	10.662861464084994
10944. after the frames and transom	are set up on the jig and temporarily braced a piece of three-inch-wide	mahogany	is butted between frames one and two below the line	of the keelson.	10.093028448250458
10945. the frames are glued and screwed to this piece.	14.708499772147393
10946. the	joints are also reinforced on each side with small blocks set in resin-saturated	fiberglas cloth and nailed.	7.737967269281737
10947. it is over this piece that the	laminated stem and keelson are spliced.	11.094295841714604
10948. the keelson made of	two three-inch widths is next installed.	8.51990541858845
10949. the first piece is glued	and screwed to the frames and transom and the piece butted between frames	one and two.	9.606522719209844
10950. the second piece is in turn glued and screwed to the	first.	16.98955914184904
10951. note however that it is six inches shorter at the forward end.	9.197550662010729
10952. one-inch no 10 screws are used in both cases.	8.380199725529394
10953. a stem	jig is next cut to the proper shape and temporarily fastened to	frame one.	7.034044816084957
10954. the stem is laminated from four pieces.	11.691582561780148
10955. take two three-inch-wide	pieces and rip them down the center of the thickness to make	the four.	7.8501092386572715

10957. the first two pieces butt against	the inner member of the keelson and are glued and screwed to the brace	between the first two frames.	11.264195508715117

10960. a number of c	clamps hold the pieces together on the jig until the glue sets.	12.894916563643228
10961. all bottom battens are two inches wide.	9.400463182999147
10962. the side ones are a half-inch	narrower.	14.003782074529433
10963. the battens are carefully fastened in place after some	necessary fairing on all frames.	7.325338286036964
10964. glue and 1-12-inch no 10 screws	are used.	6.9876505049694355

10966. with the exception of two battens all run to the stem where they	are glued and screwed after careful beveling.	13.493274555836095
10967. the chines go in the same	way except that they are made of two pieces of two-inch wood for strength	and easier bending.	7.638765906960146
10968. fairing is always a tedious job but	the work can be cut down considerably with a skill planer and a simple	jig.	9.196353352685643
10969. i clamped a 30-inch piece of aluminum to the base of the planer	with a pair of sure grips.	6.950058550380086
10970. the aluminum flush against the battens	acted as a fairing stick and enabled me to plane the chines and keelson	to the proper bevels easily.	7.937493624798932
