11069. the	wall panels are constructed of a framework of standard f and f of	a good grade free from structural faults.	5.988106729285891
11070. they should be as straight	as possible as this will effect their ability to mesh properly when	the walls are erected.	11.504891279685799
11071. the outside surface of the solid units shall	be of an exterior grade of panel board such as plywood plastic coated	panel board high density particle board asbestos-cement board or	any other product locally obtainable upon recommendation of your building	supply dealer.	5.393636490115142
11072. the inner panels do not have to be weatherproof and	the choice will depend on the quality of finish desired.	14.882182873020033
11073. all panel	board comes in standard f foot size.	8.66667726830589
11074. it is recommended that panels	be both glued as well as nailed to the frame.	15.960201158990143
11075. the fixed window panels	with louvers should have a good grade of 18-inch double-strength glass	set in a mastic glazing compound.	5.493794451538147
11076. the louvers are constructed as	shown in the detail with a drop door for ventilation.	9.689705919362503
11077. there are standard	sliding glass windows in wood or aluminum frames for those panels	requiring them.	8.917631352057672
11078. the door panels are designed to accommodate standard	doors which should be of exterior grade.	12.237996103042468
11079. the filler panels for the gable	ends are cut from full f sheets as shown leaving no wastage.	6.863656520590308
11080. the	battens covering the joints are of f stock and are applied after	the walls are erected.	8.64230296902365
11081. all nails should be rustproof and aluminum is	highly recommended.	7.39408784347839
11082. note: if 12-inch panel board is used inside	and out or 58-inch one side and 38-inch the other and 18-inch glass	is used stock lumber in f f and f can be used in making the	glass panels.	5.581851453721555
11083. other thicknesses may necessitate ripping a special	size lumber for the glass trim.	6.207911370937444
11084. in any case there is no special milling	or rabbeting required for the panels.	14.601221467349507
11085. with modern techniques of woodworking and the multitude of cutting	tools fixtures and attachments available the drill press has become	a basic home workshop tool.	6.4372659716068705
11086. the drill press consists of a vertical	shaft which is tapered or threaded on one end to hold a	drill chuck a tubular housing in which the spindle is mounted	a head in which the quill is mounted a feed lever which moves the	quill up or down a power source and a movable table upon which the work	is placed.	9.017848234527078
11087. there is often a means of locking the quill and on larger	presses the table can be tilted.	11.698653884820246
11088. the size of the press is	usually expressed in terms of chuck capacity	or distance between the spindle center and the	column.	13.601554022532932
11089. a press with an 11 inch capacity lets you drill to the center	of a 22 inch board or circle.	7.149968762996499
11090. a new radial drill press with	a 16 inch capacity has a tilting head that allows drilling to be done	at any angle.	8.502556042629841
11091. the head is mounted on a horizontal arm that swivels on	the supporting column to position the drill bit instead of the work.	8.026320903648967
11092. the drill press should be leveled and depending	on whether it is a bench or floor model bolted securely to a	sturdy bench or stand or screwed to the floor with lag or expansion screws.	10.026969457252404
11093. this will reduce vibration and increase accuracy.	10.04792499399582
11094. a coat	of paste wax or a rubdown with a piece of wax paper will protect the	polished surface of the table; wiping with a slightly oiled cloth	will discourage rusting of the column and quill.	7.195751659888221
11095. presses not fitted	with sealed spindle bearings will need a drop of oil now and then in	the lubrication holes in the quill.	7.095169630375162
11096. the rest of the press should be kept	clean by dusting with a clean rag or brush.	12.20352406494113
11097. be careful to	keep the drive belt free of oil and grease.	9.072370677027983
11098. belt tension is adjusted	by manipulation of two locking bolts and a movable motor mount.	8.249089359568496
11099. keep	the belt just tight enough so the pulleys won't slip when pulled by	hand; excess tension will only cause undue wear on the motor and spindle	bearings.	4.543817722614439
11100. most drill presses have a quill return spring that raises	the spindle automatically when the feed lever is released and holds	the quill in the raised position.	8.58043825248282
11101. the return spring tension may be	adjusted to suit individual requirements by gripping the spring housing	with a pair of pliers	loosening the lock nut or screw and rotating the housing	until the desired tension is achieved.	6.138572807343488
11102. turning the housing clockwise	will reduce tension counter-clockwise will increase it.	7.776542454070092
11103. lose the chuck key	some manufacturers have had the foresight to provide	a socket for the chuck key; otherwise you'll have to spend	a few minutes to either attach a suitable spring clip somewhere on the	press head or fit the key to a length of light chain and fasten to the	bottom of the motor mount so that the key is out of the way when not	in use.	5.771357103639164
11104. drill speeds are important if you want	a good job.	11.3941113749615
11105. each cutting tool will operate best at a given speed	depending on the material worked.	7.15799579043953
11106. on most drill presses it is impossible	to get the exact speed but you can come close by adjusting the	drive belt on the step-cone pulleys.	9.734828870756289
11107. you will find a chart giving the	various speed ratios available with your particular drill press somewhere	in the instruction booklet that came with the tool.	7.383174313949232
11108. see the table	on page 34 for exact recommended speeds.	11.22744574714331
11109. generally the larger the	tool and the harder the material the slower the speed.	7.915435271745271
11110. feed pressure	is also of major importance.	11.021644229796495
11111. too much pressure will force the	tool beyond its cutting capacity and result in rough cuts and jammed	or broken tools.	6.941924144532618
11112. too light a feed particularly with metal or other hard	material causes overheating of the tool and burning of the cutting	edge.	10.023443081384826
11113. the best results will be obtained by matching the correct speed	with a steady feed pressure that lets the tool cut easily at an even	rate.	6.943868712419005
11114. there are numerous types and styles	of tools to drill holes.	14.663223110945346
11115. the most common are the twist drill the	solid center shaft with interchangeable cutting blades the double spur	bit and the power wood bit.	6.549623517023525
11116. all will do a good job if sharp but the	twist drills don't cut quite as smoothly as the others since they	do not have the outlining spurs that sever the fibers before actual	boring starts.	7.7397813874845784
11117. the adjustable fly cutter is very useful for cutting	large diameter holes and can be used to cut exact-size discs by	reversing the cutter blade.	6.362397256832637
11118. since fly cutters are one sided and not	balanced they should be used at the slowest speed available and fed	very slowly to avoid binding.	9.65067454517513
11119. fly cutters can fool you into putting	your hand too close to the tool so if you want to avoid nicked fingers	keep your hands well out of the way.	7.543632082415184
11120. when drilling all the way through a workpiece always place a	piece of scrap wood underneath.	11.370848313316735
11121. this will not only protect the work	table but also assure a clean breakthrough.	8.81035136775017
11122. another method of assuring	a clean hole is to first drill a small pilot hole all the way through	then drill half way with the dimensional bit turn the piece over	and finish from the other side.	9.079163489566984
11123. in soft woods with pronounced grain	there is sometimes a tendency for the hole to wander due to the varying	hardness of the wood.	7.3755840510204695
11124. in this case drilling a small pilot hole or	clamping the work will do much to improve accuracy.	12.135461885677696
11125. when a hole	is to be bored to a predetermined depth mark the depth on the side	of the stock then run the bit down so that it is even with the mark.	9.75486342634482
11126. the depth gauge rod can now be set and any number of holes bored to	exact and identical depth.	9.789687617267768
11127. the old-time bridges over the merrimac river in massachusetts	are of unusual interest in many respects.	6.2359586185777784
11128. for their length their	types of construction their picturesque settings and their literary	associations they should be known and remembered.	9.4928356839611
11129. in this sequence	i shall write about them in the order of their erection.	14.194827067955318
11130. the	first bridge known to have been covered wholly or in part- and perhaps	the most interesting one connected newbury with	salisbury point.	8.047781778168204
11131. its building was first proposed in 1791 when a	group of citizens mostly newburyport men petitioned the general court	no	1 newbury port may 30th 1791 a bridge over	merrimack river from the land of hon'ble jonathan greenleaf	esquire in newbery to deer island and from said island to salisbury	would be of very extensive utility by affording a safe conveyance	to carriages teams	and travellers at all seasons of the year	and at all times of tide.	5.229430395388057
11132. we the subscribers do agree	that as soon as a convenient number of persons have subscribed to	this or a similar writing we will present a petition to the hon'ble	general court of the commonwealth of massachusetts praying	for an act incorporating into a body politic the subscribers to such	writing with liberty to build such a bridge and a right to demand	a toll equal to that received at malden bridge and on like terms	and if such an act shall be obtained then we severally agree each	with the others that we will hold in the said bridge the several shares	set against our respective names the whole into two hundred shares	being divided and that we will pay such sums of money at such times	and in such manners as by the said proposed corporation shall	be directed and required.	7.791552031143864
11133. this paper was signed by forty-five	persons subscribing a total of two hundred shares.	7.0692210911924045
11134. a month	later the general court served notice to the town of newbury that	the bridge was to be built.	10.173854382918426
11135. the matter was considered and reconsidered	and finally opposed but in spite of many objections the court	granted a charter on january 9 1792.	7.122935728053288
11136. on november 26 of that year the	bridge was completed and opened.	12.888411508880443
11137. timothy palmer who invented	and later patented the arch type of construction for wooden bridges	was the genius who planned and supervised the building of the essex	or deer island bridge although the actual work was carried	out under the direction of william coombs who received  300 as	recompense.	6.0479760015582
11138. this two-part bridge is best described by rev timothy	dwight president of yale college in his travels in new-england	and new-york published in new haven in 1821.	6.929896917283862
11139. he says	of it:   it consists of two divisions separated by an island	at a small distance from the southern shore.	6.484093874871417
11140. the division between	the island and this shore consists principally of an arch; whose	chord is one hundred and sixty feet and whose vortex is forty feet	above the high-water mark.	7.3936105863487835
11141. in appearance and	construction it resembles the pascataqua bridge.	9.021993832996927
11142. the whole length of	essex bridge is one thousand and thirty feet and its breadth thirty-four.	9.960672236518286
11143. i have already mentioned that mr timothy palmer of newburyport	was the inventor of the arched bridges in this country.	8.99635235659236
11144. as mr	palmer was educated to house-building only and had never seen a	structure of this nature; he certainly deserves not a little credit	for the invention.	6.926837845223069
11145. it is hardly necessary to remind students	of covered bridges that timothy palmer was born in 1751 in nearby	rowley; that he moved with his parents to west boxford when he was	sixteen years old; and was there apprenticed to a builder and architect	moody spofford.	6.215708724206565
11146. it was indeed a remarkable feat that a man	who had had no experience of bridge building should have applied the	principle of the arch which appears in his famous bridges at portsmouth	haverhill and philadelphia.	10.073028627341218
11147. the essex merrimack bridge	when first built was not covered.	8.017896554970152
11148. as far as we know no american	bridge had been thus protected in 1792.	15.235990472843161
11149. richard s allen is the	authority for the statement that the northern section was probably roofed	by 1810.	6.829269573124868
11150. its original appearance is shown in an engraving published	in the massachusetts magazine in may 1793 which is reproduced	herewith.	9.449655455943542
11151. a brief description accompanying the picture	says that the bridge contained more than 6000 tons of timber.	7.098881174869755
11152. between	the abutments on the newbury shore and the south bank of deer island	there was one span or arch measuring 160 feet; between the north	shore of deer island and the salisbury side there was an arch of	113 feet and a series of piers with a draw forty feet long.	7.4692926913677855
11153. a	dinner and celebration in honor of this piece of engineering took place	july 4 1793 in a tavern erected by the corporation on the island.	6.770877702906565
11154. it is said that the eccentric timothy dexter who was one of the	first share-holders stood on the table and made a speech worthy of the	occasion.	16.078387483258286
11155. the essex journal says that he delivered an oration	on the bridge which for elegance of style propriety of speech	or force of argument was truly ciceronian.	6.903145362018988
11156. the reporter must have	written this with tongue in cheek because dexter's oration could	hardly be understood; and although he later explained that he was	talking french it seems rather more likely that he had succumbed to	the joys of the evening.	7.936839040973225
11157. the north portion of the essex bridge	was well worth the cost of construction although it proved to be twice	what was estimated in the beginning.	8.296498812145273
11158. it stood in its original form	until 1882.	14.690671311706694
11159. the southern half however on account of its underbracing	was considered by boat owners a menace to navigation.	8.682139739536685
11160. in 1810 it	was torn down and replaced by a chain suspension bridge.	11.298700654942625
11161. this was built	by john templeman from plans submitted by james finley of fayette	county pennsylvania.	6.826247707528333
11162. timothy palmer had general supervision	of the work.	11.968378813550762
11163. an advertisement in the newburyport herald	december 21 1810 shows palmer in a new light as an expert on chain	bridges.	6.496889634683121
11164. it reads:    information	is hereby given that mr timothy palmer of newburyport mass	has agreed to take charge of the concerns of the patentees of the	chain bridge in the states of massachusetts new hampshire vermont	rhode island and connecticut so far as relates to the sale	of patent rights and the construction of chain bridges.	8.861809260071144
11165. mr	palmer will attend to any applications relating to bridges and if	desired will view the proposed site and lay out and superintend the	work or recommend a suitable person to execute it.	5.65466460919389
11166. john	templeman	approved timothy palmer   this chain bridge proved	less durable than the wooden arch on the salisbury end.	8.417473261688773
11167. it fell	february 6 1827 carrying with it a horse and wagon two men and four	oxen.	9.46125880861461
11168. the horse and men were saved but the oxen drowned.	12.403608862163317
11169. in spite	of this catastrophe the bridge was rebuilt on the same plan and opened	again on july 17 1827.	8.057357162293178
11170. this second chain bridge was 570 feet long	had two thirty-foot towers and a draw and a double roadway.	7.571192621486314
11171. the essex bridge was a toll crossing until 1868 when the county	commissioners laid out all the merrimack bridges as highways.	7.048808567747806
11172. sturdy and strong after more than a century of continuous	use the old covered wooden bridge that spans the tygartis valley river	at philippi will have a distinctive part in the week-long observance	of the first land battle of the civil war at its home site may	28th to june 3rd.	8.44560792587682
11173. colonel frederick w lander impersonated	will again make his break-neck ride down the steep declivity of talbott's	hill and thunder across the bridge to join colonel	benjamin f kelley's virginia infantry then swarming	through the streets in pursuit of the retreating confederates.	4.3744525956680596
11174. he was closely followed by the ohio and indiana troops- thus the	old bridge has another distinction; that of being the first such structure	secured by force of arms in the war of the '60s.	9.431130734604572
11175. the	bridge has survived the natural hazards of the elements war fire	and floods as well as injuries incident to heavy traffic for more than	a hundred years.	6.391964283322843
11176. twice during the civil war it was saved from destruction	by the opposing armies by the pleas and prayers of a local minister.	9.315656602256372
11177. it still stands as a monument to the engineering skills of the	last century and still serves in the gasoline age to carry heavy traffic	on us route 250- the old beverly and fairmont turnpike.	6.754322171654187
11178. it is one of the very few if not the only surviving bridge of	its type to serve a main artery of the us highway system thus	it is far more than a relic of the horse and buggy days.	14.749832181657045
11179. this	covered wooden bridge is so closely identified with the first action	in the early morning of june 3 1861 and with subsequent troop movements	of both armies in the philippi area that it has become a part	and parcel of the war story.	6.576923726747012
11180. so frequently has pictures of the bridge	appeared in books and in national publications that it vies with the	old john brown fort at harpers ferry as the two nationally best known	structures in west virginia.	8.054377263101266
11181. completed and opened for traffic	in 1852 the bridge was designed and built by lemuel chenoweth	and his brother eli of beverly.	6.625603089569415
11182. the chenoweth brothers were experienced	bridge builders and against the competition of other and better	known bridge designers and builders they had constructed nine of	the covered wooden bridges on the parkersburg and staunton turnpike	a dozen years before as well as many other bridges for several counties.	8.144812073675634
11183. the philippi bridge however was the chenoweth master piece	with its 139-foot dual lane span- and it stands today as a monument	to its builders.	4.816844796096808
11184. never rebuilt the bridge was strengtened in 1938	by two extra piers a concrete floor and a walk-way along the upper	side in order to care for modern traffic.	7.716607445570245
11185. during the war it	was in constant use by the wagon trains transporting supplies from the	railhead at grafton to the troops operating in the interior.	7.2337761446162165
11186. union	soldiers at times used it for sleeping quarters to escape from the	rain or other inclement weather and some of them left momentoes of their	stay by carving their names and small tokens on its walls and beams.	8.378498726494946
11187. but what the elements could not do was seriously threatened	when brigadier general william e jones reached philippi	while on the famous jones-imboden raid in may 1863.	6.133230637910327
11188. general	jones was fresh from a long series of bridge burnings including the	long bridge at fairmont and after seeing a great drove of horses	and cattle he had collected safely across the bridge he sent his men	to work piling combustibles in and around it.	8.241503932700974
11189. reverend joshual corder	a baptist minister gathered a few citizens of southern sympathies	to call on jones and plead with him to spare the structure; he	reasoned and argued pointing out that jones or other confederate	commanders would need it should troops pass that way in retreat.	5.380145388359385
11190. jones	relented he did not order his men to apply the torch- the drove of	livestock was driven up the valley via beverly and across the mountains	to feed and serve the confederate army while jones and his raiders	turned toward buckhannon to join forces with imboden.	7.881112093750075
11191. again reverend corder saved the bridge when union soldiers planned	to destroy it after filling its two lanes with hay and straw- but	for what reason is not recorded nor remembered certainly not because	of pressure from an opposing confederate force.	5.005997273110202
11192. on the second occasion	it took prayers as well as reason to dissuade the soldiers from their	purpose.	12.908149098808034
11193. centering around this historic old structure a group	of public-spirited barbour county citizens have organized and planned	a week-long series of events beginning on may 28th and continuing	through june 3rd to observe most appropriately the centennial of	the first land engagement of the civil war at philippi.	5.071085467441831
11194. it is a good eight years now since each of us acquired a swimming	pool- eight enlightening vigorous rigorous not wholly unrewarding	years.	10.66649877577609
11195. we have learned a lot- a dash of hydrochemistry here a	bit about plumbing and pump-priming there.	6.476795783258002
11196. we have had sound grounding	in the principles of the mailed-fist-in-velvet-glove school of diplomacy.	11.087066468733411
11197. we have become amateur insurance experts and fine-feathered yard	birds.	9.54342720190042
11198. true our problems have lessened a bit as more and more of	our neighbors have built their own pools thereby diluting our spectacular	attractions.	8.55662505630191
11199. but problems cling to pools as any pool owner knows.	8.686407604349782
11200. so our innate generosity of spirit prompts us to share our trials	errors and solutions with any who are taking the pool plunge for the	first time- in the pious hope that some may profit from our experience.	7.059894337001546
11201. position may not be everything but in the	case of a pool it can certainly contribute difficulties social andor	physical.	7.687534931867686
11202. we speak from varying viewpoints.	14.823635337782848
11203. one of us has a pool set	in a wooded area very near the house.	11.498852292492336
11204. the other has his pool far away	from the house in a field high on a hill.	12.666694577648569
11205. if you are dreaming	of a blue shimmering pool right outside your living room windows	close your eyes firmly and fill in the picture with lots and lots of	children damp towels squashed tubes of suntan oil and semi-inflated	plastic toys.	6.735788242830129
11206. you are likely to be nearer the truth.	22.86744840002782
11207. you can	also see that the greater the proximity of the pool to your main living	quarters the greater the chance for violation of family privacy annoying	noise and the let's-make-your-house-our-club attitude.	7.539499470099685
11208. on the	other hand out-of-sight does not lead to out-of-mind when children	cannot be easily observed and you have to make a long trek to reach the	pool.	8.973135498435195
11209. another dilemma: as picturesque as a sylvan pond in	the forest may be trees offer a leaf and root hazard to the well-being	of a pool.	4.657491061943809
11210. yet a grassy approach can turn a pool into a floating	lawn every time the grass is mowed.	10.247176909225761
11211. as in choosing a wife it	is only sensible to consider also how appealing a pool is likely to be	in bad weather as well as in good.	8.917588629717672
11212. in the colder climes for instance	you will have to live through the many unglamorous winter months when	your pool will hardly look its best.	10.052684230961363
11213. it may be a big hole in the ground	filled with salt hay or an ice floe studded with logs.	9.705639879405513
11214. even a	neat plastic-covered plunge is not exactly a joy to behold.	9.325663444783128
11215. however recommend those patented covers to prevent both people and junk-	flora and fauna generally- from accidentally wintering in the	probably no location for a pool is perfect on all counts.	4.911550360350286
11216. naturally it will be dictated to a large extent by the shape and	size of your land.	11.411822241309746
11217. but if space and money are no problem and small children	are not on hand every day it is certainly more restful to have	your pool and entertainment area removed from the immediate environs	of the house.	7.626675920808114
11218. and a good several feet around the pool should be neither	greensward nor woods but good hard pavement.	10.237548748968754
11219. the placement	of your pool however will not of itself solve the two major problems	of pool owning- those that involve your social life and those pertaining	to safety.	5.810947226627206
11220. coping with them demands stern discipline- of yourself	as well as of your family neighbors friends and anyone you ever	talked to on a transoceanic jet.	7.234991428742119
11221. eight years ago while we were	going through the mud-sweat-and-tears construction period we were	each solaced by the vision of early morning dips and evening home-comings	to a cool family collected around the pool with a buffet table laid	out nearby for the lord and master's delectation.	5.241726510730063
11222. but not even our	first pool-side	gatherings came anywhere near those rosy fantasies.	9.127075971610656
11223. we seemed to be witnessing the population explosion right in our own	backyards.	9.264482193405822
11224. our respective families looked as if they had quadrupled.	16.497694586175392
11225. had we taken a lien on a state park?	8.780388748394092
11226.  not at all.	18.661861384172425
11227. we had merely been	discovered by the pool sharks.	9.988386609598376
11228. we were in business!   from	proud pool-owners to perpetual hosts and handymen was a short step-	no more than the change from city clothes to trunks.	6.6800337890936206
11229. nai^ve of us	maybe but the results of our impulsive invitations to come over	next summer and swim in our new pool were both unexpected and unsettling.	5.3661947060131965
11230. after the first few weeks it was	obvious that rules had to be made laid down and obeyed- even if our	popularity ratings became subnormal as a result.	9.765519296150382
11231. so rules we made	in unabashed collusion.	8.722357213398215
11232. since our viewpoints in this respect coincided	precisely we present the fruits of our efforts herewith as a single	social code for pool owners.	9.112308631492366
11233. first and foremost: no one-	no not anyone- in the family is allowed to issue blanket invitations	to his or her own circle.	5.407471480854605
11234. just short of forty lashes we finally managed	to coerce our children to this view.	10.352023812101857
11235. their friends and ours are	welcome to share the pool but on our terms and at our times.	7.596729529064301
11236. no friends are to arrive without an invitation or without at least telephoning	beforehand.	10.20845385525708
11237. no ringers either- even if they are trailing	legitimate invitees.	7.299230548718038
11238. we want to know when the potlatches telephone	exactly how many they are planning to bring so that we won't	end up with a splashing mob that looks like coney island in august.	9.897354943023382
11239. no young children may come without adults except for a specific	organized chaperoned party.	7.367621771360785
11240. and accompanying adults are urged to	keep an alert and sensible eye on their responsibilities.	9.658417829832993
11241. a gaggle	of gabbling mothers backs to the pool is no safeguard.	8.4448818734079
11242. no bottle	pool is tolerated- bottle pool being our lingo for those who come	to swim and sink into our bar while protesting that they can only dunk	and run.	7.566825255124856
11243. a beating that first summer as we inadvertently became the neighborhood	we designated one day a week as the time	when neighborhood teen-agers might swim at definite hours.	5.60257713414207
11244. this has	saved us from constant requests seven days a week and made us feel less	brutal to the young less fortunate than ours.	9.514288427341
11245. we also	worked out logistics for sunday afternoon swimmers who arrive two hours	early with their weekend guests while we are still enjoying an alfresco	lunch en famille.	6.176485268232602
11246. we gently usher them to an island of tables	and chairs strategically placed on the far side of the pool where	they can amuse each other until we get ready to merge sides.	10.371736925481745
11247. all	dressing must be done in our small bath	house or at the swimmers' homes.	7.418408887269106
11248. a dripping parade through your house it is a good idea to have a telephone	extension near the pool as well as a direct outdoor route between	we do however provide a limited	number of extra suits mainly for children and we stock extra towels	and a few inexpensive bathing conveniences.	9.049249371979279
11249. life-preservers the buckle-on	kapok-filled kind are held in readiness too for the very young.	4.9930488945649865
11250. safety rules of course are more	important than all the others put together.	9.999584005858374
11251. in many localities	now the law requires all pools to be fenced usually to a minimum	height of 5 feet.	7.24693361190774
11252. but fenced or unfenced no pool-side is the place	for running or horseplay.	7.800082395686388
11253. we allow no underwater endurance contests	either or inexpert versions of water polo.	7.193954340311492
11254. diving boards must	have non-skid surfaces	.	8.355066122739792
11255. and	divers must be enjoined to look before they leap either on top of	someone else or onto a pool edge.	6.133641649916935
11256. our pools also have wide shallow	steps- for the benefit of the littlest swimmers who can thus	be introduced to the water with far greater safety than a ladder affords.	8.98363842972545
11257. all bottles must be kept a safe distance away from the pool	and drinking glasses are banned in favor of plastic or metal cups.	8.081366419144823
11258. when you first acquire a pool we earnestly recommend- for your	own mental health- a good long chat with your insurance agent.	7.514007879785855
11259. you	should be prepared to cope with any pitfall such as plunges into empty	pools or shallow ends and all manner of winter as well as summer lawsuits.	7.354448061288617
11260. soignee pools alas do not just happen.	9.580645468859808
11261. they are the	result of a constant and careful contest with the elements.	8.6951141313511
11262. unless	you want to make your wife a pool widow and to spend a great many of your	leisure hours nursing your pool's pristine purity its care and	feeding- from ph content to filtering and vacuuming- is best left	to a weekly or bi-monthly professional service.	6.029858211296583
11263. of course if your	pool is close to the house your wife can always add it to her housekeeping	chores.	9.845119637992866
11264. or you can make pool care the price of swimming	for teen-agers.	13.329328679854692
11265. even so every pool owner in case of emergency	should have some idea of what makes things work.	9.294008095546058
11266. a brief course in	hydraulics from the pool builders may well be appreciated in a future	crisis.	9.95372590869866
11267. a sudden high rise in temperature	will turn your pool poison green overnight.	6.799637520143752
11268. the	walls feel slippery.	12.265984240023474
11269. with or without professional	help you will have to be able to do some of these jobs yourself	unless you have a full-time pool nurse.	8.906773278436557
11270. you should see to it	that the trap the dirt-catcher in front of the filter is always clean.	10.82263295642374
11271. a pool is no place for a shut trap.	13.624057442085451
11272. you should firmly insist	that no bobby pins or hair pins be worn in the water.	10.195084471132203
11273. when shed	they leave rust marks.	10.291446399425691
11274. you can hope against hope that come spring	cleaning your fair-weather friends will lend a hand at scrubbing	and furbishing.	8.87874668845839
11275. many hours of spring cleaning	will be saved however if you remove the main drain grate when you	close the pool season in the fall.	6.669635707675317
11276. as the pool is emptied stand by	to brush down the walls and bottom while they are still wet.	11.143259556750643
11277. much of	the dirt and leaf stain is easily removed when damp but requires dynamite	if allowed to dry.	6.428405467672415
11278. if you have a 6- to 8-inch drain pipe you may	easily wash out all the debris when the grate is out.	10.632687532735007
11279. of course when	your 6-inch torrent of water is released it may cause a lot of comment	as it passes through or by neighboring properties.	7.296540155605569
11280. do not forget	this possibility.	19.53012386229734
11281. if your pool is located on or near sloping	ground it may have natural drainage which is certainly more desirable	than to be faced with the annual expense and labor of first pumping	out the water and then scooping out all the debris.	7.633113110506477
11282. it may be	true that pool lighting dramatizes an evening scene but lights also attract	all the insect life for miles around.	10.341742024211808
11283. once on the water these	little visitors seldom leave and this adds to your filtering and vacuuming	problems as well as providing a slapping good time for all those	present.	7.689077806660413
11284. often one floodlight high in a tree will provide all the light	you need at much less expense.	8.715081837524904
11285. our experience has taught	us that it pays to buy the best equipment possible from pipes to	brushes.	7.985350163111015
11286. follow pool-care instructions to the letter and be sure that one	person is regularly responsible for each aspect	of the job with no chance for claiming it wasn't my turn.	7.670649649263244
