11288. you may find yourself	hitting bottom literally as you discover that water is running	out even while you are putting it in.	11.419452347301466
11289. draw a line across the country at the latitude of lower pennsylvania.	8.95685168901894
11290. any house built now below that line without air conditioning	will be obsolete in 10 years.	8.1277123384172
11291. fortunately it is the fha	which has arrived at this conclusion for it means that cooling equipment	of all kinds may now be included in a mortgage and thus acquired	with a minimum of financial stress.	7.669144656808273
11292. even if you live above that line	the fha will back you for they have decided that the inclusion	of air conditioning in all new homes is a good thing and should	be encouraged.	10.443724063773795
11293. new simplified packaged units recently devised	prefabricated glass-fiber ducts and improved add-on techniques make	it possible to acquire a system for an 1800-square-foot house for as	little as $600 to $900.	3.880241734384078
11294. two men can often do the installation in a	day.	12.381191237212736
11295. you can install it yourself- this is a central system that will	cool every part of your house.	8.294401265776647
11296. its upkeep?	15.727320716068123
11297.  no less an authority	than the fha concurs that the savings air conditioning makes	possible more than offset its operating costs.	6.2033181022429185
11298. home air conditioning has come a long way from the early days	of overcooled theaters and the thermal shock they inflicted.	10.063121653548562
11299. we know	now that a 15-degree differential in temperature is the maximum usually	desirable and accurate controls assure the comfort we want.	5.962152659938221
11300. we know too that health is never harmed by summer cooling.	12.93159460567062
11301. on the	contrary there are fewer colds and smaller doctor bills.	8.026316816745414
11302. the filtered	air benefits allergies asthma sinus hay fever.	9.336024222416372
11303. control of temperature	and humidity is a godsend to the aged and the invalid.	7.53035030991177
11304. heart conditions	and high blood pressure escape the stresses brought on by oppressive	heat.	9.401693013198285
11305. the cleaner air means	less time spent pushing a vacuum fewer trips to the dry cleaners lighter	loads for the washing machine.	6.567838922172936
11306. the need for reupholstering redecorating	repainting becomes more infrequent.	15.927154112791808
11307. clothes hold their shape	better and mildew and rust become almost forgotten words.	5.671797288860656
11308. it	will improve your disposition.	11.492594054030183
11309. when you're less fatigued things	just naturally look brighter.	5.154409650977491
11310. the children can have their daytime naps	and hot meals and be put to bed on schedule in shade-darkened rooms.	9.636638546027761
11311. you'll sleep longer and better too awake refreshed and free of	hot weather nerves.	3.477492032415083
11312. you can forget about screens and leave the	storm windows up all year around.	11.773163147168555
11313. best of all central air conditioning	is something you can afford.	8.495821768015759
11314. like its long-lived cousin	the refrigerator a conditioner can be expected to last 20 to 25 years	for any	house.	10.168114754619173
11315. colonial	or contemporary central air conditioning is easily installed.	6.764879222886599
11316. the	equipment won't take up valuable space either.	5.908206334943843
11317. it can go in out-of-the-way	waste space.	14.092670991888122
11318. but there's no denying that the easiest	and most economical way to get year-'round whole-house air conditioning	is when you build.	6.262168524033601
11319. if that's done the house can be designed	and oriented for best operation and this can mean savings both in the	size of equipment and in the cost of the house itself.	7.930770788234958
11320. if you	can't see your way clear to have summer cooling included when building	by all means make provision for its easy adding later.	8.027206938310174
11321. manufacturers	have designed equipment for just such circumstances and your	savings over starting from scratch will be substantial.	6.032158094208232
11322. if your	house is to have a forced warm air system cooling can be a part of	it.	13.331586659813423
11323. this costs less than having a completely separate cooling system	for your regular heating ductwork filters and furnace blower do double	duty for cooling.	6.364324054800765
11324. you can get year-'round air conditioners in the	same variety of styles in which you buy a furnace alone- high or	low boy horizontal or counterflow.	8.668715175921758
11325. the units can be installed in basement	attic crawlspace or in a closet located in the living area.	8.89777174384723
11326. the	cooling coil is located in the furnace's outlet.	9.844694143977858
11327. from the coil	small copper pipes connect to a weatherproof refrigeration section set	in the yard garage carport or basement.	6.470838210760854
11328. if you plan to add	cooling later to your heating system there are things to watch for.	13.341611836285596
11329. be sure ducts that require insulation get it when they are installed.	10.856964459003347
11330. they may be inaccessible later.	19.39628569965818
11331. be sure your ducts and blower are	big enough to handle cooling.	9.698621995321433
11332. this is especially important if you	live in a mild-winter zone.	13.44653524746238
11333. be sure you get a perimeter heating system	and diffusers that will work as well for cooling as they do for	heating.	10.322358012230943
11334. you can get a hot water system that will also work	for cooling your house.	12.816089720848101
11335. for cooling chilled water is circulated instead	of hot water.	8.147327343318542
11336. instead of radiators you'll have cooling-heating	units each with its own thermostat.	8.383406378607726
11337. these systems are more expensive	than year-'round forced air systems.	5.627751601242792
11338. the minimum cost for an average	one-story 7-room house with basement is likely to run $1500 above	the cost of the heating alone.	7.48665210984644
11339. if the problems	of combining cooling with your heating are knotty it may be cheaper	to plan on a completely separate cooling system.	7.827712663759115
11340. the simplest kind	of separate system uses a single self-contained unit.	9.30214628480726
11341. it is in effect	an oversize room conditioner equipped with prefab glass-fiber ducts	to distribute the cooled cleaned dehumidified air where it is wanted.	7.439755773634341
11342. in a long rambling ranch two such units can be installed	one serving the living area the other the sleeping zone.	11.87904580752198
11343. in a two-story	house one unit may be installed in the basement to serve the first	floor another in the attic to cool the second.	7.4747055749393665
11344. in each case having	separate systems for living and sleeping areas has the advantage of	permitting individual zone control.	11.520636495484421
11345. one of the	more remarkable of the new cooling systems is one that can be switched	to heating.	11.648675136203755
11346. as you know a conditioner makes indoor air cool by pumping	the heat out of it and then releasing this heat outdoors.	11.025054324523296
11347. a relatively	simple switching arrangement reverses the cycle so that the machine	literally runs backward and the heat is extracted from outdoor air	and turned indoors.	6.122787668976541
11348. up until recently this heat pump method	of warming air was efficient only in areas of mild winters and when	outside temperatures were above 40 degrees.	8.993431781109534
11349. now the machine has been	improved to a point where it is generally more economical than oil heat	at temperatures down to 15 degrees.	8.214528459915138
11350. you can get this added heating	feature for as little as $200 more than the price of cooling alone.	11.441306636248909
11351. consider it as a standby setup at negligible cost for those	emergencies when the furnace quits a blizzard holds up fuel delivery	or for cool summer mornings or evenings when you don't want to start	up your whole heating plant.	4.528000844045936
11352. how large	a cooling unit you need and the method of its installation depends	on a variety of factors.	10.930591421669435
11353. among other things besides the nature of	your house and how much heat finds its way into its various rooms from	the outside it will depend upon your personal habits and the makeup	of your family.	6.912880257109053
11354. families with children usually don't want the house	quite so cool.	5.904049548758775
11355. if you are a party thrower you may need added capacity.	12.75060089011762
11356. the body is a heat machine and 20 to 25 guests can easily double	your cooling load.	11.688171435168899
11357. cooling requirements are best expressed in	terms of btu's.	7.180771917547802
11358. a btu is a unit of heat and the btu	rating of a conditioner refers to how much heat your machine can	pump out of your house in an hour.	11.25769854025079
11359. a very rough rule of thumb is	that under favorable conditions you'll need 15 btu's of cooling	for every square foot of your house.	4.720103665464135
11360. this is if outdoor temperatures	have a high average of 95 degrees.	13.163495056921368
11361. you'll need more if the high	average is above that less if it's below.	2.8985577140810315
11362. coolers are also	rated by tons.	9.767045493978214
11363. a ton of cooling compares to the cooling you get by	melting a ton of ice.	8.489677998990244
11364. by accepted definition a 1-ton conditioner will	provide 12000 btu of cooling in one hour.	7.3757721425498195
11365. you may find	a conditioner rated by horsepower.	11.125791699542013
11366. it is generally an inaccurate	method of rating for the horsepower is that of the compressor motor	and many other components beside it determine how much cooling you'll	get.	11.584766529999659
11367. a 1-hp conditioner for example may vary in effectiveness	from under 8000 btu to well over 10000 btu.	5.4822978439909384
11368. the	safest procedure is to let your builder estimate the size of the unit	you need rather than trying to do this yourself.	13.501501441437322
11369. don't urge	your builder to give you a little extra cooling capacity just to be	sure you have enough.	4.431015841773107
11370. better to have your equipment slightly undersized	than too big.	11.259577169115191
11371. here's why:   reducing humidity is often	as important as cooling.	4.0929230011731645
11372. an oversize unit will cool off your house quickly	then shut down for a long period.	9.717327086340404
11373. before it cycles on again humidity	can build up and make you uncomfortable even though the temperature	is still low.	7.735341460671455
11374. with a unit of the right size a compressor will	run continuously during hot weather reducing humidity as evenly as it	does temperature.	10.254508547786946
11375. attention to details can	cut in half the size unit you need and pare operating expense proportionately.	7.480550219002329
11376. a well-designed 1200-square-foot house can be comfortably cooled	and heated for as little as $128 a year or $11 a month.	6.095294108025461
11377. if you have a house which heat doesn't penetrate easily your unit	will have less heat to remove.	7.664509421141246
11378. keep the direct sun from reaching the	house and you've won the first battle.	7.4203921314622105
11379. in a new house generous roof	overhangs are a logical and effective solution.	9.170798251447678
11380. if the house you plan	to buy or build won't have big overhangs you can still do a fair	job of keeping the sun off walls and windows with properly designed	trellises fences and awnings.	7.696358117452034
11381. shade trees too are a big help	so keep them if you can.	6.952871431378107
11382. drawn blinds and draperies do some good	but not nearly as much as shading devices on the outside of the house.	9.693784383601262
11383. the more directly the sun strikes walls and roof the greater	its heat impact.	7.598615738630121
11384. the way a house is set on its lot can therefore influence	how much cooling you're going to need.	8.566615339521165
11385. a shift in the walls	or a change in the roof slope so the sun hits them more obliquely can	save you money.	7.562664271431654
11386. you can use heat-absorbing glass to stop the	sun double glass and insulated glass to combat condensation.	9.366784934341066
11387. restrict	large glass areas to the north and south sides of the house.	10.154680503484848
11388. they're easier to shade there.	4.337725373418925
11389. an attic space above insulation makes	a house easier to cool.	6.907624005727351
11390. you'll even gain by putting your water	heater outside the conditioned space and using an electric range instead	of a gas one.	5.221215646122266
11391. gas adds to the moisture load.	9.46055656616741
11392. insulate weatherstrip	double-glaze to the maximum.	7.301502449738308
11393. in insulation the numbers to	remember are 6-4-2.	9.491397793894938
11394. they stand for 6 inches of mineral wool insulation	in the ceiling 4 inches in the side walls 2 inches in the floors.	10.454333783533727
11395. such extra-thick insulation not only permits a much smaller cooling	installation but will continue to reduce operating expenses both in	heating and cooling.	5.857907916085916
11396. a light-colored roof will reduce sun heat by 50	per cent.	7.460214546543613
11397. it costs two to three times as much to remove a btu	in summer as it does to add one in winter so every solitary btu	is worth attention.	10.984015973307867
11398. you'll foil them in droves along with	their pal humidity by having and using a kitchen range exhaust fan a	bathroom ventilator for when you shower and an outside vent for the	clothes drier.	5.585070771027719
11399. it's no use pretending	that all conditioners are quiet but the noise they produce can	be kept to a minimum.	3.472055081000831
11400. good workmanship is important in the installation	so if you're doing your own contracting don't award the job on	the basis of price alone.	5.757845967413763
11401. avoid attic placement directly above	a bedroom.	7.1673655525822255
11402. most recreation work calls for a good deal of pre-planning.	16.405818908877226
11403. this is particularly true in site selection.	19.722302242193802
11404. you must know before	you start what the needs and objectives of your organtion are; you	must have a list of requirements on where how many and what type sites	are needed.	8.95140025577598
11405. with such a program you can make constructive selections	of the best sites available.	10.216934575356479
11406. begin the examination of a site	with a good map and aerial photos if possible.	8.66276398957266
11407. these are becoming more	and more available through the work of counties and other government	agencies.	8.703971803203531
11408. the new editions of topographic maps being made by the federal	government are excellent for orienting yourself to the natural	features of the site.	9.522644603142966
11409. these are inexpensive and available from the u	s geological society washington 25 d c.	8.065106262641178
11410. in recent	years many counties and the u s forest service have taken	aerial photos which show features in detail and are very good for planning	use.	13.87675364973916
11411. most counties also have maps available from the county engineer	showing roads and other features and from the assessor's office	showing ownerships of land.	6.0737674869385945
11412. inspect the site in the field during	the time of the year when the area will be most heavily used for	recreation.	12.83528214823985
11413. this gives you a better opportunity to get the feel of the	climate conditions the exposure to the sun and wind the water interests	etcetera which vary greatly with the seasons.	9.736802783461721
11414. it is usually helpful	to make a sketch map in the field showing the size and location	of the features of interest and to take photographs at the site.	13.282415649426303
11415. these	are a great aid for planning use back at the office.	8.471715064636808
11416. for	site planning work it is best to have a qualified and experienced	park planner to carry through the study.	8.827327885778846
11417. however there is also much	to be gained by making use of the abilities of the local people who are	available and interested in recreation.	9.00429830606533
11418. county judges commissioners	engineers assessors and others who have lived in the area for a	long time may have valuable knowledge regarding the site or opinions	to offer from their varied professional experiences.	8.918798945012956
11419. a visit to the site	by a group of several persons can usually bring out new ideas or verify	opinions most helpful to the planning study of any recreation area.	7.91349358606095
11420. how much study is required?	17.211968261319605
11421.  this of course depends on	the character of the site itself the previous experience of the investigator	and the number of factors needed to arrive at a good decision.	9.191989430451798
11422. it is too easy for the inexperienced person to make a quick	judgment	of a few values of the area and base a decision on these alone.	14.347435846828786
11423. usually	there are more factors to good site planning than first impressions.	6.45181421218818
11424. a site may be a rundown slum or a desolate piece of desert in appearance	today but have excellent potentials for the future with a little	development or water.	10.510319823187638
11425. the same is true of areas which at first look	good because of a few existing recreation features but may actually	be poor areas to develop for general public use.	7.845151152526667
11426. in looking for	the best sites available that meet the requirements you need information	to compare the site with others.	11.2088193624096
11427. you need answers to four important	questions.	13.948458058628606
11428. what are the existing recreation features?	16.310556249056432
11429. 	how well can the site be developed?	9.024343481021429
11430.     how useful	will it be to the public?	14.089915416946118
11431.     is this site available?	14.341652019190805
11432. 	check the quantity and quality of all of the recreation interests	already existing at the site.	11.22291038533031
11433. naturally a park site with scenic	views a good lake trees and sand dunes will attract more people	than a nearby area with only trees and dunes.	5.871512691175231
11434. frontage on a body of clear clean water will be vastly different	from the same amount of frontage on polluted water.	8.891610019520112
11435. some recreation	features such as scenic values and water interest also have greater	overall value than other interests.	7.111850315586481
11436. one of the most desirable	features for a park are beautiful views or scenery.	15.415345297323084
11437. it may be distant	views of a valley or the mountains or natural features such as a	small lake colorful rock formations or unusual trees.	7.4116347961332885
11438. a site which	overlooks a harbor or river may offer interest in the activities of boating	traffic.	10.569673742810908
11439. an area on the coast may have relaxing views of the surf	rolling in on a beach.	8.722562660567014
11440. a site may also be attractive just through	the beauty of its trees and shrubs.	12.024784188144336
11441. note extent of these interests and	how available they will be for the public to enjoy.	9.445084654569609
11442. water interest	is one of the most valuable factors you can find for a recreation	site.	13.728535661319896
11443. most park planners look to water frontage for basic park areas.	7.36507716396973
11444. this follows naturally since frontage on an ocean stream or lake	provides scenic values and opportunities for the very popular recreation	activities of bathing fishing boating and other water sports.	8.459545213511008
11445. a body of water is usually the center of interest at parks which attract	the greatest picnic and camping use.	8.574217469817109
11446. it also cools the air in summer	and nourishes the trees and wild life.	11.887561652899699
11447. the amount of water	frontage the quantity and quality of the water and the recreation	afforded by it are important.	12.63168277321969
11448. a restricted frontage may be too crowded	an area for public use.	10.441628758521093
11449. the quantity of water flow may be critical;	a stream or pond which is attractive in the springtime may become stagnant	or dry in late summer.	6.460230664984924
11450. if the site is on a reservoir the level	of the water at various seasons as it affects recreation should be	studied.	10.86872488123029
11451. check the quality of the water.	15.541436812886294
11452. a stream which has all of	its watershed within a national forest or other lands under good conservation	practices is less likely to be affected by pollution than one	passing through unrestricted logging or past an industrial area.	7.840495154363458
11453. other	factors such as water temperature depth of water the fish life it	supports wave action flooding etcetera will affect its recreation	value.	6.554565467195275
11454. other natural features which can be of high interest	are the forests canyons mountains deserts seacoast beaches sand	dunes waterfalls springs etcetera with which the area is blessed.	8.638762734448923
11455. just as the national and state parks place emphasis on features which	are of national or state significance counties should seek out these	features which are distinctive of their area.	6.804948297357682
11456. although the site may	not contain the features themselves there are often opportunities	to include them as additional interest to the site.	9.935728841103746
11457. the route to the	park may lead people past them or display views of them.	7.581495412677564
11458. a group of	native trees or plants which are outstanding in a particular county can	be featured at the site.	10.815059385462762
11459. the fish animals and birds which	may be found at the site are another interest.	8.621813113015527
11460. fishing interest calls	for a check of the species found quantity and size the season they	are available and the stocking program of the fish commission.	9.011723010929323
11461. animals	may be present at the site or provide hunting in nearby areas.	8.033524034810945
11462. the	site may be on one of the major flyways of migratory birds or have its	own resident bird life.	9.74570812080977
11463. clams crabs and other marine life may add	interest at coastal areas.	5.853593402493078
11464. each area has its own historical	interests with which much can be done.	10.011609782695569
11465. park visitors are always	eager to learn more about the area they are in.	7.302040930491485
11466. the historical sign	tells its story but nothing gets interest across as well as some of the	original historical items or places themselves which still have the	character of the period covered.	8.86227496731846
11467. notice should be taken of unusual rock	formations deposits or shapes of the earth's crust in your region.	4.690844548285937
11468. those which tell a story of the earth's formation in each area	can add geological interest to the recreation sites.	7.672801602627098
11469. an old shipwreck	a high dam an old covered bridge a place to find agates or other	semi-precious stones or a place to pan gold etcetera may be of interest.	6.419857592943815
11470. some areas may provide archeological values such as ancient indian	village sites or hunting areas caves artifacts etcetera.	8.629180231462758
11471. how well can the site be developed?	14.07763186845369
11472.  look at the physical features	of the land to determine how desirable it is for use what can be done	to correct the faults and what it will cost to make the area meet your	needs in comparison to other sites.	10.622402530694313
11473. many things need to be checked:	- the size of the area alone can be a determining	factor.	9.292449422119459
11474. an area may be too small for the needs of the project.	16.54916118226389
11475. areas should be large enough to include the attractions have ample	space for the use of facilities needed and have room around the edges	to protect the values of the area from encroachment by private developments.	7.381818264661491
11476. acreage in excess of the minimum is good practice as recreation	areas are never too large for the future and it is often more economical	to operate one large area than several small ones.	9.376049200422623
11477. shape	of the area is also related to the use attractions and needs of the	development.	10.185496087576757
11478. a large picnic area or camping development is most efficient	in shape as a square or rectangle several hundred feet in width	in preference to a long narrow area less than one hundred feet wide.	9.172785604075855
11479. this	is true because of savings in utility lines and the fact that your	buildings have a useful radius equal in all directions.	8.476098484412477
11480. however a	narrow strip may be very practical for small developments or to provide	additional stream frontage for a fisherman's trail or include	scenic strips within the park unit.	7.161690913468711
11481. the values	of the site may be affected by the appearance of the adjoining lands	ownership and use of the land and the utilities available there.	10.483879824648543
11482. for	instance a site adjoining other publicly owned lands such as a national	forest or a public road may be desirable whereas a site next	to an industrial plant might not.	7.507372769408346
11483. the utilities available nearby may	provide a savings in the cost of extending electricity or water to the	site.	8.55415951862704
11484. check the	elevation of the ground degree and direction of slopes drainage rock	outcrops topsoil types and quality as well as subsoil.	10.213522592750815
11485. nearly level	areas are required for parking areas beaches camp areas ballfields	etcetera.	7.498354763670716
11486. determine how much topography limits useful area or what	the costs of earth moving or grading might be.	8.471486610153597
11487. in addition	to its recreation interests water is needed for drinking sanitation	and irrigation.	8.903131336700795
11488. the quantity and quality of water sources is	often a big factor in site selection.	13.592981506965181
11489. the area may provide good springs	or opportunities for a well or be near to municipal water lines.	7.723099737962258
11490. figure	the cost of providing water to the use areas.	14.197923038250284
11491. the	existing plant growth calls for thorough checking.	7.055645074560738
11492. look at the trees	as to size and interest the amount of shade they provide how healthy	they are the problems of maintenance fire hazards wind throw	etcetera.	11.335962798300326
11493. an area may have been partially logged and requires	removal of stumps or clean up.	7.695749341174242
11494. some shrubs may be of good landscaping	value other areas of brush may need to be cleared.	11.83164327499136
11495. the extent and location	of open areas is noted.	8.834162566462092
11496. how much will wind	rain sun and temperature affect the use?	12.718354378433888
11497.  an area sheltered from	strong winds may be highly desirable for recreation use.	7.6047767577575245
11498. the direction	velocity and season of these winds should be noted as to just how	they will affect the recreation use and your maintenance and operation	of the area.	8.892862365069059
11499. lack of rainfall and extreme temperatures may call for	the development of shade and irrigation of a site to make it useable.	7.077122188833746
11500. sometimes you have a choice of exposure for sites where the topography	or trees of the area will provide afternoon shade morning sun or	whatever may be most desirable for the use intended.	10.342212941202554
11501. some areas may already have been improved and contain buildings	roads utilities cleared land etcetera which may raise the cost of	the site.	6.892948799567953
11502. your invitation to write about serge prokofieff to honor his	70th anniversary for the april issue of sovietskaya muzyka is	accepted with pleasure because i admire the music of prokofieff;	and with sober purpose because the development of prokofieff personifies	in many ways the course of music in the union of soviet socialist	republics.	8.902362826187279
11503. the serge prokofieff whom we knew in the	united states of america was gay witty mercurial full of pranks	and bonheur- and very capable as a professional musician.	6.68079750672967
11504. these	qualities endeared him to both the musicians and the social-economic	haute monde which supported the concert world of the post-world	war 1 era.	7.314828612794722
11505. prokofieff's outlook as a composer-pianist-conductor	in america was indeed brilliant.	3.787445116474157
11506. prokofieff's classical	symphony was hailed as an ingenious work from a naturally gifted	and well-trained musician still in his twenties.	5.397475294060526
11507. to the traditionalists	it was a brilliant satire on modernism; to the neo-classicists	it was a challenge to the pre-war world.	5.285196681522154
11508. what was it to prokofieff?	18.917828876225062
11509. 	a tongue-in-cheek stylization of 18th-century ideas; a trial	balloon to test the aesthetic climate of the times; a brilliant piece	de resistance?	3.9337787769301493
11510.  certainly its composer was an ascending star	on a new world horizon.	10.039084769063722
11511. i heard the classical symphony	for the first time when koussevitzky conducted it in paris in 1927.	9.426771667152282
11512. all musical paris was there.	12.980836019012205
11513. some musicians were enthusiastic some	skeptical.	9.263014042298078
11514. i myself was one of the skeptics.	22.72096933022323
11515. i remember	ernest bloch in the foyer shouting in his high-pitched voice:	h it may be a tour de force mais mon dieu can anyone take	this music seriously?	5.399978000585383
11516.    the answer is yes! certainly	america took prokofieff and his classical symphony seriously	and with a good deal of pleasure.	10.810864598440904
11517. his life-long friend serge	koussevitzky gave unreservedly of his praise and brilliant performances	in boston new york and washington d c to which	he added broadcastings and recordings for the whole nation.	5.609387467872988
11518. chicago was	also a welcome host: there in 1921 prokofieff conducted the world	premiere of the love for three oranges and played the first	performance of his third piano concerto.	7.56358358880533
11519. uncle sam was indeed	a rich uncle to prokofieff in those opulent post-war victory	years of peace and prosperity bold speculations and extravaganzas enjoyment	and pleasure: the golden twenties.	4.750748298336193
11520. we attended the	premieres of his concertos symphonies and suites; we studied taught	and performed his piano sonatas chamber music gavottes and marches;	we bought his records and played them in our schools and universities.	6.444284604657824
11521. we unanimously agreed that prokofieff had won his rights as	a world citizen to the first ranks of twentieth-century composers.	6.890842654396754
11522. nevertheless prokofieff was much influenced by paris during	the twenties: the paris which was the artistic center of the western	world- the social paris to which russian aristocracy migrated-	the chic paris which attracted the tourist dollars of rich	america- the avant-garde paris of diaghileff stravinsky koussevitzky	cocteau picasso- the laissez-faire paris of dadaism	and ultramodern art- the paris sympathique which took young	composers to her bosom with such quick and easy enthusiasms.	4.992905999741024
11523. so young prokofieff was the darling of success: in his motherland;	in the spacious hunting grounds of uncle sam; in the exciting	salons of his lovely brilliant paris- mistress of gaiety-	excess and abandon- world theatre of new-found freedoms in tone color	dance design and thought.	3.4274971428374763
11524. meanwhile three great terrible	forces were coagulating and crystallizing.	8.71273728989673
11525. in this world-wide conscription	of men minds and machines prokofieff was recalled to his	native land.	6.649524632289013
11526. the world exploded when fascism challenged all concepts	of peace and liberty and the outraged freedom-loving peoples of the	capitalist and socialist worlds combined forces to stamp fascist	tyranny into cringing submission.	7.478342672974812
11527. after this holocaust a changing world	occupied the minds of men; a world beset with new boundaries new	treaties and governments new goals and methods and the age-old fears	of aggression	and subjugation- hunger and exposure.	4.698298972235039
11528. in this	changed world prokofieff settled to find himself and to create	for	large national purpose.	10.888214727918815
11529. here this happy roving son of good fortune	proved that he could accept the disciplines of a new social-economic	order fighting for its very existence and ideals in a truculent world.	6.10302223857407
11530. here prokofieff became a workman in the vineyards of socialism-	producing music for the masses.	8.139760251525631
11531. it is at this point in his life	that the mature prokofieff emerges.	14.02078739881337
11532. one might have expected that	such a violent epoch of transition would have destroyed the creative	flair of a composer especially one whose works were so fluent and spontaneous.	8.929141141186872
11533. he accepted the environment	of his destiny- took root and grew to fulfill the stature of his	early promise.	6.0501555389590616
11534. by 1937 he had clarified his intentions to serve his	people: i have striven for clarity and melodious idiom but at	the same time i have by no means attempted to restrict myself to the	accepted methods of harmony and melody.	7.811348441945676
11535. this is precisely what makes	lucid straightforward music so difficult to compose- the clarity must	be new not old.	8.204355488204788
11536. how right he was; how clearly he saw the cultural	defection of experimentation as an escape for those who dare not	or prefer not to face the discipline of modern traditionalism.	8.516637191398388
11537. and	with what resource did prokofieff back up his credo of words- with	torrents of powerful music.	4.847807438765485
11538. compare the vast difference in scope and	beauty between his neat and witty little classical symphony and	his big muscular passionate and eloquent fifth symphony; or the	love for three oranges with the wonderful imaginative	colorful and subtle tenderness of the magnificent ballet	the stone flower.	6.47320442226088
11539. this masterpiece has gaiety too but it is	the gaiety of dancing people: earthy salty and humorous.	5.708255688591327
11540. of	course these works are not comparable even though the same brain conceived	them.	10.149042872108753
11541. the early works were conceived for a sophisticated international	audience; the later works were conceived to affirm a way	of life for fellow citizens.	6.116846672164655
11542. however in all of prokofieff's music	young or mature we find his profile- his signature- his	craftsman's attitude.	7.194406483955268
11543. prokofieff never forsakes his medium for the	cause of experimentation per se.	7.1636185618841
11544. in orchestration he stretches	the limits of instrumentation with good judgment and a fine imagination	for color.	9.821740895362382
11545. his sense for rhythmic variety and timing is impeccable.	8.829218874480027
11546. his creative development of melodic designs of slavic dance tunes and	love songs is captivating: witty clever adroit and subtle.	6.640065341645458
11547. his	counterpoint is pertinent skillful and rarely thick.	6.423596493322134
11548. also	it should be noted that the polytonal freedom of his melodies and harmonic	modulations the brilliant orchestrations the adroitness for evading	the heaviness of figured bass the skill in florid counterpoint	were not lost in his mature output even in the spectacular historical	dramas of the stage and cinema where a large dramatic canvas of sound	was required.	7.453402588198324
11549. that prokofieff's harmonies and forms sometimes	seem professionally routine to our ears may or may not indicate that	he was less of an original than we prefer to believe.	6.097103104929036
11550. need for	novelty may be a symptom of cultural fatigue and instability.	10.244019922546958
11551. prokofieff might well emerge as a cultural hero who by the force of	his creative life helped preserve the main stream of tradition to which	the surviving idioms of current experimentalism may be eventually	added and integrated.	5.75818412488491
11552. at this date it seems probable that the	name of serge prokofieff will appear in the archives of history	as an effective traditionalist who was fully aware of the lure and danger	of experimentation and used it as it served his purpose; yet	was never caught up in it- never a slave to its academic dialectics.	8.059107866256392
11553. certainly it is the traditional clarity of his music which has endeared	him to the western world- not his experimentations.	7.09926976924672
11554. so	prokofieff was able to cultivate his musical talents and harvest a	rich reward from them.	8.583119537212172
11555. nor can anyone be certain that prokofieff would	have done better or even as well under different circumstances.	8.247333656679581
11556. his fellow-countryman igor stravinsky certainly did not.	7.5237794580318305
11557. why did	prokofieff expand in stature and fecundity while stravinsky	dwindled in stature and fruitfulness?	7.3484600885705085
11558. 	i think the answer is to be found in prokofieff's own words:	the clarity must be new not old.	8.890939688270322
11559. when prokofieff forged his	new clarity of lucid straightforward music so difficult to compose	he shaped his talents to his purpose.	6.885708888431767
11560. when stravinsky	shaped his purpose to the shifting scenes of many cultures many salons	many dialectics many personalities he tried to refashion himself	into a stylist of many styles determined by many disparate cultures.	8.457995829331361
11561. prokofieff was guided in a consistent direction by the life of his own	people- by the compass of their national ideas.	6.636975423916419
11562. but stravinsky	was swayed by the attitudes of whatever culture he was reflecting.	11.800651779321926
11563. in	all his miscalculations stravinsky made the fatal historical blunder	of presuming that he could transform other composers' inspirations-	representing many peoples time periods and styles- into his own	music by warping the harmony melody or form to verify his own experiments.	4.27843969406169
11564. because of the authentic homogeneity of his early nationalistic	materials and his flair for orchestrations- his brilliant petruchka	his savage sacre du printemps his incisive les noces-	the world kept hoping that he could recapture the historical	direction for which his native talents were predisposed.	6.952907077358112
11565. but	time is running out and many of stravinsky's admirers begin to fear	that he will never find terra firma.	6.097125070642065
11566. his various aesthetic postulates	remain as landmarks of a house divided against itself: supra-expressionism	neo-paganism neo-classicism neo-romanticism	neo-jazz neo-ecclesiasticism neo-popularism and most recently	post-serialism- all competing with each other within one composer!	what a patchwork of proclamations and renunciations! meager	and shabby by-products linger to haunt our memories of a once mighty	protagonist;	a maladroit reharmonization of our national anthem	; a poor attempt to write an idiomatic	jazz concerto; a circus polka for elephants; his hopes that the tunes	from his old music might be used for popular american commercial	songs! stravinsky nearing the age of eighty is like a lost and frantic	bird flitting from one abandoned nest to another searching for	a home.	4.816182728071108
11567. how differently prokofieff's life unfolded.	6.969186143231706
11568. prokofieff	was able to adjust his creative personality to a swiftly changing	world without losing his particular force and direction.	7.747935432120883
11569. in the process	his native endowments were stretched strengthened and disciplined	to serve their human purpose.	7.264201914698264
11570. with a large and circumspect	20th-century technique he wove the materials of national heroes and	events national folklore and children's fairy tales- slavic dances	and love songs- into a solid musical literature which served his	people well and is providing much enjoyment to the world at large.	6.646889421253714
11571. of course it must not be forgotten that in achieving this historical	feat prokofieff had the vast resources of his people behind	him; time and economic security; symphony orchestras opera and ballet	companies; choruses chamber music ensembles; soloists; recordings;	broadcastings; television; large and eager audiences.	4.779736425060124
11572. it	must be conceded that his native land provided prokofieff with many	of the necessary conditions for great creative incentive: economic	security and cultural opportunities incisive idioms social fermentations	for a new national ideology- a sympathetic public and a large	body of performers especially trained to fulfill his purpose.	6.22511645873915
11573. thus	in prokofieff the union of soviet socialist republics produced	one of the great composers of the twentieth century.	7.94798303614954
11574. that his moods	even in his early years are those of his people does him honor	as his music honors those who inspired it.	10.663023839680891
11575. that he mastered every aspect	of his medium according to his own great talents and contemporary	judgments is a good and solid symbol of his people under the tremendous	pressures of proclaiming and practising the rigors of a new culture;	and perhaps of even greater significance- his music is strong 20th-century	evidence of the effectiveness of evolution based on a broad	traditionalism for the creative art of music.	5.886883077280041
11576. april 10 marked a memorable date in new york's musical history-	indeed in the musical history of the entire eastern united states.	6.904019308038909
11577. on that date the musicians emergency fund organized to furnish	employment for musicians unable to obtain engagements during the	depression and to provide relief for older musicians who lost their fortunes	in the stock market crash observed its 30th anniversary.	6.250230592621083
11578. roy mason is essentially a landscape painter whose style and direction	has a kinship with the english watercolorists of the early nineteenth	century especially the beautifully patterned art of john sell	cotman.	7.7206471608473946
11579. and like this english master mason realizes his subjects	in large simplified masses which though they seem effortless are	in reality the result of skilled design born of hard work and a thorough	distillation of the natural form that inspired them.	6.3320192295282975
11580. as a	boy roy mason began the long process of extracting the goodness of the	out-of-doors its tang of weather its change of seasons its variable	moods.	7.5052395336512
11581. his father a professional engraver and an amateur landscape	painter took his sons on numerous hunting expeditions and imparted	to them his knowledge and love of nature.	5.973873113439632
11582. out of this background of	hunting and fishing it was only natural that roy first painted subjects	he knew best: hunters in the field fishermen in the stream ducks	and geese on the wing- almost always against a vast backdrop of	weather landscape.	7.870071863460686
11583. it is this subject matter that has brought mason	a large and enthusiastic following among sportsmen but it is his exceptional	performance with this motif that commends him to artists and	discerning collectors.	8.402233452572704
11584. mason had to earn the privilege of devoting	himself exclusively to painting.	10.205749539013603
11585. like many others he had to work	hard long hours in a struggling family business which though it was	allied to art of a kind- the design and production of engraved seals-	bore no relation to the painting of pictures.	5.963399370138889
11586. but it did teach	roy the basic techniques of commercial art and later for twelve years	he and his sister nina conducted an advertising art studio in philadelphia.	10.074565460799361
11587. on the death of their father they returned to their home	in batavia new york.	11.205306439852077
11588. after more years of concentrated effort roy	and his brother max finally established a thriving family business	at the old stand.	8.643539292843652
11589. during all this time roy continued to paint	first only on weekends and then as the family business permitted	for longer periods.	8.12205110741798
11590. gradually he withdrew from the shop altogether	and for the past thirty years he has worked independently as a painter	except for his continued hunting and fishing expeditions.	9.089411854399202
11591. but even	on these the palette often takes over while the shotgun cools off!	except for a rich friendship with the painter chauncey ryder	who gave him the only professional instruction he ever had- and	this was limited to a few lessons though the two artists often went on	painting trips together- roy developed his art by himself.	5.354808637166108
11592. in the	best tradition he first taught himself to see then to draw with accuracy	and assurance and then to paint.	10.040191950254359
11593. he worked in oil for years before	beginning his work in watercolor and his first public recognition	and early honors including his election to the academy were for	his essays in the heavier medium.	6.99870063427404
11594. gradually watercolor claimed his greater	affection until today it has become his major if not exclusive	technique.	9.053183725365573
11595. it has been my privilege to paint with roy mason	on numerous occasions mostly in the vicinity of batavia.	9.273122983927324
11596. more often	than not i have found easy excuse to leave my own work and stand at	a respectable distance where i could watch this man transform raw nature	into a composed not imitative painting.	8.365743524277743
11597. what i have observed	time and time again is a process of integration integration that begins	as abstract design and gradually takes on recognizable form; color	patterns that are made to weave throughout the whole composition;	and that over-all amazing control of large washes which is the mason	stylemark.	5.559184158038535
11598. finally come those little flicks of a rigger brush and the	job is done.	8.694855816283743
11599. inspiring- yes; instructive- maybe; duplicable-	no!   but for the technical fact we have the artist's	own testimony:   of late years i find that i like best to	work out-of-doors.	4.42086511825777
11600. first i make preliminary watercolor sketches in	quarter scale in which i pay particular attention	to the design principles of three simple values- the lightest	light the middle tone and the darkest dark- by reducing the forms	of my subject to these large patterns.	6.86960508183774
11601. if a human figure or wild life	are to be part of the projected final picture i try to place them	in the initial sketch.	8.927393412798313
11602. for me these will belong more completely to	their surroundings if they are conceived in this early stage though	i freely admit that i do not hesitate to add or eliminate figures on	the full sheet when it serves my final purpose.	9.049223808946739
11603. i am thoroughly	convinced that most watercolors suffer because the artist expects	nature will do his composing for him; as a result such pictures are	only a literal translation of what the artist finds in the scene before	him.	6.617449349933477
11604. just because a tree or other object appears in a certain spot	is absolutely no reason to place it in the same position in the painting	unless the position serves the design of the whole composition.	11.471366966380018
11605. if the artist would study his work more thoroughly and move certain	units in his design often only slightly finer pictures would result.	7.012141160478479
11606. out of long experience i have found that incidental figures and other	objects like trees logs and bushes can be traced from the original	sketch and moved about in the major areas on the final sheet until they	occupy the right position which i call 'clicking'.	9.197712656264027
11607. speed	in painting a picture is valid only when it imparts spontaneity	and crispness but unless the artist has lots of experience so that	he can control rapid execution he would do well to take these first sketches	and soberly reorder their design to achieve a unified composition.	6.525661035736554
11608. if i have seemed to emphasize the structure of the composition	i mean to project equal concern for color.	15.461540291699773
11609. often in working	out-of-doors under all conditions of light and atmosphere a particular	passage that looked favorable in relation to the subject will be	too bright too dull or too light or too dark when viewed indoors in	a mat.	5.992922039326174
11610. when this occurs i make the change on the sketch or on the	final watercolor- if i have been working on a full sheet in the field.	10.602935338888146
11611. when working from one of my sketches i square it up and	project its linear form freehand to the watercolor sheet with charcoal.	7.179088892625825
11612. when this linear draft is completed i dust it down to a faint	image.	14.022655604193675
11613. from this point i paint in as direct a manner as possible by	flowing on the washes with as pure a color mixture as i can manage.	8.056682766352548
11614. however first	i thoughtfully study my sketch for improvement of color and	design along the lines i have described.	9.031244823159838
11615. then i plan my attack:	the parts i will finish first the range of values the accenting of	minor details- all in all mechanics of producing the finished job	with a maximum of crispness.	5.7582937681637505
11616. the longer i work the more i am sure	that for me at least a workmanlike method is important.	11.212272763131391
11617. trial and	error are better placed in the preliminary sketch than in hoping for miracles	in the final painting.	6.3967327374280964
11618. as for materials i use the	best available.	14.813692732433264
11619. i work on a watercolor easel in the field and frequently	resort to a large garden umbrella to protect my eyes from undue	strain.	8.754454952923586
11620. in my studio i work at a tilt-top table but leave the paper	unfixed so that i can move it freely to control the washes.	10.226729755943992
11621. i have	used a variety of heavy-weight hand-made papers but prefer an english	make rough surface in 400-pound weight.	5.159991228485744
11622. after selecting a sheet	and inspecting it for flaws	i sponge it thoroughly on both sides with	clean cold water.	9.534373302497102
11623. then i dry the sheet under mild pressure so that	it will lie flat as a board.	6.813492156386593
11624. in addition to the usual tools	i make constant use of cleansing tissue not only to wipe my brushes	but to mop up certain areas to soften edges and to open up lights	in dark washes.	9.81961589295466
11625. the great absorbency of this tissue and the fact that	it is easier to control than a sponge makes it an ideal tool for the	watercolorist.	8.222794120543346
11626. i also use a small electric hand-blower to dry large	washes in the studio.	8.582731795976107
11627. my brushes are different from those used	by most watercolorists for i combine the sable and the bristle.	6.214568438256692
11628. the	red sables are 8; two riggers 6 and 10; and a very large	flat wash brush.	5.374616731086403
11629. the bristles are a fitch 2 and a one-half	inch brush shaved to a sharp chisel edge.	5.998860329965599
11630. my usual palette	consists of top-quality colors: alizarin crimson orange raw sienna	raw umber burnt sienna sepia cerulean blue cobalt blue french	ultramarine blue winsor green hooker's green 2 cadmium yellow	pale yellow ochre payne's gray charcoal gray davy's gray	and ivory black.	4.177452067307183
11631. in analyzing the watercolors of roy mason	the first thing that comes to mind is their essential decorativeness	yet this word has such a varied connotation that it needs some elaboration	here.	6.769850272137206
11632. true a mason watercolor is unmistakably a synthesis	of nature rather than a detailed inventory.	9.146940610365853
11633. unlike many decorative patterns	that present a static flat convention this artist's pictures	are full of atmosphere and climate.	4.8416054169811575
11634. long observation has taught	mason that most landscape can be reduced to three essential planes:	a foreground in sharp focus- either a light area with dark accents	or a dark one with lights; a middle distance often containing the	major motif; and a background usually a silhouetted form foiled against	the sky.	5.743743088516392
11635. in following this general principle mason provides the	observer with a natural eye progression from foreground to background	and the illusion of depth is instantly created.	6.191665384096586
11636. when painting	mason's physical eyes are half-closed while his mind's eye	is wide open and this circumstance accounts in part for the impression	he wishes to convey.	6.46679416670444
11637. he does not insist on telling all he knows about	any given subject; rather his pictures invite the observer to draw	on his memory his imagination his nostalgia.	6.239826072151669
11638. it is for this	reason that roy avoids selecting subjects that require specific recognition	of place for their enjoyment.	11.699510487186688
11639. his pictures generalize though	they are inspired by a particular locale; they universalize in terms	of weather skies earth and people.	5.429193153591706
11640. by dealing with common landscape	in an uncommon way roy mason has found a particular niche in american	landscape art.	8.573475354143303
11641. living with his watercolors is a vicarious experience	of seeing nature distilled through the eyes of a sensitive interpretor	a breath and breadth of the outdoor world to help man honor	the creator of it all.	6.749460118133521
11642. the artist was born in gilbert mills	new york in 1886 and until two years ago when he and his wife moved	to california he lived in western new york in batavia.	12.302732285809412

11646. the russian gymnasts beat the tar out of the american gymnasts	in the 1960 olympics for one reason- they were better.	8.255301767498075

11665. in most sports as in most walks of life the angels are on the side	of those who begin young and the russian competitor of 16 has at	least thirteen years of training behind him.	7.942750114589131
