11692. even the boys will not be outstanding in these areas.	14.33728886000341
11693. this isn't surprising when we consider that over 29 percent of	the 11-year-old boys in america cannot chin themselves once and	that english school girls outdo them in almost every test	.	5.040400153446636
11694. the only area in which american boys hold their own	is the baseball throw.	11.88011122844858
11695. for arm and shoulder	strength a chinning bar is recommended.	7.56775390766206
11696. it should be installed over	a door that is in full view of everyone and a chair should be placed	under it a little to one side.	13.323132857846257
11697. those children who can chin themselves	should be told to do one chin up each time they pass under it.	6.848287043146984
11698. those who are too weak should climb on the chair and starting at the	top of the chin let themselves slowly down.	10.598186096036457
11699. when they can take	ten seconds to accomplish the descent they will have the strength to	chin up.	10.07233383494878
11700. parents should be informed about this system and encouraged	to do the same with the whole family at home.	10.808576274221227
11701. arm shoulder chest upper and lower back strength will be aided with	the horse kick.	6.0620027385806265
11702. start on hands and feet.	20.67117578745527
11703. keeping the hands in	the starting position run in place to a quick rhythm.	7.810054793545074
11704. after this has	become easy use slower and slower rhythms kicking higher and higher.	9.998901716294466
11705. follow this by crossing from one corner of the room to the other on	all fours kicking as high as possible.	8.83236870088105
11706. push-ups are	essential but few have the strength for them at first.	9.16336513625844
11707. start on the	knees in a large circle.	12.162049630791904
11708. fall slowly forward onto the hands and let	the body down to rest on the floor.	11.46381630586274
11709. push back up and repeat.	12.734802908870382
11710. do this	exercise six times each class period.	12.240293580810171
11711. as strength improves start in	a standing position with legs wide apart and upper body bent forward.	6.887354843087363
11712. start by falling forward to a point close to the feet and as strength	improves fall farther and farther out.	12.127200227800454
11713. try to push back to the stand	position from the stretched position without any intermediate pushes	from the hands.	7.856840563721996
11714. the push-up itself can be taught by starting at the	top of the push-up with legs spread wide.	7.818009190101451
11715. let the body down slowly	taking at least five seconds for the letting down.	8.895094311704021
11716. five of these	done daily for about a week will develop the strength for one push-up.	11.520070370044268
11717. handstands come after arms chest and shoulders	have developed at least a minimum of strength.	7.228884864810104
11718. of course those	who have developed more will find them easier.	14.625028681773376
11719. start with the class	standing in a circle with weight on the right foot and the left extended	a little way into the circle.	8.999379611495293
11720. at first each child should do a kick	up by himself so that the teacher can determine those ready to work	alone and those who need help.	10.98906559237302
11721. drop both hands to the floor and at the	same time kick the right foot up in back.	9.423560320043087
11722. the left will follow at	once.	16.4720976821287
11723. the right will land first followed by the left.	10.565226388873594
11724. return to the	standing position.	13.941847455686199
11725. care should be taken to see that the hands are placed	on the floor before the kick starts and also that the landing foot	is brought as close to the hands as possible.	9.39961690308498
11726. this will prevent flat	falls and toe injuries.	13.172226101820492
11727. bare feet are better for such work than any	form of slipper.	7.1188165710634435
11728. eventually the class will be able to kick up high enough	so that the teacher can catch the leading leg.	10.38877973730702
11729. the child should	then bring both legs together overhead point the toes and tighten the	seat muscles.	6.920297585819938
11730. be sure that the landing foot is brought close to the	hands and that only one foot lands at a time.	13.054892973683861
11731. the backbend	is of extreme importance to any form of free gymnastics and	as with all acrobatics the sooner begun the better the results.	6.630589446688949
11732. have	the class lie supine with knees apart and bent.	10.97494624952944
11733. place flat palms on	either side of the head a few inches away from the ears fingers pointing	toward the shoulders.	7.9573863624390215
11734. arch the back upwards to make a bridge.	11.042785744321769
11735. be sure the head drops backward so that the child looks at the floor	rather than toward the ceiling.	9.36455542584056
11736. as flexibility improves the feet will	move closer to the hands and the bridge rise higher.	12.670207403203808
11737. later this can	be combined with the handstand to provide a walkover.	8.520317595046215
11738. to further increase back flexibility work on the back circle.	14.427864072806905
11739. have	the class lie prone.	11.646520460344489
11740. place the hands in front of the chest.	19.52737701605453
11741. keep	the legs straight and the toes pointed.	8.042201714361974
11742. straighten the arms slowly	this arches the back.	8.953345591169455
11743. at the peak of the arch tip the head back and	bend the knees in an effort to touch toes to head.	8.313725654222177
11744. improvement can be	measured by the lessening distance between toes and head.	8.503538206145178
11745. the last essential to the beginner's gymnastic program is the	somersault or forward roll.	7.055234471400489
11746. this used to be part of every child's	bag of tricks but few children can do it today; some are actually	incapable of rolling forward and are completely confused when not sitting	or standing upright.	7.76852076669832
11747. for most small children learning a forward	roll is simply a matter of copying another child who can.	7.993183628669782
11748. after it has	been seen have the child start on a mat on hands and knees	inexpensive mat is quite sufficient for anything that does not require	.	10.871925767077162
11749. he places the hands on either side of the head keeping	the chin down on the chest.	9.824768966675688
11750. he then pushes his seat into the air and	the teacher guides it over.	12.150812765109816
11751. one or two practice runs should be sufficient	for solo.	9.610242563424213
11752. if however the child is weak overweight or afraid	more help will be needed.	11.334689602357043
11753. when the child raises his seat into the air	the teacher takes hold under both sides of the pelvis; then no matter	what happens the child's performance will be controlled.	5.586121430292633
11754. by lifting	the seat upwards a little the weight is taken off the neck and	the back is kept rounded.	8.788512028040387
11755. these are beginnings but correctly	learned they prepare for satisfying and exciting stunts that can be performed	by a strong flexible body.	6.458318955208302
11756. even if gymnastics are not the ultimate goal the good tumbler	will be a better dancer a better athlete and a human being with	a greater margin of safety in any activity.	9.65244212226728
11757. it is very important	for parents to understand that early training is imperative.	12.343489627682992
11758. and dancing	school so helpful in artistic and psychological development also	contributes to this essential early training- and can contribute	even more.	7.236593380583086
11759. every taxpayer is well aware of the vast size of our annual	defense	budget and most of our readers also realize that a large portion	of these expenditures go for military electronics.	7.4301602122289045
11760. we have noted how	some electronic techniques developed for the defense effort have evenutally	been used in commerce and industry.	10.223007272587076
11761. the host of novel applications	of electronics to medical problems is far more thrilling because	of their implication in matters concerning our health and vitality.	6.462019757626761
11762. when we consider the electronic industry potential for human betterment	the prospect is staggering.	12.176625148462398
11763. the author has recently studied	the field of medical electronics and has been convinced that in this	area alone the application of electronic equipment has enormous possibilities.	7.387608305289619
11764. the benefits electronics can bring to bio-medicine may be	greater by far than any previous medical discovery.	7.814745412260679
11765. we use the term	bio-medicine because of the close interrelation between biology	and medical research.	7.8914750126688515
11766. electronics has been applied to medicine	for many years in the form of such familiar equipment as the x-ray machine	the electrocardiograph and the diathermy machine.	9.51061658056407
11767. recently many	doctors have installed ultrasonic vibration machines for deep massage	of bruises	contusions and simple bursitis.	5.926786657734214
11768. commonly used electronic	devices which are found in practically every hospital are closed-circuit	tv and audio systems for internal paging and instruction	along with radiation counters timers and similar devices.	6.344553057238984
11769. in this article we will concentrate on the advances in the application	of electronics in bio-medical research laboratories because this	is where tomorrow's commonplace equipment originates.	5.856353327236978
11770. from the wealth	of material and the wide variety of different electronic techniques	perfected in the past few years we have selected a few examples which	appear to be headed for use in the immediate future and which offer completely	new tools in medical research.	11.731205468954338
11771. many cells bacteria and other microorganisms are transparent to visible	light and must be stained for microscopic investigation.	6.43426961788341
11772. this stain	often disrupts the normal cell activity or else colors only the outside.	9.108365326040579
11773. a completely new insight into living cells and their structure	will be possible by use of a new technique which replaces visible light	with ultraviolet radiation and combines a microscope with a color-tv	system to view the results.	5.600990792965606
11774. fig 1 is a simplified block	diagram of the ultraviolet microscopy system developed at the medical	electronics center of rockefeller institute.	10.575141079883547
11775. by combining the	talents of a medical man dr aterman a biophysicist mr	berkely	and an electronics expert dr zworykin this novel technique	has been developed which promises to open broad avenues to understanding	life processes.	5.358423840330345
11776. three different wavelengths of ultraviolet	radiation are selected by the variable filters placed in front of the	three mercury xenon lights which serve as the ultraviolet sources.	8.583256540794858
11777. these wavelengths are reflected in sequence through the specimen by the	rotating mirror; the specimen is magnified by the microscope.	5.429946464925308
11778. instead	of the observer's eye the image orthicon in the tv camera	does the looking.	8.15308693846436
11779. the microscope and orthicon are both selected	to operate well into the ultraviolet spectrum which means that all	lenses must be quartz.	7.799528407114584
11780. the video signal is amplified and then	switched in synchronism with the three ultraviolet light sources which	are sequenced by the rotating mirror so that during one-twentieth of	a second only one wavelength corresponding to red green or blue is	seen.	6.908908215037283
11781. to another the lights are switched by a commutator-like assembly rotated	by a synchronous motor.	6.095212783296994
11782. this assembly also supplies a 20-cps	this is the same system	as was used in the field-sequential color-tv system which preceded	the present simultaneous system.	6.758770993095448
11783. three separate amplifiers then	drive a 21-inch tricolor tube.	5.33355948015847
11784. the result is a color picture of the	specimen where the primary colors correspond to the three different ultraviolet	wavelengths.	13.517922857575178
11785. many of the cells and microorganisms which	are transparent to visible light absorb or reflect the much shorter	wavelengths of the ultraviolet spectrum.	7.854375885452776
11786. different parts of these cells	sometimes absorb or reflect different wavelengths so that it is often	possible to see internal portions of cells in a different color.	10.538675484490948
11787. where the microscope under visible light may show only vague shadows	or nothing at all ultraviolet illumination and subsequent translation	into a color tv picture reveal a wealth of detail.	6.871009314595281
11788. at the	present time the research team which pioneered this new technique is	primarily interested in advancing and perfecting it.	9.24562723861947
11789. electronically analyzed	the medical title of lobar ventilation	in man by drs c j martin and a c young covers	a brief paper which is one part of a much larger effort to apply electronics	to the study of the respiratory process.	6.632544441439435
11790. at the university	of washington medical school the electronics group has developed	the respiratory gas analyzer shown in fig 3.	10.687053437490633
11791. this unit	affectionately dubbed the monster can be wheeled to any convenient	location and provides a wealth of information about the patient's	breathing.	7.166190651554503
11792. in the lower center rack an 8-channel recorder	indicates the percentage of carbon dioxide and nitrogen from the upper	and lower lobes of one lung the total volume of inhalation per breath	the flow of air from both lobes and the pressure of the two lobes	with respect to each other.	8.742273736220795
11793. usually the patient breathes into a mouthpiece	while walking a treadmill standing still or in some other medically	significant position.	6.562374171072773
11794. from the resulting data the doctor can determine	lung defects with hitherto unknown accuracy and detail.	9.55054910298354
11795. techniques	the original electrocardiograph primarily	indicates irregularities in the heartbeat but today's techniques allow	exact measurements of the flow of blood through the aorta dimensioning	of the heart and its chambers and a much more detailed study of	each heartbeat.	5.561204567083866
11796. for many of these measurements the chest must be opened	but the blood vessels and the heart itself remain undisturbed.	15.049261800235543
11797. a group of researchers at the university of washington have given	a paper which briefly outlines some of these techniques.	9.576375103921205
11798. one simple	method of measuring the expansion of the heart is to tie a thin rubber	tube filled with mercury around the heart and record the change	in resistance as the tube is stretched.	10.938970999669099
11799. a balanced resistance bridge	and a pen recorder are all the electronic instrumentation needed.	7.152615831013295
11800. sonar can be used to measure the thickness of the heart by placing	small crystal transducers at opposite sides of the heart or blood vessel	and exciting one with some pulsed ultrasonic energy.	10.61268571110964
11801. the travel	time of sound in tissue is about 1500 meters per second thus it takes	about 16	|msec to traverse 25 mm of tissue.	5.40133493027094
11802. a sonar or radar-type	of pulse generator and time-delay measuring system is required for	body-tissue evaluation.	5.70733427974291
11803. in addition to the heart and aorta successful	measurements of liver and spleen have also been made by this technique.	11.226456310589654
11804. the doppler effect using ultrasonic signals can be employed to	measure the flow of blood without cutting into the blood vessel.	9.774538959994388
11805. a still more sophisticated system has been devised for determining	the effective power of the heart itself.	8.890171559981749
11806. it uses both an ultrasonic	dimensioning arrangement of the heart and a catheter carrying a thermistor	inserted into the bloodstream.	11.579076540302886
11807. the latter measures the heat carried	away by the bloodstream as an indication of the velocity of the blood	flow.	8.528654825846424
11808. it is also possible to utilize a pressure transducer mounted	at the end of a catheter which is inserted into the heart's left	ventricle to indicate the blood pressure in the heart itself.	12.36411474725435
11809. this pressure	measurement may be made at the same time that the ultrasonic dimensioning	measurement is made.	10.510800817770818
11810. a simplified version of the instrumentation	for this procedure is shown in fig 2.	14.200027303661855
11811. outputs of the two	systems are measured by a pulse-timing circuit and a resistance bridge	followed by a simple analogue computer which feeds a multichannel recorder.	5.0265012809165865
11812. from this doctors can read heart rate change in diameter pressure	and effective heart power.	9.95272915168906
11813. several	years ago headlines were made by a small radio transmitter capsule	which could be swallowed by the patient and which would then radio internal	pressure data to external receivers.	7.025045749618287
11814. this original capsule contained	a battery and a transistor oscillator and was about 1 cm in	diameter.	8.972534697390175
11815. battery life limited the use of this pill to about 8	to 30 hours maximum.	7.345734901107632
11816. a refinement of this technique has been described	by drs zworykin and farrar and mr berkely of the medical	electronics center of the rockefeller institute.	9.329255179287873
11817. in this	novel arrangement the pill is much smaller and contains only a resonant	circuit in which the capacitor is formed by a pressure-sensing	transducer.	7.329851899046219
11818. as shown in fig 4 an external antenna is placed over	or around the patient and excited 3000 times a second with short 400-kc	bursts.	11.01587625685898
11819. the energy received by the pill causes the resonant	circuit to ring on after the burst and this ringing takes	place at the resonant frequency of the pill.	6.7701606215091275
11820. these frequencies	are amplified and detected by the fm receiver after each burst	of transmitted energy and after the pill has been calibrated	precise internal pressure indications can be obtained.	7.71797290933265
11821. one of	the advantages of this method is that the pill can remain in the	patient for several days permitting observation under natural conditions.	7.917452675728333
11822. applications to organs other than the gastrointestinal tract are	planned for future experiments.	9.12460357029116
11823. one	of the most gratifying applications of an important technique of submarine	detection is in the exploration of the human body.	8.90626692149769
11824. our readers	are familiar with the principles of sonar where sound waves are sent	out in water and the echoes then indicate submerged objects.	9.841168273660347
11825. various	methods of pulsing scanning and displaying these sound waves are used	to detect submarines map ocean floors and even communicate under water.	5.4066899864504565
11826. in medicine the frequencies are much higher transducers and the	sonar beams themselves are much smaller and different scanning techniques	may be used but the principles involved are the same as in sonar.	9.979515625524913
11827. because the body contains so much liquid transmission of	ultrasonic signals proceeds fairly well in muscles and blood vessels.	7.123682064199634
11828. bones and cartilage transmit poorly and tend to reflect the ultrasonic	signals.	8.78135215526032
11829. based on this phenomenon a number of investigators have used	this method to look through human organs.	7.6468237346701855
11830. a good example of	the results obtainable with ultrasonic radiation is contained in papers	presented by dr g baum who has explored the human eye.	8.613809975184559
11831. he	can diagnose detachment of the retina where conventional methods indicate	blindness due to glaucoma.	5.8413067907245475
11832. the method used to scan the eye ultrasonically	is illustrated in fig 6.	10.799241060045512
11833. the transducer is coupled to the	body through a water bath not shown.	8.379511569080897
11834. for display dr baum uses	a portion of an f an airborne radar indicator and then photographs	the screen to obtain a permanent record.	8.444679429581168
11835. a typical sonogram	of a human eye together with a description of the anatomical	parts is shown in fig 5.	9.552909443110224
11836. the frequency used for these experiments	is 15 mc and the transducer is a specially cut crystal with an epoxy	lens capable of providing beam diameters smaller than one millimeter.	8.344709472837108
11837. the transducer itself moves the beam in a sector scan just like	a radar antenna while the entire transducer structure is moved over a	90-degree arc in front of the eye to look into all corners.	6.568079642763069
11838. the total	picture is only seen by the camera which integrates the many sector	scans over the entire 90-degree rotation period.	7.803776135723283
11839. drs	howry	and holmes at the university of colorado medical school have applied	the same sonar technique to other areas of soft tissue and have	obtained extremely good results.	6.678811195028158
11840. by submerging the patient in a tub	and rotating the transducer while the scanning goes on they have been	able to get cross-section views of the neck as shown in fig 7 as	well as many other hitherto impossible insights.	9.292372989225951
11841. as mentioned before	bone reflects the sound energy and in fig 7 the portion of the	spine shows as the black area in the center.	7.773926088289533
11842. arteries and veins are apparent	by their black blood-filled centers and the surrounding white	walls.	6.5298248005906006
11843. a cross-section of a normal lower human leg is shown in	fig 8 with the various parts labeled.	5.797716026120703
11844. oersted's boyhood represented a minimal chance of either	attaining greatness or serving his people so well and over so long a	span of life.	6.557038103487177
11845. he was born in the small danish town of rudkoebing on	the island of langeland in the south-central part of denmark on august	14 1777.	7.023878551488336
11846. his father soeren was the village apothecary whose slender	income made it difficult to feed his family let alone educate	them in a town without even a school.	8.848584398611047
11847. the two older boys hans and anders	his junior by a year therefore went daily to the home of a	warm	and friendly wigmaker nearby for instruction in german; his wife	taught the two boys to read and write danish.	6.061510728377335
11848. other brothers later joined	them for instruction with oldenburg the wigmaker and also arithmetic	was added to bible reading german and danish in the informal	curriculum.	8.01601271881335
11849. oldenburg's contributions were soon exhausted and the	boys had to turn to a wider circle of the town's learned such as	the pastor to supplement the simple teaching.	4.656283536394988
11850. from the town surveyor	hans learned drawing and mathematics and from a university student	some academic subjects.	11.01237581858838
11851. the mayor of the town taught them english	and french.	11.201325438931816
11852. whatever hans or anders learned separately they passed	on to each other; they read every book that they could borrow in the	village.	6.901829061543878
11853. at 12 hans was sufficiently mature to help his father in	the apothecary shop which helped stimulate his interest in medicine	and science.	7.511132019831825
11854. his earlier love for literature and history remained with	him for his entire life.	9.694825866021896
11855. in 1793 the brothers decided to enter	the university of copenhagen and the following	spring found them at the university preparing to matriculate for the	autumn session.	7.681449959241074
11856. while hans devoted himself to the sciences of medicine	physics and astronomy his brother studied law.	9.4670963814465
11857. the brothers continued	to help each other during their studies sharing a joint purse	lodging together in the dormitory and dining together at the home of	their aunt.	6.3876329623091115
11858. they supplemented their income by small government assistance	by tutoring and economizing wherever they could.	8.74687237356113
11859. so impressive	were those serious years of study at the university that hans later	wrote to be perfectly free the young man must revel in the great	kingdom of thought and imagination; there is a struggle there in which	if he falls it is easy for him to rise again there is freedom	of utterance there which draws after it no irreparable consequences on	society h.	6.480135328376715
11860. i lived in this onward-driving contest where each day	overcame a new difficulty gained a new truth or banished a previous	error.	7.571380961412497
11861. he openly proclaimed his pleasure in lecturing and writing	about science.	7.587548976099465
11862. in this third year at the university hans in 1797	was awarded the first important token of recognition a gold medal for	his essay on limits of poetry and prose.	10.615026253745889
11863. he completed his training	in pharmacy also taking his degree with high honors in 1797	and in 1799 was awarded the degree of doctor of philosophy along with	a prize for an essay in medicine.	6.733596464235689
11864. he proposed a fresh theory of alkalis	which later was accepted in chemical practices.	10.869323167393746
11865. activity	han's student days were at a time when europe	was in a new intellectual ferment following the revolutions in america	and in france germany and italy were rising from divisive nationalisms	and a strong wave of intellectual awareness was sweeping the	continent.	5.613017917023615
11866. the new century opened with oersted beginning	his professional career in charge of an apothecary shop in copenhagen	and as lecturer at the university.	9.440288396625288
11867. he was stirred by the announcement	of volta's	discovery of chemical electricity and he immediately applied	the voltaic pile to experiments with acids and alkalis.	6.541527383846914
11868. the following	year he devoted to the customary wanderjahr traveling in	germany france and the netherlands meeting the philosophers schelling	fichte and tieck.	8.543193629411697
11869. he also met count rumford	who was then serving the elector	of bavaria and the physicist ritter; these were oersted's main	contacts in science.	4.726268483103999
11870. from go^ttingen where he stayed	for 10 days he wrote the first question asked everywhere is	about galvanism.	8.464237018308522
11871. as everybody is curious to see the battery of glass	tubes i have invented i have had quite a small one made here of	four glass	tubes and intend to carry it with me.	7.769506259222104
11872. oersted joined ritter at jena and stayed with him for 3 weeks continuing	their correspondence after he left.	9.645581419166186
11873. with ritter he was exposed	to the fantastic profusion of ideas that stormed through his host's	fertile but disorganized mind.	5.839882629194894
11874. oersted remodeled ritter's notes	into an essay in french which was submitted to the institut de france	for its annual prize of 3000 francs.	7.485888083424651
11875. the sound discoveries of	this quixotic genius were so diluted by those of fantasy that the prize	was never awarded to him.	6.730825742205556
11876. in may 1803 ritter in another flight	of fancy wrote to oersted a letter that contained a remarkable prophecy.	9.303858015525662
11877. he related events on earth to periodic celestial phenomena and	indicated that the years of maximum inclination of the ecliptic coincided	with the years of important electrical discoveries.	7.331167686798679
11878. thus 1745 corresponded	to the invention of the leiden jar by kleist 1764	that of the electrophorus by wilcke 1782 produced the condenser of	volta and 1801 the voltaic pile.	6.899586720529394
11879. ritter proceeded you now emerge	into a new epoch in which late in the year 1819 or 1820 you will have	to reckon.	7.380823273634756
11880. this we might well witness.	18.40613285882067
11881. ritter died in 1810 and	oersted not only lived to see the event occur but was the author of	it.	7.243825927096874
11882. in 1803 oersted returned to copenhagen and applied for	the university's chair in physics but was rejected because he was probably	considered more a philosopher than a physicist.	8.232007784468482
11883. however he continued	experimenting and lecturing publishing the results of his experiments	in german and danish periodicals.	8.19866186580649
11884. in 1806 his ambition was	realized and he became professor of physics at the copenhagen university	though not realizing full professorship until 1817.	9.249506875360897
11885. during oersted's attendance at the university it was poorly	equipped with physical apparatus for experimenting in the sciences.	7.38827617546223
11886. he was however fortunate in his contact with prof j g	l manthey teacher of chemistry who in addition to	his academic chair was	also proprietor of the lion pharmacy in	copenhagen where oersted assisted him.	9.27258830049647
11887. manthey maintained a valuable	collection of physical and chemical apparatus which was at oersted's	disposal during and after his graduation.	5.21392209110264
11888. in 1800 manthey went	abroad and oersted was appointed manager of the lion pharmacy.	12.143833769399558
11889. in	february 1801 oersted did manage to experiment with physical apparatus	and reported experiments made with a voltaic battery of 600 plates	of zinc and silver and of later experiments with a battery of 60 plates	of zinc and lead.	6.274245096785407
11890. in the following year 1803 oersted simultaneously	with davy discovered that acids increased the strength of a voltaic	battery more than did salts.	10.783464631654606
11891. eager as he was to pursue this promising	line he was so loaded down with the management of the pharmacy	and lectures in the medical and pharmaceutical faculties at the university	that he could devote only sunday afternoons to galvanizing.	6.582893684668849
11892. he assumed his academic career with the same intensity and	thoroughness that had marked every step in his rise from boyhood.	9.98579506283417
11893. the	university was the only one in denmark and the status of professor	represented the upper social level.	7.875454473011764
11894. his broad interest in literary political	and philosophical movements opened many doors to him.	8.789795813048174
11895. his friends	were numerous and their ties to him were strong.	7.380129951842237
11896. the years	1812 and 1813 saw him in germany and france again but on this	visit to berlin he did not seek out the philosophers as he had on his	first journey.	9.808119352786894
11897. in berlin he published his views of the chemical laws	of nature in german and this was issued in french translation	under the title recherches sur l'identite des forces chimiques	et electriques a work held in very high esteem by the new	generation	of research chemists.	6.016203911242672
11898. his interest in finding a relationship between	voltaic electricity and magnetism is here first indicated.	10.12024476769733
11899. chapter	8 is entitled on magnetism and in it are included such	remarks as one has always been tempted to compare the magnetic forces	with the electrical forces.	6.336690788458515
11900. the great resemblance between electrical	and magnetic attractions and repulsions and the similarity of their	laws necessarily would bring about this comparison.	8.407172936372682
11901. it is true that	nothing has been found comparable with electricity by communication;	but the phenomena observed had such a degree of analogy to those	depending on electrical distribution that one could not find the slightest	difference h.	7.42370198707873
11902. the form of galvanic activity is halfway between	the magnetic form and the electrical form.	12.471303896303677
11903. there forces are more latent	than in electricity and less than in magnetism h.	9.223383745831413
11904. but in such	an important question we would be satisfied if the judgment were that	the principal objection to the identity of forces which produce electricity	and magnetism were only a difficulty and not a thing which is	contrary to it h.	10.025227801863934
11905. one could also add to these analogies that steel	loses its magnetism by heat which proves that steel becomes a better	conductor through a rise in temperature just as electrical bodies do.	6.393534812472707
11906. it is also found that magnetism exists in all bodies of nature as	proven by bruckmann and coulomb.	12.707245411434043
11907. by that one feels that magnetic	forces are as general as electrical forces.	8.05476158009819
11908. an attempt should be made	to see if electricity in its most latent stage has any action on the	magnet as such.	8.771769213818946
11909. his plan and intent were clearly charted.	8.055183724915963
11910. oersted returned in 1814 and resumed an active part in university and	political discussions.	10.92760583646342
11911. in one debate he supported the freedom of judgment	as opposed to dogma in another he held that the practice of science	was in fact an act of religious worship.	8.456377985510594
11912. he continued as a popular	lecturer.	16.584095744581248
11913. he devised a detonating fuse in which a short wire was	caused to glow by an electric current.	7.096128992311543
11914. in 1819 under royal command	he undertook a very successful geological expedition to bornholm	one of the danish islands being one of three scientists in the expedition.	9.134308833007148
11915. it was with the assistance of one of the members of this expedition	lauritz esmarch that oersted succeeded in producing light	by creating an electric discharge in mercury vapor through which an electric	current was made to flow.	9.448620884854593
11916. together they also developed a new	form of voltaic cell in which the wooden trough was replaced by one of	copper thereby producing stronger currents.	9.168310427185867
11917. esmarch was among those	who witnessed oersted's first demonstration of his discovery.	5.061190796225391
11918. of electromagnetism	the association between electric	forces and magnetic forces had been	recognized by investigators for many decades.	8.739397215330271
11919. electrical literature	contained numerous references to lightning that had magnetized iron and	had altered the polarity of compass needles.	5.769183557985991
11920. in the late 1700's	beccaria and van marum among others had magnetized iron by sending	an electrostatic charge through it.	8.704325549349427
11921. beccaria had almost stumbled on	a lead to the relationship between electricity and magnetism when a discharge	from a leyden jar was sent transversally through a piece	of watch-spring steel making its ends magnetic.	5.259723990792755
11922. the resulting magnetic	effect proved stronger than when the discharge was made lengthwise.	10.427899880287322
11923. the experiments of romagnosi and others have already been noted but	no one had determined the cause-and-effect relationship between these	two primary forces.	5.836472435279238
11924. oersted's own earlier experiments were unimpressive	possibly because he had like other experimenters laid the conducting	wire across the compass needle instead of parallel with it.	6.800819560276408
11925. the sequence of events leading to his important discovery still remains	ambiguous but it seems that one of the advanced students at the	university related that the first direct event that led to the publication	of oersted's discovery occurred during a private lecture made	before a group of other advanced students in the spring of 1820.	7.561229072967619
11926. at	this lecture oersted happened to place the conducting wire over and parallel	to a magnetic needle.	8.377828120052241

12458. but there is still the sometimes	complex problem of helping campers choose the best equipment for	their individual needs.	15.107539020286685
12459. throughout history the man who showed superior performance has become	the commander of others- for good or bad.	6.127654211361584
12460. since the industrial	revolution when factories emerged this classical pattern has been	followed.	10.030207699349479
12461. there have always been tales	of disillusionment- the competent technician who became an administrator	willingly or not and found he didn't like it; the scientist	who rebelled against the personnel and paper work; and much more	commonly in recent years the engineer who found that other duties interfered	with- or eliminated- his engineering contributions.	4.544335817123311
12462. there	have been many extremely competent men who have been converted into	very incompetent managers or submerged in paper work to their own and	the public's dissatisfaction and loss.	7.396875005838441
12463. this has been more	evident since our products have incorporated astronomically increased	technology.	8.943931077534474
12464. the remedies have been many and varied- attempts to	teach management techniques- either in plant at special schools	or	in university crash courses- provision of management-trained assistants	or associates.	5.178262219985339
12465. but the realization has been growing that	these are not the complete answer.	11.04148706236178
12466. some men have no talent for or	interest in management; forcing them into management can only create	trouble.	7.621867668434138
12467. the old shop adage still holds: a good mechanic is usually	a bad boss.	5.871687460608057
12468. yet our economy clings inexorably to recognition	of managerial status as the gage of success.	8.349548176480653
12469. labor fights to	change its collar from blue to white.	6.719294516490701
12470. all grades of management seek	more resounding titles and incomes because of social pressures.	9.277090119589767
12471. as several	recent books have over-emphasized we have become the most status-conscious	nation in the world.	5.455825777551842
12472. what can be done for	the individual contributor who is extremely important- and	likely to be more so- in the operation of the technically oriented	company?	10.30938141932452
12473.  he is usually conscious of the social pressures at home and	outside; usually concerned about america's belief that attainment	and success are measured in dollars and titles.	6.067578829785622
12474. yet titles are traditionally	given only to management men and income tends to rise with	title.	10.005483289465932
12475. even the college professor in america has been affected.	10.523891067608071
12476. it is as one engineer says indeed a difficult thing for the	engineer to accept that he can go as far on his technical merit as he	could employing managerial skills.	12.633289189873222
12477. this difficulty arises even though	we can give examples of men who have actually followed this course.	8.089849103229838
12478. this	leads one to conclude as you have that there is inevitably more	prestige in a management position in the minds of our people.	12.534815637791665

12480. so we asked such	men in major companies in the design field to offer their opinions on	the dual-road-up problem- and more importantly- their solutions.	7.188647431770443
12481. in the paragraphs that follow we quote from 32 men who are identified	on the final page.	8.220621554496256
12482. among	the more familiar plans for dual-channel advancement is that of	general electric.	7.36261170736947
12483. this is not a mutually exclusive plan; there	is no one point in a man's career at which he must select either the	technical or the managerial path upward.	5.980612885866426
12484. further the management path	does not open the door to higher opportunities than are offered by	the more technical path.	9.389994404602618
12485. it is common to shift back and forth working	up through a number of supervisory and individual-contributor positions.	9.344224208064315
12486. actually there are a number of individual-contributor	positions in both operating departments and in the company-wide services	operation that are filled by men with successful managerial	experience who are currently broadening their capabilities.	7.596118014228615
12487. also	moving into a managerial position does not necessarily end a man's	recognition as a technical expert.	5.393226730606275
12488. as examples at ge: glen	b warren formerly manager of the turbine division widely recognized	as a turbine designer.	8.006016049488577

12491. in	the ge plan a number of individual contributors have positions	and compensation higher than those of many managers.	7.776306778813302

12494. another factor that may hold hope is for parallel	recognition is as one man says it: h that the fad for educating	top people along managerial lines is yielding to the technically	trained approach.	7.351555960612643
12495. one company instituted	early in 1959 a vertical classification system consisting of four	levels.	7.8499874519408515
12496. there is no formal equivalence to the supervisory ranks;	the top non-supervisory level senior staff engineer enjoys status	and pay ranging up to that for the second level of engineering supervision.	9.856485647068414

12513. we have tried to make both	paths attractive so that good men could find opportunity and satisfaction	in either.	8.733128718561575

12516. the latter jobs include major management	responsibilities and have been filled by those who have come up primarily	through the engineering-management side h we have not yet	succeeded in establishing recognition of technical specialization comparable	to our higher levels of management but i believe we will trend	top	job: research scientist we	initiated a dual ladder of advancement for technical persons h the	highest position is known as a 'research scientist'.	7.99900171689099
12517. this approach	has not been entirely satisfactory.	9.665090275754633

12519. scientists who agitate	hardest	for technical recognition are often the most reluctant to accept	it h we have discovered that the outward trappings such as private	offices and private secretaries are extremely important; and although	we have attempted to provide these status symbols support of the	'dual-ladder' plan has been half-hearted h despite the creation	of a salary potential for a research scientist commensurate with that	of men in top managerial positions.	4.98236690316562
12520. a serious problem	accompanying the technical-ladder approach is the difficulty of clearly	defining responsibilities and standards of performance for each level.	8.374778960594426
12521. with no set standards there is the tendency to promote to the	next highest level when the top of a salary band is reached regardless	of performance h promotion is too often based on longevity and	time in salary grade instead of merit.	6.850927131248887

12546. sixty miles north of new york city where the wooded hills	of dutchess county meet the broad sweep of the hudson river there	is a new home development called oakwood heights.	12.03452030647113
12547. as a matter	of fact you could probably find a new home development in every populated	county in the country with three-bedroom ranch style cottages	in the $14000 range.	7.576802448573394
12548. but oakwood heights is unique in one particular	h its oil for heating is metered monthly to each home from a line	that starts at a central storage point.	9.662569294993693

12612. every year about this time national gargle your cooling	system week rolls around.	9.106841525281288
12613. it pays in the long run to take good	care of the water works.	12.297198963449738
12614. do it this way for the summer gargle:	first drain that old coolant down the storm sewer.	11.592250323500325
12615. don't	save the anti-freeze even if it the expensive permanent type.	5.358966036084987
12616. the word means it won't boil away easily nothing else.	7.278995879689204
12617. the rust	inhibitors in the fluid are used up after one year and you don't want	to risk the rust that two years' use could mean.	4.1002764678697865
12618. if a lot of rust shows in the drain use a good flushing cleaner.	13.041599854398676
12619. then fill the system and add a rust inhibitor.	10.100586773427077
12620. of	course you'll want to use the softest water you can in your radiators.	7.6439376468
12621. now check for leaks in your hoses and hose connections	around the freeze-out plugs gaskets water pump seals and heater	fittings.	5.061968329235217

12628. check its inhibitor effectiveness before leaving it in	during the summer.	9.482979731349971
12629. take precautions now to be sure you avoid	those unpleasant and costly heat breakdowns when the temperature zooms	this summer.	7.332195101705927
12630. pull the thermostats	out of those fueloil delivery trucks or installation rigs of yours.	7.948946337513136
12631. spring and summer may be here officially but those thermos stay	in.	7.274034778049824
12632. the fact is that removing and leaving out a thermostat from	any water cooled vehicle will greatly increase the fuel consumption	reduce power and contribute to spark plug fouling due to an accumulation	of excessive carbon deposits on the insulators.	9.701462121038466
12633. if you	run into excess plug fouling on one truck check to be sure that the rig	has a thermostat.	8.858123478147219
12634. the thermostat is important to get your engine up	to operating temperature quickly and to keep it running at its most	efficient temperature through the proper circulation of the coolant.	9.408216603866114
12635. for your truck insurance?	11.66736774986382

12653. the importance of the	sign industry to the plastics industry however is not in terms of	volume alone.	9.23320487072834

12655. many of today's developments in thermoforming	stem from original work done with signs and displays; the art of	preprinting in distortion was similarly perfected by the sign makers;	and the reverse-surface decorating techniques now used for escutcheons	medallions etc owes much to the field as does the technology	of designing with the light-transmitting properties of the transparent	plastics.	4.797356165629083
12656. there is much that many industries can continue to	learn from some of the more recent developments described below.	17.023275774085196
12657. the	concept of trans-illumination as just	one example offers an entirely new approach to lighting problems-	no matter what industry is involved.	5.058908345388306
12658. according	to a recent wall street journal survey plastics units now	account for more than 50% of all sign sales.	7.731707035248012
12659. five years ago they had	only 10% of the market with the remainder firmly entrenched in the	stronghold of neon tubing.	7.5729967714957995
12660. and it's far from the end for plastics.	7.23521588932909
12661. industry sources are now estimating that 75% of the signs made during	the 1960's will be of plastic construction.	4.787497339304668
12662. evidence of this	trend can best be seen in the recent activities of such leading companies	in the field as advance neon sign co los angeles calif.	10.062827286125788
12663. four years ago the company's entire line was devoted to neon	signs; today 85% is in plastics.	5.020689478004354
12664. from the volume standpoint	the total market represented by the sign industry is impressive.	12.614891727881517
12665. aggregate	sales during 1960 reached approximately $500 million.	5.590483906324754
12666. currently	there are some 6000 companies in the field ranging from small firms	with a handful of employees to major concerns having complete facilities	for production of metal electrical and plastic components.	8.230931058035054
12667. the trend to plastics?	12.352344394020207
12668. 	what accounts for the rapid growth	of plastics in the sign and display field?	9.747699714950658
12669.  out of many factors which	might be cited five are most important:  plastics combine	such properties as built-in color light weight optional transparency	or translucency resistance to corrosion as well as the ease of fabrication.	6.0647932867252745
12670. according to one	major producer materials for a typical plastic sign are approximately	25% less costly than for a comparable neon unit.	7.97637494499045
12671. shipping cost is	also reduced; a 3-by- 6-ft plastic sign weighs about 120 lb	compared to 275-300 lb for neon.	3.3459746084710273
12672. the weight advantage plus greater	durability of the plastic unit yields a saving of about one-fifth	in shipping.	8.582699528964337
12673. the lighter weight also means less costly supports and mountings	are needed.	7.123510973130028
12674. finally maintenance costs on plastic signs are	much lower than on fragile neon signs.	8.606068115672564
12675. they offer exceptional	design freedom making it	possible to incorporate contours and details	which give free range to the talents of the designer.	6.3707382555883925
12676. vacuum- and pressure-formed	sheet plastics fill the gap between cardboard and molded	plastics.	6.53496270585516
12677. pre-decoration	low-cost molds and the freedom to form large	and small thick and thin materials make plastics tailor-made for the	industry.	5.282537403521774
12678. plastics signs work around the clock.	11.955272457117745
12679. internal	illumination protected from the elements gives them powerful visual	appeal at night; during daylight hours their brilliant colors command	attention and interest.	4.874452105274493
12680. advances in equipment and fabrication	techniques give the sign or display manufacturer an extremely wide	choice of production techniques ranging from injection molding for	intricate smaller-size mass-production signs	to vacuum and pressure forming for larger signs of limited	runs.	7.176430915517101
12681. among the newest fabrication methods to enter the display field	what plastics	to use?	8.872947100430407
12682.  with its outstanding	optical characteristics weather resistance and formability strongly	dominates the picture.	9.787082035963401
12683. at present both the familiar cast acrylic	and the newer extruded sheets are being used by sign manufacturers	with extruded now representing an estimated 10% of the total.	5.816838677173286
12684. of interest is a recent	announcement by du pont's	polychemicals dept of a new methyl methacrylate	monomer designated as monocite h 100 which was developed	specifically for production of cast acrylic sheets for the sign and	lighting industry.	7.629742650992234
12685. sheeting cast from this material reportedly weighs	only one-third as much as glass is impervious to all kinds of weather	and will not yellow.	5.415872344727308
12686. its high impact strength even at low temperatures	resists chipping cracking and crazing according to du pont.	8.15074397586836
12687. cellulose acetate butyrate is used extensively for vacuum-formed	signs background panels and molded or formed letters because of its	exceptional toughness ease of forming and excellent weathering properties.	5.028353591105678
12688. its clarity and good optical properties are other important	factors.	10.455203706834052
12689. new to the field is a duplex type butyrate laminate in which	the two sheets of the laminate are of different color.	7.609080634634158
12690. thermoforming	the laminate and then sanding away the top layer is a quick and economical	way to produce a two-color sign.	7.905749979427363
12691. for specialized types of displays such as large three-dimensional	units reproducing a product package human or animal figures	etc reinforced plastics and rotationally molded vinyl plastisols	are other materials frequently used.	5.001671100110037
12692. a relative newcomer	in	outdoor signs is mylar polyester film now used as a printed overlay	for trans-illuminated signs.	9.479000164408411
12693. for outdoor signs and	displays where the problem of weathering resistance is no longer a	factor the choice of plastics is almost unlimited.	7.815481974308874
12694. here may be found	regular and impact styrene cellulose acetate cellulose butyrate and	cellulose propionate acrylic vinyl expandable styrene foam and polyethylene.	7.6171974029814535
12695. the final choice of material depends upon such factors as	costs method of fabrication degree of complexity number of units	required time available for tooling and projected life expectancy of	the unit.	6.095417464626768
12696. often the finished sign or display incorporates several types	of plastics and two or more fabricating techniques.	9.532187904602011
12697. billboards	one of the most significant advancements in design	of plastics signs is the so-called trans-illuminated billboard now	being produced by several large sign manufacturers such as advance	neon sign co los angeles and industrial electric inc	new orleans la.	4.85987494172928
12698. the essential difference between the new	trans-illuminated boards and existing billboards is that the former	constructed of translucent plastic panels are lighted from within.	7.9169764620395915
12699. with the source of light behind the copy there is no loss of lumen output	as with conventional boards illuminated by means of reflected light.	8.125023215785733
12700. also the light sources are shielded from dirt and weather exposure	and cannot obstruct the view of the sign.	10.632008618716055
12701. the copy itself	including any text or illustrations is reproduced in full color directly	on a thin mylar polyester film by a photo screen process.	6.053802915932458
12702. the	film has an adhesive on the back which permits it to be stripped onto	the acrylic panels forming the sign and also to be stripped off for	replacement by new copy as required.	9.563646643505882
12703. spare sets of face panels simplify	the change from one copy or message to another; new panels are exchanged	for the old right in the field on a single trip.	5.885377661243904
12704. panels with	outdated copy are returned to the sign shop so a new message can be applied.	9.023347552041894
12705. signs of this type have already made their appearance	in several larger cities and others are on the way.	8.480828947946517
12706. it is believed that	these boards will within the next few years replace many of the	conventional flood-lighted boards now in use.	12.357711292268942
12707. trans-illuminated	signs also show versatility in other directions.	5.289326539164407

12709. thus the film can be applied to back-lighted translucent	plastics faces; they can also be applied to opaque panels	for use on cutouts or they can be applied directly to painted bulletin	faces.	7.315871864792654

12742. from	the inside out	don't insert your components into fixed openings	they may or may not fit; position your components before you close	them in.	6.870754834544905
12743. for example:   don't wall in your kitchen before	you hang the wall cabinets and set the appliances.	5.16960336550101
12744. it's a lot quicker	and easier to dimension the kitchen to fit the cabinets and erect	the end wall after they are all in place.	5.8864405197473015
12745. set your bathtub before	you close in the end of the bathroom.	12.726748282521887

12748. finish installing and	connecting up your furnace and your water heater before you wall them	in.	8.141751560621845
12749. there is no better way to waste time than trying to install a	furnace in a finished f closet.	11.705728733705584
12750. don't position your studs	before you insert your windows in conventional construction; that way	you may pay more to shim the window into place than you paid for the	window.	4.794730108605619

12752. install your disappearing	stair to the attic and finish your overhead ducts before	you drywall the ceiling.	7.501483648998703

13883. ten-year-old richard stewart had been irritable and quarrelsome	for almost a year.	5.064724248737031

13886. then one day	dick's classmate jimmy from next door let the cat out of the	bag.	9.164363022535591
13887. the youngsters in the boys' class had nicknamed dick bugs	bunny because his teeth protruded.	5.977727016993514
13888. when richard's parents	told him they wanted to take him to an orthodontist- a dentist who	specializes in realigning teeth and jaws- their young son was interested.	6.638061697461513
13889. during the year that followed dick co-operated whole-heartedly	with the dentist and was delighted with the final result achieved-	an upper row of strong straight teeth that completely changed his	facial appearance.	6.503924663504218
13890. richard stewart is no special case.	12.038867493022938
13891. the	majority of children in the united states could benefit by some form	of orthodontic treatment says dr allan g brodie professor	and head of the department of orthodontics at the university of	illinois and a nationally recognized authority in his field.	7.996099264505443
13892. what do parents need to know about those years of the braces in	order not to waste a child's time and their money?	9.841282730331695
13893.  how can they	tell whether a child needs orthodontic treatment?	9.231651873489225
13894.  why and when should	tooth-straightening be undertaken?	10.054246720883869
13895.  what is it likely to cost?	13.661957163962173
13896. 	occlusion is the dentist's expression	for the way teeth fit together when the jaws are closed.	7.195774848773217
13897. malocclusion	or a bad fit is what parents need to look out for.	7.470622701183725
13898. one main type	of malocclusion is characterized by a receding chin and protruding upper	front teeth.	9.096466944218394
13899. a chin too prominent in relation to the rest of the	face a thrusting forward of the lower front teeth an overdeveloped lower	jawbone and an underdeveloped upper jaw indicate the opposite type	of malocclusion.	6.892516667846854
13900. these two basic malformations have of course	many variations.	10.816083818837685
13901. a child probably requires some form of treatment	if he has any of the following conditions:  a noticeable	protrusion of the upper or lower jaw.	6.998377800660955
13902. crooked overlapping	twisted or widely spaced teeth.	8.673729336071373
13903. front teeth not meeting	when the back teeth close.	9.640606781440717
13904. upper teeth completely covering	the lowers when the back teeth close.	10.891040418376214
13905. the eyeteeth	beginning	to protrude like fangs.	9.082527596581548
13906. second teeth that have come in before	the first ones have fallen out making a double row.	10.059809361155612
13907. contrary	to the thinking of 30 to 40 years ago when all malocclusion was	blamed on some unfortunate habit recent studies show that most tooth	irregularity has at least its beginning in hereditary predisposition.	7.487925672340021
13908. however this does not mean that a child's teeth or jaws must	necessarily resemble those of someone in his family.	8.953635061449559
13909. tooth deformity	may be the result of excessive thumb- or finger-sucking tongue-thrusting	or lip-sucking- but it's important to remember that	there's a difference between normal and excessive sucking	habits.	3.331288936132364
13910. it's perfectly normal for babies to suck their thumbs and	no mother need worry if a child continues this habit until he is two	or three years old.	5.223508134712394
13911. occasional sucking up to the fifth year may not affect	a youngster's teeth; but after that if thumb-sucking pressure	is frequent it will have an effect.	5.907647777631947
13912. malocclusion can also	result if baby teeth are lost too soon or retained too long.	9.085186356812809
13913. if a child	loses a molar at the age of two the adjoining teeth may shift toward	the empty space thus narrowing the place intended for the permanent	ones and producing a jumble.	7.004068481944197
13914. if baby teeth are retained too long the	incoming second teeth may be prevented from emerging at the normal	time or may have to erupt in the wrong place.	11.639882998344591
13915. every orthodontist sees children who are embarrassed by	their malformed teeth.	6.646914312479601
13916. some such youngsters rarely smile or they try	to speak with the mouth closed.	9.190996835690806
13917. in certain cases as in dick stewart's	a child's personality is affected.	5.861281090372156
13918. yet from the dentist's	point of view bad-fitting teeth should be corrected for physical reasons.	6.68983338664908
13919. bad alignment may result in early loss of teeth through	a breakdown of the bony structure that supports their roots.	7.439412368616502
13920. this serious	condition popularly known as pyorrhea is one of the chief causes	of tooth loss in adults.	12.115156186913218
13921. then too misplaced or jammed-together	teeth are prone to trapping food particles increasing the	likelihood of rapid decay.	5.65401495720649
13922. for these and other reasons says dr	brodie orthodontics can prolong the life of teeth.	11.66368054603076
13923. the failure of teeth to fit together when closed interferes with normal	chewing so that a child may swallow food whole and put a burden	on his digestive system.	7.444543438702053
13924. because of these chewing troubles a child may	avoid certain foods he needs for adequate nutrition.	11.391901362220834
13925. badly placed	teeth can also cause such a speech handicap as lisping.	6.6642493545470085
13926. how of straightening	most orthodontic work is done on children	between the ages of 10 and 14 though there have been patients	as young as two and as old as 55 says dr brodie.	10.979186540051144
13927. in	the period from 10 to 14 the permanent set of teeth is usually completed	yet the continuing growth of bony tissue makes moving badly placed	teeth comparatively easy.	5.921607821152228
13928. orthodontic work is possible because teeth	are held firmly but not rigidly by a system of peridontal membrane with	an involved nerve network to the bone in the jaw; they are not	anchored directly to the bone.	8.416169845853547
13929. abnormal pressure applied over a period	of time produces a change in the bony deposit so a tooth functions	normally in the new position into which it has been guided.	7.370280701450141
13930. what	can 10-year-old susan expect when she enters the orthodontist's	office?	6.570668690154931
13931.  on her first visit the orthodontist will take x rays	photographs tooth measurements and tooth prints- an impression	of the mouth that permits him to study her teeth and jaws.	6.035925154883711
13932. if he decides to proceed he will custom-make for susie an appliance	consisting of bands plastic plates fine wires and tiny springs.	7.932061453333988
13933. this	appliance will exert a gentle and continuous or intermittent pressure	on the bone.	6.792051068781232
13934. as the tooth moves bone cells on the pressure side	of it will dissolve and new ones will form on the side from which the	tooth has moved.	9.98683333899766
13935. this must be done at the rate at which new bony tissue	grows and no faster.	11.454874714875464
13936. if teeth are moved too rapidly serious	injury can be done to their roots as well as to the surrounding	bone holding them in place explains dr brodie.	12.0745189174963
13937. moving one	or two teeth can affect the whole system and an ill-conceived plan	of treatment can disrupt the growth pattern of a child's face.	4.938909310959748
13938. during the first few days of wearing the appliance and immediately	following each adjustment susan may have a slight discomfort or soreness	but after a short time this will disappear.	11.062315615675754
13939. parents are often	concerned that orthodontic appliances may cause teeth to decay.	7.722324859727463
13940. when	in place a well-cemented band actually protects the part of the tooth	that is covered.	9.593605107529067
13941. next susie will enter the treatment stage	and visit the orthodontist once or twice a month depending on the severity	of her condition.	7.618061032419501
13942. during these visits the dentist will adjust	the braces to increase the pressure on her teeth.	13.113022937391564
13943. last comes the	retention stage.	10.488578642159812
13944. susie's teeth have now been guided into a desirable	new position.	7.803261691184183
13945. but because teeth sometimes may drift back to	their original position a retaining appliance is used to lock them in	place.	7.455598051272972
13946. usually this is a thin band of wire attached to the molars and	stretching across the teeth.	10.104092009388685
13947. susie may wear this only at night or for	a few hours during the day.	7.771829791027785
13948. then comes the time when the last	wire is removed and susie walks out a healthier and more attractive	girl than when she first went to the orthodontist.	10.195452900799438
13949. how long	will this take?	10.471703103390746
13950.  straightening one tooth that has come in wrong may	take only a few months.	10.2601173099547
13951. aligning all the teeth may take a year or more.	8.399049097270455
13952. an added complication such as a malformed jaw may take two or three	years to correct.	9.751586647639897
13953. the charge for a	complete full-banded job differs in various parts of the country.	8.734760454786125
13954. work	that might cost $500 to $750 in the south could cost $750 to $1200	in new york city or chicago.	5.369452810463339
13955. an average national figure for two	to three years of treatment would be $650 to $1000.	7.009641766226247
13956. factors	in the cost of treatment are the length of time involved and the skill	and education of the practitioner says dr brodie.	10.911295968737717
13957. to	become an orthodontist a man must first be licensed by his state as	a dentist then he must spend at least two years in additional training	to acquire a license as a specialist.	7.392877286986403
13958. costs may seem high	but they used to be even higher says dr brodie.	11.777922584752151
13959. fees	are about half to a third of what they were 25 years ago.	9.436977516774279
13960. the	reason?	16.542242831953253
13961.  people today are aware of the value of orthodontics and	as a result there are more practitioners in the field.	9.822329778236872
13962. most	orthodontists require an initial payment to cover the cost of diagnostic	materials and construction of the appliances but usually the remainder	of the cost may be spread over a period of months or years.	9.5847766807579
13963. in many	cities in the united states clinics associated with dental schools	will take patients at a nominal fee.	8.849820098307728
13964. some municipal agencies will	pay for orthodontic treatment for children of needy parents.	9.701909292179014
13965. helps families	growth studies have been carried on consistently	by orthodontists.	6.753939002898689
13966. dr brodie has 30-year records of head growth	started 20 minutes after children's births.	7.168959039795745
13967. in the	past anyone who said that 90% of all malocclusion is hereditary was	scoffed at; now we know that family characteristics do affect tooth	formation to a large extent he says.	6.125733990294335
13968. fortunately through our	growth studies we have been able to see what nature does and that	helps us know what we can do.	10.819179370694865
13969. this knowledge both modifies	and dictates diagnosis and treatment.	8.997367858609545
13970. for example a boy may inherit	a small jaw from one ancestor and large teeth from another.	10.931158219987559
13971. in the past	an orthodontist might have tried over four or five years to straighten	and fit the boy's large teeth into a jaw that despite some growth	would never accommodate them.	6.18043812895511
13972. now a dentist can recommend extraction	immediately.	14.292909848606126
13973. in other cases in view of present-day knowledge	of head growth orthodontists will recommend waiting four or five	years before treatment.	7.071401652661043
13974. the child is kept on call and the orthodontist	watches the growth.	13.74377521130111
13975. nature often takes care of the problem	says dr brodie.	9.552325603015944
13976. a child with a certain type of head and teeth	will outgrow tooth deformity.	10.873205989805843
13977. that is why dr brodie	asks parents not to insist against their dentist's advice that their	child have orthodontic work done too early.	6.739485781184825
13978. both because of our	culture's stress on beauty and our improved economic conditions	some parents demand that the dentist try to correct a problem before it	is wise to do so.	8.11028924825893
13979. let the orthodontist decide the proper time to start	treatment he urges.	9.105123702641823
13980. superior new material for orthodontic	work is another result of research.	9.190083428414619
13981. plastics are easier to handle	than the vulcanized rubber formerly used and they save time and money.	6.428612390591998
13982. plaster of paris once utilized in making impressions of teeth has	been replaced by alginates that work quickly	and accurately and with least discomfort to a child.	7.515384288985141
13983. best	as a rule the earlier general dental treatment is started	the less expensive and more satisfactory it is likely to be.	6.410186360242649
13984. after your child's baby teeth are all in- usually at the age	of two and one half to three- it's time for that first dental appointment	dr brodie advises.	6.373121572281221
13985. then see that your youngster	has a routine checkup once a year.	8.066101971786898
13986. to help prevent orthodontic	problems from arising your dentist can do these things:	he can correct decay thus preventing early loss of teeth.	7.820130300906626
13987. if	a child does lose his first teeth prematurely because of decay-	and if no preventive steps are taken- the other teeth may shift out	of position become overcrowded and malformed.	4.574512398000195
13988. in turn the other teeth	are likely to decay because food particles may become impacted in them.	11.313802576678256
13989. from time to time the medium mentions other people around him	who were on the other side and reports what they are saying.	10.084865351380337
13990. after	a while there come initials and names and he is interested to hear	some rather unusual family nicknames.	9.177443743976047

14000. the mediums with whom the parapsychology foundation	is working in this experiment are in a waking or only slightly dissociated	state so that the sitter can make comments ask and answer questions	instead of talking with a control who speaks through an	entranced sensitive.	8.416765190285997
14001. what we have here is in some ways more like an ordinary	conversation.	12.12984952044838
14002. but it is not really only a conversation.	25.01340923308455
14003. many a sitter has been amazed to realize that	the medium was describing very vividly his state of mind.	7.124807018104398
14004. he himself	might not have been really aware of his own mood; it had been latent	unspecified semi-conscious and only partly realized- until she	described it to him! most striking indeed is this beyond-normal ability	to put a finger on pre-conscious moods and to clarify them.	5.441480257255221
14005. however in the next visit that the researcher made to the medium	he did not receive a personal reading.	9.338079661276883

14007. for this was to be a proxy sitting.	13.817792745282954
14008. as	was noted earlier it is important that in valid objective study of	this sort of communication the interested sitter should be separated	from the sensitive.	9.022806312783187
14009. dr karlis osis director of research at	the parapsychology foundation described the basis for the experiment	in a tomorrow article	.	7.331392384085626
14010. he remarked: it has been clearly established	that in a number of instances the message did not come from a	spirit but was received telepathically by the medium from the sitter.	9.221961654999204
14011. the possibility has to be ruled out that the medium's esp	may tap the memory of the sitter and to do this the two central	characters in this drama must be separated.	7.975236483762824
14012. one way to do	this is by proxy sittings wherein the person seeking a message	does not himself meet with the medium but is represented by a substitute	the proxy sitter.	9.17996889181324
14013. if the latter knows nothing about the absent sitter	except his name he cannot possibly	give any clues conscious or unconscious far less ask leading questions.	6.824807447346248

14015. sometimes in these experiments appointment	sittings are used.	8.049854042889699
14016. here the absent sitter makes a date	with a communicator asking him	to come in at a certain hour when a channel will be open for	him.	11.306998471006231
14017. in this case the proxy sitter will know only the name of the communicator	nothing else.	10.413144088519363

14021. it	is now harder to assume telepathy as a basis for the statements- though	research still does not know how far afield esp can range.	7.469053038429619
14022. now the original absent sitter must decide whether the	statements are meaningful to him.	10.508271872857435
14023. here again laboratory approaches	are being evolved for it is recognized how elastic these readings	can be how they can apply to many people and are often stated	in general terms all too easily applied to any individual's own case.	6.391531961180666
14024. if you look at a reading meant for someone else you will probably	see that many of the items could be considered as applicable to you	even when you were not in the picture at all! an interested sitter	may think the sensitive has made a hit describing something accurately	for him but can he really be sure that another sitter hearing	the same statement would not apply it subjectively to his own circumstances?	9.755673113020235
14025. 	it is of course easy to see how j will mean	uncle jack to one person and little jane to another.	6.395701109019768
14026. a journey	a	little white house a change of outlook can apply to many	people.	11.678626500687512
14027. and even more complex items can be interpreted to conform	to one's own point of view which is by nature so personal.	6.789545261213979
14028. one sitter	may think a leather couch identifies a reading as surely directed	to him; to another it seems that nobody but his father ever	used the phrase atta boy!   to get around this quite difficult	corner there is one first aid to objectiveness: prevent the	distant sitter from knowing which reading was for him.	6.863468028194296
14029. if he is	not told which of four or five readings was meant for him he can more	readily assess each item in a larger frame: does that statement	really sound as if it were for me significant in my particular life?	7.337868638547742
14030. 	or am i taking something that could really apply to almost anybody	and forgetting that many other people probably have had a similar	experience?	7.959525005226466
14031.    conversely experimenters would consider as impressive	such statements as the following which if they turned out	to be hits are so unusual as to be really significant:   he	had four children two sets of twins.	5.789505147981581

14035. methods have been developed of assigning weights	to statements; that is it is known empirically that names beginning	with r are more common than those beginning with z; that	fewer women are named miranda than elizabeth; that in the united	states more people die of heart disease than of smallpox.	5.0091363109875795
14036. so each reading	can be given a weight and each reading a score by adding up these	weights.	10.189382849597795
14037. specific dates would be important as would double names.	8.296360202242255
14038. various categories have been explored to find out about these empirical	probabilities against which to measure the readings.	10.792410656294432
14039. in	the parapsychology foundation's long-range experiment readings	are made by a variety of sensitives for a large number of cooperating	sitters trying to throw light on this question of the significance	of mediumistic statements.	6.792769225303104
14040. it is very important indeed in the field	of extra-sensory perception and its relation to the survival hypothesis	to know whether the statements are actually only those which any	intuitive person might venture and an eager sitter attach to himself.	9.432514006925446
14041. or on the other hand are unlikely facts being stated facts which are	in themselves significant and not easily applicable to everybody?	8.057195514994415
14042. 	that is one thing the experiments are designed to find out.	11.799675979942526
14043. so after the sitting has been held several readings at one time	are mailed and the distant sitter	must mark each little item as correct	incorrect doubtful or especially significant	.	6.025063519190283
14044. he is required to	mark every item and to indicate which reading he feels is actually his.	11.927211069229509
14045. all these evaluations are then totted up and tabulated by adding	up the hits and significants with the weight placed on those in the	sitter's own reading.	5.982721473214727
14046. that is if he marks as most correct a reading	not meant for him the total experimental score falls.	12.054978182192944
14047. conversely	if he gives a heavy rating to his own reading and finds more	accurate facts in it than in the others a point is chalked up for	the intrinsic objective meaningfulness of this type of mediumistic material.	6.748128604525202
14048. and there are some positive results though the final findings	will not be known for a long time- and then further research can	be formulated.	9.474231443307506
14049. in another approach to the same procedure the	content of the readings is analyzed so as to see how the particular medium	is likely to slant her statements.	8.271431883567464

14334. on april 17 1610 the sturdy little three-masted bark discovery	weighed anchor in st katherine's pool london and	floated down the thames toward the sea.	7.425577160871895

14350. this	is the story of his last tragic voyage as nearly as we are able- or	ever probably will be able- to determine:   the sailing in	the spring of 1610 was hudson's fourth in four years.	6.413576722157314

14397. with difficulty	hudson persuaded him to rejoin the ship and they sailed from iceland.	7.3776771329630515
14398. early in june the discovery passed desolation	and in mid-june entered the furious overfall.	8.333587335718626
14399. floating ice bore down from the north and west.	9.426691639570311
14400. fog hung	over the route constantly.	10.02545403598529
14401. turbulent tides rose as much as fifty feet.	8.062960614674079
14402. the ship's compass was useless because of the nearness of the magnetic	north pole.	8.400076780909728
14403. as the bergs grew larger hudson was	forced to turn south into what is now ungava bay an inlet of the	great strait.	6.595649390574525
14404. after finding that its coasts led nowhere however he	turned north again toward the main ice-filled passageway- and the	crew at first uneasy then frightened rebelled.	6.6711962575864145
14405. the trouble	was at least partly juet's doing.	7.805579964759379
14406. for weeks he had been saying that	hudson's idea of sailing through to java was absurd.	8.939006181716131
14407. the great	crushing ice masses coming into view made him sound like the voice	of pure reason.	6.690782232702088
14408. a group of sailors announced to hudson that they would	sail no farther.	12.659605690584913
14409. instead of quelling the dissension as many	captains of the era would have done	hudson decided to be reasonable.	9.372602526673026
14410. he went to his cabin and emerged carrying a large chart which	he set up in view of the crew.	13.490287987743312
14411. patiently he explained what he knew	about their course and their objectives.	6.695246722323198
14412. when hudson had finished	the town meeting broke down into a general wordy	argument.	11.763444513203535
