14413. one man remarked that if he had a hundred pounds he would give ninety	of them to be back in england.	10.12314384594101
14414. up spoke carpenter staffe who	said he wouldn't give ten pounds to be home.	7.495134858309841
14415. the meeting broke up.	12.004620095735241
14416. hudson was free to sail on.	12.021440568928027
14417. all through july the discovery picked her way along the 450-mile-long	strait avoiding ice and rocky islands.	6.4679440957250245
14418. on august 3 two massive	headlands reared out of the mists- great gateways never before	so far as hudson knew seen by europeans.	8.092140886391933
14419. to starboard was a cape	a thousand feet high patched with ice and snow populated by thousands	of screaming sea birds.	6.396440501849146
14420. to port was a point 200 feet high rising behind	to a precipice of 2000 feet.	9.574449822887605
14421. hudson named the capes digges and	wolstenholme for two of his backers.	7.606829167355574
14422. hudson pointed the discovery	down the east coast of the newly discovered sea	confident he was on his way to the warm waters of the	pacific.	11.432111027013837
14423. after three weeks' swift sailing however the ship entered	an area of shallow marshes and river deltas.	6.081907113770495
14424. the	great sea to the westwards was a dead end.	10.122666088011819
14425. this must have	been hudson's blackest discovery.	7.611077007493669
14426. for he seemed to sense at once	that before him was no south sea but the solid bulk of the north	american continent.	11.517196395406033
14427. this was the bitter end and hudson seemed to	know he was destined to failure.	8.809010352485455
14428. feverishly he tried to brush	away this intuition.	10.89016717072118
14429. north and south east and west back and forth	he sailed in the land-locked bay plowing furiously forward until land	appeared then turning to repeat the process day after day week after	week.	6.364313569368747
14430. hundreds of miles to the north the route back to england	through the furious overfall was again filling with ice.	12.433525210385296
14431. the men were at first puzzled then angered by the aimless tacking.	8.77012505679465
14432. once more juet's complaints were the loudest.	10.091741426849339
14433. hudson's reply	was to accuse the mate of disloyalty.	4.448904925319317
14434. juet demanded that hudson prove	his charges in an open trial.	10.42609424817182
14435. the trial was held september	10.	13.392710457549702
14436. hudson presiding heard juet's defense then called for testimony	from crew members.	7.155735428721971
14437. juet had made plentiful enemies several men	stepped forward.	7.83590599705012
14438. hands on bible seaman lodley and carpenter staffe	swore that juet had tried to persuade them to keep muskets and swords	in their cabins.	10.220425588059253
14439. cook bennett mathues said juet had predicted	bloodshed on the ship.	6.399059726476476
14440. others added that juet had wanted to turn the	ship homeward.	11.695347813364497
14441. hudson deposed juet and cut his pay.	8.694266352346194
14442. the new	mate was robert bylot talented but inexperienced.	10.13950823574525
14443. there were other	shifts and pay cuts according to the way individuals had conducted themselves.	10.294714382469927
14444. the important result however was that juet and francis	clemens the deposed boatswain became hudson's sworn enemies.	8.165281724714635
14445. as hudson resumed his desperate criss-crossing of the little	bay every incident lessened the crew's respect for him.	4.674818202307364
14446. once	after the discovery lay for a week in rough weather hudson ordered	the anchor raised before the sea had calmed.	8.740196188395505
14447. just as it was being	hauled inboard a sea hit the ship.	10.870117245878335
14448. michael butt and adame moore	were thrown off the capstan and badly injured.	7.6207966551846615
14449. the anchor cable would	have been lost overboard but philip staffe was on hand to sever	it with his axe.	7.020516794920122
14450. thomas douglas fifth earl of selkirk a noble humanitarian	scot concerned with the plight of the crofters of his native highlands	conceived a plan to settle them in the valley of the red river	of the north.	9.18157070588825
14451. since the land he desired lay within the great northern	empire of the hudson's bay company he purchased great blocks of	the comany's stock with the view to controlling its policies.	4.832107900430308
14452. having	achieved this end he was able to buy 116000 square miles in the	valleys of the red and assiniboine rivers.	10.000088782375446
14453. the grant which stretched	southward to lake traverse- the headwaters of the red- was	made in may 1811 and by october of that year a small group of scots	was settling for the winter at york factory on hudson bay.	5.493807871912753
14454. thus	at the same time that william henry harrison was preparing to pacify	the aborigines of indiana territory and winning fame at the battle	of tippecanoe anglo-saxon settlement made a great leap into the	center of the north american continent to the west of the american	agricultural frontier.	8.006487541724873
14455. seven hundred miles south of york factory	at the forks of the red and the assiniboine twenty-three	men located a settlement in august 1812.	6.287925463316051
14456. by october the little	colony about fort douglas numbered 100.	10.275563983559923
14457. within	a few years the scots engaged in breaking the thick sod and stirring	the rich soil of the valley were joined by a group called meurons.	6.6838513918349225
14458. the latter members of two regiments of swiss mercenaries transported	by great britain to canada to fight the americans in the	war of 1812 had settled in montreal and kingston at the close of	the war in 1815.	9.323796507786748
14459. selkirk persuaded eighty men and four officers to go	to red river where they were to serve as a military force to protect	his settlers from the hostile northwest company which resented the	intrusion of farmers into the fur traders' empire.	6.188429898812033
14460. the mercenaries	were little interested in farming and added nothing to the output of	the farm plots on which all work was still done with hoes as late as	1818.	8.43514280369302
14461. it was the low yield of the selkirk plots and the ravages	of grasshoppers in 1818 that led to the dispersal of the settlement	southward.	9.453161348580574
14462. when late in the summer the full extent of the damage was	assessed all but fifty of the scots swiss and metis moved up	the red to the mouth of the pembina river.	10.432422075265775
14463. here they built huts and	a stockade named fort daer after selkirk's barony in scotland.	5.920929176063694
14464. the new site was somewhat warmer than fort douglas and much closer	to the great herds of buffalo on which the settlement must depend for	food.	9.037484702941418
14465. the selkirk settlers had been anticipated in their move	southward by british fur traders.	6.823189926125515
14466. for many years the northwest company	had its southern headquarters at prairie du chien on the mississippi	river some 300 miles southeast of present-day st paul	minnesota.	9.995848563239907
14467. when in 1816 an act of congress forced the foreign firm	out of the united states its british-born employees now become american	citizens- joseph rolette joseph renville and alexis bailly-	continued in the fur business.	5.548737242282282
14468. on big stone lake near the	headwaters of the red river robert dickson superintendent of	the western indian department of canada had a trading post and planned	in 1818 to build a fort to be defended by twenty men and two small	artillery pieces.	8.653899181328699
14469. his trading goods came from canada to the forks	of red river and from selkirk's settlement he brought them south	in carts.	5.9477404555759055
14470. these carts were of a type devised in pembina in the days	of alexander henry the younger about a decade before the selkirk	colony was begun.	9.045559590755945
14471. in 1802 henry referred to our new carts as	being about four feet off the ground and carrying five times as much as	a horse could pack.	7.866581040410852
14472. they were held together by pegs and withes and	in later times drawn by a single ox in thills.	9.702516964424072
14473. it was dickson	who suggested to lord selkirk that he return to the atlantic coast	by way of the united states.	11.403338155220732
14474. in september 1817 at fort daer	dickson met the noble lord whom with the help of a band of sioux	he escorted to prairie du chien.	11.239042197599998
14475. during the trip selkirk decided	that the route through illinois territory to indiana and the eastern	united states was the best route for goods from england to reach	red river and that the united states was a better source of supply	for many goods than either canada or england.	7.206909437222256
14476. upon arriving at	baltimore selkirk on december 22 wrote to john quincy adams	secretary of state at washington inquiring about laws covering trade	with missouri and illinois territories.	7.362857178496041
14477. this traffic he	declared prophetically tho' it might be of small account at first	would increase with the progress of our settlements h.	6.231489409418499
14478. the route which he had traveled and which he believed might develop	into a trade route was followed by his settlers earlier than he might	have expected.	9.62315429181093
14479. in 1819 grasshoppers again destroyed the crop at the	forks and in december 1819 twenty men left fort	daer for the most northerly american outpost at prairie du chien.	7.182388397809737
14480. it was a three-month journey in the dead of winter followed by three	months of labor on mackinac boats.	11.01044497418713
14481. with these completed and ice	gone from the st peter's river	their 250 bushels of wheat 100 bushels of oats and barley and 30 bushels	of peas and some chickens were loaded onto the flat-bottomed boats	and rowed up the river to big stone lake across into lake traverse	and down the red.	5.184369991370793
14482. they reached fort douglas in june 1820.	13.31216385812593
14483. this	epic effort to secure seed for the colony cost selkirk 1040.	6.833672204034929
14484. nevertheless so short was the supply of seed that the settlers were	forced to retreat to fort daer for food.	8.699755086625682
14485. thereafter seed and food became	more plentiful and the colony remained in the north the year round.	8.356218622544592
14486. activity by british traders and the presence of a colony	on the red prompted the united state war department in 1819 to send	lieutenant-colonel henry leavenworth from detroit to put a post	300 miles northwest of prairie du chien until then the most advanced	united states post.	7.7437749041997765
14487. in september 1822 two companies of infantry	arrived at the mouth of the st peter's river the head of navigation	on the mississippi and began construction of fort st	anthony which upon completion was renamed in honor of its commander	colonel josiah snelling.	6.5256622060625435
14488. it was from the american outposts	that red river shortages of livestock were to be made good.	15.659386643602724
14489. hercules	l dousman fur trader and merchant at prairie du chien contracted	to supply selkirk's people with some 300 head of cattle and	alexis bailly and francois labothe were hired as drovers.	4.887581178928881
14490. bailly	after leaving fort snelling in august 1821 was forced to leave	some of the cattle at the hudson's bay company's post on lake	traverse in the sieux country and reached fort garry as the	selkirk hudson's bay company center was now called late in the	fall.	5.902522675789834
14491. he set out on his 700-mile return journey with five families	of discontented and disappointed swiss who turned their eyes toward	the united states.	6.3880178942775805
14492. observing their distressing condition colonel	snelling allowed these half-starved immigrants to settle on the military	reservation.	6.659945723165099
14493. as these swiss were moving from the selkirk	settlement to become the first civilian residents of minnesota dousman	of michilimackinac michigan and prairie du chien was traveling	to red river to open a trade in merchandise.	6.803549886464377
14494. early in 1822 he was	at fort garry offering to bring in pork flour liquor and tobacco.	9.782259384917623
14495. alexander mcdonnell governor of red river and james bird	a chief factor of the hudson's bay company ordered such sundry	articles to a value of 4500.	5.195270284024173
14496. for its part the hudson's	bay company was troubled by the approach of american settlement.	10.197353316329256
14497. as the time drew near for the drawing of the british-american frontier	by terms of the agreement of 1818 the company suspected that the	pembina colony- its own post and fort daer- was on american	territory.	5.496856684207888
14498. accordingly selkirk's agents ordered the settlers to move	north and by october john halkett had torn down both posts floating	the timber to the forks in rafts.	6.821185790523235
14499. i have done everything	he wrote to break up the whole of that unfortunate establishment	h.	12.732945984215128
14500. despite company threats duly carried through to cut	off supplies of powder ball and thread for fishing nets about 350	persons stayed in the village.	8.099536484657621
14501. they would attempt to bring supplies	from st louis or prairie du chien at great expense as well	as danger.	8.057054565830658
14502. at fort garry some of the swiss also decided	to cast their lot with the united states and in 1823 several families	paid guides to take them to fort snelling.	11.50753028148811
14503. the disasters of 1825-1826	caused more to leave.	6.495680232476814
14504. after heavy rains and an onslaught of mice	snow fell on october 15 1825 and remained on the ground through	a winter so cold that the ice on the red was five feet thick.	8.563587993865731
14505. in april	came a rapid thaw that produced high waters which did not recede until	mid-june.	7.4240890207848445
14506. on june 24 more than 400 families started the three-month	trip across the plains to the mississippi.	8.931341893337295
14507. by fall 443 survivors	of this arduous journey were clustered about fort snelling but	most of them were sent on to galena and st louis with a few going	as far as vevay indiana a notable swiss center in the united	states.	5.907897283223111
14508. in 1837 157 red river people with more than 200 cattle were	living on the reservation at fort snelling.	10.569823590192552
14509. below the fort	high bluffs extended uninterruptedly for six miles along the mississippi	river.	6.751542223227189
14510. at the point where they ended another settlement grew	up around a chapel built at the boat landing by father lucian galtier	in 1840.	10.667901091209972
14511. its people including pierre bottineau and other american	fur company employees and the refugees from fort garry were	joined by the remaining scots and swiss from fort snelling when major	joseph plympton expelled them from the reservation in may 1840.	5.574254541851984
14512. the resultant town platted in 1847 and named for the patron of father	galtier's mission st paul was to become an important center	of the fur trade and was to take on a new interest for those selkirkers	who remained at red river.	8.004911228521056
14513. while population at fort	garry increased rapidly from 2417 in 1831 to 4369 in 1840 economic	opportunities did not increase at a similar rate.	5.738560658088659
14514. accordingly though	the practice violated the no-trading provision of the selkirk charter	which reserved all such activity in merchandise and furs to the	hudson's bay company some settlers went into trade.	6.234786298057524
14515. the company	maintained a store at which products of england could be purchased	and brought in goods for the new merchants on the understanding that they	refrain from trading in furs.	6.7301150858822405
14516. despite this prohibiton by 1844 some	of the fort garry merchants were trading with the indians for furs.	8.811399163854395
14517. in june 1845 the governor and council of assiniboia imposed	a 20 per cent duty on imports via hudson's bay which were viewed	as aimed at the very vitals of the company's trade and power.	5.245519931055506
14518. to reduce further the flow of goods from england the company's	local officials asked that its london authorities refrain from forwarding	any more trade goods to these men.	8.60280597645541
14519. with their customary source	of supply cut off the fort garry free traders engaged three men	to cart goods to them from the mississippi country.	7.613467277930166
14520. others carried	pemmican from the forks to st paul and goods from st	paul to red river as in the summer of 1847 when one trader wells	transported twenty barrels of whisky to the british settlement.	8.660877891136364
14521. this	trade was subject to a tariff of 7.	7.169773750275948
14522. 5 per cent after february 1835	but much was smuggled into assiniboia with the result that the duty	was reduced by 1841 to 4 per cent on the initiative of the london committee.	12.32413256613032
14523. the trade in a few commodities noted above was to grow	in volume as a result of changes both north and south of the 49th parallel.	9.167465253067922
14524. the letters of the common soldiers are rich in humor.	17.342452367068745
14525. indeed no richer	humor is to be found in the whole of american literature than in	the letters of the semi-literate men who wore the blue and the gray.	8.603189958173354
14526. some	of their figures of speech were colorful and expressive.	9.53026985578985
14527. a confederate	observed that the yankees were: thicker than lise on a hen	and a dam site ornraier.	5.2765737936685975
14528. another reported that his comrades were	in fine spirits pitching around like a blind dog in a meat house.	8.55258095605002
14529. a third wrote that it was raining like poring peas on a rawhide.	9.693007405912471
14530. yanks were equally adept at figurative expression.	9.3616779423824
14531. one	wrote: i am so hungry i could eat a rider off his horse +	snap at the stirups.	4.5361244676170385
14532. a second reported that the dilapidated houses	in virginia look like the latter end of original sin and hard times.	10.242515744189312
14533. a third remarked of slowness of southerners: they moved	about from corner to corner as uneasy as a litter of hungry leaches	on the neck of a wooden god.	5.460561820948738
14534. still another annoyed by the brevity	of a recently received missive wrote: yore letter was short and	sweet jist like a roasted maget.	6.557103119846255
14535. a yankee sergeant gave the following	description of his sweetheart: my girl is none of your one-horse	girls.	5.831114870772468
14536. she is a regular stub and twister double geered.	13.061546847402582
14537. h	she is well-educated and refined all wildcat and fur and union from	the muzzle to the crupper.	4.968021603125643
14538. humor found many modes of expression.	10.269234672886379
14539. a texan wrote to a male companion at home: what has become	of halda and laura?	5.59784295572516
14540.  h when you see them again give them my	love- not best respects now but love by god.	9.068608448341836
14541. william r stillwell	an admirable georgian whose delightful correspondence is preserved	in the georgia department of archives and history liked	to	tease his wife in his letters.	5.691807239942939
14542. after he had been away from home about	a year he wrote: dear wife if i did not write and receive	letters from you i believe that i would forgit that i was married	i don't feel much like a maryed man but i never forgit it sofar	as to court enny other lady but if i should you must forgive me as	i am	so forgitful.	8.171100755493343
14543. a yank disturbed by his increasing corpulence wrote:	i am growing so fat h i am a burden 2 myself.	6.330337309427201
14544. another	yank parodied the familiar bedtime prayer: now i lay me down	to sleep the gray-backs o'er my body creep; if they should bite	before i wake i pray the lord their jaws to break.	5.157014322158927
14545. charles	thiot a splendid georgia soldier differed from most of his	comrades in the ranks in that he was the owner of a large plantation	well-educated and nearly fifty years of age.	7.818397391924879
14546. but he was very much like	his associates in his hatred of camp routine.	13.48467277074753
14547. near the end of his	service he wrote that when the war was over he was going to buy two pups	name one of them fall-in and the other close-up and	then shoot them both and that will be the end of 'fall-in' and	'close-up'.	8.176365020891154
14548. the soldiers who comprised the rank and file	of the civil war armies were an earthy people.	10.490296137408771
14549. they talked and	wrote much about the elemental functions of the body.	8.742907444498833
14550. one of the most	common of camp maladies was diarrhoea.	17.576323749510962
14551. men of more delicate sensibilities	referred to this condition as looseness of the bowels; but	a much more common designation was the sh-ts.	5.680783707444352
14552. a michigan soldier	stationed in georgia wrote in 1864: i expect to be tough	as a knott as soon as i get over the georgia shitts.	8.795613173911232
14553. johnny rebs	from the deep south who were plagued with diarrhoea after transfer	to the virginia front often informed their families that they were suffering	from the the virginia quickstep.	5.849030244930171
14554. a georgia soldier	gave his wife the following description of the cause and consequence	of diarrhoea: i have bin a little sick with diorah two or three	days h.	9.038245501241251
14555. i eat too much eggs and poark it sowered on my stomack	and turn loose on me.	7.215716713956752
14556. a michigan soldier wrote his brother:	i am well at present with the exception i have got the dyerear	and i hope thease few lines find you the same.	8.64817749717703
14557. the letters	which poured forth from camps were usually written under adverse circumstances.	6.43569659086164
14558. save for brief periods in garrison or winter quarters soldiers	rarely enjoyed the luxury of a writing desk or table.	8.166400228568692
14559. most of	the letters were written in the hubbub of camp on stumps pieces of	bark drum heads or the knee.	6.691810372934786
14560. in the south after the first year of	the war paper and ink were very poor.	15.378168900278546
14561. scarcity of paper caused many	southerners to adopt the practice of cross-writing ie after writing	from left to right of the page in the usual manner they gave the	sheet a half turn and wrote from end to end across the lines previously	written.	6.020204635854053
14562. sometimes soldiers wrote letters while bullets were whizzing	about their heads.	8.617320388992095
14563. a yank writing from vicksburg may 28 1863	stated not less than 50 balls have passed over me since i commenced	writing h.	7.323783005103598
14564. i could tell you of plenty narrow escapes but we	take no notice of them now.	11.010061520030126
14565. a reb stationed near petersburg informed	his mother: i need not tell you that i dodge pretty often	h for you can see that very plainly by the blots in this letter.	6.211195414981417
14566. just	count each blot a dodge and add in a few for i don't dodge every	time.	5.787878545645391
14567. another reb writing under similar circumstances before atlanta	reported: the yankees keep shooting so i am afraid they	will knock over my ink so i will close.	5.452945967763977
14568. the most	common type of letter was that of soldier husbands to their wives.	11.586169008072037
14569. but	fathers often addressed communications to their small children; and	these full of homely advice are among the most human and revealing	of civil war letters.	4.977896096400549
14570. rebs who owned slaves occasionally would include	in their letters admonitions or greetings to members of the negro	community.	8.513574787819643
14571. occasionally they would write to the slaves.	11.268563320219153
14572. early in the	war it was not uncommon for planters' sons to retain in camp negro	body servants to perform the menial chores such as cooking foraging	cleaning the quarters shining shoes and laundering clothes.	7.2123397373738
14573. sometimes these servants wrote or dictated for enclosure with the letters	of their soldier-masters messages to their relatives and to members	of their owners' families.	4.72797237063802
14574. unmarried soldiers carried on	correspondence with sweethearts at home.	8.358654772058
14575. owing to the restrained usages	characteristic of 19th-century america these letters usually were	stereotyped and revealed little depth of feeling.	4.828536402707361
14576. occasionally	gay young blades would write vividly to boon companions at home about	their amorous exploits in richmond petersburg washington or	nashville.	7.079706783207879
14577. but these comments are hardly printable.	12.34956342330806
14578. an alabama soldier	whose	feminine associations were of the more admirable type wrote boastfully	of his achievements among the virginia belles: they thout	i was a saint.	7.090941019636576
14579. i told them some sweet lies and they believed it	all h i would tell them i got a letter from home stating that five	of my negroes had runaway and ten of pappies but i wold say i	recond he did not mind it for he had a plenty more left and then they	would lean to me like a sore eyd kitten to a basin of milk.	6.725618380358626
14580. some of the letters were pungently expressive.	19.003696185920436
14581. an ohio soldier who	from a comrade just returned from leave received an unfavorable comment	on the conduct of his sister took pen in hand and delivered himself	thus: dear sis alf sed he heard that you and hardy was	a runing together all the time and he though he wod gust quit having	any thing mor to doo with you for he thought it was no more yuse h.	6.0226079815124285
14582. i think you made a dam good chouise to turn off as nise a feler as alf	dyer and let that orney thefin drunkard damed card playing sun	of a bich com to sea you the god damed theaf and lop yeard pigen tode	helion he is too orney for hel h.	7.4355573430340955
14583. i will shute him as shore as	i sea him.	9.293643353134241
14584. initiation into combat sometimes elicited from	soldier correspondents choice comments about their experiences and reactions.	7.555326905675234
14585. a federal infantryman wrote to his father shortly after his	first skirmish in virginia: dear pa h.	5.873271952893311
14586. went out a skouting	yesterday.	13.079615081416968
14587. we got to one house where there were five secessionist they	brok + run and arch holored out to shoot the ornery suns of biches	and we all let go at them.	5.86293230443976
14588. thay may say what they please but godamit	pa it is fun.	10.065691834527202
14589. some of the choicest remarks made by soldiers	in their letters were in disparagement of unpopular officers.	8.349801371112246
14590. a mississippi	soldier wrote: our general reub davis h is a vain	stuck-up illiterate ass.	5.916272903698296
14591. an alabamian wrote: col henry	is an ignoramus fit for nothing higher than the cultivation	of corn.	5.17067307286567
14592. a floridian stated that his officers were not fit to	tote guts to a bear.	9.261397680895234
14593. on december 9 1862 sergeant edwin h	fay an unusual louisianan who held ab and ma degrees	from harvard university and who before the war was headmaster of a	private school for boys in louisiana wrote his wife: i saw pemberton	and he is the most insignificant puke i ever saw h.	5.665312814092756
14594. his head	cannot contain enough sense to command a regiment much less a corps	h.	9.96552547120204
14595. jackson h runs first and his cavalry are well drilled to follow	their leader.	6.182813752144548
14596. he is not worth shucks.	23.068949973083132
14597. but he is a west point	graduate and therefore must be born to command.	12.342829837374092
14598. similar comments	about officers are to be found in the letters of northern soldiers.	16.27553450241977
14599. a massachusetts soldier who seems to have been a civil war	version of bill mauldin wrote: the officers consider themselves	as made of a different material from the low fellows in the ranks	h.	6.624603906526729
14600. they get all the glory and most of the pay and don't earn ten	cents apiece on the average the drunken rascals.	9.2800346818209
14601. private george	gray hunter of pennsylvania wrote: i am well convinced in my	own mind that had it not been for officers this war would have ended	long ago.	6.246422581962118
14602. another yankee became so disgusted as to state: i	wish to god one half of our officers were knocked in the head by slinging	them against the other half.	9.004961567553217
14603. no group of officers	came in for more spirited denunciation than the doctors.	8.135179344434569
14604. one federal	soldier wrote: the docters is no a conte h hell will be filde	with docters and offersey when this war is over.	7.070224520197387
14605. shortly after	the beginning of sherman's georgia campaign an ailing yank	wrote his homefolk: the surgeon insisted on sending me to the hospital	for treatment.	4.746986152879804
14606. i insisted on takeing the field and prevailed-	thinking that i had better die by rebel bullets than by union	quackery.	8.719016734668832
14607. the attitudes which the rebs and yanks took toward	each other were very much the same and ranged over the same gamut	of feeling from friendliness to extreme hatred.	7.084745865411871
14608. the rebs were to	a massachusetts corporal fighting madmen or not men at all but whiskey	+ gunpowder put into a human frame.	8.164199552487355
14609. a pennsylvania soldier	wrote that they were the hardest looking set of men that ever i saw	they looked as if they had been fed on vinegar and shavings h.	8.081707276884744
14610. private jenkins lloyd jones of the wisconsin light artillery wrote	in his diary: i strolled among the alabamans on the right	h found some of the greenest specimens of humanity i think in the universe	their ignorance being little less than the slave they despise	with as imperfect a dialect 'they recooned as how you'uns all would	be a heap wus to we'uns all'.	5.89135232100333
14611. in a similar vein but writing	from the opposite side thomas taylor a private in the 6th alabama	volunteers in a letter to his wife stated: you know that	my heart is with you but i never could have been satisfied to have staid	at home when my country is invaded by a thievin foe by a set of	cowardly skunks whose motto is booty h.	6.636775543274531
14612. the popularity of folklore in america stands in direct proportion	to the popularity of nationalism in america.	11.66181773301172
14613. and the emphasis on nationalism	in america is in proportion to the growth of american influence	across the world.	10.999652283870146
14614. thus if we are to observe american folklore	in the twentieth century we will do well to establish the relationships	between folklore nationalism and imperialism at the outset.	12.6601018670219
14615. historians have come to recognize two cardinal facts concerning nationalism	every age rewrites the events	of its history in terms of what should have been creating legends	about itself that rationalize contemporary beliefs and excuse contemporary	actions.	6.459261893532837
14616. what actually occurred in the past is seldom as important	as a country	superimposes its cultural and political attitudes on others it searches	its heritage in hopes of justifying its aggressiveness.	8.580378535360216
14617. its folklore	and legend usually disguised as history are allowed to account	for group actions to provide a focal point for group loyalty and to	become a cohesive force for national identification.	6.173953985572561
14618. one can apply	these facts to britain in the late eighteenth and nineteenth centuries	as she spread her dominion over palm and pine and they can be	applied again to the united states in more recent years.	12.078713741954344
14619. the popularity	of local color literature before the spanish-american war the	steady currency of the lincoln myth the increased emphasis on the	frontier west in our mass media are cases in point.	5.565170367941671
14620. nor is it an accident	that baseball growing into the national game in the last 75 years	has become a microcosm of american life that learned societies such	as the american folklore society and the american historical	association were founded in the 1880s or that courses in american literature	american civilization american anything have swept our school	and college curricula.	8.60449478578801
14621. of course nationalism has really	outlived its usefulness in a country as world-oriented as ours and its	continued existence reflects one of the major culture lags of the	twentieth-century	united states.	6.310916399881114
14622. yet nationalism has lost few of its	charms for the historian writer or man in the street.	10.04650177338353
14623. it is an understandable	paradox that most american history and most american literature	is today written from an essentially egocentric and isolationistic	point of view at the very time america is spreading her dominion	over palm and pine.	7.8812922062942254
14624. after all the average american as he lies and	waits for the enemy in korea or as she scans the newspaper in some vain	hope of personal contact with the front is unconcerned that his or	her plight is the result of a complex of personal economic and governmental	actions far beyond the normal citizen's comprehension and control.	8.745197853001233
14625. anyone's identification with an international struggle whether	warlike or peaceful requires absurd oversimplification and intense	emotional involvement.	5.073191024227263
14626. such identification comes for each group in each	crisis by rewriting history into legend and developing appropriate	national heroes.	8.447527646216452
14627. in america such self-deception has served	a particularly useful purpose.	6.726043637137287
14628. a heterogeneous people have needed it	to attain an element of cultural and political cohesion in a new and	ever-changing	land.	9.879916859649796
14629. but we must never forget most of the appropriate	heroes and their legends were created overnight to answer immediate needs	almost always with conscious aims and ends.	7.216016290858214
14630. parson weems's george	washington became the symbol of honesty and the father image of	the uniting states.	7.597483200700175
14631. abraham lincoln emerged as an incarnation of	the national constitution.	6.510417214440966
14632. robert e lee represented the dignity	needed by a rebelling confederacy.	9.000079010437936
14633. and their roles are paralleled by	those of patrick henry nathan hale andrew jackson davy crockett	theodore roosevelt and many many more.	5.915875380924687
14634. therefore the	scholar as he looks at our national folklore of the last 60 years	most of the legends that are created	to fan the fires of patriotism are essentially propagandistic and are	the concept that an american national	folklore exists is itself probably another propagandistic legend.	7.504700778964227
14635. folklore is individually created art that a homogeneous group	of people preserve vary and recreate through oral transmission.	6.630368353669302
14636. it	has come to mean myths legends tales songs proverbs riddles superstitions	rhymes and such literary forms of expression.	7.731868708761873
14637. related to	written literature and often remaining temporarily frozen in written	form it loses its vitality when transcribed or removed from its oral	existence.	5.403304622097368
14638. though it may exist in either literate or illiterate societies	it assumes a role of true cultural importance only in the latter.	11.225040431727416
14639. in its propagandistic and commercial haste to discover our	folk heritage the public has remained ignorant of definitions such as	this.	6.90685526942466
14640. enthusiastically americans have swept subliterary and bogus	materials like paul bunyan tales abe lincoln anecdotes and labor	union songs up as true products of our american oral tradition.	7.149482235573926
14641. nor	have we remembered that in the melting pot of america the hundreds of	isolated and semi-isolated ethnic regional and occupational groups did	not fuse into a homogeneous national unit until long after education	and industrialization	had caused them to cast oral tradition aside as	a means of carrying culturally significant material.	5.649125077720969
14642. naturally	such scholarly facts are of little concern to the man trying to make	money or fan patriotism by means of folklore.	9.360921218318127
14643. that much of what he	calls folklore is the result of beliefs carefully sown among the people	with the conscious aim of producing a desired mass emotional reaction	to a particular situation or set of situations is irrelevant.	6.855120980956365
14644. as long	as his material is americana can in some way be ascribed to the masses	and appears democratic to his audience he remains satisfied.	10.023042653401012
14645. from all this we can now see that two streams of development	run through the history of twentieth-century american folklore.	7.548372367781736
14646. on	the one side we have the university professors and their students trained	in teutonic methods of research who have sought out collected	and studied the true products of the oral traditions of the ethnic	regional and occupational groups that make up this nation.	10.08093270630293
14647. on the other	we have the flag-wavers and the national sentimentalists who have been	willing to use any patriotic frontier western or colonial material	willy-nilly.	6.038625552540578
14648. unfortunately few of the artists	who have used american folklore	since 1900 have known enough to distinguish between the two streams	even in the most general of ways.	9.545562594604077
14649. after all the field is large difficult	to define and seldom taught properly to american undergraduates.	8.621739491786121
14650. in addition this country has been settled by many peoples of many	heritages and their lore has become acculturated slowly in an age of	print and easy communication within an ever-expanding and changing society.	8.81514997281628
14651. the problems confuse even the experts.	9.888004859436396
14652. for that matter	the experts themselves are a mixed breed.	12.9453089468679
14653. anthropologists housewives	historians and such by profession they approach their discipline	as amateurs collectors commercial propagandists analysts or some combination	of the four.	5.205284796767733
14654. they have widely varying backgrounds and aims.	15.60227568741931
14655. they have little esprit de corps.	12.315907239663328
14656. the outlook for the	amateur for instance is usually dependent on his fondness for local	history or for the picturesque.	11.16220248489702
14657. his love of folklore has romanticism	in it and he doesn't care much about the dollar-sign or the footnote.	4.422258901219841
14658. folklore is his hobby and he all too rightly wishes it to remain	as such.	10.552489961158141
14659. the amateur is closely related to the collector who is	actually no more than the amateur who has taken to the field.	9.74237949313901
14660. the collector	enjoys the contact with rural life; he hunts folklore for the	very field and stream reasons that many persons hunt game; and	only rarely is he acutely concerned with the meaning of what he has	located.	7.290676895570449
14661. fundamentally both these types the amateur and the collector	are uncritical and many of them don't distinguish well between	real folklore and bogus material.	5.756783258194987
14662. but there are also the commercial	propagandists and the analysts- one dominated by money the other	by nineteenth-century german scholarship.	9.382301529459072
14663. both are primarily concerned	with the uses that can be made of the material that the collector	has found.	8.8574047660358
14664. both shudder at the thought of proceeding too far beyond	the sewage system and the electric light lines.	10.019242742888617
14665. the commercial propagandist	who can't afford to be critical gets along well with the	amateur from whom he feeds but he frequently steps on the analyst's	toes by refusing to keep his material genuine.	5.0082786130793995
14666. his standards are	of course completely foreign to those of the analyst.	12.195591249767782
14667. to both the amateur	and the commercial progandist the analyst lacks a soul lacks appreciation	with his endless probings and classifications.	6.958103548692973
14668. dominated by	the vicious circle of the university promotion system the analyst looks	down on and gets along poorly with the other three groups although	he cannot deny his debt to the collector.	9.268988582186594
14669. the knowledge that	most americans have of folklore comes through contact with commercial	propagandists and a few energetic amateurs and collectors.	7.184719746119145
14670. the work	done by the analysts the men who really know what folklore is all about	has no more appeal than any other work of a truly scientific sort	and reaches a limited learned audience.	9.110214110747433
14671. publishers want books that	will sell recording studios want discs that will not seem strange to	ears used to hillbilly and jazz music grade and high schools want quaint	but moral material.	5.578946665289591
14672. the analyst is apt to be too honest to fit	in.	14.76977294778933
14673. as a result most people don't have more than a vague idea what	folklore actually is; they see it as a potpourri of charming moral	legends and patriotic anecdotes with a superstition or remedy thrown	in here and there.	5.408797622604898
14674. and so well is such ignorance preserved by the amateur	and the money-maker that even at the college level most of the	hundred-odd folklore courses given in the united states survive on sentiment	and nationalism alone.	9.441571393977824
14675. if one wishes to discuss a literary	figure who uses folklore in his work the first thing he must realize	is that the literary figure is probably part of this ignorant american	public.	8.737606427547991
14676. and while every writer must be dealt with as a special	case the interested student will want to ask himself a number of questions	about each.	9.725166725560438
14677. does the writer know the difference between an ersatz	ballad or tall tale and a true product of the folk?	8.445659638197263
14678.  when	the writer uses material does he tamper with it to improve its commercial	effect or does he leave it pure?	8.935270036985264
14679.  is the writer propagandistic?	15.463133680286559
14680. 	is he swept away by sentiment and nostalgia for an america that was?	8.656743451619981
14681. 	or does he sincerely want to tap the real springs of american	attitude and culture regardless of how unpopular and embarrassing they	may be?	5.332620609939762
14682.    when he gets the answers to his questions he will be	discouraged.	15.30455405368597
14683. in the first place a good many writers who are said to	use folklore do not unless one counts an occasional superstition or	tale.	9.351409189647946
14684. robert frost for instance writes about rural life in new england	but he does not include any significant amount of folklore in	his poems.	9.823645493257308
14685. this has not however prevented publishers from labeling	him a folk poet simply because he is a rural one.	8.988989663065524
14686. in the second	place a large number of writers making a more direct claim than frost	to being folk writers of one sort or another clearly make	no distinctions between genuine and bogus material.	9.872903082555297
14687. stephen vincent	benet's john brown's body comes immediately to mind in this	connection as does john steinbeck's the grapes of wrath	and carl sandburg's the people yes.	3.4723201469077676
14688. the last two writers	introduce strong political bias into their works and not unlike the union	leaders that we will discuss soon see folklore as a reservoir of	protest by a downtrodden and publically silenced mass.	8.178756771019733
14689. folklore as	used by such writers really reflects images engraved into it by the very	person using it.	7.062140857676295
14690. the folk are simply not homogeneous with respect	to nation or political attitude.	10.98719357080524
14691. in fact there is much evidence to	indicate they don't care a bit about anything beyond their particular	regional ethnic and occupational limits.	6.166067984385661
14692. nevertheless with a reading	public that longs for the good old days and with an awareness	of our expanding international interests it is easy for the benets	to obtain a magnified position in literature by use of all sorts of	americana real or fake and it is easy for the steinbecks and sandburgs	to support their messages of reform by reading messages of reform	into the minds of the folk.	9.810422516635448
14693. as part of the same arrangement torrio had in the spirit of peace	and good will and in exchange for armed support in the april election	campaign bestowed upon o'banion a third share in the hawthorne	smoke shop proceeds and a cut in the cicero beer trade.	8.428397815480198
14694. the coalition	was to prove inadvisable.	12.934414432636201
14695. o'banion was a complex and frightening	man whose bright blue eyes stared with a kind of frozen candour	into others'.	4.619412008265076
14696. he had a round frank irish face creased in a	jovial grin that stayed bleakly in place even when he was pumping bullets	into someone's body.	9.242169895438034
14697. he carried three guns- one in the right	trouser pocket one under his left armpit one in the left outside coat	pocket- and was equally lethal with both hands.	5.627413901400293
14698. he killed accurately	freely and dispassionately.	14.073655250035918
14699. the police credited him with twenty-five	murders but he was never brought to trial for one of them.	7.744582922724197
14700. like a fair number of bootleggers he disliked alcohol.	10.935430208072434
14701. he was an expert	florist tenderly dextrous in the arrangement of bouquets and wreaths.	8.294044754277287
14702. he had no apparent comprehension of morality; he divided humanity	into right guys and wrong guys and the wrong ones he	was always willing to kill and trample under.	8.449374689127364
14703. he had what was described	by a psychologist as a sunny brutality.	9.25565053534723
14704. he walked with a heavy	list to the right as that leg was four inches shorter than the other	but the lurch did not reduce his feline quickness with his guns.	9.240130293056493
14705. landesco	thought him just a superior sort of plugugly but he was	in fact with his aggression and hostility and nerveless indifference	to risking or administering pain a casebook psychopath.	5.39284611470801
14706. he was also	at this time although not so interwoven in high politics and the rackets	as torrio and capone the most powerful and most dangerous mob	leader in the chicago underworld the roughneck king.	8.984468126841149
14707. o'banion	was born in poverty the son of an immigrant irish plasterer	in the north side's little hell close by the sicilian quarter	and death corner.	4.749233603806257
14708. he had been a choir boy at the holy name cathedral	and also served as an acolyte to father o'brien.	10.598106406727203
14709. the influence	of mass was less pervasive than that of the congested slum tenements	among the bawdy houses honkytonks and sawdust saloons of his birthplace;	he ran wild with the child gangs of the neighbourhood and	went through the normal pressure-cooker course of thieving police-dodging	and housebreaking.	4.770100375853419
14710. at the age of ten when he was working as	a newsboy in the loop he was knocked down by a streetcar which resulted	in his permanently shortened leg.	10.287880355808582
14711. because of this he was known as	gimpy	.	15.972399937865253
14712. in his teens o'banion was enrolled in the vicious	market street gang and he became a singing waiter in mcgovern's	cafe a notoriously low and rowdy dive in north clark street where	befuddled customers were methodically looted of their money by the singing	waiters before being thrown out.	6.513064040584962
14713. he then got a job with the chicago	herald-examiner as a circulation slugger a rough fighter	employed to see that his paper's news pitches were not trespassed upon	by rival vendors.	5.743982166478504
14714. he was also at the same time gaining practical	experience as a safe breaker and highwayman and learning how to shoot	to kill from a neanderthal convicted murderer named gene geary later	committed to chester asylum as a homicidal maniac but whose eyes	misted with tears when the young dion sang a ballad about an irish	mother in his clear and syrupy tenor.	7.736048677707912
14715. o'banion's first conflict	with the police came in 1909 at seventeen when he was committed	to bridewell prison for three months for burglary; two years	later he served another three months for assault.	4.881695422595616
14716. those were his only	interludes behind bars although he collected four more charges on his	police record in 1921 and 1922 three for burglary and one for robbery.	8.648642925246175
14717. but by now o'banion's political pull was beginning to be effective.	7.732452468795829
14718. on the occasion of his 1922 indictment the $10000 bond was	furnished by an alderman and the charge was nolle prossed.	8.76824080122478
14719. on one	of his 1921 ventures he was actually come upon by a detective sergeant	john j ryan down on his knees with a tool embedded in a labour	office safe in the postal telegraph building; the jury wanted	better evidence than that and he was acquitted at a cost of $30000	in bribes it was estimated.	5.46925520611713
14720. as promptly as torrio o'banion jumped	into bootlegging.	9.08544105076624
14721. he conducted it with less diplomacy and more spontaneous	violence than the sicilians but he had his huge north side	portion to exploit and he made a great deal of money.	8.404303202142927
14722. unlike the	sicilians he additionally conducted holdups robberies and safe-cracking	expeditions and refused to touch prostitution.	7.1936291159894745
14723. he was also personally	active in ward politics and by 1924 o'banion had acquired	sufficient political might to be able to state: i always deliver	my borough as per requirements.	5.446575270720561
14724. but whose requirements?	20.401047956458438
14725. 	until 1924 o'banion pistoleers and knuckle-duster bullyboys had	kept his north side domain solidly democratic.	4.023480357542903
14726. there was a question-and-answer	gag that went around at that time: q who'll	carry the forty-second and forty-third wards?	6.920085994633772
14727.  a o'banion	in his pistol pocket.	6.454924867881637
14728. but as november 1924 drew close the democratic	hierarchy	was sorely troubled by grapevine reports that o'banion	was being wooed by the opposition and was meeting and conferring	with important republicans.	7.589954788308047
14729. to forestall any change of allegiance	the democrats hastily organised a testimonial banquet for o'banion	as public reward for his past services and as a reminder of where	his loyalties lay.	5.668613708187137
14730. the reception was held in a private dining	room of the webster hotel on lincoln park west.	9.8231520443205
14731. it was an interesting	fraternisation of ex-convicts union racketeers ward heelers	sold-out officials and gunmen.	6.284354956569501
14732. the guest list is in itself a little	parable of the state of american civic life at this time.	11.935069323425155
14733. it included	the top o'banion men and chief of detectives michael hughes.	7.061452315754199
14734. when mayor dever heard of the banquet he summoned hughes	for an explanation of why he had been dishonouring the police department	by consorting with these felons and fixers.	8.59272009692307
14735. hughes said that he had	understood the party was to be in honour of jerry o'connor the	proprieter of a loop gambling house.	7.34548086847644
14736. but when i arrived and recognised	a number of notorious characters i had thrown into the detective	bureau basement half a dozen times i knew i had been framed and	withdrew almost at once.	9.418935319643982
14737. in fact o'connor was honoured	during the ceremony with the presentation of a $2500 diamond stickpin.	6.123443753884128
14738. there was a brief interruption while one of o'banion's men	jerked out both his guns and threatened to shoot a waiter who was pestering	him for a tip.	9.265670122584785
14739. then o'banion was presented with a platinum	watch set with rubies and diamonds.	5.507570935592308
14740. this dinner was the start	of a new blatancy in the relationship between the gangs and the politicians	which prior to 1924 says pasley had been maintained with	more or less stealth but which henceforth was marked by these ostentatious	gatherings denounced by a clergyman as belshazzar feasts	at which politicians fraternized cheek by jowl with gangsters	openly in the big downtown hotels.	7.222228568024309
14741. pasley continued: they	became an institution of the chicago scene and marked the way to the	moral and financial collapse of the municipal and county governments	in 1928-29.	6.122373583018739
14742. however this inaugural feast did its sponsors	no good whatever.	11.016012657688053
14743. o'banion accepted his platinum watch and the tributes	to his loyalty and proceeded with the bigger and better republican	deal.	4.765201705475692
14744. on election day- november 4- he energetically marshalled	his force of bludgeon men bribers and experts in forging repeat	votes.	6.931843505419973
14745. the result was a landslide for the republican candidates.	11.543084886295238
14746. this further demonstration of o'banion's ballooning power	did not please torrio and capone.	7.381204730050275
14747. in the past year there had been	too many examples of his euphoric self-confidence and self-aggrandisement	for their liking.	7.497175629507894
14748. he behaved publicly with a cocky swaggering truculence	that offended their vulpine latin minds and behaved towards	them personally with an unimpressed insolence that enraged them beneath	their blandness.	6.954823000092507
14749. they were disturbed by his idiotic bravado- as	when his bodyguard yankee schwartz complained that he had been snubbed	by dave miller a prize-fight referee chieftain of a jewish	gang and one of four brothers of tough reputation who were hirschey	a gambler-politician in loose beer-running league with torrio and o'banion	frank a policeman and max the youngest.	4.413174673670747
14750. to settle this	slight o'banion went down to the la salle theatre in the loop	where he had learned dave miller was attending the opening of	a musical comedy.	7.521605059234817
14751. at the end of the performance dave and max came	out into the brilliantly lit foyer among a surge of gowned and tuxedoed	first nighters.	9.263723345903209
14752. o'banion drew his guns and fired at dave severely	wounding him in the stomach.	7.015190525968662
14753. a second bullet ricocheted off max's	belt buckle leaving him unhurt but in some distress.	6.1209740045803605
14754. o'banion	tucked away his gun and walked out of the theatre; he was neither	prosecuted nor even arrested.	6.426052204810743
14755. that sort of braggadocio for that sort	of reason in the view of torrio and capone was a nonsense.	9.828544485555435
14756. a further example of the incompatible difference in personalities was	when two policemen held up a torrio beer convoy on a west side street	and demanded $300 to let it through.	8.016285279332692
14757. one of the beer-runners telephoned	o'banion- on a line tapped by the detective bureau- and	reported the situation.	6.366912159584272
14758. o'banion's reaction was: three hundred	dollars! to them bums?	3.622759735758006
14759.  why i can get them knocked off for	half that much.	8.994074549948563
14760. upon which the detective bureau despatched rifle	squads to prevent trouble if o'banion should send his gunmen out	to deal with the hijacking policemen.	7.926965273912714
14761. but in the meantime the beer-runner	unhappy with this solution telephoned torrio and returned to	o'banion with the message: say dionie i just been talking	to johnny and he said to let them cops have the three hundred.	6.267148510684936
14762. he	says he don't want no trouble.	5.448490744735808
14763. but torrio and capone had	graver cause to hate and distrust the irishman.	8.908379722913343
14764. for three years	since the liquor territorial conference torrio had with his elastic	patience and because he knew that retaliation could cause only violent	warfare and disaster to business tolerated o'banion's impudent	double-crossing.	8.01609417965951
14765. they had suffered in sulky silence the sight of	his sharp practice in cicero.	7.684566584259516
14766. when as a diplomatic gesture	of amity and in payment for the loan of gunmen in the april election	torrio had given o'banion a slice of cicero the profits from	that district had been $20000 a month.	7.030621552378567
14767. in six months o'banion had	boosted the profits to $100000 a month- mainly by bringing pressure	to bear on fifty chicago speak-easy proprietors to shift out to the	suburb.	4.13958028341562
14768. these booze customers had until then been buying their supplies	from the sheldon saltis-mcerlane and druggan-lake gangs	and now they were competing for trade with the torrio-capone saloons;	once again o'banion's brash recklessness had caused a proliferation	of ill will.	5.306820443262243
14769. the revenue from o'banion's cicero territory	went up still higher until the yield was more than the torrio-capone	takings from the far bigger trade area of chicago's south and	west sides.	5.115187654688827
14770. but he still showed no intention of sharing with the	syndicate.	15.020840389789432
14771. at last even the controlled torrio was unable to hold still	and he tentatively suggested that o'banion should take a percentage	in the stickney brothels in return for one from his cicero beer	concession.	6.139280303413911
14772. o'banion's reply was a raucous laugh and a flat refusal.	5.887732511972924
14773. still more jealous bitterness was engendered by the o'banion	gang's seizure from a west side marshalling yard of a freight-car	load of canadian whisky worth $100000 and by one of the biggest	coups of the prohibition era- the sibley warehouse robbery	which became famous for the cool brazenness of the operation.	4.520890316344225
14774. here was	stored $1000000 worth of bonded whisky.	8.561270205303764
14775. these 1750 cases were carted	off in a one-night operation by the o'banion men who left in	their stead the same number of barrels filled with water.	4.833991829007316
14776. a tsunami may be started by a sea bottom slide an earthquake	or a volcanic eruption.	9.45458280479615
14777. the most infamous of all was launched by the	explosion of the island of krakatoa in 1883; it raced across the pacific	at 300 miles an hour devastated the coasts of java and sumatra	with waves 100 to 130 feet high and pounded the shore as far away	as san francisco.	6.2012497958988115
14778. the ancient greeks recorded several catastrophic	inundations by huge waves.	9.497627432871733
14779. whether or not plato's tale of	the lost continent of atlantis is true skeptics concede that the myth	may have some foundation in a great tsunami of ancient times.	5.716787520617879
14780. indeed	a tremendously destructive tsunami that arose in the arabian sea	in 1945 has even revived the interest of geologists and archaeologists	in the biblical story of the flood.	8.412293715405475
14781. one of the most damaging	tsunami on record followed the famous lisbon earthquake of november	1 1755; its waves persisted for a week and were felt as far away	as the english coast.	7.52321343236148
14782. tsunami are rare however in the atlantic	ocean; they are far more common in the pacific.	9.981964735792568
14783. japan has had 15	destructive ones since 1596.	7.613826247313708
14784. the hawaiian	islands are struck severely an average of once every 25 years.	10.32015839329449
14785. in 1707 an earthquake in japan generated waves so huge that they piled	into the inland sea; one wave swamped more than 1000 ships and	boats in osaka bay.	5.4318866119026366
14786. a tsunami in the hawaiian islands in 1869	washed away an entire town leaving only two forlorn trees	standing where the community had been.	8.555064088828955
14787. in 1896 a japanese tsunami killed	27000 people and swept away 10000 homes.	8.108204737336102
14788. the dimensions	of these waves dwarf all our usual standards of measurement.	9.745649377195113
14789. an ordinary	sea wave is rarely more than a few hundred feet long from crest to	crest- no longer than 320 feet in the atlantic or 1000 feet in the	pacific.	6.3153270778501955
14790. but a tsunami often extends more than 100 miles and sometimes	as much as 600 miles from crest to crest.	10.939251590425213
14791. while a wind wave never	travels at more than 60 miles per hour the velocity of a tsunami in	the open sea must be reckoned in hundreds of miles per hour.	8.63064707883087
14792. the greater	the depth of the water the greater is the speed of the wave;	lagrange's law says that its velocity is equal to the square root of	the product of the depth times the acceleration due to gravity.	9.282435662841348
14793. in	the deep waters of the pacific these waves reach a speed of 500 miles	per hour.	7.713136704700489
14794. tsunami are so shallow in comparison with their length	that in the open ocean they are hardly detectable.	9.694654146104291
14795. their amplitude	sometimes is as little as two feet from trough to crest.	7.606448945861567
14796. usually it	is only when they approach shallow water on the shore that they build	up to their terrifying heights.	10.522047041398421
14797. on the fateful day in 1896 when the	great waves approached japan fishermen at sea noticed no unusual swells.	7.15599018011784
14798. not until they sailed home at the end of the day through a sea	strewn with bodies and the wreckage of houses were they aware of what	had happened.	11.817832048334202
14799. the seemingly quiet ocean had crashed a wall of water	from 10 to 100 feet high upon beaches crowded with bathers drowning	thousands of them and flattening villages along the shore.	6.112291009192316
14800. the	giant waves are more dangerous on flat shores than on steep ones.	8.664837294167237
14801. they	usually range from 20 to 60 feet in height but when they pour into	a v-shaped inlet or harbor they may rise to mountainous proportions.	5.351061004306368
14802. generally the first salvo of a tsunami is a rather sharp swell	not different enough from an ordinary wave to alarm casual observers.	9.961972084317875
14803. this is followed by a tremendous suck of water away from the shore	as the first great trough arrives.	10.000152462221036
14804. reefs are left high and dry and	the beaches are covered with stranded fish.	8.910417162572198
14805. at hilo large numbers	of people ran out to inspect the amazing spectacle of the denuded beach.	7.805130306041775
14806. many of them paid for their curiosity with their lives for some	minutes later the first giant wave roared over the shore.	10.682298723807707
14807. after an earthquake	in japan in 1793 people on the coast at tugaru were so terrified	by the extraordinary ebbing of the sea that they scurried to higher	ground.	6.8421640585816235
14808. when a second quake came they dashed back to the beach	fearing that they might be buried under landslides.	12.358017421772924
14809. just as they reached	the shore the first huge wave crashed upon them.	8.654854849609638
14810. a tsunami	is not a single wave but a series.	10.934118315525554
14811. the waves are separated by intervals	of 15 minutes to an hour or more	and this has often lulled people into thinking after the first great	wave has crashed that it is all over.	7.3529586459387835
14812. the waves may keep coming for many	hours.	12.510402499059131
14813. usually the third to the eighth waves in the series are the	biggest.	10.479663082388688
14814. among the observers of the 1946 tsunami at hilo was	francis p shepard of the scripps institution of oceanography	one of the world's foremost marine geologists.	6.5009525621738495
14815. he was able to make	a detailed inspection of the waves.	12.55347665121473
14816. their onrush and retreat he reported	was accompanied by a great hissing roaring and rattling.	8.704839033894007
14817. the	third and fourth waves seemed to be the highest.	9.098244932440418
14818. on some of the islands'	beaches the waves came in gently; they were steepest on the	shores facing the direction of the seaquake from which the waves had come.	9.384132961138386
14819. in hilo bay they were from 21 to 26 feet high.	8.130058990299892
14820. the highest waves	55 feet occurred at pololu valley.	11.354336266698855
14821. scientists and fishermen	have occasionally seen strange by-products of the phenomenon.	5.181336789763706
14822. during	a 1933 tsunami in japan the sea glowed brilliantly at night.	9.274123759120549
14823. the	luminosity of the water is now believed to have been caused by the	stimulation of vast numbers of the luminescent organism noctiluca miliaris	by the turbulence of the sea.	7.033497206919892
14824. japanese fishermen have sometimes	observed that sardines hauled up in their nets during a tsunami have	enormously swollen stomachs; the fish have swallowed vast numbers	of bottom-living diatoms raised to the surface by the disturbance.	6.4137650735006515
14825. the	waves of a 1923 tsunami in sagami bay brought to the surface and	battered to death huge numbers of fishes that normally live at a depth	of 3000 feet.	6.1552542778329205
14826. gratified fishermen hauled them in by the thousands.	10.529576170134478
14827. the tsunami-warning system developed since the 1946 disaster in	hawaii relies mainly on a simple and ingenious instrument devised	by commander c k green of the coast and geodetic survey staff.	5.5622149624103985
14828. it consists of a series of pipes and a pressure-measuring chamber	which record the rise and fall of the water surface.	12.014988001372368
14829. ordinary water	tides are disregarded.	8.656729721063883
14830. but when waves with a period of between 10 and	40 minutes begin to roll over the ocean they set in motion a corresponding	oscillation in a column of mercury which closes an electric circuit.	9.224458140095383
14831. this in turn sets off an alarm notifying the observers at the	station that a tsunami is in progress.	8.154316787175796
14832. such equipment has been installed	at hilo midway attu and dutch harbor.	9.039460343592772
14833. the moment the alarm	goes off information is immediately forwarded to honolulu which	is the center of the warning system.	8.920274950520348
14834. this center also receives	prompt reports on earthquakes from four coast survey stations in the	pacific which are equipped with seismographs.	9.588358583741197
14835. its staff makes a preliminary	determination of the epicenter of the quake and alerts tide	stations near the epicenter for a tsunami.	6.157172016891765
14836. by means of charts showing	wave-travel times and depths in the ocean at various locations it is	possible to estimate the rate of approach and probable time of arrival	at hawaii of a tsunami getting under way at any spot in the pacific.	7.998341272913402
14837. the civil and military authorities are then advised of the danger	and they issue warnings and take all necessary protective steps.	6.781726082773629
14838. all	of these activities are geared to a top-priority communication system	and practice tests have been held to assure that everything will work	smoothly.	8.436625290759585
14839. since the 1946 disaster there have been 15 tsunami	in the pacific but only one was of any consequence.	8.60051387876234
14840. on november 4	1952 an earthquake occurred under the sea off the kamchatka peninsula.	10.618977223575312
14841. at 17:07 that afternoon the shock was recorded	by the seismograph alarm in honolulu.	6.080772665826283
14842. the warning system immediately	went into action.	15.731082368271364
14843. within about an hour with the help of reports	from seismic stations in alaska arizona and california the quake's	epicenter was placed at 51 degrees north latitude and 158 degrees	east longitude.	5.927306829661652
14844. while accounts of the progress of the tsunami came	in from various points in the pacific	the hawaiian station made its calculations	and notified the military services and the police that the first big	wave would arrive at honolulu at 23:30 greenwich time.	7.92868453756687
14845. it	turned out that the waves were not so high as in 1946.	9.593238760549202
14846. they hurled a	cement barge against a freighter in honolulu harbor knocked down telephone	lines marooned automobiles flooded lawns killed six cows.	7.758760107877056
14847. but not a single human life was lost and property damage in the hawaiian	islands did not exceed $800000.	8.923423752068592
14848. there is little doubt that the	warning system saved lives and reduced the damage.	20.257814527973547
14849. but it is	plain that a warning system however efficient is not enough.	10.508786233926108
14850. in the	vulnerable areas of the pacific there should be restrictions against	building homes on exposed coasts or at least a requirement that they	be either raised off the ground or anchored strongly against waves.	10.576797015649893
14851. the key to the world of geology is change; nothing remains the	same.	10.437252258284612
14852. life has evolved from simple combinations of molecules in the	sea to complex combinations in man.	9.043486512394445
14853. the land too is changing and	earthquakes are daily reminders of this.	7.890291492063161
14854. earthquakes result when movements	in the earth twist rocks until they break.	9.60696807358754
14855. sometimes this is accompanied	by visible shifts of the ground surface; often the shifts	cannot be seen but they are there; and everywhere can be found scars	of earlier breaks once deeply buried.	5.394088763647884
14856. today's earthquakes are most	numerous in belts where the earth's restlessness is presently concentrated	but scars of the past show that there is no part of the earth	that has not had them.	6.931067278936853
14857. the effects of earthquakes on civilization	have been widely publicized even overemphasized.	7.854870679567834
14858. the role of	an earthquake in starting the destruction of whole cities is tremendously	frightening but fire may actually be the principal agent in a particular	disaster.	9.72793528714307
14859. superstition has often blended with fact to color reports.	6.990843520698917
14860. we have learned from earthquakes much of what we now know	about the earth's interior for they send waves through the earth	which emerge with information about the materials through which they	have traveled.	8.264495724923048
14861. these waves have shown that 1800 miles below the surface	a liquid core begins and that it in turn has a solid inner core.	7.815913160537369
14862. earthquakes originate as far as 400 miles below the surface	but they do not occur at greater depths.	11.394194848755951
14863. two unsolved mysteries are	based on these facts.	7.467137604527042
14864. as far down as 400 miles below the surface	the material should be hot enough to be plastic and adjust itself to	twisting forces by sluggish flow rather than by breaking as rigid surface	rocks do.	9.371028429160246
14865. if earthquakes do occur at such depths why not deeper?	9.015626643527483
14866. 	knowledge gained from studying earthquake waves has been	applied in various fields.	7.476329885871107
14867. in the search for oil and gas we make	similar waves under controlled conditions with dynamite and learn from	them where there are buried rock structures favorable to the accumulation	of these resources.	7.008663785289672
14868. we have also developed techniques for recognizing	and locating underground nuclear tests through the waves in the	ground which they generate.	10.653275870073708
14869. the following discussion of this subject	has been adapted from the book by	l don leet.	8.254581226686447
14870. at twelve	minutes after five on the morning of wednesday april 18 1906	san francisco was shaken by a severe earthquake.	9.764331976365021
14871. a sharp tremor	was followed by a jerky roll.	8.688173430383035
14872. ireland's county limerick near the river	shannon there is a quiet little suburb by the name of garryowen which	means garden of owen.	8.220663193905308
14873. undoubtedly none of the residents realize	the influence their town has had on american military history	or the deeds of valor that have been done in its name.	7.109924679127199
14874. the cry garryowen!	bursting from the lips of a charging cavalry trooper was	the last sound heard on this earth by untold numbers of cheyennes	sioux and apaches mexican banditos under pancho villa japanese	in the south pacific and chinese and north korean communists	in korea.	7.144245461279037
14875. garryowen is the battle cry of the 7th u s cavalry	regiment the fighting seventh.	8.780255963118885
14876. today a battle	cry may seem an anachronism for in the modern army esprit de corps	has been sacrificed to organizational charts and tables.	9.187990984064044
14877. but don't	tell that to a veteran of the fighting seventh especially in a	saloon on saturday night.	9.007039458200799
14878. of all the thousands of men who have	served in the 7th cav perhaps no one knows its spirit better than	lieutenant colonel melbourne c chandler.	11.54018585195509
14879. wiry and burr-headed	with steel blue eyes and a chest splattered with medals chandler	is the epitome of the old-time trooper.	4.323204524112934
14880. the truth is however that	when mel chandler first reported to the regiment the only steed he	had ever ridden	was a swivel chair and the only weapon he had ever wielded	was a pencil.	9.910339162076511
14881. chandler had been commissioned in the medical	service corps and was serving as a personnel officer for the kansas	city medical depot when he decided that if he was going to make	the army his career he wanted to be in the fighting part of it.	8.383957317373753
14882. though	he knew no more about military science and tactics than any other	desk officer he managed to get transferred to the combat forces.	8.64591821181714
14883. the	next thing he knew he was reporting for duty as commanding officer	of troop h 7th cavalry in the middle of corps maneuvers in japan.	8.777377739945324
14884. outside of combat he couldn't have landed in a tougher	spot.	8.288759586255521
14885. first of all no unit likes to have a new co brought in from	the outside especially when he's an armchair trooper.	6.821857804079937
14886. second	if there is ever a perfect time to pull the rug out from under him it's	on maneuvers.	9.504224168177972
14887. in combat helping your co make a fool of himself	might mean getting yourself killed.	7.031453804701033
14888. but in maneuvers with the top	brass watching him all the time it's easy.	11.547098061707143
14889. chandler understood	this and expected the worst.	8.568328114773298
14890. but his first few days with troop	h were full of surprises beginning with first sergeant robert	early.	12.21357526312764
14891. chandler had expected a tough old trooper with a gravel voice.	7.697978938409518
14892. instead sergeant early was quiet sharp and confident.	14.62192979595499
14893. he had	enlisted in the army straight out of high school and had immediately	set about learning his new trade.	8.974381753363442
14894. there was no weapon early could not	take apart and reassemble blind-folded.	14.735930522409294
14895. he could lead a patrol and	he knew his paper work.	9.495518329251297
14896. further he had taken full advantage of the army's	correspondence courses.	10.635686632785557
14897. he not only knew soldiering but mathematics	history and literature as well.	8.217630865336442
14898. but for all his erudite	confidence sergeant early was right out of the garryowen mold.	16.134305183679377
14899. he was filled with the spirit of the fighting seventh.	18.772329605293066
14900. sergeant early let the new co know just how lucky	he was to be in the best troop in the best regiment in the united	states army.	12.727898737165916
14901. he fed the captain bits of history about the troops and	the regiment.	8.579360156618383
14902. for example it was a battalion of the 7th cavalry	under colonel george armstrong custer that had been wiped out at the	battle of the little big horn.	11.70614360935621
14903. it didn't take captain	chandler long to realize that he had to carry a heavy load of tradition	on his shoulders as commander of troop h.	7.141921994777949
14904. but what made the	load lighter was the realization that every officer non-com and trooper	was ready and willing to help him carry it for the good of the troop	and the regiment.	10.453773813964045
14905. maneuvers over the 7th returned to garrison	duty in tokyo captain chandler still with them.	6.5486805502890855
14906. it was the	7th cavalry whose troopers were charged with guarding the imperial	palace of the emperor.	11.187330503897874
14907. but still mel chandler was not completely	convinced that men would really die for a four-syllable word garryowen.	6.356353390724474
14908. the final proof was a small incident.	13.067910927920071
14909. it happened	at the st patrick's day party a big affair for a regiment which	had gone into battle for over three-quarters of a century to the strains	of an irish march.	5.8646846515237465
14910. in the middle of the party chandler looked	up to see four smiling faces bearing down upon him each beaming above	the biggest greenest shamrock he had ever seen.	13.052237027482692
14911. the faces belonged	to lieutenant marvin goulding his wife and their two children.	7.719890080096809
14912. and	when the singing began it was the gouldings who sang the old irish	songs the best.	8.809248000681892
14913. though there was an occasional good-natured	chuckle about marvin goulding the jewish officer from chicago	singing tearfully about the ould sod no one really thought it was strange.	6.183326335290892
14914. for marvin goulding like giovanni martini the bugler boy	who carried custer's last message or margarito lopez the one-man	army on leyte was a garryowen through and through.	5.984091565370989
14915. it was no	coincidence	that goulding was one of the most beloved platoon leaders	in the regiment.	12.45649879380026
14916. and so mel chandler got the spirit of garryowen.	16.637221806613272
14917. he set out to keep troop h the best troop in the best regiment.	12.085159934584036
14918. one of his innovations was to see to it that every man- cook	and clerk as well as rifleman- qualified with every weapon in the	troop.	9.677930484436818
14919. even the mess sergeant bill brown a dapper cocky transfer	from an airborne division went out on the range.	7.462946945672854
14920. the troop received	a new leader lieutenant robert m carroll fresh out of	rotc and bucking for regular army status.	8.176993625180609
14921. carroll was sharp	and military but he was up against tough competition for that ra	berth and he wanted to play it cool.	7.642189389966566
14922. so mel chandler set out to	sell him on the spirit of garryowen just as he himself had been sold	a short time before.	11.949124226104203
