14923. when the korean war began on june 25	1950 the anniversary of the day custer had gone down fighting at the	little big horn and the day the regiment had assaulted the beachhead	of leyte during world war 2 the 7th cavalry was not in the	best fighting condition.	8.9436360020399
14924. its entire complement of non-commissioned	officers on the platoon level had departed as cadre for another unit	and its vehicles were still those used in the drive across luzon in world	war 2.	6.9775195634977525
14925. just a month after the korean war broke out	the 7th cavalry was moving into the lines ready for combat.	8.834534107707368
14926. from	then on the fighting seventh was in the thick of the bitterest fighting	in korea.	10.905219086211858
14927. one night on the naktong river mel chandler	called on that fabled esprit de corps.	8.64666458734325
14928. the regiment was dug in	on the east side of the river and the north koreans were steadily building	up a concentration of crack troops on the other side.	14.15234290565832
14929. the troopers	knew an attack was coming but they didn't know when and they	didn't know where.	4.452501947726248
14930. at 6 o'clock on the morning of august 12 they	were in doubt no longer.	10.880697352350655
14931. then it came against troop h.	12.339023671867722
14932. the enemy had filtered across the river during the night and a full	force of 1000 men armed with russian machine guns attacked the position	held by chandler's men.	8.689985128334195
14933. first came the	cannon fodder white-clad civilians being driven into death as a massive	human battering ram.	5.319940461401802
14934. they were followed by crack north korean troops	who mounted one charge after another.	10.14869464998311
14935. they overran the 7th cav's	forward machine-gun positions through sheer weight of numbers over	piles of their own dead.	5.508623527933784
14936. another force flanked the company	and took up a position on a hill to the rear.	10.11758321878709
14937. captain chandler saw	that it was building up strength.	7.948728167601839
14938. he assembled a group of 25 men composed	of wounded troopers awaiting evacuation the company clerk supply	men cooks and drivers and led them to the hill.	9.74152411402066
14939. one of the more	seriously wounded was lieutenant carroll the young officer bucking	for the regular army.	8.972312384007953
14940. chandler left carroll at the bottom of the hill	to direct any reinforcements he could find to the fight.	10.939387917799442
14941. then	mel chandler started up the hill.	7.378231101142172
14942. he took one step two broke	into a trot and then into a run.	11.790539526687619

14980. i do not mean to suggest that these assumptions are self-evident in	the sense that everyone agrees with them.	11.924185118826927

14982. i do mean however that	i take them for granted and that everything i shall be saying	assumption	the ultimate objective of american policy is to help establish	a world in which there is the largest possible measure of freedom	and justice and peace and material prosperity; and in particular-	since this is our special responsibility- that these conditions	be enjoyed by the people of the united states.	9.756594761592673
14983. i speak of the largest	possible measure because any person who supposes that these	conditions can be universally and perfectly achieved- ever- reckons	without the inherent imperfectability of himself and his fellow human	assumption	these conditions are unobtainable- are not even approachable	in the qualified sense i have indicated- without the prior defeat	of world communism.	4.931923437638157
14984. this is true for two reasons: because communism	is both doctrinally and in practice antithetical to these conditions;	and because communists have the will and as long as soviet	power remains intact the capacity to prevent their realization.	8.78524554048195
14985. moreover	as communist power increases the enjoyment of these conditions	throughout the world diminishes pro rata and the possibility of	their restoration becomes increasingly remote.	5.888660704479464
14986. it	follows that victory over communism is the dominant proximate goal	of american policy.	8.926489261455298

14989. peace is a worthy	objective; but if we must choose between peace and keeping the	communists out of berlin then we must fight.	6.670607344093306

14993. it may be of course that such objectives	can be pursued consisently with a policy designed to overthrow communism;	my point is that where conflicts arise they must always be	resolved in favor of achieving the indispensable condition for a tolerant	world- the absence of soviet communist power.	7.084122623016015
14994. power	this much having been said the question remains whether we	have the resources for the job we have to do- defeat communism-	and if so how those resources ought to be used.	8.062879408220295
14995. this brings us squarely	to the problem of power and the uses a nation makes of power.	9.617973136272674

14997. and i suggest further	that the main cause of the trouble we are in has been the failure of	american policy-makers ever since we assumed free world leadership	in 1945 to deal with this problem realistically and seriously.	6.88296524966426
14998. in the recent political campaign two charges were leveled affecting	the question of power and i think we might begin by trying to put them	into proper focus.	11.461984173228867
14999. one was demonstrably false; the other for the	most part true.	8.186077534199187

15001. i know i	do not have to dwell here on the absurdity of that contention.	10.594742047818658
15002. you	may have misgivings about certain aspects of our military establishment-	i certainly do- but you know any comparison of over-all american	strength with over-all soviet strength finds the united states	not only superior but so superior both in present weapons and in the	development of new ones that our advantage promises to be a permanent	feature of us-soviet relations for the foreseeable future.	6.034145094078004
15003. i have often searched for a graphic way of impressing our superiority	on those americans who have doubts and i think mr jameson	campaigne has done it well in his new book american might and soviet	myth.	7.267285548053304
15004. suppose he says that the tables were turned and we	were in the soviets' position: there would be more than 2000	modern soviet fighters all better than ours stationed at 250 bases	in mexico and the caribbean.	8.946073674427579
15005. overwhelming russian naval power would	always be within a few hundred miles of our coast.	7.090106468161324
15006. half of the population	of the us would be needed to work on arms just to feed	the people.	15.06797586626834

15012. the argument was typically advanced in terms of us prestige.	12.904989000250497

15014. prestige	is a measure of how other people think of you well or ill.	11.377480087358919
15015. but contrary	to what was implied during the campaign prestige is surely not important	for its own sake.	7.769985648062709

15024. 	in answering these questions we need to ask not merely whether	communist troops have crossed over into territories they did not occupy	before and not merely whether disciplined agents of the cominform	are in control of governments from which they were formerly excluded:	the success of communism's war against the west does not depend	on such spectacular and definitive conquests.	7.112576769982849

15142. in keng kok the city of silkworms the prime minister	bought fried chickens and fried cicadas and two notebooks for me.	8.295981103490565
15143. then we drove on until there was no more road and we traversed dry rice	fields bouncing across their squat earth walls.	7.709303563234097
15144. it was a	spleen-crushing day.	22.867305158924196
15145. an hour of bouncing a brief stop in a village to	inspect a new school or dispensary.	7.662946847411538
15146. more bouncing another stop a	new house for teachers a new well.	9.962101308605071
15147. then off again rushing to keep up.	10.427587652283435

15149. together they had probably	done more than any other men to help push laos toward the 20th century-	constructively.	8.88717585868446
15150. mr keo once a diplomat in paris and washington	was commissioner of rural affairs.	9.571622185536159
15151. john an engineer and anthropologist	with a doctorate from the london school of economics	headed the rural development division of usom the united states	operations mission administering us aid.	5.553817914872739
15152. what	you see are self-help projects john said.	6.73497912422216

15155. that way they have an infirmary	for $400.	12.960427718862096

15157. mr	keo agreed.	9.723875566280467

15168. we did it for three days.	18.856562377478483

15172. briefly we rolled	over a paved road up to pak song on the cool bolovens plateau.	8.294102328061703

15174. keep souls in place	in the village of soukhouma which means	peaceful we had a baci.	9.646067202523493
15175. this is the most endearing of lao	ceremonies.	15.321432196129196
15176. it takes place in the household a rite of well-wishing	for myriad occasions- for the traveler a wedding a newborn child	the sick the new year for any good purpose.	9.656006959037779

15180. i was careful to keep my feet the seat of the least worthy	spirits from pointing at anyone's head where the worthiest spirits	reside.	8.496689982263185

15192. my interviews with teen-agers confirmed this portrait of the weakening	of religious and ethnic bonds.	7.606215209293063
15193. jewish identity was often confused	with social and economic strivings.	7.492390348398147
15194. being jewish gives you tremendous	drive a boy remarked.	10.079328475785971
15195. it means that you have to get	ahead.	23.094671457023146
15196. when i pressed for a purely religious definition i encountered	the familiar blend of liberal piety interfaith good will and	a small residue of ethnic loyalty.	8.336350165671218
15197. i like the tradition	a girl said.	12.664695334723902

15201. as i see it there's no real difference between	being jewish catholic or protestant.	7.2847455646850365
15202. another teen-ager	remarked: most jews don't believe in god but they believe	in people- in helping people.	4.51584312791419
15203. still another boy asserted:	to be a good jew is to do no wrong; it's to be a good person.	5.547416735800911

15206. they discovered that although	42 per cent of a sample of catholic students and 15 per cent of the	protestants believed it important to live in accordance with the teachings	of their religion only 8 per cent of the jewish students had this	conviction.	14.583037896257823
15207. the most important aims of the jewish students were as	follows: to make the world a better place to live in- 30 per cent;	to get happiness for yourself- 28 per cent; and financial independence-	21 per cent.	4.617641237281893
15208. nevertheless most of the teen-agers	i interviewed believed in maintaining their jewish identity and even	envisioned joining a synagogue or temple.	7.839337537326543
15209. however they were hostile	to jewish orthodoxy professing to believe in judaism but in a	moderate way.	6.915469292061459
15210. one boy said querulously about orthodox jews: it's	the twentieth century and they don't have to wear beards.	5.24037020901106
15211. the reason offered for clinging to the ancestral faith lacked	force and authority even in the teen-agers' minds.	7.549883888206203
15212. we were brought	up that way was one statement which won general assent.	11.579907749952564
15213. i	want to show respect for my parents' religion was the way in which	a boy justified his inhabiting a halfway house of judaism.	6.2714678715939085
15214. still	another suggested that he would join a temple for social reasons	since i'll be living in a suburb.	7.680540115430505
15215. intermarriage which	is generally regarded as a threat to jewish survival was regarded not	with horror or apprehension but with a kind of mild clinical disapproval.	6.58048116628559
15216. most of the teen-agers i interviewed rejected it on pragmatic	grounds.	11.85780508254733
15217. when you marry you want to have things in common a	girl said and it's hard when you don't marry someone with your	own background.	4.3074793121346975
15218. a fourteen-year-old girl from the middle	west observed wryly that in her community religion inconveniently interfered	with religious activities- at least with the peripheral activities	that many middle class jews now regard as religious.	6.160444754086247
15219. it appears	that an orthodox girl in the community disrupted plans for an outing	sponsored by one of the jewish service groups because she would	not travel on saturday and in addition required kosher food.	8.40414600037625
15220. another	girl from a relatively large midwestern city described herself as the	only orthodox girl in town.	8.238141757847336
15221. this is no doubt inaccurate	but it does convey how isolated she feels among the vast army of the	nonobservant.	9.095616324441917
15222. one of the significant things about	jewish culture in the older teen years is that it is largely college-oriented.	21.196198058198057

15224. this is substantially higher	than the figures for the american population at large- 45.	13.326813252736821

15226. 2 per cent for females.	21.571088618316207

15231. the percentage of jewish girls	who attend college is almost as high as that of boys.	10.611867072513002
15232. the motivations	for both sexes to be sure are different.	12.267876741394275

15239. the jewish working girl almost invariably works in an	office- in contradistinction to gentile factory workers- and buttressed	by a respectable income she is likely to dress better and live	more expansively than the college student.	5.042827637571264

15241. one of the reasons for the high percentage of jewish teen-agers	in college is that a great many urban jews are enabled to attend	local colleges at modest cost.	9.891380165717228

15244. perhaps the jewish students at brooklyn college-	constituting 85 per cent of those who attend the day session- can	serve as a paradigm of the urban lower-middle class jewish student.	8.755336813859868
15245. there is to begin an important sex difference.	19.795165493162028
15246. typically in	a lower-middle class jewish family a son will be sent to an out-of-town	school if financial resources warrant it while the daughter will	attend the local college.	6.051127523521067
15247. there are two reasons for this.	28.52005242185339

15298. this should be used frequently.	23.141411969862958
15299. for galled	breasts the mother should shave into half a cup of fresh unsalted lard	enough white chalk to make a paste.	7.3763230233789185

15303. the sufferer	drinks tansy tea.	9.877609856374363
15304. bruises burns cuts etc occurred frequently	on the frontier and folk medicine gave the answers to these	problems too.	8.731704104702475
15305. bruises and black eyes were relieved by application of	raw beefsteak.	7.7250588160002955
15306. salted butter was	another	cure for bruises.	10.260234182662947
15307. many people agreed that burns should be treated	with bland oily salves or unsalted butter or lard but one informant	told me that a burn should be bathed in salt water; the burn oozed	watery fluid for many days and finally the healing was completed by	bathing it with epsom salts.	5.42922561959601
15308. another swore by vinegar baths for burns	and still another recommended salted butter.	8.105324148873306
15309. butter salve or	butter ointment was used for burns and for bruises as well.	7.436642195625237
15310. this	was made by putting butter in a pan of water and allowing it to boil;	when it was cool the fat was skimmed off and bottled.	8.564666728784832
15311. cow's	milk was another cure for burns and burns covered with gum arabic or	plain mucilage healed quickly.	5.318135787666271
15312. one man badly burned about the face and	eyes by an arc welding torch was blinded and could not find a doctor	at the time.	9.731840686000561
15313. a sympathetic friend made poultices of raw potato parings	which she said was the best and quickest way to draw out the heat.	6.790063882506718
15314. later the doctor used mineral oil on the burns.	11.698801027962572
15315. the results	were good but which treatment helped is still not known.	8.139447079955149
15316. to	stop bleeding cobwebs were applied to cuts and wounds.	8.587081402481719
15317. one old-timer	said to sprinkle sugar on a bleeding cut even when on a knuckle if it	was made by a rusty tool; this would stop the flow and also prevent	infection.	5.518360323770703
15318. my lawyer told me that his mother used a similar remedy	for cuts and wounds; she sprinkled common sugar directly on the injury	and then bound it loosely with cotton cloth over which she poured	turpentine.	7.150082612583608
15319. he showed me one of his fingers which had been practically	amputated and which his mother had treated; there is scarcely a scar	showing.	7.076842684269743
15320. tobacco was common first aid.	10.186012480003827
15321. a chaw of tobacco put	on an open wound was both antiseptic and healing.	6.782542296380565
15322. or a thin slice	of plug tobacco might be laid on the open wound without chewing.	9.814990626662775
15323. one	old man told me that when he was a boy he was kicked in the head by a	fractious mule and had his scalp laid back from the entire front of his	head.	7.766405144959441
15324. his brother ran a mile to get the father; when they reached	the boy the father sliced a new plug of tobacco put the scalp back	in place and covered the raw edges with the slices.	7.520881523062133
15325. then he put a rag	around the dressing to keep it in place.	10.317304915046801
15326. there was no cleaning or further	care but the wound healed in less than two weeks and showed no	scar.	13.984848015022834
15327. veronica from the herb garden was also used to stop bleeding	and rue was an antiseptic.	6.961002351430805
15328. until quite recently sterile maggots	could be bought to apply to a wound; they would feed on its surface	leaving it clean so that it could be medically treated.	8.95588238762743
15329. tetanus	could be avoided by pouring warm turpentine over a wound.	6.831380780092917
15330. one family	bound wounds with bacon or salt pork strips or if these were not	handy plain lard.	8.803128287236147
15331. another sprinkled sugar on hot coals and held the	wounded foot or hand in the smoke.	7.034366312216406
15332. rabies were cured or prevented	by madstones which the pioneer wore or carried.	8.001060945151995
15333. in 1872 there were	known to be twenty-two in norton county and one had been in the	family for 200 years.	6.6917202196566725
15334. another cure for hydrophobia was to suck the wounds	then cauterize them with a hot knife or poker.	8.923631458839546
15335. while nowadays	we recognize the fact that there are many causes for bleeding at	the nose not long ago a nosebleed was simply that and treatment had	little	variation.	9.088220364863522
15336. since a fall or blow might have caused it a cold pack	was usually first aid.	9.14874295120259
15337. this might be applied to the top of the nose	or the back of the neck pressed on the upper lip or inserted into the	nostril.	12.132832473628612
15338. nosebleed could be	stopped by wrapping a red woolen string about the patient's neck and	tying in it a knot for each year of his life.	6.941022501864754
15339. or the victim could chew	hard on a piece of paper meanwhile pressing his fingers tight in	his ears.	7.750695723702263
15340. old sores could be healed by the constant application	of a wash made of equal parts vinegar and water.	8.531114001601779
15341. blood blisters could	be prevented from forming by rubbing a work blister immediately with	any hard nonpoisonous substance.	5.41977767749507
15342. felons were cured by taking common	salt and drying it in the oven pounding it fine and mixing it with equal	parts of spirits of turpentine; this mixture was then spread on	a cloth and wrapped around the affected part.	8.013644719803724
15343. as the cloth dried more	of the mixture was applied and after twenty-four hours the felon was	supposed to be killed.	6.425990079900597
15344. insect bites were cured in many	ways.	10.665393000919167
15345. many an old-timer swore by the saliva method; get a bite	spit on it was a proverb.	5.288254748644721
15346. this was used also for bruises.	16.82936737801656
15347. yellow	clay was used as a poultice for insect bites and also for swellings;	not long ago denver mud was most popular.	6.224011147325658
15348. chiggers were a	common pest along streams and where gardens and berries thrived; so	small as to be scarcely visible to the eye they buried themselves in	the victim's flesh.	6.451713671028427
15349. bathing the itching parts with kerosene gave relief	and also killed the pests.	6.087787742492667
15350. ant bites were eased by applying liquid	bluing.	9.749660936406361
15351. for mosquito bites a paste of half a glass of salt and half	a glass of soda was made.	8.146976153267525
15352. for wasp stings onion juice obtained by	scraping an onion gave quick relief.	9.044204260413839
15353. a handier remedy was to bathe the	painful part in strong soapy water; mud was sometimes used as well	as soap.	6.024564147150684
15354. just plain old black dirt was also used as a pack to relieve	wasp or bee stings.	11.257375537009382
15355. bedbugs were a common pest in pioneer days;	to keep them out of homes even in the 1900's was a chore.	5.270183478711153
15356. bed	slats were washed in alum water legs of beds were placed in cups	of kerosene and all woodwork was treated liberally with corrosive sublimate	applied with a feather.	7.310838746480929
15357. kerosene was very effective in ridding	pioneer homes of the pests.	6.714162850542327
15358. at times pioneer children got lice in their	hair.	13.17582079906435
15359. a kerosene shampoo seems a heroic treatment but it did the	job.	8.179420270991669
15360. to remove an insect from one's ear warm water should	be inserted.	7.189081610141476
15361. a cinder or other small object could be removed from the	eye by placing a flaxseed in the eye.	6.6459221718704065
15362. as the seed swelled its glutinous	covering protected the eyeball from irritation and both the cinder	and the seed could soon be washed out.	8.665911451168068
15363. another way to remove small	objects from the eye was to have the person look cross-eyed; the particle	would then move toward the nose where it could be wiped out with	a wisp of cotton.	6.2451068732360975
15364. shingles were cured by gentian an old drug	used in combinations.	9.082413147187147
15365. for erysipelas a mixture of one dram borax and	one	ounce glycerine was applied to the afflicted part on linen cloth.	7.357935707059119
15366. itching	skin considered just nerves was eased by treating with	whiskey and salt.	8.110057622719243
15367. winter itch was treated by applying strong apple cider	in which pulverized bloodroot had been steeped.	5.802700083351913
15368. to cure fungus growths	on mouth or hands people made a strong tea by using a handful of	sassafras bark in a quart of water.	8.335932052167179
15369. they drank half a cup of this morning	and night and they also washed and soaked their hands in the same	solution.	7.881780521775881
15370. six treatments cured one case which lasted a month and	had defied other remedies.	8.843990563171108
15371. frostbite was treated by putting the feet	and hands in ice water or by rubbing them with snow.	6.504481631269185
15372. now one hears that	heat and hot water are used instead.	10.836851070062352
15373. another remedy was oil of eucalyptus	used as well for chilblains.	8.005025287452288
15374. chilblains were also treated with	tincture of capsicum or cabbage leaves.	8.090068922357998
15375. boils have always been	a source of much trouble.	7.362061751145684
15376. a german informant gave me a sure cure	made by combining rye flour and molasses into a poultice.	8.661322563043864
15377. another poultice	was made from the inner bark of the elm tree steeped in water	until it formed a sticky gummy solution.	6.349459921161144
15378. this was also used for sores.	19.994085211233763
15379. another frequent pioneer difficulty caused by wearing rough and heavy	shoes and boots was corns.	5.803219954031707
15380. one veracious woman tells me she has	used thin potato parings for both corns and calluses on her feet and they	remove the pain or fire.	7.839798725117468
15381. another common cure was to soak the	feet five or ten minutes in warm water then to apply a solution of	equal parts of soda and common brown soap on a kid bandage overnight.	6.302602650764027
15382. this softened the skin so that in the morning when the bandage was removed	the corn could be scraped off and a bit of corn plaster put on.	10.039030227388952
15383. there were many cures for warts.	15.688558541275997
15384. one young girl told me how her	mother removed a wart from her finger by soaking a copper penny in	vinegar for three days and then painting the finger with the liquid several	times.	8.925074153164207
15385. another wart removal method was to rub each wart with a	bean split open and then to bury the bean halves under the drip of the	house for seven days.	5.955747975227704
15386. saliva gathered in the mouth after a night's	sleep was considered poisonous; wetting a wart with this saliva on	wakening the first thing in the morning was supposed to cause it to disappear	after only a few treatments and strangely enough many warts did	just that.	7.671473793396991
15387. one wart cure was to wrap it in a hair from a blonde gypsy.	8.886598478969452
15388. another was to soak raw beef in vinegar for twenty-four hours tie	it on the wart and wear it for a week.	8.52286653084135
15389. a simpler method was to tie	a thread tightly around the wart at its base and wear it this way.	7.430522723988387
15390. one person recommended to me washing the wart with	sulphur water; another said it should be rubbed with a cut potato	three times daily.	8.360866872984477
15391. another common method was to cut an onion in two and	place each half on the wart for a moment; the onion was then fastened	together with string and placed beneath a dripping eave.	5.757715586006151
15392. as the	onion decayed so did the wart.	12.774126028271699
15393. sore muscles were relieved by	an arnica rub; sore feet by calf's-foot an herb from the pioneer's	ubiquitous herb garden or by soaking the feet in a pan of hot water	in which two cups of salt had been dissolved.	4.355379752535979
15394. leg cramps one person	tells me were relieved by standing barefoot with the weight of the	body on the heel and pressing down hard.	9.2148595056692
15395. this does give relief as i	can testify.	11.265529231182079
15396. one doctor prescribed a tablespoon of whiskey or brandy	before each meal for leg cramps.	9.062635948392407
15397. pains in the back of the leg and in	the abdomen were prevented from reaching the upper body by tying a rope	about the patient's waist.	6.860893517181053
15398. for sprains and swellings one	pint of cider vinegar and half a pint of spirits of turpentine added	to three well beaten eggs was said to give speedy relief.	9.919511850446261
15399. except for the wine waiter in a restaurant- always an inscrutable	plenipotentiary unto himself the genii with the keys to unlock	the gates of the wine world are one's dealer and the foreign shipper	or negociant who in turn supplies him.	5.2542893456204665
15400. in instances where	both of these are persons or firms with integrity the situation is ideal.	10.98316584720472
15401. it may on occasion be anything but that.	13.853610860591965
15402. however by cultivating	a wine dealer and accepting his advice one will soon enough ascertain	whether he has any knowledge of wines	and better yet whether he	has a taste for wine.	8.27388933507867
15403. again by spreading one's purchases over several	wine dealers one becomes familiar with the names and specialties	of reputable wine dealers and shippers abroad.	5.125118512516501
15404. this is important because	despite all the efforts of the french government an appreciable	segment of france's export trade in wines is still tainted with a	misrepresentation approaching downright dishonesty and there are many	too many negociants who would rather turn a sou than amass a	creditable reputation overseas.	8.082852958123201
15405. a good negociant or shipper	will not only be the man or the firm which has cornered the wines from	the best vineyards or the best parts of them; he may also be the	one who makes and bottles the best blends- sound wines from vineyards	generally in his own district.	5.201566774629228
15406. these are the wines the french themselves	use for everyday drinking for even in france virtually no one	drinks the grands crus on a meal-to-meal basis.	8.292346132722662
15407. the grands	crus are expensive and even doting palates tire of them.	6.934548071390817
15408. and certainly	in the case of the beginner or the comparatively uninitiated wine	drinker the palate and the capacity for appreciation will not be ready	for the grands crus as a steady diet without frequent recourse	to crus of less renown.	8.817614681124017
15409. there is nothing infra dig about a	good blend from a good shipper.	12.086429765926027
15410. some of them are very delicious indeed	and there are many good ones exported- unfortunately along with	others not so good and worse.	10.454614795163744
15411. consultation with a reputable wine dealer	and constant experimentation- steering ever from the known to	the unknown- are the requisites.	4.678606681769407
15412. wine waiters are something	else again; especially if one is travelling or dining out a great	deal their importance mounts.	7.052305956755287
15413. most of them the world over operate	on the same principle by which justice is administered in france and	some other latin countries: the customer is to be considered guilty	of abysmal ignorance until proven otherwise with the burden of proof	on the customer himself.	6.655075319893187
15414. now the drinking of wine	is for the most part a recondite affair for manifestly if everyone	in the world who could afford the best wines also liked them the	supply would dry up in no time at all.	9.31991062271369
15415. this is the only valid and extenuating	argument that may be advanced in defense of the reprehensible	attitude of the common wine waiter.	9.810260243689987
15416. a really good wine waiter is	paradoxically the guardian of his cellar against	the visigoths.	9.620807861103517
15417. faced on the one hand with an always exhaustible	supply of his best wines and on the other by a clientele usually equipped	with inexhaustible pocketbooks it is a wonder indeed that all wine	waiters are not afflicted with chronic ambivalence.	7.3084813104215085
15418. the one way to	get around them- short of knowing exactly what one wants and sticking	to it- is to frequent a single establishment until its wine waiter	is persuaded that one is at least as interested in wine as in spending	money.	7.686020004240804
15419. only then perhaps will he reveal his jewels and his bargains.	7.746325593006539
15420. wine bought from a dealer should ideally be allowed to rest	for several weeks before it is served.	10.974712744736701
15421. this is especially true of	red wines and a practice which though not always practicable is well	worth the effort.	7.842161651467512
15422. it does no harm for wine to stand on end for a matter	of days but in terms of months and years it is fatal.	12.684057388010729
15423. wine stored	for a long time should be on its side; otherwise the cork dries	and air enters to spoil it.	6.022105916145117
15424. when stacking wine on its side in a bin	care should always be taken to be sure there is no air bubble left next	to the cork.	13.580928949929557
15425. fat bottles such as burgundies have a way of rolling	around in the bin and often need little props such as a bit of cardboard	or a chip of wood to hold them in the proper reclining posture.	7.022267981551842
15426. too much dampness in the cellar rots the corks again with ill effects.	12.029730607317234
15427. the best rule of thumb for detecting corked wine	is to smell the wet end of the cork after	pulling it: if it smells of wine the bottle is probably all right;	if it smells of cork one has grounds for suspicion.	5.7190185747071896
15428. seasonal	rises or drops in temperature are bad for wine: they age it prematurely.	6.894112999808679
15429. the ideal storage temperature for long periods is about fifty-five	degrees with an allowable range of five degrees above or below	this provided there are no sudden or frequent changes.	5.747845460247734
15430. prolonged vibration	is also undesirable; consequently one's wine closet or cellar	should be away from machines or electrically driven furnaces.	5.133727270493391
15431. if	one lives near a subway or an express parkway the solution is to have	one's wines stored with a dealer and brought home a few at a time.	5.785149498848727
15432. light especially daylight is always bad for wine.	10.900036094091394
15433. all in	all though there is a good deal of nonsense expended over the preparations	thought necessary for ordinary wine drinking; many people go	to extreme lengths in decanting chilling or warming or banishing without	further investigation any bottle with so much as a slightly suspicious	cork.	6.1186509309482915
15434. no one should wish to deny these purists the obvious pleasure	they derive from all this and to give fair warning where warning	is due no one who becomes fond of wines ever avoids acquiring some degree	of purism! but the fact remains that in most restaurants including	some of the best of paris and bordeaux and dijon the bottle	is frankly and simply brought from the cellar to the table when ordered	and all the conditioning or preparation it ever receives takes place	while the chef is preparing the meal.	7.981255294635877
15435. a white wine already at cool	cellar temperature may be adequately chilled in a bucket of ice and	water or the freezing compartment of a refrigerator	in about fifteen minutes; for those who live in a winter	climate there is nothing better than a bucket of water and snow.	6.835797583343649
15436. though	by no means an ideal procedure a red wine may similarly be brought	from the cellar to the dining room and opened twenty minutes or so	before serving time.	9.227651159483992
15437. it may be a bit cold when poured; but again	as one will have observed at any restaurant worth its salt wine should	be served in a large tulip-shaped glass which is never filled more	than half full.	6.461701591073022
15438. in this way red wine warms of itself quite rapidly-	and though it is true that it may not attain its potential of taste	and fragrance until after the middle of the meal in	the meantime it will have run the gamut of many beguiling and interesting	stages.	11.863162826245265
15439. the only cardinal sin which may be committed in warming	a wine is to force it by putting it next to the stove or in front of an	open fire.	8.378899558961773
15440. this invariably effaces any wine's character and drives	its fragrance underground.	7.361482457047659
15441. it should not be forgotten that	wines mature fastest in half-bottles less fast in full bottles slowly	in magnums- and slower yet in tregnums double magnums jeroboams	methuselahs and imperiales respectively.	5.8823587877692525
15442. very old red wines	often require several hours of aeration and any red wine brought from	the cellar within half an hour of mealtime should be uncorked and allowed	some air.	8.406034274424185
15443. but white wines never! white wines should be opened	when served having been previously chilled in proportion to their	sweetness.	6.545788006576649
15444. thus sauternes or barsacs should be very cold; a pouilly-fuisse	or a chablis somewhat less cold.	6.1751382877720715
15445. over-chilling is an accepted	method for covering up the faults of many a cheap or poor white	wine especially a dry wine- and certainly less of a crime than serving	a wine at a temperature which reveals it as unattractive.	4.7139844266636715
15446. the fragrance and taste of any white wine will die a lingering death	when it is allowed to warm or is exposed for long to the air.	9.172519453368588
15447. to quote	professor saintsbury: the last glass of claret or burgundy	is as good as the first; but the first glass of chateau d'yquem	or montrachet is a great deal better than the last! this does not	mean though that a red wine improves with prolonged aeration: there	is a reasonable limit- and wines kept over to the next meal or	the next day after they have once been opened are never as good.	5.05144454964822
15448. if	this must be done they should always be corked and kept in a cool place;	it should be remembered that their lasting qualities are appreciably	shorter than those of milk.	8.564737219338973
15449. a few red wines notably those	of the beaujolais are better consumed at cellar temperature.	6.885808439968078
15450. by	tradition a red wine should be served at approximately room temperature-	if anything a little cooler- and be aged enough for the tannin	and acids to have worked out and the sediment have settled well.	7.294828156143677
15451. thus	red wine must if possible never be disturbed or shaken; very old	red wine is often decanted so that the puckering bitter elements which	have settled to the bottom will not be mingled with the wine itself.	5.418945869900019
15452. a tug-of-war between an old bottle and an inefficient corkscrew may	do as much harm as a week at sea.	7.540680426893778
15453. the cork should be pulled gradually	and smoothly and the lip of the bottle wiped afterward.	7.396504024036045
15454. many	people use wicker cradles for old red wine lifting the bottle carefully	from the bin into the cradle and eventually to the table without	disturbing the sediment.	8.755348135338895
15455. another school frowns on such a shortcut and	insists that after leaving the bin an old red wine should first stand	on end for several days to allow the sediment to roll to the very bottom	after which the bottle may be gently eased to a tilted position	on its side in the cradle.	6.564523721691318
15456. in france when one wishes to entertain	at a restaurant and serve truly fine old red wines one visits the	restaurant well ahead of time chooses the wines and with the advice	of the manager and his chef builds the menu around them.	9.470118291643175
15457. the wine	waiter will see to it that the bottles are taken from the bin and opened	at least in time to warm and aerate preferably allowed to stand on	end for as long as possible and perhaps in the case of very old wines	be decanted.	8.512104872883153
15458. decanting old wine aerates it fully; it may also be-	practically speaking- a matter of good economy.	6.004037319179056
15459. for in the process	of decanting the bottle is only tilted once instead of several	or more times at the table: hence a minimum of the undesirable mixture	of wine and dregs.	7.145694207460918
15460. though there are many exceptions which	we have noted in preceding pages white wine is as a rule best consumed	between two and six years old and red wines nowadays between three	and ten.	9.701345105814053
15461. red wines of good years tend to mature later and to keep	longer; the average claret is notably longer-lived than its opposite	number red burgundy.	4.8567102266025355
15462. some clarets do not come into their own until	they are ten or fifteen years of age or even more.	10.482214346692063
15463. if a red bordeaux	of a good name and year is bitter or acid or cloying and muddy-tasting	leave it alone for a while.	6.282197580932767
15464. most of the wines of beaujolais on	the other hand should be drunk while very young; and alsatians	may be.	9.851099983593175
15465. giffen replied punctually and enthusiastically: rest assured that	your accompanying letter of instructions shall be in the letter	and spirit strictly complied with h and most particularly in regard	to that part of them relative to the completion of your noble and humane	views.	5.898901197587319
15466. giffen lost no time in visiting the plantation.	10.963272262029816
15467. the slaves appeared to be in good health and at work under john palfrey's	overseer.	10.203173107802867
15468. an excellent crop was expected that year.	13.353424691032368
15469. william	who lived in neighboring st mary's parish had taken charge and	decided that it would be best for all if the plantation were operated	for another year.	6.367356097599139
15470. giffen advised acceptance of this plan citing the	depressed market for land then prevailing and the large stock of provisions	at the plantation.	8.380096698232474
15471. if sold then the land and improvements might	bring only $5000.	9.254450481254699
15472. early in january 1844 he had a conference with	henry and william in new orleans and upon learning of gorham's	intention henry remonstrated calmly but firmly with his brother.	8.463265692268577
15473. the emancipation plan would not only be injurious to all the heirs	he contended but would be a form of cruelty perpetrated on the hapless	negroes.	8.092659165547678
15474. they were not capable of supporting themselves off the plantation	and louisiana law required their removal from the state.	9.721151914349445
15475. gorham	refused to accept money for slave property but did he realize how	much expense and trouble the transportation of his negroes to the	north involved?	6.1581378651790875
15476.  the suggestion that giffen hire out the slaves was	not realistic since no planter would take the risk of having negroes	who knew they were to be free living with his own slaves.	10.204776275949229
15477. henry hid	his annoyance although both he and william were furious with their	yankee brother.	6.731422924021468
15478. william who did not write to gorham told giffen	that unless he could operate the plantation as usual for a year he would	sue amicably to protect his interests.	9.86929927913383
15479. palfrey was	determined	that his portion of the slaves be converted to wage laborers	during the transition period before emancipation.	7.994458040033374
15480. if william wished	to continue operations for a year why not simply leave the negroes	undisturbed and pay them as high wages to remain there as are ever	paid the labor of persons of their sex + age.	8.458488788092382
15481. a disposition to exert	themselves for my benefit would perhaps be a motive with some of them	h to come into the scheme.	7.52780369554787
15482. their having family ties on our plantation	+ the adjoining one would be a stronger inducement.	8.696320305351877
15483. when he heard	of his brothers' anger palfrey was still hopeful that they could	be persuaded to accept his notion of paying wages.	6.305797089803587
15484. if not he was willing	to accede to william's wishes in any way that did not block	his ultimate aim.	9.384190815740073
15485. william was adamant on one point: under no circumstances	would he allow the negroes to remain on the plantation with his	and henry's slaves if they were told of their coming freedom.	5.272795971836401
15486. knowing	the antipathy that existed in louisiana against increasing the	number of free negroes giffen suggested that palfrey bring them	to boston at once and then send them on to liberia.	7.975421768313216
15487. lacking specific	instructions he agreed to william's condition.	7.318436653492218
15488. in march	there was a division of the slaves and giffen carried out his instructions	as nearly as possible.	11.117667674738973
15489. of the fifty-two slaves giffen succeeded	in getting a lot of twenty twelve of whom were females.	7.903065563204451
15490. i considered	that your views would be best carried out he explained	by taking women whose progeny will of course be free + more fully extend	the philantrophy of emancipation.	7.422538869565351
15491. i have also taken the old servants	of your father as a matter of conscience + justice.	8.575545966142043
15492. the ages	of the slaves ranged from sixty-five for an old house servant to	an unnamed newborn child.	7.013802870332398
15493. if palfrey ever had any doubts about the	wickedness of slavery they were put aside after he received an inventory	of the slave property he had inherited.	7.309996630371007
15494. this cold reckoning of human	worth in a legal paper devoid of compassion or humanity was all	he needed.	8.846365735305929
15495. each human being known only by a given name had a cash value.	7.378452770971545
15496. old sam's sixty-five years had reduced his value to $150;	rose a twelve-year-old with child-bearing potential was worth $400.	4.423433357182532
15497. in rejecting any claim to the value of the slave property palfrey	was giving up close to $7000.	9.907673088761344
15498. palfrey's brothers each received	lots of sixteen negroes and for bookkeeping purposes it was agreed	that all lots were to be valued at $6666.	7.085965997911591
15499. thus twenty black	souls were to remain ignorant of their imminent journey to the land	of free men.	6.5929796152927995
15500. giffen extracted one concession from william: the house	servants could be free at any time gorham thought expedient.	7.803766261196256
15501. despite giffen's warning palfrey still had plans for freeing	his slaves in louisiana.	5.789095552196232
15502. yet even if he could get the necessary approval	fourteen of his negroes could not be manumitted without special	permission.	11.469906859340703
15503. according to state law a slave had to be at least thirty	years old before he could be freed.	10.335805525986261
15504. palfrey petitioned the state legislature	to waive the requirement.	10.418887388914142
15505. otherwise freedom would mean removal	from the state in which as the place of their past residence from	birth or for many years it would h be materially for their advantage	to be at liberty to remain.	7.8229963100850926
15506. on march 11 the louisiana legislature	voted unanimously to table the petition.	12.707755806271866
15507. news of the legislative	veto appeared in the new orleans papers and henry and william	became incensed by the fact that they had not been told of the attempt	in advance.	9.33878397615978
15508. henry stormed into giffen's office waving a copy of	the new orleans courier shouting that the emancipation scheme	had become a public affair and that it would reach the ears of the	people on the plantation and make them restless + unhappy.	7.995654225294388
15509. his brothers' anger caused palfrey genuine concern for he had	imposed a dual mission upon himself: to free his slaves and to keep	the family from falling apart over the issue.	4.635787722957189
15510. when giffen decided	to charge him interest on the loan from john palfrey gorham readily	assented vowing that in a matter of dollars and cents his brothers	would never have any cause to complain of him.	10.335186513525734
15511. in view of these	difficulties palfrey decided to go to louisiana.	13.932312432080819
15512. giffen had already	urged him to journey south if only for a few days to clear up matters.	11.945372083664097
15513. his duties as massachusetts secretary of state obliged him	to wait until the adjournment of the legislature in mid-april.	7.937222856648053
15514. palfrey	told his wife of his intentions for the first time and left for new	orleans apprehensively invoking a special blessing of providence	that he might be allowed to see his family again.	10.683121115981088
15515. during his journey	palfrey stopped off to see two abolitionists.	10.287095316209037
15516. in both cases he	desired information about placing the freedmen in homes once they arrived	in the north.	12.087816219381256
15517. in new york lydia maria child welcomed him	enthusiastically: i have lately heard of you from the legislature	of louisiana and felt joy at your public recognition of the brotherhood	of man.	6.229258435696342
15518. mrs child who had once apologized for sending	editor palfrey a book on slavery now confided that she had helped one	of henry palfrey's slaves escape to canada some years before	but asked him not to advertise the fact in louisiana.	8.070571530869193
15519. she agreed to	take charge of five or six of the negroes should palfrey decide to send	them north immediately.	7.766524132761271
15520. at lexington kentucky palfrey consulted	with cassius m clay on the same subject but with no apparent	result.	9.983356380395653
15521. despite his apprehensions about his personal safety	palfrey's reception in new orleans was more than cordial.	7.4583950057792405
15522. instead	of the expected annoyances due to the nature of his mission	he received many calling cards and invitations from gentlemen of mark	on whom i had no sort of claim + have had many more invitations	than i could accept.	7.550210974870922
15523. he later told abolitionist edmund quincy of	the marked attention and civility with which the new orleans	gentlemen and the upriver planters greeted him.	6.604686583950822
15524. the memory of this southern	hospitality did not survive the trials of coming antislavery years	and civil war.	9.966419227944739
15525. palfrey's autobiography contains a melodramatic	account of two perilous days spent among the planters of attakapas	many of whom were coarse + passionate people much excited by what	they heard of my plans.	4.0405209981413694
15526. he proceeded with his task bravely- in	his memoirs at least- before the passions of my neighbors should	have time to boil too high.	6.817851569062991
15527. palfrey had already made up his	mind that he would allow the men but not the women to choose freely	whether or not to go north for freedom.	8.449642926371066
15528. the women by remaining behind	condemned their children born and unborn to bondage.	10.62043571582175
15529. he had a	short private talk with each adult slave.	10.038118327415853

15905. miss upton spoke gratefully of	the response of spelman graduates and negro friends in helping to raise	the fund and their continuing efforts to raise money for greatly	needed current expenses.	6.600368645775312
15906. she spoke also with deep thankfulness of the	many individuals and agencies whose interest and efforts through the	years had made the work so fruitful in results.	8.501812380581887
15907. two bequests	were recorded: one of $200 under the will of mrs harriet a	copp of los angeles; and one of $2000 under the will of miss celia	l brett of hamilton new york a friend from the early days.	5.111996905550136
15908. miss upton told the trustees that the death of miss giles	was the sorest grief the seminary had ever been called upon	to bear.	9.521311750632576
15909. the daughters of spelman she said had never known or thought	of spelman without her.	7.301920538920668
15910. the removal of miss packard 18 years earlier	had caused them great sorrow but they still had miss giles.	10.62867358979055
15911. now the school was indeed bereft.	11.785588199301921
15912. yet spelman has strong deep roots	and will live for the blessing of generations to come.	9.64334187695984
15913. miss mary jane packard sophia's half-sister became ill in	march 1910; and when school closed she was unable to travel to massachusetts.	4.583229951831169
15914. she remained in atlanta through june and july; she	died on august sixth.	8.593166768208945
15915. before coming on a visit to spelman	in 1885 miss mary had been a successful teacher in worcester and	her position there was held open for her for a considerable period.	7.2065364682501105
15916. but	she decided to stay at spelman.	12.343691060254939
15917. she helped with teaching as well	as office work for a few years- the catalogues show that she had classes	in geography rhetoric and bookkeeping.	6.311772012912092
15918. soon the office work claimed	all her time.	11.551192659971916
15919. she was closely associated with the founders in all	their trials and hardships.	8.598546837957262
15920. quiet and energetic cheerful and calm	she too was a power in the development of the seminary.	11.181908157720283
15921. miss giles	always used to refer to her as sister.	8.782311308967074
15922. she served as secretary	in the seminary office for 25 years and was in charge of correspondence	records and bookkeeping.	11.703456081281091
15923. the books of the school hold a memorial	to her; and so do the hearts of students and of teachers.	7.644172944159848
15924. mary j packard states a messenger editorial was efficient	pains-taking self-effacing loving radiating the spirit of her	master.	7.21124919528762
15925. with infinite patience she responded to every call no matter	at what cost to herself and to her all went for she was sure to	have the needed information or word of cheer.	6.521784018283363
15926. in a few school districts one finds a link between school and	job.	13.338970288207287
15927. in those vocational programs organized with smith-hughes money	there may be a close tie between the labor union and a local employer	on the one hand and the vocational teacher on the other.	8.082471873960328
15928. in these cases	a graduate may enter directly into an apprentice program saving	a year because of his vocational courses in grades 11 and 12.	10.70427302121924
15929. the apprentice	program will involve further education on a part-time basis usually	at night perhaps using some of the same equipment of the high	school.	5.345373941264668
15930. these opportunities are to be found in certain cities in such	crafts as auto mechanics carpentry drafting electrical work tool-and-die	work and sheet-metal work.	8.672417590421007
15931. formally organized vocational	programs supported by federal funds allow high school students to	gain experience in a field of work which is likely to lead to a full-time	job on graduation.	7.41158396535336
15932. the diversified occupations program is a	part-time trade-preparatory program conducted over two school years on	a cooperative basis between the school and local industrial and business	employers.	7.326037803014602
15933. the distributive education program operates in	a similar way with arrangements between the school and employers in	merchandising	fields.	7.60647563705581
15934. in both cases the student attends school half-time	and works in a regular job the other half.	10.270950782061524
15935. he receives remuneration	for his work.	10.097372504126255
15936. in a few places cooperative programs between schools	and employers in clerical work have shown the same possibilities for allowing	the student while still in school to develop skills which are	immediately marketable upon graduation.	9.261125271720394
15937. adult education courses	work-study programs of various sorts- these are all evidence of	a continuing interest of the schools in furthering educational opportunities	for out-of-school youth.	4.684921713499372
15938. in general however it may be said	that when a boy or a girl leaves the high school the school authorities	play little or no part in the decision of what happens next.	12.31406484019878
15939. if the	student drops out of high school the break with the school is even	more complete.	11.647429524429226
15940. when there is employment opportunity for youth this	arrangement- or lack of arrangement- works out quite well.	7.7590483789963915
15941. indeed	in some periods of our history and in some neighborhoods the job opportunities	have been so good that undoubtedly a great many boys who were	potential members of the professions quit school at an early age and	went to work.	6.869626012397823
15942. statistically this has represented a loss to the nation	although one must admit that in an individual case the decision in	retrospect may have been a wise one.	9.523724778791996
15943. i make no attempt to measure the	enduring satisfaction and material well-being of a man who went to work	on graduation from high school and was highly successful in the business	which he entered.	8.172840908575239
15944. he may or may not be better off than his	classmate who went on to a college and professional school.	14.189065737809553
15945. but in	the next decades the nation needs to educate for the professions all	the potential professional talent.	7.280556026574213
15946. in a later chapter dealing	with the suburban school i shall discuss the importance of arranging	a program for the academically talented and highly gifted youth in any	high school where he is found.	9.502238280703649
15947. in the negro neighborhoods and also	to some extent in the mixed neighborhoods the problem may be one of	identification and motivation.	8.538726061994337
15948. high motivation towards higher education	must start early enough so that by the time the boy or girl reaches	grade 9 he or she has at least developed those basic skills which are	essential for academic work.	9.127373370773308
15949. undoubtedly far more can be done in the	lower grades in this regard in the negro schools.	9.661238690668737
15950. however the teacher	can only go so far if the attitude of the community and the family	is anti-intellectual.	13.829885775585623
15951. and the fact remains that there are today few	shining examples of negroes in positions of intellectual leadership.	12.349428423033821
15952. this is not due to any policy of discrimination on the part of the northern	universities.	21.17108793935818
15953. quite the contrary as i can testify from personal	experience as a former university president.	7.85221211426811
15954. rather we see here	another vicious circle.	12.406724428155721
15955. the absence of successful negroes in the world	of scholarship and science has tended to tamp down enthusiasm among	negro youth for academic careers.	7.739192463135425
15956. i believe the situation is improving	but the success stories need to be heavily publicized.	14.755309824841486
15957. here again	we run into the roadblock that negroes do not like to be designated	as negroes in the press.	8.522975530702503
15958. how can the vicious circle be broken?	14.889545399932802
15959.  this	is a problem to which leaders of opinion both negro and white	should devote far more attention.	7.539498016497357
15960. it is at least as important as the	more dramatic attempts to break down barriers of inequality in the south.	15.870605506383667
15961. i should like to underline four points	i made in my first report with respect to vocational education.	9.573180077668606
15962. first	and foremost vocational courses should not replace courses which	are essential parts of the required academic program for graduation.	9.337631284485763
15963. second	vocational courses should be provided in grades 11 and 12 and	not require more than half the student's time in those years; however	for slow learners and prospective dropouts these courses ought to	begin earlier.	5.613085291079333
15964. third the significance of the vocational courses is	that those enrolled are keenly interested in the work; they realize	the relevance of what they are learning to their future careers and this	sense of purpose is carried over to the academic courses which they	are studying at the same time.	9.03327232668434
15965. fourth the type of vocational training	programs should be related to the employment opportunities in the	general locality.	7.654460156881433
15966. this last point is important because if high school	pupils are aware that few if any graduates who have chosen a certain	vocational program have obtained a job as a consequence of the training	the whole idea of relevance disappears.	9.804805906233216
15967. vocational training which	holds no hope that the skill developed will be in fact a marketable	skill becomes just another school chore for those whose interest	in their studies has begun to falter.	6.743365577977517
15968. those who because of population	mobility and the reputed desire of employers to train their own employees	would limit vocational education to general rather than specific	skills ought to bear in mind the importance of motivation in any kind	of school experience.	9.286210509303947
15969. i have been using the word vocational	as a layman would at first sight think it should be used.	9.36437238798854
15970. i intend	to include under the term all the practical courses open to boys	and girls.	10.35377301417487
15971. these courses develop skills other than those we think of	when we use the adjective academic.	7.4126369724920815
15972. practically all of these practical	skills are of such a nature that a degree of mastery can be obtained	in high school sufficient to enable the youth to get a job at	once on the basis of the skill.	10.800411160805506
15973. they are in this sense skills marketable	immediately on graduation from high school.	12.751282596309672
15974. to be sure in tool-and-die	work and in the building trades the first job must be often	on an apprentice basis but two years of half-time vocational training	enables the young man thus to anticipate one year of apprentice status.	8.476897475394304
15975. similarly a girl who graduates with a good working knowledge of stenography	and the use of clerical machines and who is able to get a job	at once may wish to improve her skill and knowledge by a year or two	of further study in a community college or secretarial school.	7.096578454353063
15976. of course	it can be argued that an ability to write english correctly and	with some degree of elegance is a marketable skill.	10.089083383754689
15977. so too is the	mathematical	competence of a college graduate who has majored in mathematics.	8.286531370360402
15978. in a sense almost all high school and college courses could be	considered as vocational to the extent that later in life the student	in his vocation will be called upon to use	some of the skills developed and the competence obtained.	10.795697484897163
15979. in spite	of the shading of one type of course into another i believe it is useful	to talk about vocational courses as apart from academic courses.	7.847019080365936
15980. perhaps a course in typewriting might be regarded as the exception which	proves the rule.	13.386745804196645
15981. today many college bound students try to take a	course in personal typing as they feel a certain degree of mastery of	this skill is almost essential for one who proposes to do academic work	in college and a professional school.	6.502366078184417
15982. most of our largest	cities have one or more separate vocational or technical high schools.	15.902251005085375
15983. in this respect public education in the large cities differs from education	in the smaller cities and consolidated school districts.	8.686337989535831
15984. the	neighborhood high schools are not strictly speaking comprehensive schools	because some of the boys and girls may be attending a vocational	or technical high school instead of the local school.	9.83928137946265
15985. indeed one	school superintendent in a large city objects to the use of the term	comprehensive	high school for the senior high schools in his city because	these schools do not offer strictly vocational programs.	8.338363236099541
15986. he prefers	to designate such schools as general high schools.	11.327381775397427
15987. the suburban	high school it is worth noting also is not a widely comprehensive	high school because of the absence of vocational programs.	8.366762718823512
15988. the reason	is that there is a lack of interest on the part of the community.	22.180078139706808
15989. therefore	employment and education in all the schools in a metropolitan	area are related in different ways from those which are characteristic	of the comprehensive high school described in my first report.	6.940883847572112
15990. the separate vocational or technical high schools in the large cities	must be reckoned as permanent institutions.	12.653240109836759
15991. by and large their programs	are satisfactorily connected both to the employment situation and	to the realities of the apprentice system.	7.866034842231976
15992. it is not often realized	to what degree certain trades are in many communities closed areas of	employment except for a lucky few.	11.625223090568712
15993. one has to talk confidentially with	some of the directors of vocational high schools to realize that a	boy cannot just say i want to be a plumber and then by doing	good work find a job.	8.2287815467788
15994. it is far more difficult in many communities	to obtain admission to an apprentice program which involves union approval	than to get into the most selective medical school in the nation.	14.03092623074609
15995. two stories will illustrate what i have in mind.	10.082836604568218
15996. one vocational instructor	in a city vocational school speaking of his course in a certain	field said he had no difficulty placing all students in jobs outside	of the city.	9.502235960504278
15997. in the city he said the waiting list for those	who want to join the union is so long that unless a boy has an inside	track he can't get in.	8.044664201086341
15998. in a far distant part of the united states	i was talking to an instructor about a boy who in the twelfth grade	was doing special work.	13.009058564997316
15999. what does he have in mind to do when he	graduates?	14.2174765924679
16000.  oh he'll be a plumber came the answer.	7.871341203825923
16001. but	isn't it almost impossible to get into the union?	8.54420596985766
16002.  i asked.	23.93887313146454
16003. he'll have no difficulty i was told.	4.565138505205529
16004. he has very good	connections.	19.98725790046177
16005. in my view there should be a school which offers	significant vocational programs for boys within easy reach of every	family in a city.	7.825197317164074
16006. ideally these schools should be so located that	one or more should be in the area where demand for practical courses is	at the highest.	10.01688531946621
16007. an excellent example of a successful location	of a new vocational high school is the dunbar vocational high school	in chicago.	7.875121806843056
16008. located in a bad slum area now undergoing redevelopment	this school and its program are especially tailored to the vocational	aims of its students.	7.963643407395338
16009. hardly a window has been broken since	dunbar	first was opened	.	8.230235027180186
16010. i discovered in the course of a visit there that almost	all the pupils were negroes.	15.25288193522811
16011. they were learning trades as diverse	as shoe repairing bricklaying carpentry cabinet making auto mechanics	and airplane mechanics.	6.125270461532273
16012. the physical facilities at dunbar are	impressive but more impressive is the attitude of the pupils.	12.310608621226491
16013. the soybean seed is the most important leguminous food in the	world.	8.348268659754572
16014. in the united states where half of the world crop is grown	soybeans are processed for their edible oil.	15.955467570906354
16015. the residue from soybean	processing goes mainly into animal feeds.	7.168742646389064
16016. soybeans are extensively	processed into a remarkable number of food products in the orient.	9.041871632462456
16017. american chemists seeking to increase exports of soybeans have	adapted modern techniques and fermentation methods to improve their	use in such traditional japanese foods as tofu and miso and in tempeh	of indonesia.	5.655915866450786
16018. soybean flour grits flakes milk and curd can	be bought in the united states.	10.972873905758162
16019. peanuts are the world's	second most important legume.	5.465192685770114
16020. they are used mainly for their oil.	17.014535835937654
16021. we	produce peanut oil but to a much greater extent we eat the entire seed.	6.80950648467804
16022. blanched peanuts as prepared for making peanut butter or for eating	as nuts are roasted seeds whose seedcoats have been rubbed off.	7.260725331713773
16023. cereal grains supplemented with soybeans or dry edible peas or beans	comprise about two-thirds or three-fourths of the diet in parts of	asia and africa.	4.626940561444128
16024. in western europe and north america where	the level of economic development is higher grains and other seed	products furnish less than one-third of the food consumed.	8.701681096934802
16025. rather	meat and potatoes sugar and dairy products are the main sources of	carbohydrate	protein oils and fats.	7.006324581100047
16026. people depend less on seeds for	foods in australia new zealand and argentina where extensive grazing	lands support sheep or cattle and the consumption of meat is high.	7.803235371275244
16027. feeds for livestock took about one-sixth of the world's	cereal crop in 1957-1958.	4.166597659215215
16028. most of the grain is fed to swine and dairy	cows and lesser amounts to beef cattle and poultry.	12.258890940838063
16029. about 90 percent	of the corn used in the united states is fed to animals.	11.939209670106072
16030. the rest	is used for human food and industrial products.	11.167448231164325
16031. more than half of the	sorghum and barley seeds we produce and most of the byproducts of the	milling of cereals and the crushing of oilseeds are fed to livestock.	8.525202833523746
16032. more than 200 million tons of seeds and seed products are fed	to livestock annually in the united states.	14.266762363573632
16033. the efficiency	with which animals convert grains and forages to meat has risen steadily	in the united states since the 1930's and has paralleled the increased	feeding of the cake and meal that are a byproduct when seeds	are processed for oil.	5.901898301301166
16034. the demand for food is so great in	the world that little arable land can be given over to growing the nonfood	crops.	10.981043010737162
16035. seeds grown for industrial uses hold a relatively minor	position.	8.064248019158928
16036. chief among the seed crops grown primarily for industrial	uses are the oil-bearing seeds- flax castor tung	perilla and oiticica	.	6.237243612678744
16037. oils or liquid fats from the	seeds of flax and tung have long been the principal constituents of paints	and varnishes for protecting and beautifying the surfaces of wood	and metal.	5.845706061854661
16038. these oils develop hard smooth films when they dry and form	resinlike substances.	8.886566477738665
16039. the artist who paints in oil uses drying	oils to carry the pigments and to protect his finished work for the	ages.	8.085429362571828
16040. one of the finest of artists' oils comes from poppy seeds.	13.307952806993013
16041. seeds of soybean cotton corn sesame and rape yield semidrying	oils.	7.847238425164514
16042. some are used in paints along with drying oils.	13.811091699234991
16043. palm oil	protects the surfaces of steel sheets before they are plated with tin.	6.799011335969347
16044. castor oil made from castorbeans has gone out of style as a	medicine.	10.410417050490478
16045. this nondrying oil however is now more in demand than ever	before as a fine lubricant as a constituent of fluids for hydraulically	operated equipment and as a source of chemicals to make plastics.	7.116372679094139
16046. almond oil another nondrying oil was once used extensively	in perfumery to extract flower fragrances.	7.840859444553245
16047. it is still used in drugs	and cosmetics but it is rather scarce and sometimes is adulterated with	oils from peach and plum seeds.	8.64765916650241
16048. liquid fats from all these	oilseeds enter into the manufacture of soaps for industry and the household	and of glycerin for such industrial uses as making explosives.	8.826774990331746
16049. sizable amounts of soybean coconut and palm kernel oil- seed	oils that are produced primarily for food purposes- also are used	to make soaps detergents and paint resins.	4.58394233627641
16050. solid fats from	the seeds of the mahua tree the shea tree and the coconut palm are used	to make candles in tropical countries.	8.826965376037737
16051. seeds are a main source	of starch for industrial and food use in many parts of the world.	8.34048883992607
16052. corn and wheat supply most of the starch in the united states canada	and australia.	12.353350176234686
16053. in other countries where cereal grains are not	among the principal crops of a region starchy tubers or roots are processed	for starch.	7.567390731217974
16054. starch is used in the paper textile and food-processing	industries and in a multitude of other manufacturing operations.	9.03431216019029
16055. gums were extracted from quince psyllium flax	and locust seeds in ancient times.	5.910143150251576
16056. today the yearly import	into the united states of locust bean gum is more than 15 million pounds;	of psyllium seed more than 2.	10.173052279939421
16057. the discovery during	the second world war that guar gum was similar to imported locust	gum increased its cultivation in western asia and initiated it in the	united states.	6.770477019028433
16058. water-soluble gums are used in foods and drugs	and in the manufacture of pulp and paper as thickeners stabilizers	or dispersing agents.	7.623771049460935
16059. guar gum thickens salad dressings and stabilizes	ice cream.	6.014903318861526
16060. quince seed gum is the main ingredient in wave-setting	lotions.	9.664845207652617
16061. once regarded as an agricultural nuisance psyllium was sold	in the 1930's as a mechanical laxative under 117 different brands.	5.389837836393731
16062. locust gum is added to pulp slurries to break up the lumps of fibers	in making paper.	10.464878591958767
16063. the seeds of hard fibrous stony fruits	called nuts provide highly concentrated foods oils and other materials	of value.	6.159523727660868
16064. most nuts consist of the richly packaged storage kernel	and its thick adherent brown covering- the seedcoat.	7.2448544681316
16065. the	kernels of brazil nuts cashews coconuts filberts hazelnuts hickory	nuts pecans walnuts and pine nuts are predominantly oily.	5.08178524545726
16066. almonds	and pistachio nuts are not so high in oil but are rich in protein.	12.032657331937608
16067. all nut kernels are rich in protein.	10.241150678144528
16068. the world production of familiar seed nuts- almonds brazil nuts	filberts and the english walnuts- totals about 300 thousand tons annually.	7.241118976915829
16069. coconuts the fruit of the coconut palm have the largest	of all known seeds and are grown in south pacific islands as a	crop for domestic and export markets.	5.820243333208601
16070. the oil palm of west africa yields	edible oil from both the flesh and the seed or kernel of its fruit.	9.295187158540127
16071. world production of copra the oil-bearing flesh of the coconut	was a little more than 3 million tons in 1959.	6.896795939694591
16072. exports from producing	countries in terms of equivalent oil were a little more than 1 million	tons about half of which was palm kernels or oil from them and about	half was palm oil.	11.104845423468683
16073. other nuts consumed in lesser quantity include	the spicy nutmeg; the soap nut which owes its sudsing power	to natural saponins; the marking nut used for ink and varnish; the	aromatic sassafras nut of south america; and the sweet-smelling	cumara nut which is suited for perfumes.	3.6047448652943195
16074. a forest crop that has	not been extensively cultivated is ivory nuts from the tagua palm.	8.074220130750867
16075. the so-called vegetable ivory is the hard endosperm of the egg-sized	seed.	4.982274202859127
16076. it is used for making buttons and other small hard objects of	turnery.	17.642762893245855
16077. seeds of the sago palm are used in bermuda to make heads and	faces of dolls sold to tourists.	8.15899725210272
16078. the color and shape of	seeds have long made them attractive for ornaments and decorations.	9.641282086080475
16079. since biblical times rosaries have been made from jobs-tears-	the seeds of an asiatic grass.	6.43127292539545
16080. bead tree seeds are the necklaces	of south pacific islanders and the eyes of buddha dolls in cuba.	9.920043039913466
16081. victorian ladies had a fad of stringing unusual seeds to wear as jewelry.	5.928372096138074
16082. handmade christmas wreaths and trees often contain a variety	of seeds collected during the year.	7.873951681239286
16083. tradition has assigned	medicinal values to seeds because of their alkaloids aromatic oils	and highly flavored components.	5.92646365715
16084. although science has given us more effective	materials preparations from anise castorbean colchicum nux	vomica mustard fennel and stramonium are familiar to many for the	relief of human ailments.	7.361465360033041
16085. flaxseed poultices and mustard plasters still	are used by some persons.	6.241343193539036
16086. peanut and sesame oils often are	used as carriers or diluents for medicines administered by injection.	7.275185489040366
16087. still another	group of seeds	provide distinctive flavors and odors to foods although the	nutrients they supply are quite negligible.	5.681090145366265
16088. the common spices flavorings	and condiments make up this group.	12.012957509781758
16089. each year millions of	pounds of anise caraway mustard celery and coriander and the oils	extracted from them are imported.	6.359407734015171
16090. single-seeded dry fruits used	for flavoring include several of the carrot family such as cumin	dill fennel and angelica.	6.937436329894937
16091. less common seeds used in cooking and beverages	include fenugreek and cardamom.	7.759683703687446
16092. white	pepper is the ground seed of the common black pepper fruit.	10.186526353885258
16093. sesame	seed which comes from the tall pods of a plant grown in egypt	brazil and central america has a toasted-nut flavor and can be	used in almost any dish calling for almonds.	5.30214519279416
16094. it is a main flavoring for	halvah the candy of the middle east.	17.295487036311005
16095. sesame sticks a snack dip	originated in the southwest.	6.666802282507469
16096. beverages are made from seeds	the world over.	10.126905575171099
16097. coffee is made from the roasted and ground seeds	of the coffee tree.	7.307080718710763
16098. world production of coffee broke all previous	records in 1959 and 1960 at more than 5 million tons.	12.07576441703973
16099. per capita consumption	remains around 16 pounds in the united states.	9.203329243658517
16100. cocoa	chocolate and cocoa butter come from the ground seeds of the cacao	tree.	11.235776148938845
16101. world production of about 1 million tons is divided primarily between	africa.	8.791328576235532
16102. several	soft drinks contain extracts from kola nuts the seed of the kola	tree cultivated in the west indies and south america.	8.689376300176816
16103. cereal	grains have been used for centuries to prepare fermented beverages.	8.069743996183263
16104. the japanese sake is wine fermented from rice grain.	10.525830329750356
16105. arrack is	distilled from fermented rice in india.	6.387406102076266
16106. beer generally fermented	from barley is an old alcoholic beverage.	9.115269633438476
16107. beer was brewed by the	babylonians and egyptians more than 6 thousand years ago.	6.41916592574217
16108. brewers	today use corn rice and malted barley.	8.578383922179222

16110. seed crops hold a prominent place in the agricultural economy	of the united states.	11.132945725591151

16122. to hold a herd of cattle on a new range till they felt at home	was called locatin' 'em.	11.37705483527624
16123. to keep 'em scattered somewhat	and yet herd 'em was called loose herdin'.	4.042639114502223

16125. cattle were inclined to remain	in a territory with which they were acquainted.	8.347607226203413

16129. cattle would drift day and night in a blizzard till it	was over.	7.343616978465812
