16131. such marchin' in wholesale	numbers was called a drift or winter drift and if the storm	was prolonged it usually resulted in one of the tragedies of the	range.	7.226631638769274
16132. the cowboy made a technical distinction in reference to the number	of them animals.	13.139353055044523
16133. the single animal or a small bunch were referred	to as strays; but when a large number were bunched up	or banded up and marched away from their home range as long as	they stayed together the group was said to be a drift.	7.470165051645049
16134. drifts	usually occurred in winter in an effort to escape the severe cold winds	but it could also occur in summer as the result of lack of water or	grass because of a drought or as an aftermath of a stampede.	9.52972661929213
16135. drifts	usually happened only with cattle for hosses had 'nough sense to avoid	'em and to find shelter for 'emselves.	4.628616534859518
16136. the wholesale	death of cattle as a result of blizzards and sometimes droughts over	a wide range of territory was called a die-up.	10.670470946744706

16176. tailin'	was the throwin' of an animal by the tail in lieu of a	rope.	6.121268117624601

16340. it is here that the ecumenical must become	local and the local become ecumenical.	17.84859167513159
16341. it has become almost	trite to say that the ecumenical movement must be carried down to the	grass roots.	14.037830241110038

16464. hypothesizing a series of developmental	stages that begin in the individual's infancy and end in his old	age erikson has indicated that the adolescent is faced with a series	of identity crises.	7.992131857946995
16465. the successful and positive resolution of these	crises during adolescence involves an epigenetic principle- during	adolescence the individual's positive resolutions in each area of identity	crisis depend to a considerable degree on his already having	resolved preliminary and preparatory identity crises during his infancy	childhood and early adolescence.	4.712238449768616
16466. within erikson's schema the	adolescent's delinquent behavior- in this case her unwed motherhood-	reflects her identity diffusion or her inability to resolve	these various identity crises positively.	5.455701767662452
16467. the adolescent	experiences identity crises in terms of time perspective vs time diffusion.	8.89979027935351
16468. time perspective- the ability to plan for the future and	to postpone gratifying immediate wants in order to achieve long-range	objectives- is more easily developed if from infancy on the individual	has been able to rely on and trust people and the world in which	she lives.	9.482616935822483
16469. erikson has noted that unless this trust developed early	the time ambivalence experienced in varying degree and temporarily	by all adolescents	gratification of wants during childhood while not yet having fully	may develop	into a more permanent sense of time diffusion.	5.9049701801345655
16470. experience of this time	diffusion ranges from a sense of utter apathy to a feeling of desperate	urgency to act immediately.	9.946925617442188
16471. these polar extremes in time	diffusion were indicated in some of the comments by unwed mothers reported	in earlier chapters.	7.216065066074793
16472. some of these mothers apparently feeling a	desperate urgency made on the spur of the moment commitments in love	and sex that would have life-long consequences.	9.728397616983603
16473. others displayed	utter apathy and indifference to any decision about the past or the future.	7.051935022659766
16474. for many of these unwed mothers the data on their family life	and early childhood experiences revealed several indications and sources	of their	basic mistrust of their parents in particular and of the world in	general.	10.302642249098229
16475. however as erickson has noted the individual's	failure to develop preliminary identities during infancy and childhood	need not be irreversibly deterministic with respect to a given area of	identity diffusion in his adolescence.	5.738361766968602
16476. and as shown in chapter	6 some snp females originally developed such trust only	during their adolescence through the aid of and their identification	with alter-parents.	10.112974397050982
16477. in the specific case of time diffusion we	must emphasize the significance of the earlier development of mistrust	when it is combined with the inevitable time crisis experienced by	most adolescents in our society and with the failure of	the adolescent period to provide opportunities for developing trust.	8.017759047961025
16478. the adolescent experiences two closely related crises: self-certainty	vs an identity consciousness; and role-experimentation	vs negative identity.	5.489853316854487
16479. a sense of self-certainty and the freedom	to experiment with different roles or confidence in one's own unique	behavior as an alternative to peer-group conformity is more easily	developed during adolescence if during early childhood the individual	was permitted to exercise initiative and encouraged to develop some	autonomy.	4.5936027969867
16480. however if the child has been constantly surrounded	during nursery and early school age by peer groups; inculcated	with the primacy of group acceptance and group standards; and allowed	little initiative in early play and work patterns- then in adolescence	her normal degree of vanity sensitivity and preoccupation with	whether others find her appearance and behavior acceptable will be compounded.	6.171417575076196
16481. her ostensible indifference to and rebellion against suggestions	and criticisms by anyone except peer friends during adolescence	are the manifestations in her adolescence of her having been indoctrinated	in childhood to feel shame if not guilt for failing to behave	in a manner acceptable to and judged by the performance of her nursery-	and elementary-school peer friends.	5.508832798333107
16482. to be different is to invite	shame and doubt; and it is better to be shamed and criticized by one's	parents who already consider one different and difficult to understand	than by one's peers who are also experiencing a similar groping	for and denial of adult status.	6.669067741636381
16483. the attitudes of some unwed	mothers quoted in chapter 2 revealed both considerable preoccupation	with being accepted by others and a marked absence of self-certainty.	6.906184184329498
16484. many appeared to regard their sexual behavior as a justifiable	means of gaining acceptance from and identification with others; but	very few seemed aware that such acceptance and identification need	to be supplemented with more enduring and stable identification of and	with one's self.	6.941762742496533
16485. another identity crisis confronting the	adolescent involves anticipation of achievement vs work-paralysis.	7.718517358581531
16486. the adolescent's capacity to anticipate achievement and to exercise	the self-discipline necessary to complete tasks successfully depends	on the degree to which he or she developed autonomy initiative and	self-discipline during childhood.	7.376045596144672
16487. the developmental process involves	the individual's progressively experiencing a sense of dignity and achievement	resulting from having completed tasks having kept commitments	and having created something	dress of one's own design rather than in the design it ought	.	5.04319331051606
16488. these childhood experiences are sources of the self-certainty	that the adolescent needs for experimenting with many roles and	for the freedom to fail sometimes in the process of exploring and	discovering her skills and abilities.	9.542562199610305
16489. if she has not had such	experiences the female's normal adolescent degree of indecision will	be compounded.	6.83777167834392
16490. she may well be incapacitated by it when she is confronted	with present and future alternatives- eg whether to prepare	primarily for a career or for the role of a homemaker; whether	to stay financially dependent on her parents or help support herself	while attending school; whether to pursue a college education or a	job after high school; and whether to attend this or that college and	to follow this or that course of study.	6.945090111934343
16491. erikson has noted that as	this indecision mounts it may result in a paralysis of workmanship.	8.469775784447068
16492. this paralysis may be expressed in the female's starting- and	never completing- many jobs tasks and courses of study; and in	the fact that she bases her decisions about work college carreer and	studies on what others are doing rather than on her own sense of identity	with given skills abilities likes and dislikes.	6.668016598585479
16493. the absence	during her childhood and early adolescence of experiences in developing	the self-discipline to complete tasks within her ability- experiences	that would have been subsequent sources of anticipation of achievement-	and her lack of childhood opportunities to practice autonomy	and initiative in play and expression both tend in her adolescence	to deprive her of the freedoms to role-experiment and to fail occasionally	in experimenting.	4.664662626837857
16494. the comments made by some unwed mothers	reflect this paralysis of workmanship.	11.176767227145952
16495. they	attended school and selected courses primarily on the basis of decisions	others made; they accepted a job primarily because it was available	convenient and paid reasonably.	5.92484823063216
16496. these things both express and	at the same time continue contributing to their identity diffusion	in an area that could have become a source of developing dignity and	self-certainty.	10.390353334890918
16497. as their identity diffusion increased they became more	susceptible to sporadic diversions in love and sexual affairs.	6.893787639663325
16498. these	affairs temporarily relieved the monotony of school or work activities	containing no anticipation of achievement and joy of craftsmanship	no sense of dignity derived from a job well done.	9.890946190693962
16499. childhood	experiences in learning work and self-discipline habits within a context	of developing autonomy and initiative have considerable significance	for the prevention of illegitimacy.	5.836847435219213
16500. the excerpts from case histories	presented above confirm this significance though through different	facets of experience.	8.47475843321377
16501. for example some unwed mothers had had no work	experiences household chores and responsibilities during childhood	and early adolescence; they subsequently occupied their leisure hours	in searching for something exciting and diverting.	6.263358787656298
16502. on	the other hand some unwed mothers had had so much work and responsibility	imposed on them at an early age and had thus had so little freedom	or opportunity to develop autonomy and initiative that their work	and responsibilities became dull and unrewarding burdens- to be escaped	and rebelled against through fun and experimentation with forbidden	sexual behavior.	8.636907454871283
16503. the adolescent also faces the identity	crisis that erikson has termed ideological polarization vs diffusion	of ideals.	6.65692607548865
16504. in discussing the ways this crisis is germane to consderations	for the prevention of illegitimacy we shall again superimpose	erikson's concept on our data.	9.25294837774679
16505. adolescents have a much-discussed	tendency to polarize ideas and values to perceive things as	either-or black or white- nuances of meaning are relatively	unimportant.	4.349666018779173
16506. this tendency is perhaps most clearly revealed in the	literature on religious conversions and experiences of adolescents.	9.277304664275166
16507. erikson	has postulated that such ideological polarization temporarily	resolves their search for something stable and definite in the rapidly	changing and fluctuating no-man's-land between childhood and adulthood.	4.9722852619076345
16508. it provides identification- with an idea a value a cause that	cuts through or even transcends the multiple and ambivalent identities	of their passage from child to adult and permits their forceful	and overt expression of emotion.	7.816052503252231
16509. the positive development during	adolescence of this capacity to think and to feel strongly and with	increasing independence and to identify overtly either with or against	given ideas values and practices depends to a considerable degree	on both previous and present opportunities for developing autonomy	initiative and self-certainty.	6.01079442690139
16510. most adolescents have some ideological	diffusion at various developmental stages as they experience a proliferation	of ideas and values.	9.403465120608875
16511. the diffusion is most pronounced and	most likely to become fixed however in those who have had no or very	minimal opportunities to develop the autonomy and initiative that could	have been directed into constructive expression and so served as sources	of developing self-certainty.	7.212510503756277
16512. a pronounced ideological	diffusion- ie inability to identify independently with given	ideas and value systems- is reflected in many ways.	6.740654398932005
16513. for example	it is evinced by the adolescent whose beliefs and actions	represent primarily his rebellion and reaction again the ideas and behavior	patterns of others rather than his inner conviction and choice.	5.9450242423397945
16514. it is mirrored by the individual willie lohmans whose ideas and	behavior patterns are so dependent and relativistic that they always coincide	with those of the individual or group present and most important	at the moment.	10.231453344368827
16515. in another sense it is represented in the arguments	of the true believers who seek to disprove the validity of all	other beliefs and ideas in order to retain confidence in theirs.	7.609691299656269
16516. the case histories provide some interesting illustrations of ideological	diffusion embodied in the unwed mother's inability to identify	independently with a given value system or behavior pattern and	her subsequent disinclination to assume any individual responsibility	for her sexual behavior.	7.327498226241478
16517. for example the unwed mothers expressed	their frustration with males who did not indicate more explicitly what	it is they really want from a girl so one can act accordingly.	7.54303928756995
16518. they were disappointed by the physical and emotional hurt of premarital	sexual intercourse.	11.51900949294187
16519. they condemned the movie script writers for implying	that sex was enjoyable and exhilarating.	6.786423499459681
16520. they criticized parents	for never having emphasized traditional concepts of right and wrong;	and they censured parents who never disciplined and were too permissive	or who never explained how easy it was to get pregnant.	7.612019410693094
16521. in the adult world there are a number of rather general and	diffuse sources of ideological diffusion that further compound the	adolescent's search for meaning during this particular identity crisis.	7.031233487509647
16522. for example some contemporary writing tends to fuse the good	guys and the bad guys to portray the weak people as heroes and	weakness as a virtue and to explain asocial behavior	by attributing it to deterministic psychological familial and social	experiences.	8.332295885371337
16523. in the final accounting these would have augmented the bill for both	sides.	9.589650924954494
16524. an estimate of one million dollars is probably not excessive.	11.435307471681337
16525. yet the huge amount of money consumed by the selden litigation	which many regarded as wasteful indirectly contributed to constructive	changes in legal procedure.	7.537922403877414
16526. the duration and other circumstances	of the selden case made it a flagrant example of the gross abuses of	patent infringement actions.	10.174739338924699
16527. the suit as we have seen came before	the courts when patent attorneys inventors and laymen were making mounting	demands for reforms in the american patent system.	6.722750615173332
16528. chief among	the defects they singled out were the complicated and wearisome procedures	in equity.	8.206512508863621
16529. in a long and angry footnote to his opinion	judge hough had lent the weight of judicial condemnation to such criticism.	8.364244935627285
16530. it is a duty said hough not to let pass this opportunity	of protesting against the methods of taking and printing testimony	in equity current in this circuit excused	if not justified by the rules of the supreme court especially to	be found in patent causes and flagrantly exemplified in this litigation.	9.963675744965627
16531. as long as the bar prefers to adduce evidence by written deposition	rather than viva voce before an authoritative judicial officer	i fear that the antiquated rules will remain unchanged and expensive	prolixity remain the best known characteristic of equity.	6.747527855346422
16532. observing	that reforms sometimes begin with the contemplation of horrible	examples hough catalogued the many abuses encouraged by existing	procedures.	8.07914162823717
16533. he cited the elephantine dimensions of the selden case	record; the duplication of testimony and exhibits; the numerous	squabbles over minor matters; the objections stated at outrageous	length; and the frequent and rancorous verbal bouts uncalled	for and	unjustifiable from the retort discourteous to the lie direct.	4.284450932278154
16534. the fundamental difficulty of which the selden case was	a striking example concluded hough will	remain as long as testimony is taken without any authoritative judicial	officer present and responsible for the maintenance of discipline	and the reception or exclusion of testimony.	9.155042598480257
16535. not least	among the members of the patent bar who echoed this powerful indictment	were those who had participated in the selden suit.	10.078938691317187
16536. william a	redding asserted that if the case had been heard in open court under	rules of evidence the testimony would have been completed in sixty	days instead of five years.	10.426245968755527
16537. inventors joined lawyers in the clamor for	reform inevitably centering upon the selden litigation as a horrible	example.	5.978570940090437
16538. its costive deliberations were likened to those of	the british courts of chancery mercilessly caricatured by dickens in	bleak house.	6.977846948773254
16539. parker who agreed with much of this criticism	did not conceal his dissatisfaction with procedural defects.	6.7864756166226226
16540. but	he felt that the selden case was being unfairly pilloried.	12.268623670128012
16541. in a detailed	letter published in the scientific american in 1912 he	remarked that loose statements about the case showed scant understanding	of the facts.	7.740919906905368
16542. the suit although commonly designated as a single	action actually embraced five cases.	9.753390568553003
16543. parker insisted that the size	of the record would have been drastically reduced but for an unavoidable	duplication of testimony.	7.90496955962293
16544. in a private communication written	in 1911 parker had been more to the point.	12.629946965608758
16545. noting the complaints	of inventors and members of the patent bar he admitted that some	of the strictures were fairly well founded but he added that under	existing rules the courts could not consolidate testimony in a group	of suits involving separate infringements of the same patent.	6.566610391837957
16546. the	vast industrial interests caught up in the selden suit as well as the	complex character of the automotive art encouraged both sides to exploit	every possible chance for or against the patent said parker.	11.006758862436785
16547. this very seldom happens in this class or in other cases and	of course all of these matters led to a volume and an expense of the	record beyond what ordinarily would occur.	8.013398843766158
16548. parker listed the	remedies he deemed essential for reducing the cost and mass of testimony.	9.518577029793974
16549. the most important of these found him in agreement with hough's	plea for reform.	7.758969850626631
16550. parker called for abolition of the indiscriminate	or uncontrolled right of taking depositions before officers of the court	who had no authority to limit testimony.	8.645367620575058
16551. the taking of depositions	he suggested should be placed under a special court examiner empowered	to compel responsive and relevant answers and to exclude immaterial	testimony.	6.391175829219989
16552. i am satisfied that in the selden case had this power	existed and this course been pursued it would have shortened	the depositions of some of the experts nearly one-half and of some of	the other witnesses thereto more than that.	9.988338936635245
16553. in the end hough's	acidulous protest which parker called the now somewhat famous	note on this 'selden' case did not go unheeded.	6.571057957936909
16554. in 1912	the united states supreme court adopted a new set of rules of equity	which became effective on february 1 1913.	10.508768482225488
16555. the revised procedure	was acclaimed as a long-overdue reform.	6.9816416087549955
16556. under the new rules testimony	is taken orally in open court in all cases except those of an extraordinary	character.	10.891819695511984
16557. other expeditious methods are designed to prevent	prolixity limit delays and reduce the expense of infringement suits.	7.231071486731392
16558. one of the alam lawyers observed that if the selden	case had been tried under this simplified procedure the testimony	which filled more than a score of volumes at a minimum cost of $1	a page for publication alone could have been contained in one volume.	9.880884703360389
16559. while patent suits are still among the most complex and expensive	forms of litigation these rules have saved litigants uncounted sums	of money.	6.098155256461476
16560. there is little doubt that they were promulgated by the supreme	court as a direct result of the selden patent suit.	19.573755376103172
16561. even	before it was formally dissolved in 1912 the alam	was succeeded by the automobile board of trade the direct lineal	ancestor of the present-day automobile manufacturers association.	5.861318134284759
16562. the trade bodies which came in the wake of the alam	were more representative for they never adopted a policy of exclusion.	11.540209355941656
16563. nevertheless it is from the selden organization that the industry	inherited its institutional machinery for furthering the broader interests	of the trade.	7.031497271209269
16564. one of the chief features of this community of interest	is the automotive patents cross-licensing agreement a milestone	in the development of american industrial cooperation.	10.486404960001082
16565. its origin	lies in the selden patent controversy and its aftermath.	8.021998828796333
16566. from	the earliest days of the motor car industry before the alam	was established patent infringement loomed as a serious and	vexing problem.	9.430999266650087
16567. many patent contests were waged over automobile components	and accessories among them tires detachable rims ball bearings	license brackets and electric horns.	5.334466020718225
16568. the fluidity and momentum of	the young industry abetted a general disregard of patent claims.	8.611713794226592
16569. as	early as 1900 a wall street combination acquired detail patents with	the intention of exacting heavy tribute from automobile manufacturers.	5.6815737875269425
16570. this scheme failed and the following decade brought a deluge of infringement	suits among individual manufacturers that reached its crest	in 1912.	9.622685930768325
16571. in this tangle of conflicting claims the patent-sharing	scheme adopted by the alam at its founding proved	to be the best device for avoiding or mitigating the burdens of incessant	litigation.	6.033003569685136
16572. the interchange of shop licenses for a nominal royalty	eliminated infringement suits among the members of the alam	patent pool	and kept open channels for the cross-fertilization of automotive	technology.	8.623510287083166
16573. one of the conditions of the pool was a prohibition	upon the withholding of patent rights among alam members.	11.33687519047583
16574. within its limits this arrangement had the actual or potential characteristics	of a cross-licensing agreement.	7.978512844824278
16575. its positive features	outweighed the fact that the pool was an adjunct of a wouldbe monopoly.	8.236279704438742
16576. since the alam holdings embraced only about twenty-five	per cent of motor vehicle patents the denial of rights to independent	companies did not retard technical progress in unlicensed sectors	of the industry.	7.067330904553426
16577. the highly important dyer patents on the sliding	gear transmission were held by the alam pool.	7.364365067815608
16578. but henry	ford used the planetary transmission in his model t and earlier	cars and in 1905 as a precautionary measure took out a license	from the man who claimed to be its inventor.	8.65463561485411
16579. for those affiliated	with it the alam pool was a haven from the infringement	actions involving detail patents that beset the industry with mounting	intensity after 1900.	7.678105673424325
16580. by 1910 the courts were crowded with cases	many of them brought by freebooters who trafficked in disputed inventions.	8.288347063109688
16581. it was commonplace for auto makers parts-suppliers and dealers	to find warning notices and threats of infringement suits in their	daily mail.	6.772146292464967
16582. purely from the business man's standpoint and without	regard to the lawyer's view commented a trade journal the	matter of patents in the automobile and accessory trade is developing	some phases and results that challenge thought as to how far patents	are to become weapons of warfare in business instead of simple beneficient	protection devices for encouraging inventive creation.	6.439926717648698
16583. occasionally new enterprise was discouraged by the almost certain	prospect of legal complications.	6.625305253214521
16584. one manufacturer who held an allegedly	basic patent said: i would readily put over $50000 into the	manufacture of the device but it is so easy to make that we would enter	immediately into a prolonged ordeal of patent litigation which would	eat up all our profits.	7.7153520350078635
16585. the prevailing view in the industry was	summed up in 1912 by a group of auto makers who told a senate committee:	the exceedingly unsatisfactory and uselessly expensive conditions	including delays surrounding legal disputes particularly in patent	litigation are items of industrial burden which must be written	large in figures of many millions of dollars of industrial waste.	6.310317613996481
16586. by that time it was commonly agreed that patent warfare was sapping	constructive achievement and blocking the free exchange of technical	information.	9.363278547889548
16587. at this point charles c hanch long an advocate	of patent peace in the industry became chairman of the patents committee	of the national automobile chamber of commerce successor	to the automobile board of trade.	8.259699167604781
16588. hanch was treasurer of the nordyke	+ marmon company an indianapolis firm which had manufactured flour-milling	machinery before producing the marmon car in 1904.	6.038832787886147
16589. he had	first-hand knowledge of the patent wars which had driven about ninety	per cent of the milling equipment makers out of business in the mid-1890's.	7.558315906796145
16590. anxious to avoid a similar debacle in the motor car industry	hanch went to detroit in 1909 to enlist the support of leading	alam members for an industry-wide patent-sharing plan.	7.565380599795617
16591. the breach created by the selden patent doomed his proposal but hanch	did not abandon his scheme.	7.745568659149648
16592. after the demise of the alam	the time was propitious for establishing such a pool.	10.465798660947966
16593. most manufacturers were now disposed to heed a proposal for the formal	interchange of patents.	7.108551317085553
16594. it is a much easier course to agree to	let one another alone so far as ordinary patents are concerned said	a trade authority than to continue the costly effort of straightening	the tangle in the courts or seeking to reform the patent system	which appears to be getting into deeper confusion every day.	9.578803032200444
16595. with the other members of the patents committee- wilfred c leland	howard e coffin windsor t white and w h	vandervoort- hanch drafted a cross-licensing agreement whose essential	feature of royalty-free licensing was his own contribution.	4.529021382779922
16596. the	plan was supported by frederick p fish counsel for the national	automobile chamber of commerce.	8.973901781112364
16597. it will be recalled that in his	summation for the alam before judge hough fish had	condemned patent litigation as the curse of the american industrial	community.	9.561153790053462
16598. he was well aware that some inventors and their allies used	their patents solely for nuisance value.	11.040537394572079
16599. my personal view is that	not one patented invention in ten is worth making he later told	a congressional committee.	6.262301590660403
16600. the eloquent persuasions of fish guaranteed	the adoption of the plan by the members of the automotive trade association.	14.012170864821433
16601. drawn up in 1914 the cross-licensing agreement became	effective in 1915.	6.2934324625338
16602. it remained in force for ten years and has been	renewed at five-year intervals since 1925.	10.67637636725003

16680. rare indeed is the harlem citizen from the most circumspect church	member to the most shiftless adolescent who does not have a long tale	to tell of police incompetence injustice or brutality.	9.673531725137
16681. i myself	have witnessed and endured it more than once.	8.659680031958736

16684. perhaps the place to discuss harlem's very complex attitude toward	black policemen nor the reasons according to harlem that they	it is hard on the other hand to blame	the policeman blank good-natured thoughtless and insuperably	innocent for being such a perfect representative of the people he serves.	8.614790359952908
16685. he too believes in good intentions and is astounded and offended	when they are not taken for the deed.	7.889588318869444
16686. he has never himself done	anything for which to be hated- which of us has?	10.646119693859799
16687. - and yet he is	facing daily and nightly people who would gladly see him dead and he	knows it.	4.788199951401618
16688. there is no way for him not to know it: there are few things	under heaven more unnerving than the silent accumulating contempt	and hatred of a people.	10.532366768058797
16689. he moves through harlem therefore like	an occupying soldier in a bitterly hostile country; which is precisely	what and where he is and is the reason he walks in twos and threes.	6.559958532777114
16690. and he is not the only one who knows why he is always in company:	the people who are watching him know why too.	12.13682294007848
16691. any street meeting	sacred or secular which he and his colleagues uneasily cover has as	its explicit or implicit burden the cruelty and injustice of the white	domination.	5.711603003337824
16692. and these days of course in terms increasingly vivid and	jubilant it speaks of the end of that domination.	15.488972149651364
16693. the white policeman	standing on a harlem street corner finds himself at the very center	of the revolution now occurring in the world.	7.5238823023180075
16694. he is not prepared	for it- naturally nobody is- and what is possibly much more to the	point he is exposed as few white people are to the anguish of the	black people around him.	8.156661726862808
16695. even if he is gifted with the merest mustard	grain of imagination something must seep in.	8.787704200584434

16697. he	knows that he certainly does not want his children living this	way.	7.444252861133054

16699. he becomes more	callous the population becomes more hostile the situation grows	more tense and the police force is increased.	7.1538886224086635
16700. one day to everyone's	astonishment someone drops a match in the powder keg and everything	blows up.	9.098916390466654
16701. before the dust has settled or the blood congealed editorials	speeches and civil-rights commissions are loud in the land demanding	to know what happened.	6.156962439691285
16702. what happened is that negroes want to	be treated like men.	12.748251477644176
16703. negroes want to be treated like men:	a perfectly straightforward statement containing only seven words.	6.049649351116119
16704. people who have mastered kant hegel shakespeare marx freud	and the bible find this statement utterly impenetrable.	9.595692431143254
16705. the idea seems	to threaten profound barely conscious assumptions.	9.038047454567664
16706. a kind of panic	paralyzes their features as though they found themselves trapped on	the edge of a steep place.	10.675165757602544
16707. i once tried to describe to a very well-known	american intellectual the conditions among negroes in the south.	7.697755575927987
16708. my recital disturbed him and made him indignant; and he asked me	in perfect innocence why don't all the negroes in the south	move north?	6.341027120816836
16709.  i tried to explain what has happened unfailingly	whenever a significant body of negroes move north.	7.948989472074183
16710. they do not	escape jim crow: they merely encounter another not-less-deadly	variety.	9.270338559801774
16711. they do not move to chicago they move to the south side;	they do not move to new york they move to harlem.	10.715154518415648
16712. the pressure	within the ghetto causes the ghetto walls to expand and this expansion	is always violent.	9.204218301923378
16713. white people hold the line as long as they can	and in as many ways as they can from verbal intimidation to physical	violence.	8.309006980433969

16715. the white	people fall back bitterly before the black horde; the landlords make	a tidy profit by raising the rent chopping up the rooms and all but	dispensing with the upkeep; and what has once been a neighborhood	turns into a turf.	4.903475857507462
16716. this is precisely what happened when the puerto	ricans arrived in their thousands- and the bitterness thus caused	is as i write being fought out all up and down those streets.	10.162547956544904
16717. northerners indulge in an extremely dangerous luxury.	8.010677057019503
16718. they seem	to feel that because they fought on the right side during the civil	war and won they have earned the right merely to deplore what is going	on in the south without taking any responsibility for it; and	that they can ignore what is happening in northern cities because what	is happening in little rock or birmingham is worse.	9.283043139325548
16719. well in the	first place it is not possible for anyone who has not endured both	to know which is worse.	9.34585780895107
16720. i know negroes who prefer the south and	white southerners because at least there you haven't got to	play any guessing games! the guessing games referred to have driven	more than one negro into the narcotics ward the madhouse or the	river.	6.9116267640350735
16721. i know another negro a man very dear to me who says with	conviction and with truth the spirit of the south is the spirit	of america.	9.541398252865465
16722. he was born in the north and did his military training	in the south.	17.78354223438537

16725. the world has never lacked for horrifying examples;	but i do not believe that these examples are meant to be used as justification	for our own crimes.	8.70714045770744

16729. as far as the color problem	is concerned there is but one great difference between the southern	white and the northerner: the southerner remembers historically and	in his own psyche a kind of eden in which he loved black people and	they loved him.	7.705149199078905

16746. river downtown: postscript to a letter from harlem	the	fact that american negroes rioted in the un while adlai	stevenson was addressing the assembly shocked and baffled most white	americans.	7.54316851834322

16748. stevenson stated in the course of	his address that the united states was against colonialism.	15.868843454152193
16749. god	knows what the african nations who hold 25 per cent of the voting	stock in the un were thinking- they may for example have	been thinking of the us abstention when the vote on algerian	freedom was before the assembly- but i think i have a fairly accurate	notion of what the negroes in the gallery were thinking.	7.138682835275988
16750. i had	intended to be there myself.	17.55476222844703

16757. the	climate and the events of the last decade and the steady pressure of	the cold war have given americans yet another means of avoiding	self-examination and so it has been decided that the riots were communist	inspired.	6.757133735720712

16762. one	has only for example to walk through harlem and ask oneself two questions.	10.043982608179213

16772. color was delayed until 1935 the wide screen until the early fifties.	9.172382857837812
16773. movement itself was the chief and often the only attraction	of the primitive movies of the nineties.	7.082176716507937
16774. each film consisted of fifty	feet which gives a running time of about one minute on the screen.	11.298830036066775
16775. as long as audiences came to see the movement there seemed little reason	to adventure further.	9.680706988529778
16776. motion-picture exhibitions took place in stores	in a general atmosphere like that of the penny arcade which can	still be found in such urban areas as times square.	9.211797606752631
16777. brief snips of	actual events were shown: parades dances street scenes.	4.896738704111803

16782. in the field	of entertainment there is no spur to financial daring so effective	as audience boredom and the first decade of the new device was not over	before audiences began staying away in large numbers from the simple-minded	one-minute shows.	10.077787124306433
16783. in response the industry allowed the discovery	of the motion picture as a form of fiction and thus gave the movies	the essential form they have had to this day.	9.412742387269244
16784. despite the sheer	beauty and spectacle of numerous documentaries art films and travelogues	despite the impressive financial success of such a recent development	as cinerama the movies are at heart a form of fiction like the	play the novel or the short story.	8.879177858597853

16786. thus such great american documentaries	as the river and the plow that broke the plains	were composed as visual stories rather than as illustrated lectures.	8.967724891233186
16787. the discovery that movies are a form of fiction was made in the early	years of this century and it was made chiefly by two men a french	magician georges melies and an american employee of edison edwin	s porter.	8.05515778733864
16788. of the two porter is justly the better known for	he went far beyond the vital finding of fiction for films to take the	first step toward fashioning a language of film toward making the motion	picture the intricate efficient time machine that it has remained	since even in the most inept hands.	9.265453482563046
16789. melies however out of his professional instincts as a magician	discovered and made use of a number of illusionary techniques that remain	part of the vocabulary of film.	7.094413982070551
16790. one of these is the dissolve	which makes possible a visually smooth transition from scene to scene.	11.70078535703348
16791. as the first scene begins to fade the succeeding scene begins	to appear.	9.108153431441853
16792. for a moment or two both scenes are present simultaneously	one growing weaker one growing stronger.	11.611095582791217
16793. in a series of fairy tales	and fantasies melies demonstrated that the film is superbly equipped	to tell a straightforward story with beginning middle and end complications	resolutions climaxes and conclusions.	7.1001845830932035
16794. immediately the	film improved and it improved because in narrative it found a content	based on time to complement its own unbreakable connection with time.	8.625351458040067
16795. physically a movie is possible because a series of images is projected	one at a time at such a speed that the eye remembers the one	that has gone before even as it registers the one now appearing.	7.126083605947334
16796. linking	the smoothly changing images together the eye itself endows them	with the illusion of movement.	8.269544008486726
16797. the projection time of painting	and sculpture is highly subjective varying from person to person and	even varying for a given person on different occasions.	6.898925482436423
16798. so is the time	of the novel.	15.912972383400573
16799. the drama in the theater and the concert in the hall	both have a fixed time but the time is fixed by the director and the	players the conductor and the instrumentalists subject therefore	to much variation as record collectors well know.	6.98928260195787
16800. the time of the motion	picture is fixed absolutely.	18.35227466447299
16801. the film consists of a series of still	transparent photographs or frames 35-mm-wide.	9.141372119147228
16802. each frame	comes between the light and the lens and is individually projected	on the screen at the rate for silent movies of 16 frames per second	and for sound films 24 frames per second.	8.759670146689464
16803. this is the rate of projection;	it is also the rate of photographing.	11.456312700490551
16804. time is built into	the motion picture which cannot exist without time.	10.606407283656537
16805. now time is also	the concern of the fictional narrative which is at its simplest	the story of an action with usually a beginning a middle and an end-	elements which demand time as the first condition for their existence.	6.515281935363354
16806. the moving picture of the train or the wave coming at the	audience is to be sure more intense than a still picture of the same	subject but the difference is really one of degree; the cinematic	element of time is merely used to increase the realism of an object which	would still be reasonably realistic in a still photo.	8.699161445771441
16807. in narrative	time is essential as it is in film.	13.267832376094887
16808. almost everything about the	movies that is peculiarly of the movies derives from a tension created	and maintained between narrative time and film time.	8.391334806909933
16809. this discovery	of melies was vastly more important than his sometimes dazzling	magician's tricks produced on film.	6.0022718218465245
16810. it was porter however	who produced the very first movie whose name has lived on through the	half century of film history that has since ensued.	10.835970524878654
16811. the movie was the	great train robbery and its effects on the young industry and	art were all but incalculable.	7.975530672067079
16812. overnight for one thing porter's	film multiplied the standard running time of movies by ten.	8.864329047817108
16813. the	great train robbery is a one-reel film.	7.993929318399889
16814. one reel- from eight to	twelve minutes- became the standard length from the year of robbery	1903 until griffith shattered that limit forever with birth of	a nation in 1915.	6.578983157256866
16815. the reel itself became and still is the standard	of measure for the movies.	7.937812674733035
16816. the material of the porter film	is simplicity itself; much of it has continued to be used over the	years and the heart of it- good guys and bad guys in the old west-	pretty well dominated television toward the end of the 1950's.	9.234578919893538
16817. a	band of robbers enters a railroad station overpowers and ties up the	telegraph operator holds up the train and escapes.	5.9248124760577525
16818. a posse is formed	and pursues the robbers who having made their escape are whooping	it up with some wild wild women in a honky-tonk hide-out.	7.526819372141849
16819. the robbers	run from the hide-out take cover in a wooded declivity and are shot	dead by the posse.	5.586682101491203
16820. as a finale is appended a close-up of one of the	band taking aim and firing his revolver straight at the audience.	9.530410714670817
16821. all this is simple enough but in telling the story porter did	two important things that had not been done before.	9.696897914193135
16822. each scene is shot	straight through as had been the universal custom from a camera fixed	in a single position but in the outdoor scenes especially in the	capture and destruction of the outlaws porter's camera position	breaks necessarily with the camera position standard until then which	had been roughly that of a spectator in a center orchestra seat at	a play.	7.638750478560331
16823. the plane of the action in the scene is not parallel with the	plane of the film in the camera or on the screen.	10.624097709511707
16824. if the change at	first sight seems minor we may recall that it took the italian painters	about two hundred years to make an analogous change and the italian	painters by universal consent were the most brilliant group of	geniuses any art has seen.	9.035114988676002
16825. in that apparently simple shift porter	opened the way to the sensitive use of the camera as an instrument of	art as well as a mechanical recording device.	9.750835564291835
16826. he did more than	that.	23.32925956575531
16827. he revealed the potential value of the cut as the basic	technique in the art of the film.	11.101745213392082
16828. cutting of course takes place automatically	in the creation of a film.	11.534044392543032
16829. the meaning of the word is quite	physical to begin with.	12.66219535679319
16830. the physical film is cut with a knife at the	end of one complete sequence and the cut edge is joined physically	by cement to the cut edge of the beginning of the next sequence.	12.266537828769524
16831. if	as a home movie maker you shoot the inevitable footage of your child	taking its first steps you have merely recorded an historical event.	5.478635162975065
16832. if in preparing that shot for the inevitable showing to your friends	you interrupt the sequence to paste in a few frames of the child's	grandmother watching this event you have begun to be an artist in	film; you are employing the basic technique of film; you are cutting.	7.340373926232604
16833. this is what porter did.	18.07116089635575
16834. as the robbers leave the looted	train the film suddenly cuts back to the station where the telegrapher's	little daughter arrives with her father's dinner pail only	to find him bound on the floor.	7.134266122194636
16835. she dashes around in alarm.	10.324754201148686
16836. the two	events are taking place at the same time.	15.286757158305646
16837. time and space have both become	cinematic.	11.149319374854999
16838. we leap from event to event- including the formation	of the posse- even though the events in reality are taking	place not in sequence but simultaneously and not near each other but	at a considerable distance.	6.986628088257087
16839. the chase as a standard film	device probably dates from the great train robbery and there	is a reason for the continued popularity of the device.	7.966041474159213
16840. the chase in	itself is a narrative; it presumes both speed and urgency and it demands	cutting- both from pursued to pursuer and from stage to stage	of the journey of both.	6.316426810080484
16841. the simple naked idea of one man chasing another	is of its nature better fitted for the film than it is for any other	form of fiction.	7.9841907921628765
16842. the cowboy films the cops and robbers films and	the slapstick comedy films culminating in an insane chase are not	only catering to what critics may assume to be a vulgar taste for violence;	these films and these sequences are also seeking out- instinctively	or by design- the peculiarly cinematic elements of narrative.	5.912034484350121
16843. there	still remained the need for one great film artist to explore the full	potential of the new form and to make it an art.	9.109426107774478
16844. the man was dw	griffith.	23.723588594397874
16845. when he came to the movies- more or less by accident-	they were still cheap entertainment capable of enthralling the unthinking	for an idle few minutes.	5.938373327463872
16846. in about seven years griffith either	invented or first realized the possibilities of virtually every resource	at the disposal of the film maker.	10.016374535471893
16847. before he was forty griffith	had created the art of the film.	11.679290526840518
16848. not that there had not been	attempts mostly european to do exactly that.	13.085296924553344
16849. but in general the european	efforts to make an art of the entertainment had ignored the slowly	emerging language of the film itself.	9.975081097102962
16850. staggeringly condensed versions	of famous novels and famous plays were presented.	7.433680387260517
16851. great actors	and actresses- the most notable being sarah bernhardt- were hired	to repeat their stage performances before the camera.	4.27094439824276
16852. in all of this	extensive and expensive effort the camera was downgraded to the status	of recording instrument for art work produced elsewhere by the actor	or by the author.	9.760313258073294
16853. the phonograph today for all its high fidelity	and stereophonic sound is precisely what the early art purveyors in	the movies wished to make of the camera.	6.843761663958459
16854. not surprisingly this approach	did not work.	12.613257243425195
16855. the effort produced a valuable record of stage techniques	in the early years of the century and some interesting records	of great theater figures who would otherwise be only names.	7.560137009282395
16856. but no art	at all was born of the art effort in the early movies.	16.48739030261624
16857. in general religious interest seems to exist in all parts of the metropolis;	congregational membership however is another thing.	8.7301738497871
16858. a congregation	survives only if it can sustain a socially homogeneous membership;	that is when it can preserve economic integration.	8.477236657633123
16859. religious	faith can be considered a necessary condition of membership in	a congregation since the decision to join a worshiping group requires	some motive force but faith is not a sufficient condition for joining;	the presence of other members of similar social and economic	level is the sufficient condition.	6.45971140479891
16860. the breakdown of social	homogeneity in inner city areas and the spread of inner city blight account	for the decline of central city churches.	10.17631246827565
16861. central cities reveal	two adverse features for the major denominations: central cities	tend to be areas of residence for lower social classes; central	cities tend to be more heterogeneous in social composition.	5.166387066066514
16862. the central	city areas in other words exhibit the two characteristics which	violate the life principle of congregations of the major denominations:	they have too few middle-class people; they mix middle-class people	with lower-class residents.	6.258989020262694
16863. central city areas have become progressively	poorer locales for the major denominations since the exodus	of middle-class people from most central cities.	6.072134720579444
16864. with few exceptions	the major denominations are rapidly losing their hold on the central	city.	11.079903346665294
16865. the key to protestant development therefore is economic	integration of the nucleus of the congregation.	10.229692579967189
16866. members of higher	and lower social status often cluster around this nucleus so that protestant	figures on social class give the impression of spread over all	social classes; but this is deceptive for the core of membership	is	concentrated in a single social and economic stratum.	9.114466806251016
16867. the congregation	perishes when it is no longer possible to replenish that core from the	neighborhood; moreover residential mobility is so high in metropolitan	areas that churches have to recruit constantly in their core stratum	in order to survive; they can lose higher- and lower-status members	from the church without collapsing but they need adequate recruits	for the core stratum in order to preserve economic integration.	5.244456066630371
16868. the	congregation is first and foremost an economic peer group; it is	secondarily a believing and worshiping fellowship.	7.133602476891582
16869. if it were primarily	a believing fellowship it would recruit believers from all social	and economic ranks something which most congregations of the new protestantism	have not been able to do.	8.263162878485103
16870. they survive only when they can recruit social and economic peers.	14.397979671396053
16871. the vulnerability of protestant congregations to social differences	has often been attributed to the folksy spirit of protestant	religious life; in fact a contrast is often drawn in this regard	with the impersonal roman catholic parish.	6.394236673549114
16872. we have seen that	the folksy spirit is confined to economic peers; consequently the	vulnerability to social difference should not be attributed to the stress	on personal community in protestant congregations; actually there	is little evidence of such personal community in protestant congregations	as we shall see in another connection.	8.24063190314993
16873. the vulnerability of	protestantism to social differences stems from the peculiar role of	the new religious style in middle-class life where the congregation is	a vehicle of social and economic group identity and must conform therefore	to the principle of economic integration.	6.461991332427185
16874. this fact is evident	in the recruitment of new members.	11.262177190497276
16875. the	rule of economic integration in congregational life can be seen in the	missionary outreach of the major denominations.	10.415129390448826
16876. there is much talk	in theological circles about the church as mission and the church's	mission; theologians have been stressing the fact that	the church does not exist for its own sake but as a testimony in	the world for the healing of the world.	10.570470942377401
16877. a crucial question therefore	is what evangelism and mission actually mean in metropolitan protestantism.	6.890421570176071
16878. if economic integration really shapes congregational life then	evangelism should be a process of extending economic integration.	11.668791315172031
16879. the task of a congregation would be defined according to economic integration	as the work of co-opting individuals and families of similar	social and economic position to replenish the nuclear core of the congregation.	6.481905373250907
16880. fill a vacancy; it can also mean the assimilation of centers of power	in a	mobile society congregational health depends on a constant process of	recruitment; this recruitment however must follow the pattern of	economic integration or it will disrupt the congregation; therefore	the recruitment or missionary outreach of the congregation will be co-optation	rather than proclamation- like elements will have to be assimilated.	6.543064934912248
16881. evangelism and congregational outreach have not been	carefully studied in the churches; one study in pittsburgh however	has illuminated the situation.	5.107406655940293
16882. in a sample of new members of pittsburgh	churches almost 60 per cent were recruited by initial contacts	with friendly members.	13.523554530101727
16883. if we add to these contacts with friendly	members the contacts with an organization of the church	then a substantial two thirds of all recruitment	is through friendly contact.	9.356366444836443
16884. on the surface this seems a sound	approach to christian mission: members of the congregation show by	their friendly attitudes that they care for new people; the new people	respond in kind by joining the church.	8.230257738568163
16885. missionary outreach	by friendly contact looks somewhat different when one reflects on what	is known about friendly contact in metropolitan neighborhoods; the majority	of such contacts are with people of similar social and economic	position; association by level of achievement is the dominant principle	of informal relations.	5.244513169635336
16886. this means that the antennae of the congregation	are extended into the community picking up the wave lengths	of those who will fit into the social and economic level of the congregation;	the mission of the church is actually a process of informal	co-optation; the lay ministry is a means to recruit like-minded people	who will strengthen the social class nucleus of the congregation.	9.200600728474756
16887. churches can be strengthened through this process of co-optation so long	as the environs of the church provide a sufficient pool of people	who can fit the pattern of economic integration; once the pool of recruits	diminishes the congregation is helpless- friendly contacts no	longer keep it going.	5.258317824546828
16888. the transmutation of mission to co-optation	is further indicated by the insignificance of educational activities	worship preaching and publicity in reaching new members.	8.420146734401584
16889. the	proclamation of the churches is almost totally confined to pastoral contacts	by the clergy and friendly contacts	by members.	6.115727869567055
16890. 1 per cent of the initial contacts with	new members.	20.280581135742757
16891. in general friendly contact with a member followed by	contact with a clergyman will account for a major share of recruitment	by the churches making it quite evident that the extension of economic	integration through co-optation is the principal form of mission	in the contemporary church; economic integration and co-optation are	the two methods by which protestants associate with and recruit from	the neighborhood.	5.339023860861084
16892. the inner life of congregations will prosper so long	as like-minded people of similar social and economic level can fraternize	together; the outer life of congregations- the suitability	of the environment to their survival- will be propitious so long as	the people in the area are of the same social and economic level as the	membership.	8.061668816165932
16893. economic integration ceases when the social and economic	statuses in an area become too mixed or conflict with the status of	the congregation.	7.052482798344512
16894. in a rapidly changing society congregations will run	into difficulties repeatedly since such nice balances of economic integration	are hard to sustain in the metropolis for more than a single	generation.	10.80016677012453
16895. the fact that metropolitan churches of the major denominations	have moved approximately every generation for the last hundred	years becomes somewhat more intelligible in the light of this struggle	to maintain economic balance.	8.632956291361083
16896. the expense of this type of organization	in religious life when one recalls the number of city churches which	deteriorated beyond repair before being abandoned raises fundamental	questions about the principle of protestant survival in a mobile	society; nonetheless the prevalence of economic integration in congregations	illumines the nature of the protestant development.	10.663556200694169
16897. it was observed in the introductory chapter that metropolitan life had	split into two trends- expanding interdependence on an impersonal	basis and growing exclusiveness in local communal groupings.	6.374542347482021
16898. these trends	seem to be working at cross-purposes in the metropolis.	8.147511534518843
16899. residential	associations struggle to insulate themselves against intrusions.	7.219864401396966
16900. the motifs of impersonal interdependence and insulation of residential	communities have polarized; the schism between central city and suburb	negro and white blue collar and white collar can be viewed as	symptomatic of this deeper polarization of trends in the metropolis.	6.95878961065685
16901. it now becomes evident that the denominational church is intimately involved	with the economy of middle-class culture for it serves to crystallize	the social class identity of middle-class residential groupings.	5.66420875768004
16902. the accelerated pace of metropolitan changes has accentuated the	drive to conformity in congregations of the major denominations.	10.197809726835413
16903. this	conformity represents a desperate attempt to stabilize a hopelessly unstable	environment.	6.474289344363617
16904. more than creatures of metropolitan forces the	churches have taken the lead in counteracting the interdependence of metropolitan	life crystallizing and perpetuating the stratification of	peoples giving form to the struggle for social homogeneity in a world	of heterogeneous peoples.	8.456836341120566
16905. since american life is committed	above all to productivity and a higher standard of economic life the	countervailing forces of residential and religious exclusiveness have	fought a desperate rearguard action against the expanding interdependence	of the metropolis.	5.827520327056596
16906. consumer communities have suffered at the hands	of the productive interests.	9.092040025257681
16907. negroes puerto ricans and rural	newcomers are slowly making their way into the cities.	7.198110130805917
16908. soon they will	fight their way into the lower middle-class suburbs and the churches	will experience the same decay and rebuilding cycle which has characterized	their history for a century.	7.824034854911129
16909. the identification of the basic unit	of religious organization- the parish or congregation- with a	residential area is self-defeating in a modern metropolis for it simply	means the closing of an iron trap on the outreach of the christian	fellowship and the transmutation of mission to co-optation.	5.491231576792489
16910. mission	to the metropolis contradicts survival of the congregation in the residential	community because the middle classes are fighting metropolitan	interdependence with residential exclusion.	11.147822518413468
16911. this interpretation	of the role of residence in the economy of middle-class culture could	lead to various projections for the churches.	6.447203476403272
16912. it could be argued	that any fellowship which centers in residential neighborhoods is doomed	to become an expression of the panic for stable identity among the	middle classes.	11.415701310465499
16913. it could be argued that only such neighborhoods can sustain	religious activity since worship presupposes some local stabilities.	9.06480886893713
16914. whatever projection one makes the striking fact about congregational	and parochial life is the extent to which it is a vehicle of the	social identity of middle-class people.	9.312725486948404
16915. attention will be given	in the next chapter to the style of association in the denominational	churches; this style is characteristically an expression of the	communal style of the middle classes.	7.21045375980988
16916. the keynotes of this style are	activism and emphasis on achievements in gaining self-esteem.	9.500645600714444
16917. these	values give direction to the life of the middle-class man or woman dictating	the methods of child rearing determining the pattern of community	participation setting the style for the psychiatric treatment of	middle-class illness and informing the congregational life of the major	denominations.	6.002289985742588
16918. fellowship by likeness and mission by friendly	contact form the iron cage of denominational religion.	8.771717653532509
16919. its contents	are another matter for they reveal the kinds of interests pursued	by the congregation.	6.5425437827926975
16920. what goes on in the cage will occupy our attention	under the rubric of the organization church.	10.889967337975571
16921. an understanding	of the new role of residential association in an industrial society	serves to illuminate the forces which have fashioned the iron cage of	conformity which imprisons the churches in their suburban captivity.	6.370602220389951
16922. the perplexing question still remains as to why the middle classes	turn to the churches as a vehicle of social identity when their clubs	and charities should fill the same need.	10.144669922955831
16923. with capital largely squandered there seemed to them no other course	to pursue.	9.071693166734782
16924. the directors sold directly to concessionaires who	had to make their profits above the high prices asked by the company.	9.87465967554784
16925. these concessionaires traded where they wished and generally dealt	with the indians through engages who might be habitants voyageurs	or even soldiers.	6.073055287865293
16926. the concessionaires also had to pay a tax of	one-tenth on the goods they traded and all pelts were to be taken to	company stores and shipped to france in company ships.	8.42106398818081
16927. the company	disposed of the pelts but with what profit the records do not show.	7.621790739929155
16928. in accord with its penurious policy the company failed to furnish	presents to hold the loyalty of the principal indians.	11.92636976957032
16929. the lavish	use of presents had been effective in expanding the indian trade	of new france and louisiana in the previous century and the change	in liberality aroused resentment in the minds of the red men.	6.923641682398208
16930. traders	from the english colonies were far more generous and indian loyalty	turned to them.	8.356285319346279
16931. protests from governors and intendants passed unheeded	and the parsimonious policy of the company probably let loose indian	insurrections that brought ruin to the company.	6.192852566509954
16932. in 1721	the king sent three commissioners to louisiana with full powers to do	all that was necessary to protect the colony.	11.104308469927664
16933. they ordered the raising	of troops and obtained 75000 livres with which to build forts.	8.529384396436171
16934. they	adopted a program by which louisiana was divided into five districts.	9.333953776432251
16935. in each of these there was to be a strong military post and a trading	depot to supply the smaller trading houses.	10.419403229165408
16936. for southeastern	louisiana	mobile was the principal post and it was to furnish supplies	for trade to the north and east in the region threatened by british	traders.	12.080133553994742
16937. mobile was to be the anchor of a chain of posts extending	northward to the sources of the tennessee river.	8.908807562819122
16938. fort toulouse	on the alabama river had been erected in 1714 for trade with the alabamas	and choctaws but money was available for only one other new	post near the present nashville tennessee and this was soon abandoned.	8.095440066121041
16939. west of the mobile district was the lower mississippi	district of which new orleans was headquarters.	10.536560617792196
16940. dependent upon it	were posts on the lower mississippi and the region westward to the frontiers	of new spain.	9.13096918803735
16941. on the middle mississippi a principal	post was to be located near the mouth of the arkansas.	10.776395109396132
16942. it was hoped	that to this post would flow a large quantity of furs from the west	principally down the arkansas river.	11.095850905270071
16943. on the ohio or wabash was to	be built another post at the fork of two great rivers.	8.290301920521935
16944. other	posts would be established up the ohio and wabash to protect communication	with canada.	10.69650458270907
16945. on the upper mississippi the illinois post was	to be established near kaskaskia and dependent posts were to be built	on the missouri where there are mines in abundance.	7.629715684665324
16946. each of the five principal posts was to have a director responsible	to a director-general at new orleans.	10.877487266205465
16947. an elaborate system of accounting	and reports was worked out and the trade was to be managed in the	most scientific way.	8.379674955664733
16948. concessionaires were to be under the supervision	of the directors.	12.059553300764566
16949. engages must be loyal to the concessionaires	and must serve until the term provided in the engagement was ended.	7.08807315943841
16950. the habitants were to be encouraged to trade and were to dispose	of their pelts to the concessionaires.	12.53349596367956
16951. only two principal storehouses	were actually established- one at mobile the other at new	orleans.	6.21452252000856
16952. new orleans supplied the goods for the trade on the mississippi	and west of that river and on the ohio and wabash.	13.170463526079617
16953. mobile	was also supplied by new orleans with goods for the mobile district.	7.463039859026617
16954. the power that bienville exercised during his first administration	cannot be determined.	11.526808379373652
16955. regulations for the indian trade were	made by the conseil superieure de la louisiane and bienville	apparently did not have control of that body.	6.947160696363815
16956. the conseil even	treated the serious matter of british aggression as its business and	on its own authority sent to disaffected savages merchandise suitable	for the peltry trade.	7.50754326356321
16957. it decided also that the purely secular	efforts of bienville were insufficient and sent missionaries to	win the savages from the heathen carolinians.	7.145349492282141
16958. during the first	administration of bienville the peltry trade of the mobile district	was a lucrative source of revenue.	12.60167299548692
16959. the alabamas brought in annually	15000 to 20000 deerskins and the choctaws and chickasaws brought	the total up to 50000 pelts.	6.171667831727814
16960. these deerskins were the raw material	for the manufacture of leather and were the only articles which the	tribes of this district had to exchange for european goods.	8.86244055445709
16961. during his first administration bienville succeeded in keeping carolina	traders out of the alabama country and the choctaw country.	8.982458147944923
16962. the	director of the post at mobile kept an adequate amount of french	goods of a kind to which they were accustomed to supply the indian	needs.	12.450917143678124
16963. the alabama and tombigbee rivers furnished a highway by which	goods could be moved quickly and cheaply.	6.458244710292096
16964. de la laude commander	of the alabama post had the friendship of the natives and was able	to make them look upon the british as poor competitors.	8.361915966134125
16965. diron d'artaguette	the most prominent trader in the district was energetic and	resourceful but his methods often aroused the ire of the french governors.	5.340061279329135
16966. he became after a time commander of a post on the alabama	river but his operations extended from mobile throughout the district	and he finally obtained a monopoly of the indian trade.	10.109122016008884
16967. the	chickasaws were the principal source of trouble in the mobile district.	7.58670252185406
16968. their territory lay to the north near the sources of the alabama	the tombigbee the tennessee and cumberland rivers and was	easily accessible to traders among the near-by cherokees.	8.670182913031606
16969. in 1720 some	chickasaws massacred the french traders among them and did not	make peace for four years.	7.339579665564462
16970. venturesome traders however continued to	come to them from mobile and to obtain a considerable number of pelts	for the french markets.	9.033602073789076
16971. british traders from south carolina incited	the indians against the french and there developed french and	british factions in the tribe.	6.6849488932830035
16972. the chickasaws finally were the occasion	for the most disastrous wars during the french control of louisiana.	9.06217713992864
16973. to hold them was an essential part of french policy for they	controlled the upper termini of the routes from the north to mobile.	8.00536682606819
16974. they threatened constantly to give the british a hold on this region	from whence they could move easily down the rivers to the french	settlements near the gulf.	8.910597607007828
16975. bienville realized that if the french	were to hold the southeastern tribes against the enticements of british	goods french traders must be able to offer a supply as abundant	as the carolinians and at reasonable prices.	6.639021256706022
16976. his urgings brought	some results.	11.489770875828032
16977. the company of the indies promised to send over a supply	of indian trading goods and to price them more cheaply in terms	of deerskins.	7.541250768314488
16978. but it coupled with this a requirement that indians	must bring their pelts to mobile and thus save all costs of transportation	into and out of the indian country.	13.13087798289248
16979. the insistence of bienville	upon giving liberal prices to the indians in order to drive	back the carolina traders was probably a factor that led to his recall	in 1724.	8.5630694919675
16980. for two years his friend and cousin boisbriant remained	as acting governor and could do little to stem the anglican advance.	9.678151052422356
16981. although he incited a few friendly indians to pillage the invaders	and even kill some of them the carolina advance continued.	7.952733830574551
16982. the company was impressed with some ideas of the danger from carolina	and when perier came over as governor in 1727 he was given special	instructions regarding the trade of the mobile district.	10.09927577918107
16983. but the	company of the indies holding to its program of economy made no arrangements	to furnish better goods at attractive prices.	7.1670010504180635
16984. to the directors	the problem appeared a matter of intrigue or diplomacy.	12.39356818219751
16985. perier	attempted to understand the problem by sending agents to inquire among	the indians.	6.849099052281829
16986. these agents were to ascertain the difference between	english and french goods and the prices charged the indians.	9.003528037298764
16987. they	were to conciliate the unfriendly savages and wherever possible to	incite the natives to pillage the traders from carolina.	6.236722447000353
16988. they were	to promise fine presents to the loyal red men as well as an abundant	supply of trading goods at better prices than the opposition was offering.	9.86417223571795
16989. perier's intrigues gained some successes.	4.6894459214429505
16990. the savages divided	into two factions; one was british and the other french.	9.130886167017161
16991. so hostile	did these factions become that among the choctaws civil war broke	out.	7.90855485905511
16992. perier's efforts however were on the whole ineffective	in winning back the tribes of the mobile district and he decided	to send troops into the troubled country.	8.39364540639394
16993. he asked the government	for two hundred soldiers who were to be specifically assigned to arrest	english traders and disloyal indians.	7.898065791130411
16994. in spite of the company's	restrictions he planned to build new posts in the territory.	11.219697413314373
16995. he asked	also for more supplies to trade at a low price for the indians'	pelts.	8.48284763688391
16996. no help came from the crown and perier in desperation	gave a monopoly of the indian trade in the district to d'artaguette.	13.129823974223713
16997. d'artaguette went vigorously to work and gave credit to many	hunters.	6.043675206156955
16998. but they brought back few pelts to pay their debts and soon	french trade in the region was at an end.	12.131318792510184
16999. perier finally in one	last bid in 1730 cut the price of goods to an advance of 40 per cent	above the cost in france.	7.825025468009356
17000. the indians were not impressed and held	to the carolina traders who swarmed over the country almost to the	mississippi.	11.297045265420532
17001. with the loss of the mobile trade which ended	all profits from louisiana the natchez indians revolted.	9.476940101983118
17002. they destroyed	a trading house and pillaged the goods and harassed french shipping	on the mississippi.	8.920165203708642
17003. the war to subdue them taxed the resources	of the colony and piled up enormous debts.	7.2106239718101195
17004. in january 1731 the company	asked the crown to relieve it of the government of the colony.	12.65419808234072
17005. it stated that it had lost 20000000 livres in its operations and apparently	blamed its poor success largely on the indian trade.	7.398414400906089
17006. it offered	to surrender its right to exclusive trade but asked an indemnity.	11.065744311311246

17008. thenceforth the commerce of louisiana	was free to all frenchmen.	9.611504248283081
17009. company rule in louisiana left the	colony without fortifications arms munitions or supplies.	5.706272678778614
17010. the difficulties	of trade had ruined many voyageurs and numbers of them	had gone to live with the natives and rear half-blood families.	8.947231635619618
17011. others	left the country and there was no one familiar with the indian trade.	11.041370984970838
17012. if this trade should be resumed the habitants who had come	to be farmers or artisans and soldiers discharged from the army must	be hardened to the severe life of coureurs de bois.	8.704549030874123
17013. this was a	slow and difficult course and french trade suffered from the many mistakes	of the new group of traders.	7.354152626157513
17014. these men were without capital or	experience.	14.332713588205483
17015. perier and salmon the intendant wished either	to entrust the trade to an association of merchants or to have the crown	furnish goods on credit to individuals who would repay their debts	with pelts.	6.2609115210874755
17016. bienville who returned to succeed perier in 1732 objected	that the merchants would not accept the responsibility of managing	a trade in which they could see no hope of profits.	9.991818021353588
17017. he reported too	that among the habitants there were none of probity and ability	sufficient to justify entrusting them with the king's goods.	6.067439232327231

17021. the king should expect	no profit and an advance of only 20 per cent above the cost in france	which would cover the expense of transportation and handling was all	he charged the traders.	8.421190280561877
17022. they would not be pleased to have it published back home that they planned	a frolic in paris or hong kong at the treasury's expense.	10.368811238115715
17023. they would be particularly displeased with the state department if	it were the source of such reports.	10.810750203665743
17024. few things are more perilous for	the state department than a displeased congressman.	9.27725422069678
17025. the reason	for this bears explaining for those who may wonder why state spends	so much of its diplomatic energy on congress when the russians are	so available.	7.096738779149185
17026. first the state department is unique among government	agencies for its lack of public supporters.	12.770883997209538
17027. the farmers may be aroused	if congress cuts into the agriculture department's budget.	6.2537254010419305
17028. businessmen	will rise if congress attacks the commerce department.	9.31781317116676
17029. labor restrains undue brutality toward the labor department; the	chamber of commerce assaults upon the treasury.	5.670000032957201
17030. a kaleidoscope of	pressure groups make it unpleasant for the congressman who becomes ugly	toward the department of health education and welfare.	10.429183028220994
17031. the congressman's	patriotism is always involved when he turns upon the defense	department.	6.301054361496545
