17036. after	all the money dispensed by state goes not to the farmer the laborer	or the businessman but to foreigners.	9.984731746991564
17037. not only do these foreigners	not vote for american congressmen; they are also probably	ungrateful for uncle's sam's bounty.	5.696134044856086
17038. and are not the state department	men who dispense this largesse merely crackpots and do-gooders	who have never met a payroll?	8.351554700215612
17039.  will not the righteous congressman	be cheered at the polls if he reminds them to get right with america	and if he saves the taxpayer some money by spoiling a few of their schemes?	6.714800817660384
17040. 	the chances are excellent that he will.	9.1143910147635
17041. the result is	that the state department's perpetual position before congress is	the resigned pose of the whipping boy who expects to be kicked whenever	the master has had a dyspeptic outing with his wife.	5.65613573214224
17042. people in this	position do not offend the master by relating his peccadilloes to the	newspapers.	8.83674839821142

17056. the department's constant	fight with the house for money is a polite minuet compared with its periodic	bloody engagements with the senate.	8.481326715322469

17079. here is the world of the	chauffeured limousine and the gossip reporter of caviar on stale crackers	and the warm martini of the poseur the spy the party crasher	and the patriot of the rented tails the double cross and the tired	lothario.	6.374691497333884

17211. as far	as i am concerned there is continuous piling up of evidence that the	creative fresh ideas which are needed in the world are going to be found	by educated women unafraid to break traditions.	8.752669194453553

17218. occasionally they return	for additional training.	12.379389757769772

17223. here again it was vacation time and there were many things i could	not see but i was able to visit with a professor who is famous	in japanese circles and be guided through the grounds by his assistant.	7.920836120797442
17224. the achievement of the desegregation of certain lunch counters not only	by wise action by local community leaders but by voluntary action following	consultation between attorney general rogers and the heads	of certain national chain stores should of course be applauded.	8.001265768755488
17225. but	for it to be just to attain this same result by means of the force of	a boycott throughout the nation would require the verification of facts	contrary to those assumed in the foregoing case.	7.618668536126973
17226. the suppositions	in the previous illustration might be sufficiently altered by establishing	a connection between general company practice and local practice	in the south and by establishing such direct connection between the	practice and the economic well-being of stores located in new york	and general company policy.	7.312507364964741
17227. then the boycott would not be secondary	but a primary one.	8.958398798253517
17228. it would be directed against the actual location of	the unjust policy which for love's sake and for the sake of justice	must be removed and indivisible from this to the economic injury	of the people directly and objectively a part of this policy.	10.712242625114557
17229. perhaps	this would be sufficient to justify an economic boycott of an entire	national chain in order by threatening potential injury to its entire	economy to effect an alteration of the policy of its local stores	in the matter of segregation.	6.386212810153393

17232. moreover prudence alone	would indicate that unless the local customs are already ready to	fall when pushed the results of direct economic action everywhere upon	national chain stores will likely be simply to give undue advantage	to local and state stores which conform to these customs leading to	greater decentralization and local autonomy within the company or even	to its going out of business in certain sections	of the country	meetings in the pre-civil war south largely went out of business	in that part of the country over the slavery issue never to recover	.	7.892195493489561
17233. in any case anyone who	fails to make significant distinction between primary and secondary	applications of economic pressure would in principle already have justified	that use of economic boycott as a means which broke out a few years	ago or was skillfully organized by white citizens' councils	in the entire state of mississippi against every local philco dealer	in that state in protest against a philco-sponsored program over a	national tv network on which was presented a drama showing it seemed	a high yellow gal smooching with a white man.	5.6096560044742025
17234. it is true	of course that the end or objective of this action was different.	15.911888682538368
17235. but	since this is a world in which people disagree about ends and goals	and concerning justice and injustice and since in a situation where	direct action and economic pressure are called for the justice of the	matter has either not been clearly defined by law or the law is not	effectively present there has to be a morality of means applied in	every case in which people take it upon themselves to use economic pressures	or other forms of force.	7.101078913280823
17236. the need that we not give unqualified	approval to any but a limited use of economic pressure directed	against the actual doers of injustice is clear also in light of the	fact that white citizens' councils seem resolved to maintain segregation	mainly by the use of these same means and not ordinarily by physical	violence.	8.56028079375935
17237. an unlimited use of economic pressures for diametrically	opposite causes could devastate the pre-conditions of any fellow	humanity as surely as this would be destroyed by the use of more obviously	brutal means.	6.345602347455057
17238. the end or aim of the action of course is also	important especially where it is not alone a matter of changing community	customs but of the use of deadly economic power to intimidate a person	from stepping forward to claim his legal rights eg against	negroes who register to vote in fayette county tennessee at the	present moment.	10.290946202504108
17239. here the recourse is in steps to give economic sustenance	to those being despoiled and to legal remedies.	7.178005516444955
17240. this however	is sufficient to show that more or less non-violent resistance and	economic conflict can be war of all	against all no less than if other means are used.	8.769422196114512
17241. it is also sufficient	to show the christian and any other champion of justice that he needs	to make sure not only that his cause is just but also that his conduct	is just ie that if economic pressure has to be resorted	to this be applied directly against those persons directly in the	way of some salutary change in business or institutional practices while	if injury fall upon others it fall upon them indirectly and secondarily	and not by deliberate intent and direct	action against them.	6.395257246260643
17242. it is clear that non-violent resistance is	a mode of action in need of justification and limitation in christian	morality like any other form of resistance.	11.420359757460838
17243. the language used	itself often makes very clear that this is only another form of struggle	for victory.	8.00077514237913
17244. one of the sit-in	leaders has said: nobody from the top of heaven to the bottom	of hell can stop the march to freedom.	9.848761923021144
17245. everybody in the world today	might as well make up their minds to march with freedom or freedom	is going to march over them.	8.056125665748068
17246. the present writer certainly agrees	with that statement and would also affirm this- in the order of justice.	10.05030456772516
17247. however it is also a christian insight to know that unless charity	interpenetrates justice it is not likely to be freedom that marches	forward.	12.241534078222756
17248. and when charity interpenetrates man's struggle for justice	and freedom it does not simply surround this with a sentimental	good will.	8.002046399788648
17249. it also definitely fashions conduct in the way explained	above and this means far more than in the choice of non-violent	means.	11.420305934099403
17250. r b gregg has written that non-violence and good will of	the victim act like the lack of physical opposition by the user of physical	jiu-jitsu to cause the attacker to lose his moral balance.	6.664813713532027
17251. he	suddenly and unexpectedly loses the moral support which the usual violent	resistance of most victims would render him; and again that	the object of non-violent resistance is partly analogous to this object	of war- namely to demoralize the opponent to break his will	to destroy his confidence enthusiasm and hope.	4.119602516172046
17252. in another respect	it is dissimilar for non-violent resistance demoralizes the opponent	only to re-establish in him a new morale that is firmer because it is	based on sounder values.	6.571464796852049
17253. a trial of strength however is made	quite inevitable by virtue of the fact that anyone engaging in non-violent	resistance will be convinced that his action is based on sounder	values than those of his opponent; and in warfare with any means	men commonly disagree over the justice of the cause.	6.975333131747817

17255. the question	then is whether sufficient discrimination in the use of even non-violent	means of coercion is to be found in the fact that such conduct demoralizes	and overcomes the opponent while re-moralizing and re-establishing	him.	7.934319488020573
17256. here it is relevant to remember that men commonly regard some	causes as more important than their lives; and to them it will seem	insignificant that it is proposed to defeat such causes non-violently.	11.12624927338866
17257. a technique by which it is proposed to enter with compulsion into	the very heart of a man and determine his values may often in fact seem	the more unlimited aggression.	7.979910355486713
17258. among christian groups the	mennonites have commonly been aware more than others of the fact that	the nature of divine charity raises decisively the question of the	christian use of all forms of pressure.	10.865863406174476
17259. since the will and word of god	are for them concentrated in christlike love it seems clear to them	that non-violent resistance is quite another thing.	6.494535660038481
17260. the primary	objective of non-violence writes the outstanding mennonite ethicist	is not peace or obedience to the divine will but rather certain	desired social changes for personal or class or national advantage.	6.909162538732081
17261. without agreeing with every phrase in this statement we must	certainly assert the great difference between christian love and any	form of resistance and then go on beyond the mennonite position and	affirm that christian love-in-action must first justify and then determine	the moral principles limiting resistance.	5.460967807904919

17351. and there is no section of the nation more	ardent than the south in the cold war against communism.	15.839898386143611
17352. had the	situation been reversed had for instance england been the enemy in	1898 because of issues of concern chiefly to new england there is	little doubt that large numbers of southerners would have happily put	on their old confederate uniforms to fight as allies of britain.	8.344822407805545
17353. it	is extraordinary that a people as proud and warlike as southerners	should have been as docile as they have.	6.59233436176499
17354. the north should thank its	stars that such has been the case; but at the same time it should not	draw false inferences therefrom.	10.52585957915197
17355. the two main charges levelled	against the bourbons by liberals is that they are racists and social	reactionaries.	7.907511924266947
17356. there is much truth in both these charges and not	many bourbons deny them.	15.792662252254575
17357. whatever their faults they are not hypocrites.	8.805289651211407
17358. most of them sincerely believe that the anglo-saxon is the best	race in the world and that it should remain pure.	16.84788920781126
17359. many northeners	believe this too but few of them will say so publicly.	8.988017965931823
17360. the bourbon	economic philosophy moreover is not very different from that of northern	conservatives.	11.600964169131608
17361. but those among the bourbons who remain unreconstructed	go much further than this.	8.571833126903753
17362. they believe that if the south	had been let alone it would have produced a civilization superior to that	of modern america.	11.2354463662472
17363. as it is they consider that the north is now	reaping the fruits of excess egalitarianism that in spite of its high	standard of living the american way has been proved inferior	to the english and scandinavian ways although they disapprove of the	socialistic features of the latter.	7.956419325418203
17364. the south's antipathy	to northern civilization includes such charges as poor manners harsh	accents lack of appreciation of the arts of living like gastronomy	and the use of leisure.	8.479609192881867
17365. their own easier slower tempo is especially	dear to southerners; and i have heard many say that they are content	to earn a half or a third as much as they could up north because	they so much prefer the quieter habits of their home town.	6.40957873347015
17366. in the past the duties of the state as sir henry maine noted	long ago were only two in number: internal order and external security.	11.84064644877362
17367. by prevailing over other claimants for the loyalties of men	the nation-state maintained an adequate measure of certainty and order	within its territorial borders.	5.380374612004389
17368. outside those limits it asserted as	against other states a position of sovereign equality and as against	the inferior peoples of the non-western world a position of	dominance.	7.7182539558381835
17369. it became the sole subject of international law		a body of legal principle which by and large was made up of what western	nations could do in the world arena.	10.06474062438069
17370. reflection of the power system in existence during the eighteenth and	nineteenth centuries.	13.732686090727256
17371. speaking generally it furthered- and still	tends to further- the interests of the western powers.	5.790672519424172
17372. the enormous	changes in world politics have however thrown it into confusion so	much so that it is safe to say that all international law is now in	need of reexamination and clarification in light of the social conditions	beyond the two basic tasks mentioned	above no attention was paid by statesman or scholar to an idea of state	responsibility either internally or externally.	9.80581525599418
17373. this was particularly	true in the world arena which was an anarchical battleground characterized	by strife and avaricious competition for colonial empires.	8.167928343024663
17374. that any sort of duty was owed by his nation to other nations would have	astonished a nineteenth-century statesman.	8.565044794915128
17375. his duty was to his sovereign	and to his nation and an extension to peoples beyond the territorial	boundaries was not to be contemplated.	7.612779858003524
17376. thus to cite but one	example the pax britannica of the nineteenth century whether with	the british navy ruling the seas or with the city of london ruling	world finance was strictly national in motivation however much other	nations may have incidentally benefited.	9.748166361568646
17377. at the same time all suggestions that some sort of societal	responsibility existed for the welfare of the people within the territorial	state was strongly resisted.	10.975258838386827
17378. social darwinism was able to stave	off the incipient socialist movement until well into the present century.	10.553576541784679
17379. however in recent decades for what doubtless are multiple	reasons an unannounced but nonetheless readily observable shift has	occurred in both facets of national activity.	6.757142478009724
17380. a concept of responsibility	is in process of articulation and establishment.	11.161511738438554
17381. already firmly	implanted internally it is a growing factor in external matters.	7.909248246210476
17382. a little more than twenty years ago the american people turned	an important corner.	18.014412424902492
17383. in what has aptly been called a constitutional	revolution the basic nature of government was transformed from	one essentially negative in nature to	one with affirmative duties to perform.	6.861124473766293
17384. the positive state came	into existence.	15.999676580661111
17385. for lawyers reflecting perhaps their parochial preferences	there has been a special fascination since then in the role	played by the supreme court in that transformation- the manner in	which its decisions altered in the switch in time that saved nine	president roosevelt's ill-starred but in effect victorious court-packing	plan the imprimatur of judicial approval that was	finally placed upon social legislation.	4.897675288479295
17386. of greater importance however	is the content of those programs which have had and are having enormous	consequences for the american people.	10.468785308424318
17387. labor relations have been	transformed income security has become a standardized feature of political	platforms and all the many facets of the american version of	the welfare state have become part of the conventional wisdom.	7.193277117763743
17388. a national	consensus of near unanimity exists that these governmental efforts	are desirable as well as necessary.	9.72355875674705
17389. ratified in the republican party	victory in 1952 the positive state is now evidenced by political	campaigns being waged not on whether but on how much social	legislation there should be.	6.5560525394174185
17390. the general acceptance of the idea	of governmental responsibility for the economic	well-being of the american people is surely one of the two most significant	watersheds in american constitutional history.	10.4054536767867
17391. the other of	course was the civil war the conflict which a century ago insured	national unity over fragmentation.	8.48589089572259
17392. a third one of at least equal and	perhaps even greater importance is now being traversed: american	immersion and involvement in world affairs.	8.55175059073224
17393. internal national	responsibility now a truism need not be documented.	7.304601479639544
17394. nevertheless	it may be helpful to cite one example- that of employment- for as	will be shown below it cuts across both facets of the new concept.	7.563201693565077
17395. thirty	years ago while the nation was wallowing in economic depression	the prevailing philosophy of government was to stand aside and allow	natural forces to operate and cure the distress.	6.591350627319598
17396. that guiding	principle of the hoover administration fell to the siege guns of the	new deal; less than a score of years later congress enacted the	employment act of 1946 by which the national government assumed the	responsibility of taking action to insure conditions of maximum employment.	8.21798865237001
17397. hands-off the economy was replaced by conscious guidance through	planning- the economic side of the constitutional revolution.	5.103227414692207
17398. in	1961 the first important legislative victory of the kennedy administration	came when the principle of national responsibility for local	economic distress won out over a state's-responsibility	proposal- provision was made for payment for unemployment relief	by nation-wide taxation rather than by a levy only on those states afflicted	with manpower surplus.	7.808616934747056
17399. the american people have indeed come	a long way in the brief interval between 1930 and 1961.	8.865639764815059
17400. internal	national responsibility is a societal response to the impact of the	industrial revolution.	10.449368576471738
17401. reduced to its simplest terms it is an assumption	of a collective duty to compensate for the inability of individuals	to cope with the rigors of the era.	7.844969349981576
17402. national responsibility for	individual welfare is a concept not limited to the united states or	even to the western nations.	12.942018755729665
17403. a measure of its widespread acceptance	may be derived from a statement of the international congress of jurists	in 1959.	9.133608295273893
17404. meeting in new delhi under the auspices of the international	commission of jurists a body of lawyers from the free world	the congress redefined and expanded the traditional rule of law	to include affirmative governmental duties.	8.447142764283589
17405. it is noteworthy that	the majority of the delegates to the congress were from the less developed	former colonial nations.	11.797660941471651
17406. the rule of law historically a principle	according everyone his day in court before an impartial tribunal	was broadened substantively by making it a responsibility of	government to promote individual welfare.	9.067546233484318
17407. recognizing that the rule	of law is a dynamic concept h which should be employed not only	to safeguard the civil and political rights of the individual in a free	society the congress asserted that it also included the responsibility	to establish social economic educational and cultural conditions	under which his legitimate aspirations and dignity may be realized.	6.301562905618165
17408. the idea of national responsibility thus has become a common	feature of the nations of the non-soviet world.	16.172707287160858
17409. for better or for worse	we all now live in welfare states the organizing principle of which	is collective responsibility for individual well-being.	8.334878787708528
17410. whether	a concept analogous to the principle of internal responsibility	operates in a nation's external relations is less obvious and more	difficult to establish.	6.667636918766841
17411. the hypothesis ventured here is that it does	and that evidence is accumulating validating that proposition.	8.235519133209372
17412. the content	is not the same however: rather than individual security it	is the security and continuing existence of an ideological group-	those in the free world- that is basic.	5.9068658629556205
17413. external national	responsibility involves a burgeoning requirement that the leaders of	the western nations so guide their decisions as to further the viability	of other friendly nations.	5.975336630329322
17414. if internal responsibility suggests acceptance	of the socialist ideal of equality then external responsibility	implies adherence to principles of ideological supranationalism.	9.23186082280197
17415. reference to two other concepts- nationalism and sovereignty-	may help to reveal the contours of the new principle.	5.035197285067069
17416. in its beginnings	the nation-state had to struggle to assert itself- internally	against feudal groups and externally against the power and influence	of such other claimants for loyalty as the church.	7.4710634123432555
17417. the breakup of	the holy roman empire and the downfall of feudalism led not more	than two centuries ago to the surge of nationalism.	7.917099265261576
17418. of the nation-state coincides roughly with the separate existence	of the united states as an independent entity it is perhaps natural	for americans to think of the nation as representative of the highest	the concept of	nationalism is the political principle that epitomizes and glorifies	the territorial state as the characteristic type of socal structure.	9.338320067723945
17419. but	it is more than that.	15.923313057921272
17420. for it includes the emotional ties that bind	men to their homeland and the complex motivations that hold a large	group of people together as a unit.	9.619587462559954
17421. today as new nations rise from	the former colonial empires nationalism is one of the hurricane forces	loose in the world.	8.88369016640216
17422. almost febrile in intensity the principle has	become worldwide in application- unfortunately at the very time that	nationalist fervors can wreak greatest harm.	7.270280030600757
17423. historically however	the concept is one that has been of marked benefit to the people of the	western civilizational group.	9.049503104972167
17424. by subduing disparate lesser groups	the nation has to some degree at least broadened the capacity for individual	liberty.	10.469047715929653
17425. within their confines moreover technological and	industrial growth has proceeded at an accelerated pace thus increasing	the cornucopia from which material wants can be satisfied.	5.822270462178442
17426. while the	pattern is uneven some having gained more than others nationalism	has in fact served the western peoples well.	9.143942145765152
17427. helped the peoples of the remainder of the world and whether	today's nationalism in the former colonial areas has equally beneficial	it is one of the ironic quirks	of history that the viability and usefulness of nationalism and the	territorial state are rapidly dissipating at precisely the time that	the nation-state attained its highest number.	6.496586100414816
17428. but	it is more than irony: one of the main reasons why nationalism is	no longer a tenable concept is because it has spread throughout the	planet.	11.613542856003725
17429. in other words nationalism worked well enough when it had	limited application both as to geography and as to population; it	becomes a perilous anachronism when adopted on a world-wide basis.	6.5998822281658525
17430. complementing the political principle of nationalism is the legal	principle of sovereignty.	10.083211972947149
17431. the former receives its legitimacy from the	latter.	8.652756066608793
17432. operating side by side together they helped shore up the nation-state.	11.13075532601728
17433. while sovereignty has roots in antiquity in its present	usage it is essentially modern.	6.807967730793366
17434. jean bodin writing in the sixteenth	century may have been the seminal thinker but it was the vastly influential	john austin who set out the main lines of the concept as now	understood.	11.174068618282035
17435. austin's nineteenth-century view of law and sovereignty	still dominates much of today's legal and political thinking.	3.9031527879765453
17436. to	him law is the command of the sovereign who	personifies the power of the nation while sovereignty is the power to	make law- ie to prevail over internal groups and to be free	from the commands of other sovereigns in other nations.	9.2467562574803
17437. these fundamental	ideas- the indivisibility of sovereignty and its dual	aspects- still remain the core of that concept of ultimate	political power.	5.348477019806357
17438. the nation-state then exemplifies the principle	of nationalism and exercises sovereignty: supreme power over	domestic affairs and independence from outside control.	6.0096719853139735
17439. in fact however	both principles have always been nebulous and loosely defined.	9.174008010771072
17440. high-level	abstractions are always difficult to pin down with precision.	7.635594905106291
17441. that is particularly true of sovereignty when it is applied to democratic	societies in which popular sovereignty is said to exist	and in federal nations in which the jobs of government are split.	8.67842675083119
17442. nevertheless	nationalism and sovereignty are reputed in the accepted	wisdom to describe the modern world.	9.082646681325308
17443. is there a different reality behind	the facade?	11.861524694588008
17444.  does the surface hide a quite different picture?	14.21965499591797
17445. 	the short answer to those questions is yes.	6.995483753841528
17446. both concepts	are undergoing alteration; to some degree they are being supplanted	by a concept of national responsibility.	8.653323964484336
17447. as evidence to support	that view consider the following illustrative instances.	8.284717776849657
17448. can thermonuclear war be set off by accident?	12.330995246470064
17449.  what steps have been	taken to guard against the one sort of mishap that could trigger the	destruction of continents?	7.124944362305295
17450.  are we as safe as we should be from such	a disaster?	15.731870458151558
17451.  is anything being done to increase our margin of safety?	8.8672224303098
17452. 	will the danger increase or decrease?	8.703394419860947
17453.    i have just asked	these questions in the pentagon in the white house in offices of	key scientists across the country and aboard the submarines that prowl	for months underwater with neat rows of green launch tubes which contain	polaris missiles and which are affectionately known as sherwood	forest.	7.280487856933462
17454. i asked the same questions inside the launch-control	rooms of an atlas missile base in wyoming where officers who wear	sidearms are manning the commit buttons that could start a war-	accidentally or by design- and in the command centers where other	pistol-packing men could give orders to push such buttons.	6.758955588422433
17455. to	the men in the instrument-jammed bomber cockpits submarine compartments	and the antiseptic windowless rooms that would be the foxholes of	tomorrow's impersonal intercontinental wars the questions seem farfetched.	4.8798036007648005
17456. there is unceasing pressure but its sources are immediate.	18.07428274238046
17457. readiness exercises are almost continuous.	7.770962487485832
17458. each could be the real	thing.	13.442387294195681
17459. in the command centers there are special clocks ready	to tick off the minutes elapsed since e hour.	8.033044388766235
17460. e	stands for execution- the moment a go order would unleash	an american nuclear strike.	9.020263413143498
17461. there is little time for the men in the	command centers to reflect about the implications of these clocks.	13.999104751278736
17462. they are preoccupied riding herd on control panels switches flashing	colored lights on pale green or gray consoles that look like business	machines.	9.076248995828825
17463. they know little about their machinery beyond mechanical	details.	9.862570833496704
17464. accidental war is so sensitive a subject that most of the people	who could become directly involved in one are told just enough so	they can perform their portions of incredibly complex tasks.	8.771143738380628
17465. among	the policy makers generals physicists psychologists and others	charged with controlling the actions of the button pushers and their	hardware the answers to my questions varied partly according to	a man's flair for what the professionals in this field call scenarios.	5.926414801661089
17466. as an air force psychiatrist put it: you can't have	dry runs on this one.	6.4272689849402305
17467. the experts are thus forced to hypothesize	sequences of events that have never occurred probably never will-	but possibly might.	6.7859848063175905
17468. only one rule prevailed in my conversations with	these men: the more highly placed they are- that is the more they	know- the more concerned they have become.	6.265215712131379
17469. already accidental	war is a silent guest at the discussions within the kennedy administration	about the urgency of disarmament and nearly all other questions	of national security.	5.950544688384707
17470. only recently new holes were	discovered in our safety measures and a search is now on for more.	9.24545854912737
17471. work	is under way to see whether new restraining devices should be installed	on all nuclear weapons.	7.055466789336521
17472. meanwhile the experts speak of	wars triggered by false pre-emption escalation unauthorized	behavior and other terms that will be discussed in this report.	8.28575498243055
17473. they inhabit a secret world centered on go codes and gold	phones.	8.143507311873597
17474. their conversations were almost invariably accompanied	by the same gestures- arms and pointed forefingers darting toward	each other in arclike semicircular motions.	6.766499497440895
17475. one arm represented our bombers	and missiles the other arm theirs.	7.629635819874177
17476. yet implicit in each	movement was the death of millions perhaps hundreds of millions perhaps	you and me- and the experts.	9.699695907846356
17477. these men are not callous.	12.944235407808204
17478. it is their job to think about the unthinkable.	19.441216559575707
17479. unanimously they believe	that the world would become a safer place if more of us- and more	russians and communist chinese too- thought about accidental	war.	4.840369313918666
17480. the first systematic thinking about this pandora's box	within pandora's boxes was done four years ago by fred ikle a	frail meek-mannered swiss-born sociologist.	6.788722026582675
17481. he was and is with the	rand corporation a nonprofit pool of thinkers financed by the	u s air force.	8.458181110228008
17482. his investigations made him the paul revere	of accidental war and safety procedures were enormously increased.	8.73925624275683
17483. in recent weeks as a result of a sweeping defense policy reappraisal	by the kennedy administration basic united states strategy	has been modified- and large new sums allocated- to meet the accidental-war	danger and to reduce it as quickly as possible.	6.0781050508080545
17484. the	chain starts at bmews	in thule greenland.	9.362794088760605
17485. its radar screens would register soviet	missiles shortly after they are launched against the united states.	6.940539677201616
17486. bmews intelligence is simultaneously flashed to norad	in colorado springs	colorado for interpretation; to the sac command and control	post forty-five feet below the ground at offutt air force base near	omaha nebraska; to the joint war room of the joint chiefs	of staff in the pentagon and to the president.	6.5403614598133055
17487. telephones	teletypes several kinds of radio systems and in some cases television	link all vital points.	6.795036541141227
17488. alternate locations exist for all key command	centers.	9.86445230802299
17489. for last-ditch emergencies sac has alternate command	posts on kc-135 jet tankers.	4.8885777088682785
17490. multiple circuits routings and	frequencies make the chain as unbreakable as possible.	7.958821617096724
17491. the	same principle of redundancy applies to all communications on these	special networks.	6.714054454179157
17492. and no messages can be transmitted on these circuits	until senders and receivers authenticate in advance by special	codes	that the messages actually come from their purported sources.	8.03142869409569
17493. additional	codes can be used to challenge and counterchallenge the authentications.	8.730115085564892
17494. only the president is permitted to authorize the	use of nuclear weapons.	13.07345610299036
17495. but what if somebody decides	to break it?	11.816204557573924
17496.  the president cannot personally remove the safety	devices from every nuclear trigger.	11.240813388626991
17497. he makes the momentous decision.	11.5867222994674
17498. hundreds of men are required to pass the word to the button pushers	and to push the buttons.	13.060114095732757
17499. what if one or more of them turn irrational	or suddenly coolly decide to clobber the russians?	10.246544540866408
17500.  what if the president	himself in the language of the military goes ape?	13.748020213625304
17501. 	or singlehandedly decided to reverse national policy and hit the soviets	without provocation?	6.22253826116565
17502.    nobody can be absolutely certain of	the answers.	12.00106878270675
17503. however the system is designed ingeniously and hopefully	so that no one man could initiate a thermonuclear war.	8.53386934833751
17504. even	the president cannot pick up his telephone and give a go order.	9.896754076003278
17505. even he does not know the one signal for a nuclear strike- the	go code.	9.20123754309232
17506. in an emergency he would receive available intelligence	on the gold-phone circuit.	12.168752044845148
17507. a system of gold- actually	yellow- phones connects him with the offices and action stations of	the secretary of defense the joint chiefs of staff the sac	commander and other key men.	5.796439112647719
17508. all can be connected with the gold circuit	from their homes.	11.28188316472807
17509. all could help the president make his decision.	10.240307221229202
17510. the talk would not be in code but neither would it ramble.	11.832219375283817
17511. vital	questions would be quickly answered according to a preprepared agenda.	7.357122202192485
17512. officers who participate in the continual practice drills assured	me that the president's decision could be made and announced on the	gold circuit within minutes after the first flash from bmews.	7.431968417654018
17513. if communications work his decision would be instantly known	in all command posts that would originate the actual go order.	6.882001135524138
17514. for	these centers too are on the gold circuit.	11.382977052843659
17515. they include the navy's	atlantic command at norfolk virginia which is in contact with	the polaris subs; nato headquarters in europe; air force	forward headquarters in europe and in the pacific which control	tactical fighters on ships and land bases; and sac which controls	long-range bombers and atlas missiles.	4.750241548500706
17516. let us look in on	one of these nerve centers- sac at omaha- and see what must	still happen before a wing of b-52 bombers could drop their h-bombs.	6.819749811813943
17517. the key man almost certainly would	be col william w wisman sac's senior controller.	6.124281822647098
17518. he	or his deputy or one of their seven assistants all full colonels	mans the heart of the command post twenty-four hours a day.	8.074974396954627
17519. it is a quiet	but impressive room- 140 feet long thirty-nine feet wide twenty-one	feet high.	6.407118658902636
17520. movable panels of floor-to-ceiling maps and charts	are crammed with intelligence information.	6.422206472364727
17521. and bill wisman forty-three	a farmer's son from beallsville ohio is a quiet but impressive	man.	5.596404258333482
17522. his eyes are steady anchors of the deepest brown.	10.025115226115789
17523. his movements	and speech are precise clear and quick.	7.347224783627735
17524. no question ruffles him	or causes him to hesitate.	12.09782044801704
17525. wisman who has had the chief controller's	job for four years calls the signals for a team operating	three rows of dull-gray consoles studded with lights switches and buttons.	5.409447034048073
17526. at least a dozen men some armed are never far away from him.	13.688960652700269
17527. in front of him is a gold phone.	16.678213632188015
17528. in emergencies the sac commander	gen thomas power or his deputies and their staff would occupy	a balcony that stretches across the length of the room above wisman	and his staff.	9.439900065673083
17529. at general power's seat in the balcony there is	also a gold phone.	6.6422031995578354
17530. general power would participate in the decision	making.	13.0751837195477
17531. wisman below would listen in and act.	8.280301608694169
17532. his consoles can give	him instant contact with more than seventy bases around the world and	with every sac aircraft.	10.072485468376115
17533. he need only pick up one of	the two red telephone receivers at his extreme left right next to the	big red button marked alert.	6.7529248216153634
17534. but wisman too does not	know the go code.	12.439376834624735
17535. he must take it from the red box.	12.839136852398592
17536. in point	of fact this is a beige box with a bright red door about one and a half	feet square and hung from the wall about six feet from the door to	wisman's right.	9.641433585545553
17537. the box is internally wired so the door can never	be opened without setting off a screeching klaxon.	6.346286423985278
17538. now we must become vague for we are approaching	one of the nation's most guarded secrets.	6.835968483987976
17539. the codes in the red box-	there are several of them covering various contingencies- are contained	in a sealed x-ray-proof unique device.	4.755296945723234
17540. they are supplied	a batch at a time by a secret source and are continually changed	by wisman or his staff at random intervals.	10.474689492323225
17541. but even the contents	of wisman's box cannot start a war.	7.3704274231699
17542. they are mere fragments	just one portion of preprepared messages.	12.003534712120773
17543. what these fragments are	and how they activate the go order may not be revealed.	8.003562487058133
17544. the pieces must	be placed in the context of the prepared messages by wisman's staff.	10.850908960090726
17545. in addition to the authentication and acknowledgment procedures	which precede and follow the sending of the go messages again in special	codes each message also contains an internal authenticator	another specific signal to convince the recipient that he is getting	the real thing.	7.161717673389946
17546. i asked wisman what would happen if he broke	out the go codes and tried to start transmitting one.	12.106463043186329
17547. i'd wind	up full of .	4.112026720967966

17549. now let	us imagine a wing of b-52's on alert near their positive control	points the spots on the map many miles from	soviet territory beyond which they are forbidden to fly without specific	orders to proceed to their targets.	5.6198562338187905

17761. poetry in persian life is far	more than a common ground on which- in a society deeply fissured by	antagonisms- all may stand.	4.834155750993789
17762. it contains in fact their whole outlook	on life.	15.312850389579337
17763. and it is expressed at least to their taste in a perfect	form.	11.225703712032415
17764. poetry for a persian is nothing less than truth and beauty.	10.856998132262984
17765. in most western cultures today these twins have been sent away to the	libraries and museums.	7.684463691325834
17766. in persia where practically speaking there	are no museums or libraries or for that matter hardly any books the	twins run free.	9.371136063683652
17767. it is perhaps difficult to conceive but imagine	that tonight on london bridge the teddy boys of the east end	will gather to sing marlowe herrick shakespeare and perhaps some	lyrics of their own.	7.0570792722616495
17768. that at any rate is what happens at the khaju	bridge.	13.663274042018568

17771. each mode is believed to have a specific attribute-	one inducing pleasure another generosity another love and so	on to include all of the emotions.	6.670391336012079
17772. the singer simply matches the poem	to a mode; for example the mode of bravery to this anonymous folk	poem: they brought me news that spring is in the plains and	ahmad's blood the crimson tulip stains; go tell his aged mother	that her son fought with a thousand foes and he was one.	6.483720169543238

17774. in this true lover's tomb interred a world of love lies sepulchred	h.	11.134933763243827
17775. these songs	are limited to a range of two octaves.	8.878123499899209
17776. yet within this	limitation there is an astonishing variety: design as intricate as	that in the carpet or miniature with the melodic line like the painted	or woven line often flowing into an arabesque.	6.885543098815637

17778. the music director of the pittsburgh	symphony orchestra william steinberg has molded his group	into a prominent musical organization which is his life.	9.388523350633438

17943. this sense of moderation and fairness is superbly exemplified	in an exchange of letters between john jay and a tory refugee	peter van schaack.	6.003057330554556
17944. jay had participated in the decision that exiled	his old friend van schaack.	10.64112914116452
17945. yet when at war's end the ex-tory	made the first move to resume correspondence jay wrote him from	paris where he was negotiating the peace settlement:	as	an independent american i considered all who were not for us and you	amongst the rest as against us yet be assured that john jay never	ceased to be the friend of peter van schaack.	5.15808022666322
17946. the latter	in turn assured him that were i arraigned at the bar and you my	judge i should expect to stand or fall only by the merits of my cause.	9.894579337839465
17947. all seven recognized that independence was but the first	step toward building a nation.	7.867272875200007
17948. we have now a national character	to establish washington wrote in 1783.	13.706284704501282
17949. think continentally	hamilton counseled the young nation.	8.352415274146335
17950. this new force love of country	super-imposed upon- if not displacing- affectionate ties to one's	own state was epitomized by washington.	5.502578578385289
17951. his first inaugural	address speaks of my country whose voice i can never hear but with	veneration and love.	6.63969960290171
17952. all sought the fruition of that nationalism	in a federal government with substantial powers.	9.74870715950076
17953. save jefferson	all participated in the framing or ratification of the federal	constitution.	7.712237438178989
17954. they supported it not as a perfect instrument but as	the best obtainable.	11.5113993768533
17955. historians have traditionally regarded the great	debates of the seventeen nineties as polarizing the issues of centralized	vs limited government with hamilton and the nationalists	supporting the former and jefferson and madison upholding the latter	position.	5.580138352808526
17956. the state's rights position was formulated by	jefferson and madison in the kentucky and virginia resolves but	in their later careers as heads of state the two proved themselves better	hamiltonians than jeffersonians.	6.275164465933833
17957. in purchasing louisiana jefferson	had to adopt hamilton's broad construction of the constitution	and so did madison in advocating the rechartering of hamilton's	bank which he had so strenuously opposed at its inception and in	adopting a hamiltonian protective tariff.	5.025926110988898
17958. indeed the old jeffersonians	were far more atune to the hamilton-oriented whigs than they	were to the jacksonian democrats.	7.695477416062453
17959. when in 1832 the south	carolina nullifiers adopted the principle of state interposition	which madison had advanced in his old virginia resolve they elicited	no encouragement from that senior statesman.	6.674318110812562
17960. in his political testament	advice to my country penned just before his death madison	expressed the wish that the union of the states be cherished	and perpetuated.	12.108624328024284
17961. let the open enemy to it be regarded as a pandora	with her box opened; and the disguised one as the serpent creeping	with his deadly wiles into paradise.	6.076011121846338
17962. nostalgic yankee	readers of erskine caldwell are today informed by proud georgians	that tobacco road is buried beneath a four-lane super highway over	which travel each day suburbanite businessmen more concerned with the	dow-jones average than with the cotton crop.	5.8691275446850755
17963. thus we are compelled	to face the urbanization of the south- an urbanization which despite	its dramatic and overwhelming effects upon the southern culture	has been utterly ignored by the bulk of southern writers.	5.271685130751566
17964. indeed it	seems that only in today's southern fiction does tobacco road	with all the traditional trimmings of sowbelly and cornbread and mint	juleps continue to live- but only as a weary overexploited phantom.	5.956021613669868
17965. those writers known collectively as the southern school	have received accolades from even those critics least prone to eulogize;	according to many critics in fact the south has led the north	in literature since the civil war both quantitatively and qualitatively.	6.227663505164898
17966. such writers as william faulkner and robert penn warren	have led the field of somewhat less important writers in a sort of post-bellum	renaissance.	9.84164909784509
17967. it is interesting however that despite this	strong upsurge in southern writing almost none of the writers has	forsaken the firmly entrenched concept of the white-suited big-daddy colonel	sipping a mint julep as he silently recounts the revenue from the	season's cotton and tobacco crops; of the stereotyped negro servants	chanting hymns as they plow the fields; of these and a host of	other antiquated legends that deny the south its progressive leaps	of the past century.	5.067034593857789
17968. this is not to say that the south is no longer	agrarian; such a statement would be the rankest form of oversimplification.	15.643962454169285
17969. but the south is and has been for the past century engaged	in a wide-sweeping urbanization which oddly enough is not reflected	in its literature.	8.627629971051563
17970. in 1900 the south was only 15% urban;	in 1950 it had become 47.	8.760307011700705
17971. in a mere half-century the south	has more than tripled its urban status.	6.9216790031844395
17972. there is a new south emerging	a south losing the folksy traditions of an agrarian society with	the rapidity of an avalanche- especially within recent decades.	10.185982911982931
17973. as	the new south snowballs toward further urbanization it becomes more	and more homogeneous with the north- a tendency which willard	thorp terms yankeefication as evidenced in such cities as charlotte	birmingham and houston.	4.998399939368814
17974. it is said that even at the present	stage of southern urbanization such a city as atlanta is not distinctly	unlike columbus or trenton.	13.64045497919454
17975. undoubtedly even the old southern	stalwart richmond has felt the new wind: william styron mentions	in his latest novel an avenue named for bankhead mcgruder a civil	war general now renamed in typical california fashion buena	vista terrace.	4.782766666240469
17976. the effects of television and other mass media	are erasing regional dialects and localisms with a startling force.	8.959906656747497
17977. as for progress the backward south can boast of baton rouge	which increased its population between 1940 and 1950 by two hundred	and sixty-two percent to 126000 the second largest growth of the period	for all cities over 25000.	5.867932722999305
17978. the field then is ripe for	new southerners to step to the fore and write of this twentieth-century	phenomenon the southern yankeefication: the new urban economy	the city-dweller the pains of transition the labor problems; the	list is obviously endless.	5.9030447366112355
17979. but these sources have not been tapped.	12.700802997273364
17980. truman capote is still reveling in southern gothicism exaggerating	the old southern legends into something beautiful and grotesque but	as unreal as- or even more unreal than- yesterday.	6.030636480189716
17981. william	styron while facing the changing economy with a certain uneasy reluctance	insists he is not to be classified as a southern writer and	yet includes traditional southern concepts in everything he publishes.	7.219406156785587
17982. even the great god faulkner the south's one probable contender	for literary immortality has little concerned himself with these matters;	such are simply not within his bounded province.	6.605469416686718
17983. where	are the writers to treat these changes?	7.124521179155247
17984.  has the agrarian tradition	become such an addiction that the switch to urbanism is somehow dreaded	or unwanted?	8.83300378254957
17985.  perhaps present writers hypnotically cling to the	older order because they consider it useful and reliable through repeated	testings over the decades.	6.654190813022345
17986. lacking the pioneer spirit necessary to	write of a new economy these writers seem to be contenting themselves	with an old one that is now as defunct as confederate money.	8.779605222355665
17987. an example of the changes which have crept over the southern region	may be seen in the southern negro's quest for a position in	the white-dominated society a problem that has been reflected in regional	fiction especially since 1865.	6.373572132805603
17988. today the negro must discover his	role in an industrialized south which indicates that the racial	aspect of the southern dilemma hasn't changed radically but rather	has gradually come to be reflected in this new context this new coat	of paint.	7.6885688488534
17989. the negro faces as much if not more difficulty in fitting	himself into an urban economy as he did in an agrarian one.	6.822198311941945
17990. this	represents a gradual change in an ever-present social problem.	7.59815601375946
17991. but there	have been abrupt changes as well: the sit-ins the picket lines	the bus strikes- all of these were unheard-of even ten years ago.	4.169325987255039
17992. today's evidence such as the fact that only three southern states	still openly defy integration	would have astounded many of yesterday's southerners into speechlessness.	5.830543058885023
17993. other examples of gradual changes that have	affected the negro have been his moving up row by row in the busses;	his requesting and often getting higher wages better working conditions	better schools- changes that were slowly emerging even before	the supreme court decision of 1954.	4.813169057811389
17994. then came this decision which	sped the process of gaining equality	: an abrupt change.	9.43483640918929
17995. since 1954 the negro's desire for social justice has led	to an ironically anarchical rebellion.	5.220075781065322
17996. he has frequently refused to move	from white lunch counters refused to obey local laws which he	considers unjust while in other cases he has appealed to federal	laws.	10.101214939533893
17997. this bold self-assertion after decades of humble subservience	is indeed a twentieth-century phenomenon an abrupt change in the southern	way of existence.	5.482209660731705
17998. a new order is thrusting itself into being.	11.512631494904435
17999. a new south is emerging after the post-bellum years of hesitation	uncertainty and lack of action from the negro in defining his new role	in the amorphously defined socio-political organizations of the white	man.	5.273798573027792
18000. the modern negro has not made a decisive debut into southern	fiction.	11.68460877107654
18001. it is clear that while most writers enjoy picturing	the negro as a woolly-headed humble old agrarian who mutters yassuhs	and sho' nufs with blissful deference to his white employer	this stereotype is doomed	to become in reality as obsolete as caldwell's lester.	5.537533741897637
18002. while	there may still be many faulknerian lucas beauchamps scattered through	the rural south such men appear to be a vanishing breed.	8.57677846476024
18003. writers	openly admit that the negro is easier to write than the white man;	but they obviously mean by this not a negro personality but a negro	type.	6.614841587692012
18004. presenting an individualized negro character it would	seem is one of the most difficult assignments a southern writer could	tackle; and the success of such an endeavor is as suggested above	glaringly rare.	9.487958474720646
18005. just as the negro situation points up the	gradual and abrupt changes affecting southern life it also points up	the non-representation of urbanism in southern literature.	6.0990644410991495
18006. the book	concerned with the negro's role in an urban society is rare indeed;	recently only keith wheeler's novel peaceable lane has	openly faced the problem.	5.340865237208588
18007. all but the most rabid of confederate	flag wavers admit that the old southern tradition is defunct in	actuality and sigh that its passing was accompanied by the disappearance	of many genteel and aristocratic traditions of the reputedly languid	ante-bellum way of life.	5.752385684967224
18008. many earlier writers mourning the demise	of the old order tended to romanticize and exaggerate this gracious	old south imagery creating such lasting impressions as margaret	mitchell's	tara plantation.	6.927312210360649
18009. modern writers who are supposed	to keep their fingers firmly upon the pulse of their subjects insist	upon drawing out this legend prolonging its burial when it well deserves	a rest after the overexploitation of the past century.	5.739270215378769
18010. perhaps	these writers have been too deeply moved by this romanticizing; but	they can hardly deny that exaggerated or not the old panorama is dead.	7.118084340053719
18011. as john t westbrook says in his article twilight of southern	regionalism: h	the miasmal mausoleum where an old south already too minutely	autopsied in prose and poetry should be left to rest in peace forever	dead and forever done with.	5.50846683762431
18012. westbrook	further bemoans the southern writers' creation of an unreal image	of their homeland which is too readily assimilated by both foreign	readers and visiting yankees: our northerner is suspicious of	all this crass evidence of urbanization presented to his senses.	6.00699610903534
18013. it bewilders and befuddles him.	12.379930678195697
18014. he is too deeply steeped in william	faulkner and robert penn warren.	13.762631861047614
18015. the fumes of progress are in his	nose and the bright steel of industry towers before his eyes but his	heart is away in yoknapatawpha county with razorback hogs and night	riders.	5.792023130155895
18016. on this trip to the south he wants above all else to sniff	the effluvium of backwoods-and-sand-hill subhumanity and to see at	least one barn burn at midnight.	10.351952874004226
18017. obviously such a northern tourist's	purpose is somewhat akin to a child's experience with disneyland:	he wants to see a world of make-believe.	4.332220992984864
18018. in the	meantime while the south has been undergoing this phenomenal modernization	that is so disappointing to the curious yankee southern writers	have certainly done little to reflect and promote their region's	progress.	8.675817051149165
18019. willard thorp in his new book american writing in	the twentieth century observes quite validly it seems: h	certain subjects are conspicuously absent or have been only lightly touched.	5.373088651365784
18020. no southern novelist has done for atlanta or birmingham what	herrick dreiser and farrell did for chicago or dos passos did	for new york h there are almost no fictional treatments of the	industrialized south.	7.6675296379994915
18021. not a single southern author major or minor	has made the urban problems of an urban south his primary source material.	6.900342903304487
18022. faulkner for one appears to be safe from the accusing	fingers of all assailants in this regard.	9.748794950563767
18023. faulkner culminates the	southern legend perhaps more masterfully than it has ever been or could	ever be done.	6.673788380015481
18024. he has made it his and his it remains irrevocably.	16.99109751484202
18025. he treats it with a mythological universal application.	10.136286950896842
18026. as	his disciples boast even though his emphasis is elsewhere faulkner	does show his awareness of the changing order of the south quite keenly	as can be proven by a quick recalling of his sartoris and snopes	families.	8.499775608008841
18027. even two decades ago in go down moses faulkner	was looking to the more urban future with a glimmer of hope that through	its youth and its new way of life the south might be reborn and the	curse of slavery erased from its soil.	6.785870431738237
18028. yet his concern even here is	with a slowly changing socio-economic order in general and he never	deals with such specific aspects of this change as the urban and industrial	impact.	7.252923924796154
18029. faulkner traces in his vast and overpowering saga	of yoknapatawpha county the gradual changes which seep into the	south building layer upon layer of minute subtle innovation which eventually	tend largely to hide the old way.	5.342282169950082
18030. thus faulkner reminds	us and wisely that the new south has gradually evolved out of	the old south and consequently its agrarian roots persist.	8.996728751921397
18031. yet he	presents a realm of source material which may well serve other writers	if not himself: the problems with which a new south must grapple	in groping through a blind adolescence into the maturity of urbanization.	5.782089781532981
18032. with new mechanization the modern farmer must perform the work of	six men: a machine stands between the agrarian and his soil.	7.732065090345467
18033. the	thousands of city migrants who desert the farms yearly must readjust with	even greater stress and tension: the sacred wilderness is gradually	surrendering to suburbs and research parks and industrial areas.	4.697294244389032
18034. another element to concern the choreographer is that of the visual	devices of the theatre.	11.284881791857705
18035. most avant-garde creators true to their	interest in the self-sufficiency of pure movement have tended to dress	their dancers in simple lines and solid colors and to	give them a bare cyclorama for a setting.	4.781706713010973
18036. but robert rauschenberg	the neo-dadaist artist has collaborated with several of them.	8.907090347075448
18037. he has	designed a matching backdrop and costumes of points of color on white	for mr cunningham's summerspace so that dancers and background	merge into a shimmering unity.	5.54104384973602
18038. for mr taylor's images	and reflections he made some diaphanous tents that alternately	hide and reveal the performer and a girl's cape lined with grass.	7.059240114326101
18039. mr	nikolais has made a distinctive contribution to the arts of costume	and decor.	8.51275791199471
18040. in fact he calls his productions dance-theatre works	of motion shape light and sound.	10.479296096927992
18041. to raise the dancer out of his personal	pedestrian self mr nikolais has experimented with relating	him to a larger environmental orbit.	6.890832233186652
18042. he began with masks to make	the dancer identify himself with the creature he appeared to be.	11.907224325239596
18043. he	went on to use objects- hoops poles capes- which he employed as	extensions of the body of the dancer who moved with them.	6.0978382911320494
18044. the depersonalization	continued as the dancer was further metamorphosed by the play	of lights upon his figure.	9.292125456306096
18045. in each case the object the color even	the percussive sounds of the electronic score were designed to become	part of the theatrical being of the performer.	8.724596581694088
18046. the dancer who never	loosens her hold on a parasol begins to feel that it is part of herself.	13.536903253425773
18047. or clad from head to toe in fabric stretched over a series of	hoops the performer may well lose his sense of self in being a finial.	8.828082494732307
18048. as the dancer is depersonalized his accouterments are animized	and the combined elements give birth to a new being.	11.087012151532061
18049. from this being	come new movement ideas that utilize dancer and property as a single	unit.	7.572066949820545
18050. thus the avant-garde choreographers have extended the	scope of materials available for dance composition.	8.756500261560674
18051. but since they	have rejected both narrative and emotional continuity how are they	to unify the impressive array of materials at their disposal?	6.652168678437368
18052.  some	look deliberately to devices used by creators in the other arts and apply	corresponding methods to their own work.	8.706067407332041
18053. others less consciously	but quite probably influenced by the trends of the times experiment	with approaches that parallel those of the contemporary poet painter	and musician.	7.444969530277992
18054. an approach that has appealed to some choreographers	is reminiscent of charles olson's statement of the process	of projective verse: one perception must immediately and directly	lead to a further perception.	6.859658764640425
18055. the creator trusts his intuition to	lead him along a path that has internal validity because it mirrors	the reality of his experience.	6.440943598962118
18056. he disdains external restrictions- conventional	syntax traditional metre.	8.512546429966784
18057. the unit of form is determined	subjectively: the heart by the way of the breath to the line.	10.393496514595709
18058. the test of form is fidelity to the experience a gauge also accepted	by the abstract expressionist painters.	11.146389465023573
18059. an earlier but	still influential school of painting surrealism had suggested the way	of dealing with the dream experience that event in which seemingly	incongruous objects are linked together through the curious associations	of the subconscious.	6.033281361304777
18060. the resulting picture might appear a maze of	restless confusions and contradictions but it is more true to life than	a portrait of an artificially contrived order.	9.696375359867558
18061. the contemporary painter	tends to depict not the concrete objects of his experience but	their essences as revealed in abstractions of their lines colors masses	and energies.	6.577978255273106
18062. he is still concerned however with a personal event.	14.952615453334385
18063. he accepts the accidents of his brushwork because they provide evidence	of the vitality of the experience of creation.	9.907453056624068
18064. the work must	be true to both the physical and the spiritual character of the experience.	13.594285307861034
18065. some painters have less interest in the experience of the	moment with its attendant urgencies and ambiguities than in looking	beyond the flux of particular impressions to a higher more serene level	of truth.	6.263001439993488
18066. rather than putting their trust in ephemeral sensations	they seek form in the stable relationships of pure design which symbolize	an order more real than the disorder of the perceptual world.	8.80243974045106
18067. but in this approach it is the artist's	ultimate insight rather than his immediate impressions that gives	form to the work.	8.461529262411924
18068. others look to more objective devices of	order.	11.40248914497294
18069. the musician employing the serial technique of composition establishes	a mathematical system of rotations that once set in motion	determines the sequence of pitches and even of rhythms and intensities.	6.536117128933175
18070. the composer may reverse or invert the order of his original set of	intervals.	11.15142141961242
18071. he may even alter the pattern	by applying a scheme of random numbers.	8.33580610296039
18072. but he cannot order his	elements by will either rational or inspired.	12.391226118020889
18073. the system works as an	impersonal mechanism.	10.977438849617691
18074. musicians who use the chance method also exclude	subjective control of formal development.	10.60436556293387
18075. again the composer must	select his own materials.	9.121963874616528
18076. but a tossing of coins with perhaps the added	safeguard of reference to the oracles of the i ching the chinese	book of changes dictates the handling of the chosen materials.	9.195621854865179
18077. avant-garde choreographers seeking new forms of continuity	for their new vocabulary of movements have turned to similar approaches.	4.987419528754469
18078. some let dances take their form from the experience of creation.	11.599470446652242
18079. according to katherine litz the becoming the process of realization	is the dance.	8.542790794984258
18080. the process stipulates that the choreographer	sense the quality of the initial movement he has discovered and that	he feel the rightness of the quality that is to follow it.	12.131558585806562
18081. the sequence	may involve a sharp contrast: for example a quiet meditative sway	of the body succeeded by a violent leap; or it may involve more subtle	distinctions: the sway may be gradually minimized or enlarged	its rhythmic emphasis may be slightly modified or it may be transferred	to become a movement of only the arms or the head.	5.183773627231957
18082. even the least	alteration will change the quality.	13.674370962070986
18083. an exploration of these possible	relationships constitutes the process of creation and thereby gives form	to the dance.	7.378126363529745
18084. the approach to the depiction of the experience	of creation may be analytic as it is for miss litz or spontaneous	as it is for merle marsicano.	10.52793997485707
18085. she too is concerned with the	becoming the process of realization but she does not think in	terms of subtle variations of spatial or temporal patterns.	7.726706334074453
18086. the design	is determined emotionally: i must reach into myself for the spring	that will send me catapulting recklessly into the chaos of event	with which the dance confronts me.	6.995758010300113
18087. looking back miss marsicano	feels that her ideas may have been influenced by those of jackson pollock.	7.584119545996523
18088. at one time she felt impelled to make dances that moved all	over the stage much as pollock's paintings move violently over	the full extent of the canvas.	9.97297947657527
18089. but her conscious need was to break away	from constricting patterns of form a need to let the experience shape	itself.	8.422311973990936
18090. midi garth also believes in subjective continuity	that begins with the feeling engendered by an initial movement.	8.525015433280867
18091. it	may be a free front-back swing of the leg leading to a sideways swing	of the arm that develops into a turn and the sensation of taking off	from the ground.	5.979343260709799
18092. this became a dance called prelude to flight.	13.459382544030912
18093. a pervading quality of free lyricism and a building from turns close	to the ground towards jumps into the air gives the work its central focus.	6.383267123208365
18094. alwin nikolais objects to art as an outpouring of personal	emotion.	9.420883315894473
18095. he seeks to make his dancers more godlike by relating	them to the impersonal elements of shape light color and sound.	7.124711859200027
18096. if	his dancers are sometimes made to look as if they might be creatures	from mars this is consistent with his intention of placing them in	the orbit of another world a world in which they are freed of their	pedestrian identities.	9.770386952437443
18097. it is through the metamorphosed dancer that the	germ of form is discovered.	12.311826299920938
18098. in his recognition of his impersonal self	the dancer moves and this self in the first revealed stroke of	its existence states the theme from which all else must follow.	9.847286721219835
18099. the	theme may be the formation of a shape from which other shapes evolve.	8.595374757465853
18100. it may be a reaction to a percussive sound the following movements	constituting further reactions.	15.012557465103303
18101. it may establish the relation of the	figure of the dancer to light and color in which case changes in the	light or color will set off a kaleidescope of visual designs.	8.540561012065387
18102. unconcerned	with the practical function of his actions the dancer is engrossed	exclusively in their motional content.	8.780087089354652
18103. movements unfold freely	because they are uninhibited by emotional bias or purposive drive.	5.496765597505155
18104. but the metamorphosis must come first.	15.727884984467964
18105. though he is also concerned	with freeing dance from pedestrian modes of activity merce	cunningham has selected a very different method for achieving his aim.	6.520922674180951
18106. he rejects all subjectively motivated continuity any line of action	related to the concept of cause and effect.	10.41669205669002
18107. he bases his approach	on the belief that anything can follow anything.	8.943482033575421
18108. an order can be chanced	rather than chosen and this approach produces an experience that	is free and discovered rather than bound and remembered.	8.495850660644015
18109. thus	there is freshness not only in the individual movements of the dance	but in the shape of their continuity as well.	9.210328721738291
18110. chance he finds enables	him to create a world beyond imagination.	10.250945973219816
18111. he cites with pleasure	the comment of a lady who exclaimed after a concert: why	it's extremely interesting.	5.606940981988427
18112. but i would never have thought of it myself.	19.323908495594146
18113. the sequence of movements in a cunningham dance is	unlike any sequence to be seen in life.	10.11576946384035
18114. at one side of the stage a dancer	jumps excitedly; nearby another sits motionless while still another	is twirling an umbrella.	10.605938309357024
18115. a man and a girl happen to meet; they	look straight at the audience not at each other.	8.989525501894393
18116. he lifts her puts	her down and walks off neither pleased nor disturbed as if nothing	had happened.	8.877126427881882
18117. if one dancer slaps another the victim may do a pirouette	sit down or offer his assailant a fork and spoon.	7.059017583813187
18118. events occur	without apparent reason.	10.490675214025023
18119. their consequences are irrelevant- or there	are no consequences at all.	5.385448623336485
18120. the sequence is determined by	chance and mr cunningham makes use of any one of several chance	devices.	13.713995373184478
18121. he may toss coins; he may take slips of paper from a grab	bag.	6.8460939620499826
18122. the answers derived by these means may determine not only the temporal	organization of the dance but also its spatial design special	slips designating the location on the stage where the movement is to be	performed.	9.84833541889204
