18519. the only extended view possible to anyone less tall than the fences	was that obtained from an upper bough of the apple tree.	6.732024548487832
18520. the primary	quality of that view seems now to have been its quietness but that	cannot at the time have impressed us.	10.526750310608874
18521. what one actually remembers	is its greenness.	9.409529722806056
18522. from high in the tree the whole block lay within	range of the eye but the ground was almost nowhere visible.	9.947352623948731
18523. one looked	down on a sea of leaves a breaking wave of flower.	8.870016698559272
18524. every path from	back door to barn was covered by a grape-arbor and every yard had its	fruit trees.	6.978213042257712
18525. in the center of any open space remaining our grandfathers	had planted syringa and sweet-shrub snowball rose-of-sharon and	balm-of-gilead.	7.2147576997227825
18526. from above one could only occasionally catch a glimpse	of life on the floor of this green sea: a neighbor's gingham	skirt flashing into sight for an instant on the path beneath her grape-arbor	or the movement of hands above a clothesline and the flutter	of garments hung there half-way down the block.	6.706414985283534
18527. that was one	epoch: the apple-tree epoch.	7.662280974846714
18528. another had ended before it began.	12.196462381802986
18529. time	is a queer thing and memory a queerer; the tricks that time plays	with memory and memory with time are queerest of all.	5.016447512851973
18530. from maturity	one looks back at the succession of years counts them and makes them	many yet cannot feel length in the number however large.	9.505538802704026
18531. in a	stream that turns a mill-wheel there is a lot of water; the mill-pond	is quiet its surface dark and shadowed and there does not seem to	be much water in it.	5.329461711452462
18532. time in the sum is nothing.	17.153540367000776
18533. and yet- a year to	a child is an eternity and in the memory that phase of one's being-	a certain mental landscape- will seem to have endured without beginning	and without end.	4.6250381198689166
18534. the part of the mind that preserves dates and	events may remonstrate it could have been like that for only a	little while; but true memory does not count nor add: it holds	fast to things that were and they are outside of time.	9.59679835461274
18535. once	then- for how many years or how few does not matter- my world was	bound round by fences when i was too small to reach the apple tree bough	to twist my knee over it and pull myself up.	5.629101429089298
18536. that world was in	scale with my own smallness.	12.302752372095688
18537. i have no picture in my mind of the garden	as a whole- that i could not see- but certain aspects of certain	corners linger in the memory: wind-blown frost-bitten white chrysanthemums	beneath a window with their brittle brown leaves and their	sharp scent of november; ripe pears lying in long grass to be turned	over by a dusty-slippered foot cautiously lest bees still worked	in the ragged brown-edged holes; hot-colored verbenas in the corner	between the dining-room wall and the side porch where we passed on	our way to the pump with the half-gourd tied to it as a cup by my grandmother	for our childish pleasure in drinking from it.	4.441814494378068
18538. it was	mother who planted the verbenas.	16.115212124137823
18539. i think that my grandmother was not	an impassioned gardener: she was too indulgent a lover of dogs and	grandchildren.	7.485111198339298
18540. my great-grandmother i have been told made her garden	her great pride; she cherished rare and delicate plants like oleanders	in tubs and wall-flowers and lemon verbenas in pots that had to	be wintered in the cellar; she filled the waste spots of the yard with	common things like the garden heliotrope in a corner by the woodshed	and the plantain lilies along the west side of the house.	6.4579901414120435
18541. these my	grandmother left in their places	and planted others like	them that flourished without careful tending.	6.127887649177441
18542. three of these only	were protected from us by stern commandment: the roses whose petals	might not be collected until they had fallen to be made into perfume	or rose-tea to drink; the peonies whose tight sticky buds would	be blighted by the laying on of a finger although they were not apparently	harmed by the ants that crawled over them; and the poppies.	6.07473258583963
18543. i	have more than once sat cross-legged in the grass through a long summer	morning and watched without touching while a poppy bud higher than	my head slowly but visibly pushed off its cap unfolded and shook out	like a banner in the sun its flaming vermilion petals.	4.894715875163003
18544. other flowers	we might gather as we pleased: myrtle and white violets from beneath	the lilacs; the lilacs themselves that bloomed so prodigally but	for the most part beyond our reach; snowballs; hollyhock blossoms	that	turned upside down make pink-petticoated ladies; and the little	dark blue larkspur that scattered its seed everywhere.	4.992641744673459
18545. more	potent a charm to bring back that time of life than this record of a	few pictures and a few remembered facts would be a catalogue of the minutiae	which are of the very stuff of the mind intrinsic because they	were known in the beginning not by the eye alone but by the hand that	held them.	7.561629432204865
18546. flowers stones and small creatures living and dead.	9.294546483541142
18547. pale	yellow snapdragons that by pinching could be made to bite; seed-pods	of the balsams that snapped like fire-crackers at a touch; red-and-yellow	columbines whose round-tipped spurs were picked off and	eaten	for the honey in them; morning-glory buds which could be so grasped	and squeezed that they burst like a blown-up paper bag; bright flowers	from the trumpet vine that made gloves on the ends of ten	waggling fingers.	3.626227669238282
18548. fuzzy caterpillars snails with their sensitive horns	struggling grasshoppers held by their long hind legs and commanded	to spit tobacco spit.	6.851574250171144
18549. dead fledgling birds their squashed-looking	nakedness and the odor of decay that clung to the hand when they	had been buried in our graveyard in front of the purple flags.	6.754803270642292
18550. and	the	cast shell of a locust straw-colored and transparent weighing nothing	fragile but entire with eyes like bubbles and a gaping slit down	its back.	6.522416990649305
18551. every morning early in the summer we searched the trunks	of the trees as high as we could reach for the locust shells carefully	detached their hooked claws from the bark where they hung and stabled	them a weird faery herd in an angle between the high roots of the	tulip tree where no grass grew in the dense shade h.	5.6492220497121615
18552. we collected	lucky stones- all the creamy translucent pebbles worn smooth	and round that we could find in the driveway.	7.751041370360318
18553. when these had been	pocketed we could still spend a morning cracking open other pebbles	for our delight in seeing how much prettier they were inside than their	dull exteriors indicated.	5.992461315335978
18554. we showed them to each other and said would	you have guessed h?	13.031793854541407
18555.  squatting on our haunches beside the	flat stone we broke them on we were safe behind the high closed gates	at the end of the drive: safe from interruption and the observation	and possible amusement of the passers-by.	5.63604263806401
18556. thus shielded we played	many foolish games in comfortable unselfconsciousness; even when the	fences became a part of the game- when a vine-embowered gate-post	was the sleeping beauty's enchanted castle or when rapunzel let	down her golden hair from beneath the crocketed spire even then we paid	little heed to those who went by on the path outside.	6.305422740988773
18557. we enjoyed	a paradoxical freedom when we were still too young for school.	8.145403722444529
18558. in	the heat of the summer the garden solitudes were ours alone; our	elders stayed in the dark house or sat fanning on the front porch.	9.223534738247105
18559. they	never troubled themselves about us while we were playing because	the fence formed such a definite boundary and don't go outside	the gate was a command so impossible of misinterpretation.	4.599260232974476
18560. we were	not however entirely unacquainted with the varying aspects of the street.	11.341759008493622
18561. we were forbidden to swing on the gates lest they sag on their	hinges in a poor-white-trash way but we could stand on them when they	were latched rest our chins on the top and stare and stare committing	to memory quite unintentionally all the details that lay before	our eyes.	5.590457825167091
18562. the street that is full now of traffic and parked	cars then and for many years drowsed on an august afternoon in the shade	of the curbside trees and silence was a weight almost palpable	in the air.	8.750943376646168
18563. every slight sound that rose against that pressure fell	away again crushed beneath it.	5.998954308303826
18564. a hay-wagon moved slowly along the gutter	the top of it swept by the low boughs of the maple trees and loose	straws were left hanging tangled among the leaves.	7.5488120730238775
18565. a wheel squeaked	on a hub was still and squeaked again.	6.86891258852641
18566. if a child watched its progress	he whispered hay hay load of hay- make a wish and turn	away and then stared rigidly in the opposite direction until the	sound of the horses' feet returned no more.	7.095405818033591
18567. when the hay wagon had	gone and an interval passed a huckster's cart might turn the corner.	6.552797912710469
18568. the horse walked the reins were slack the huckster rode with bowed	shoulders his forearms across his knees.	8.202764364161137
18569. sleepily as if half-reluctant	to break the silence he lifted his voice: rhu-beb-ni-ice	fresh rhu-beb today! the lazy sing-song was spaced in time	like the drone of a bumble-bee.	3.4658851780704913
18570. no one seemed to hear him no one heeded.	14.029294971550625
18571. the horse plodded on and he repeated his call.	9.006664165365628
18572. it became so monotonous	as to seem a part of the quietness.	19.654637914014273
18573. after his passage the street	was empty again.	9.267509857868387
18574. the sun moved slant-wise across the sky and down;	the trees' shadows circled from street to sidewalk from sidewalk	to lawn.	6.34535325781374
18575. at four-o'clock or four-thirty the coming of the newsboy	marked the end of the day; he tossed a paper toward every front	door and housewives came down to their steps to pick them up and read	what their neighbors had been doing.	5.913005256437783
18576. the streets of any county	town were like this on any sunshiny afternoon in summer; they were	like this fifty-odd years ago and yesterday.	7.211064690401435
18577. but the fences were still	in place fifty-odd years ago and when we stood on the gate to look	over the sidewalk under our eyes was not cement but two rows of paving	stones with grass between and on both sides.	6.575727334506738
18578. the curb was a line	of stone laid edgewise in the dirt and tilted this way and that by frost	in the ground or the roots of trees.	10.158875491112942
18579. opposite every gate was a hitching	post or a stone carriage-step set with a rusty iron ring for tying	a horse.	5.270161679774294
18580. the street was unpaved and rose steeply toward the center;	it was mud in wet weather and dust ankle-deep in dry and could	be crossed only at the corner where there were stepping stones.	6.951327499712408
18581. it had	a bucolic atmosphere that it has lost long since.	11.260663727191584
18582. the hoofmarks of	cattle and the prints of bare feet in the mud or in the dust were as	numerous as the traces of shod horses.	9.96186283421152
18583. cows were kept in backyard barns	boys were hired to drive them to and from the pasture on the edge	of town and familiar to the ear morning and evening were the boys'	coaxing voices the thud of hooves and the thwack of a stick on cowhide.	5.795970861422377
18584. it is worth dwelling in some detail on the crisis of this story	because it brings together a number of characteristic elements and	makes of them a curious riddling compound obscurely but centrally significant	for mann's work.	9.24835769554513
18585. the wife amra and her lover are	both savagely portrayed she as incarnate sensuality voluptuous	and indolent possibly a mischief maker with a kind	of luxurious cunning to set against her apparent simplicity her birdlike	brain.	5.5139030434806955
18586. la^utner for his part belonged to the present-day	race of small artists who do not demand the utmost of themselves	and the bitter description of the type includes such epithets	as wretched little poseurs the devastating indictment they	do not know how to be wretched decently and in order and the somewhat	extreme prophecy so far not fulfilled: they will be destroyed.	7.29565233622208
18587. the trick these two play upon jacoby reveals their want	not simply of decency but of imagination as well.	6.368040210137069
18588. his appearance as	lizzy evokes not amusement but horror in the audience; it is a spectacle	absolutely painful an epiphany of the suffering flesh unredeemed	by spirit untouched by any spirit other than abasement and humiliation.	6.732289649970212
18589. at the same time the multiple transvestitism involved- the fat	man as girl and as baby as coquette pretending to be a baby- touches	for a moment horrifyingly upon the secret sources of a life like jacoby's	upon the sinister dreams which form the sources of any human	life.	6.150546177794011
18590. the music which la^utner has composed for this episode	is for the most part rather pretty and perfectly banal.	9.611547323998598
18591. but	it is characteristic of him we are told his little artifice	to be able to introduce into a fairly vulgar and humorous piece of	hackwork a sudden phrase of genuine creative art.	6.6707547924969814
18592. and this occurs	now at the refrain of jacoby's song- at the point in fact of	the name lizzy-; a modulation described as almost a stroke	of genius.	7.579575754486931
18593. a miracle a revelation it was like a curtain suddenly	torn away to reveal something nude.	7.0323659834206955
18594. it is this modulation	which reveals to jacoby his own frightful abjection and simultaneously	his wife's infidelity.	10.365188937214448
18595. by the same means he perceives this fact	as having communicated itself to the audience; he collapses and dies.	5.910843031505695
18596. in the work of every artist i suppose there may be found	one or more moments which strike the student as absolutely decisive	ultimately emblematic of what it is all about; not less strikingly	so for being mysterious as though some deeply hidden constatation of	thoughts were enciphered in a single image a single moment.	8.812176354833378
18597. the horrifying humor the specifically sexual embarrassment of the joke	gone wrong the monstrous image of the fat man dressed up as a whore	dressing up as a baby; the epiphany of that quivering flesh; the	bringing together around it of the secret liaison between indolent	mindless sensuality and sharp shrewd talent cleverness with an occasional	touch of genius	; the miraculous way in which music revelation	and death are associated in a single instant- all this seems	a triumph of art a rather desperate art in itself; beyond itself	also	it evokes numerous and distant resonances from the entire body of mann's	work.	4.747529664016639
18598. when i try to work out my reasons for feeling that	this passage is of critical significance i come up with the following	ideas which i shall express very briefly here and revert to in	a later essay.	9.944211545016035
18599. love is the crucial dilemma of experience for mann's	heroes.	8.694842973532493
18600. the dramatic construction of his stories characteristically	turns on a situation in which someone is simultaneously compelled	and forbidden to love.	9.142822770381112
18601. the release the freedom involved in loving	another is either terribly difficult or else absolutely impossible;	and the motion toward it brings disaster.	5.847011613868741
18602. this prohibition	on love has an especially poignant relation to art; it is particularly	the artist who suffers	from it.	7.361111786807562
18603. the specific analogy to the dilemma of love is the problem	of the breakthrough in the realm of art.	8.645297461854886
18604. again the sufferings	and disasters produced by any transgression against the commandment	not to love are almost invariably associated in one way or another	with childhood with the figure of a child.	9.47569452720201
18605. finally the	theatrical notions of dressing up cosmetics	disguise and especially change of costume	are characteristically associated with the catastrophes	of mann's stories.	5.515920867260124
18606. we shall return to these statements	and deal with them more fully as the evidence for them accumulates.	11.441846827675173
18607. for the present it is enough to note that in the grotesque figure of	jacoby at the moment of his collapse all these elements come together	in prophetic parody.	8.796302063850737
18608. professionally a lawyer that is to say associated	with dignity reserve discipline with much that is essentially	middle-class he is compelled by an impossible love to exhibit himself	dressed up disguised- that is paradoxically revealed- as a	child and worse as a whore masquerading as a child.	6.638216513538118
18609. that this abandonment	takes place on a stage during an 'artistic' performance	is enough to associate jacoby with art and to bring down upon him the	punishment for art; that is he is suspect guilty punishable as	is anyone in mann's stories who produces illusion and this is	true even though the constant elements of the artist-nature technique	magic guilt and suffering are divided in this story between jacoby	and la^utner.	5.102256000971279
18610. it appears that the dominant tendency of	mann's early tales however pictorial or even picturesque the surface	is already toward the symbolic the emblematic the expressionistic.	7.715444562113812
18611. in a certain perfectly definite way the method and the theme of his	stories are one and the same.	9.314406569685364
18612. something of this can be learned	from the way to the churchyard an anecdote about	an old failure whose fit of anger at a passing cyclist causes him to die	of a stroke or seizure.	9.961135967112618
18613. there is no more plot than that; only	slightly more perhaps than a newspaper account of such an incident	would give.	8.700892947170132
18614. the artistic interest then lies in what the encounter	may be made to represent in the power of some central significance	to draw the details into relevance and meaningfulness.	9.534819754444209
18615. the first	sentence with its platitudinous irony announces an emblematic intent:	the way to the churchyard ran along beside the highroad ran	beside it all the way to the end; that is to say to the churchyard.	7.685732084742137
18616. and the action is consistently presented with regard for this distinction.	14.327330682473434
18617. the highroad one might say at first belongs to life while	the way to the churchyard belongs to death.	10.988550717490568
18618. but that is too simple	and won't hold up.	12.073757919474843
18619. as the first sentence suggests both roads belong	to death in the end.	9.988737181290928
18620. but the highroad according to the description	of its traffic belongs to life as it is lived in unawareness of death	while the way to the churchyard belongs to some other sort of life:	a suffering form an existence wholly comprised in the awareness	of death.	10.839405322021655
18621. thus on the highroad a troop of soldiers marched in their	own dust and sang while on the footpath one man walks alone.	6.650745254813522
18622. this man's isolation is not merely momentary it is permanent.	8.37712304180722
18623. he is a widower his three children are dead he has no one left on	earth; also he is a drunk and has lost his job on that account.	7.659090881485638
18624. his	name is praisegod piepsam and he is rather fully described as to	his clothing and physiognomy in a way which relates him to a sinister	type in the author's repertory- he is a forerunner of those enigmatic	strangers in death in venice for example who represent	some combination of cadaver exotic and psychopomp.	7.316869575146381
18625. this strange	person quarrels with a cyclist because the latter is using the path	rather than the highroad.	8.096939137537106
18626. the cyclist a sufficiently commonplace	young fellow is not named but identified simply as life- that	and a license number which piepsam uses in addressing him.	7.298244492280682
18627. life	points out that everybody uses this path and starts to ride	on.	6.600712374060658
18628. piepsam tries to stop him by force receives a push in the chest	from life and is left standing in impotent and growing rage	while a crowd begins to gather.	8.788442779488985
18629. his rage assumes a religious form;	that is on the basis of his own sinfulness and abject wretchedness	piepsam becomes a prophet who in his ecstasy and in the name of god	imprecates doom on life- not only the cyclist now but the audience	the world as well: all you light-headed breed.	5.225637757665669
18630. this passion	brings on a fit which proves fatal.	11.448539027114274
18631. then an ambulance comes along	and they drive praisegod piepsam away.	7.496036498161864
18632. this is simple enough	but several more points of interest may be mentioned as relevant.	12.841788598570242
18633. the	season between spring and summer belongs to life in its carefree	aspect.	8.63555863149278
18634. piepsam's fatal rage arises not only because he cannot	stop the cyclist but also because god will not stop him; as piepsam	says to the crowd in his last moments: his justice is not of	this world.	6.8742687392325275
18635. life is further characterized in antithesis to	piepsam as animal: the image of a dog which appears at several	places is first given as the criterion of amiable irrelevant interest	aroused by life considered simply as a spectacle: a dog in a wagon	is admirable a pleasure to contemplate; another wagon	has no dog and therefore is devoid of interest.	5.064491419578089
18636. piepsam calls	the cyclist cur and puppy among other things and at the crisis	of his fit a little fox-terrier stands before him and howls into	his face.	7.797612682838607
18637. the ambulance is drawn by two charming little horses.	8.044697072050106
18638. piepsam is not certainly religious in any conventional sense.	11.783773413018311
18639. his religiousness is intimately or dialectically connected with	his sinfulness; the two may in fact be identical.	5.235608474146543
18640. his unsuccessful	strivings to give up drink are represented as religious strivings;	he keeps a bottle in a wardrobe at home and before this wardrobe praisegod	piepsam had before now gone literally on his knees and in	his wrestlings had bitten his tongue- and still in the end capitulated.	7.651819822404452
18641. the cyclist by contrast blond and blue-eyed is simply	unreflective unproblematic life blithe and carefree.	5.438460635893768
18642. he	made no claims to belong to the great and mighty of this earth.	10.48926954617721
18643. piepsam is grotesque a disturbing parody; his end is ridiculous	and trivial.	6.07659643059624
18644. he is a man raving mad on the way to the churchyard.	23.742250355336832
18645. but he is more interesting than the others the ones who come from	the highroad to watch him more interesting than life considered	as a cyclist.	8.992049096230959
18646. and if i have gone into so much detail about so small	a work that is because it is also so typical a work representing the	germinal form of a conflict which remains essential in mann's writing:	the crude sketch of piepsam contains in its critical destructive	and self-destructive tendencies much that is enlarged and illuminated	in the figures of for instance naphta and leverku^hn.	8.091139268012762
18647. in method as well as in theme this little anecdote with its details	selected as much for expressiveness and allegory as for realism	anticipates a kind of musical composition as well as a kind of fictional	composition in which as leverku^hn says there shall be	nothing unthematic.	7.5465452352842
18648. it resembles too pictures such as du^rer	and bruegel did in which all that looks at first to be solely pictorial	proves on inspection to be also literary the representation of a	proverb for example or a deadly sin.	8.481642817620344
18649. gladius dei	resembles the way to the churchyard in its representation	of a conflict between light and dark between life and a spirit	of criticism negation melancholy but it goes considerably further	in characterizing the elements of this conflict.	7.1563067715097555
18650. the monk savonarola	brought over from the renaissance and placed against the background	of munich at the turn of the century protests against the luxurious	works displayed in the art-shop of m bluthenzweig; in	particular against a madonna portrayed in a voluptuous style and modeled	according to gossip upon the painter's mistress.	7.179336907059023
18651. hieronymus	like piepsam makes his protest quite in vain and his rejection though	not fatal is ridiculous and humiliating; he is simply thrown out	of the shop by the porter.	4.863664343825003
18652. on the street outside hieronymus envisions	a holocaust of the vanities of this world such a burning of artistic	and erotic productions as his namesake actually brought to pass in	florence and prophetically he issues his curse: gladius dei	super terram cito et velociter.	6.929845001385013
18653. the reality to which they respond is rationally empty and their	art is an imitation of the inescapable powerfulness of this unknown and	empty world.	6.68215572296009
18654. their artistic rationale is given to the witness of unreason.	11.992814863833974
18655. these polar concerns reflect	a philosophical and religious situation which has been developing	over a long period of time.	8.417035685743096
18656. the breakdown of classical structures of	meaning in all realms of western culture has given rise to several generations	of artists who have documented the disintegrative processes.	9.356235903816719
18657. thus the image of man has suffered complete fragmentation in personal	and spiritual qualities and complete objectification in sub-human and	quasi-mechanistic powers.	6.6406501187395115
18658. the image of the world tends to reflect the	hostility and indifference of man or else to dissolve into empty spaces	and overwhelming mystery.	11.936371598392437
18659. the image of god has simply disappeared.	16.163250433656742
18660. all such imitations of negative quality have given rise to a compensatory	response in the form of a heroic and highly individualistic humanism:	if man can neither know nor love reality as it is he can at	least invent an artistic reality which is its own world and which	can speak to man of purely personal and subjective qualities capable	of being known and worthy of being loved.	8.455426497068375
18661. the person of the artist	becomes a final bastion of meaning in a world rendered meaningless by	the march of events and the decay of classical religious and philosophical	systems.	7.311776256894099
18662. whatever pole of this contrast one emphasizes and	whatever the tension between these two approaches to understanding	the artistic imagination it will be readily seen that they are not mutually	exclusive that they belong together.	8.71464568262661
18663. without the decay of a	sense of objective reference the	stress on subjective invention would never have been stimulated into	being.	6.5141404444885564
18664. and although these insights into the nature of art may be in themselves	insufficient for a thoroughgoing philosophy of art their peculiar	authenticity in this day and age requires that they be taken seriously	and gives promise that from their very substance new and valid	chapters in the philosophy of art may be written.	9.89758714153142
18665. for better or worse	we cannot regard imitation in the arts in the simple mode of	classical rationalism or detached realism.	7.574980077212097
18666. a broader concept of imitation	is needed one which acknowledges that true invention is important	that the artist's creativity in part transcends the non-artistic	causal factors out of which it arises.	6.842645588826892
18667. on the other hand we cannot regard	artistic invention as pure uncaused and unrelated to the times	in which it occurs.	8.458490636117899
18668. we need a doctrine of imitation to save us from	the solipsism and futility of pure formalism.	11.741182591554107
18669. accordingly it is the	aim of this essay to advance a new theory of imitation	call mimesis in order to distinguish it from earlier theories of	and a new theory of invention	.	6.9917545144896325
18670. the arts	the word mimesis is usually associated	with plato and aristotle.	10.168922450478734
18671. for plato imitation is twice	removed from reality being a poor copy of physical appearance which	in itself is a poor copy of ideal essence.	7.621638953349807
18672. all artistic and mythological	representations therefore are imitations of imitations and	are completely superseded by the truth value of dialectic the	proper use of the inquiring intellect.	8.653899709798342
18673. in plato's judgment the	arts play a meaningful role in society only in the education of the young	prior to the full development of their intellectual powers.	7.016177771008917
18674. presupposed	in plato's system is a doctrine of levels of insight in which	a certain kind of detached understanding is alone capable of penetrating	to the most sublime wisdom.	7.259179045760733
18675. aristotle also tended to stratify all	aspects of human nature and activity into levels of excellence and	like plato he put the pure and unimpassioned intellect on the top level.	6.24348817909003
18676. the poetics in affirming that all human arts are modes	of imitation gives a more serious role to artistic mimesis than	did plato.	8.374905168627656
18677. but aristotle kept the principle of levels and even augmented	it by describing in the poetics what kinds of character and	action must be imitated if the play is to be a vehicle of serious and	important human truths.	7.961866444650516
18678. for both plato and aristotle artistic mimesis	in contrast to the power of dialectic is relatively incapable of	expressing the character of fundamental reality.	11.608472326041575
18679. the central	concern of erich auerbach's impressive volume called mimesis	is to describe the shift from a classic theory of imitation	to a christian theory of imitation	in which the levels are dissolved.	5.313694819532106
18680. following the theme of incarnation	in the gospels the christian artist and critic sees in the most	commonplace and ordinary events figures of divine power and reality.	8.464438129427462
18681. here artistic realism involves the audience in an impassioned participation	in events whose overtones and implications are transcendent.	7.046725936186148
18682. artistic mimesis under christian influence records the involvement	of all persons however humble in a divine drama.	7.639139232562272
18683. the artist unlike	the philosopher is not a removed observer aiming at neutral and rarified	high levels of abstraction.	7.23558800596223
18684. he is the conveyor of a sacred reality	by which he has been grasped.	14.774206371812813
18685. i have chosen to use the word mimesis	in its christian rather than its classic implications and	to discover in the concrete forms of both art and myth powers of theological	expression which as in the christian mind are the direct consequence	of involvement in historical experience which are not reserved	as in the greek mind only to moments of theoretical reflection.	6.849883225634387
18686. in the first instance mimesis is here used to mean the	recalling of experience in terms of vivid images rather than in terms	of abstract ideas or conventional designations.	11.986482969986161
18687. by image is meant	not only a visual presentation but also remembered sensations of any	of the five senses plus the feelings which are immediately conjoined	therewith.	6.0216735664997865
18688. this is the primary function of the imagination operating	in the absence of the original experiential stimulus by which the images	were first appropriated.	13.844304246306196
18689. mimesis is the nearest possible thing to	the actual re-living of experience in which the imagining person recovers	through images something of the force and depth characteristic	of experience itself.	6.251459172617916
18690. the images themselves like their counterparts	in experience are not neutral qualities to be surveyed dispassionately;	they are fields of force exerting a unique influence on the sensibilities	and a unique relatedness to one another.	7.2878130335138565
18691. they bring an inextricable	component of value within themselves with attractions and repulsions	native to their own quality.	7.755886024658223
18692. as in experience one is seized by	given entities and their interrelations and is forced to respond in	value feelings to them so one is similarly seized in the mimetic presentation	of images.	9.245268280538292
18693. mimesis here is not to be confused with literalism	or realism in the conventional sense.	9.101459936275674
18694. a word taken in its dictionary	meaning a photographic image of a recognizable object the mere picturing	of a scene tends to lose experiential vividness and to connote	such conventional abstractions as to invite neutral reception without	the incitement of value feelings.	7.727103570788124
18695. similarly experience itself can	be conventionalized so that people react to certain preconceived clues	for behavior without awareness of the vitality of their experiential	field.	6.804379957760121
18696. a truly vivid imagination moves beyond the conventional recollection	to a sense of immediacy.	10.009212568731728
18697. the mimetic character of the	imaginative consciousness tends to express itself in the presentation	of artistic forms and materials.	6.926394363054478
18698. when words can be used in a more fresh	and primitive way so that they strike with the force of sights and	sounds when tones of sound and colors of paint and the carven shape	all strike the sensibilities with an undeniable force of data in and of	themselves compelling the observer into an attitude of attention all	this imitates the way experience itself in its deepest character strikes	upon the door of consciousness and clamors for entrance.	8.743674504090796
18699. these	are like the initial ways in which the world forces itself upon the self	and thrusts the self into decision and choice.	7.759914705736477
18700. the presence of genuine	mimesis in art is marked by the persistence with which the work	demands attention and compels valuation even though it is but vaguely	understood.	11.617892308506246
18701. underlying these conceptions of mimesis are certain	presuppositions concerning the nature of primary human experience which	require some exposition before the main argument can proceed.	5.86148404896363
18702. experience	is not seen as it is in classical rationalism as presenting	us initially with clear and distinct objects simply located in space	and	registering their character movements and changes on the tabula	rasa of an uninvolved intellect.	8.464388276622099
18703. neither is primary experience understood	according to the attitude of modern empiricism in which nothing	is thought to be received other than signals of sensory qualities producing	their responses in the appropriate sense organs.	7.294522182756205
18704. primary feelings	of the world come neither as a collection of clearly known objects	nor a collection of isolated and	neutral sensory qualities.	8.67798633726296
18705. in contrast to all this primary data are	data of a self involved in environing processes and powers.	8.484371629007835
18706. the	most primitive feelings are rudimentary value feelings both positive	and negative: a desire to appropriate this or that part of the environment	into oneself; a desire to avoid and repel this or that other	part.	8.069057249937343
18707. these desires presuppose a sense of causally efficacious powers	in which one is involved some working for one's good others threatening	ill.	5.44275550425274
18708. gone is the tabula rasa of the mind.	9.463792759748301
18709. in its place	is a passionate consciousness grasped and molded to feelings of positive	or negative values even as the actions of one's life are determined	by constellations of process in which one is caught.	5.595637872745073
18710. the principal	defender of this view of primary experience as causal efficacy	is alfred north whitehead.	10.885632308009427
18711. our most elemental and unavoidable	impressions he says are those of being involved in a large arena of	powers which have a longer past than our own which are interrelated	in a vast movement through the present toward the future.	6.618812938838088
18712. we feel the	quality of these powers initially as in some degree wholesome or threatening.	11.568712617615871
18713. later abstractive and rational processes may indicate errors	of judgment in these apprehensions of value but the apprehensions themselves	are the primary stuff of experience.	6.140217710229164
18714. it takes a great deal	of abstraction to free oneself from the primitive impression of larger	unities of power and influence and to view one's world simply as a	collection of sense data arranged in such and such sequence and pattern	devoid of all power to move the feelings and actions except in so far	as they present themselves for inspection.	8.328320575405098
18715. whitehead is here questioning	david hume's understanding of the nature of experience; he	is questioning also every epistemology which stems from hume's	presupposition	that experience is merely sense data in abstraction from	causal efficacy and that causal efficacy is something intellectually	imputed to the world not directly perceived.	5.350161095211279
18716. what hume calls sensation	is what whitehead calls perception in the mode of presentational	immediacy which is a sophisticated abstraction from perception	in the mode of causal efficacy.	9.83312358760077
18717. as long as perception is seen as	composed only of isolated sense data most of the quality and interconnectedness	of existence loses its objectivity becomes an invention	of consciousness and the result is a philosophical scepticism.	8.346849528921323
18718. whitehead	contends that the human way of understanding existence as a unity	of interlocking and interdependent processes which constitute each other	and which cause each other to be and not to be is possible only because	the basic form of such an understanding for all its vagueness and	tendency to mistake the detail is initially given in the way man	feels the world.	9.160081905564251
18719. in this respect experience is broader and full of	a richer variety of potential meanings than the mind of man or any of	his arts or culture are capable of making clear and distinct.	7.584965925063404
18720. a chief characteristic of experience in the mode of causal efficacy is	one of derivation from the past.	12.399090497334246
18721. both i and my feelings come up out	of a chain of events that fan out into the past into sources that are	ultimately very unlike the entity which i now am.	6.90060526765724

18858. a dominant motive is the poet's longing	for his homeland and its boyhood associations: not men-folk but	the fields where i would stray the stones where as a child i used	to play.	6.266322136152602
18859. he is utterly disappointed in himself and in the desultory	life he has been leading.	11.566819973369443
18860. what he really wants is to find a	sacred cause to which he can honestly devote himself.	12.643610307702403
18861. this restless	individualism found its answer when he returned to live nearly all	the rest of his life in sweden.	9.002478168372907
18862. his cause was to commemorate the glory	of her past and to incite her people to perpetuate it in the present.	8.910935746534
18863. he did not however find himself at once.	13.497946429818143
18864. his next major	work completed in 1892 was a long fantastic epic in prose entitled	hans alienus which professor bo^o^k describes as a monument	on the grave of his carefree and indolent youth.	6.431180736408911
18865. the hero who is	himself is represented as a pilgrim in the storied lands of the east	a sort of faustus type who to quote from professor bo^o^k again	even in the pleasure gardens of sardanapalus can not cease from	his painful search after the meaning of life.	5.6392599882378285
18866. he is driven back by	his yearning to the wintry homeland of his fathers in the forest of	tiveden.	10.878011920095755
18867. from this time on heidenstam proceeded to find his	deeper self.	9.552348800524118
18868. by the death of his father in 1888 he had come into possession	of the family estate and had re-assumed its traditions.	11.407801478147585
18869. he	did not however settle back into acquiescence with things as they were.	6.972012964976671
18870. like his friend and contemporary august strindberg he had little	patience with collective mediocrity.	10.085891979244277
18871. he saw sweden as a country of	smug and narrow provincialism indifferent to the heroic spirit of its	former glory.	7.095948327812407
18872. strindberg's remedy for this condition was to tear	down the old structures and build anew from the ground up.	7.960272935715556
18873. heidenstam's	conception on the contrary was to revive the present by the memories	of the past.	5.827787134748383
18874. whether in prose or poetry all of heidenstam's	later work was concerned with sweden.	8.838687952360582
18875. with the first of a group	of historical novels the charles men published	in 1897-8 he achieved the masterpiece of his career.	8.103312535307248
18876. in scope	and power it can only be compared to tolstoy's war and peace.	9.745504718871267
18877. about one-third as long it is less intimate and detailed but better	coordinated more concise and more dramatic.	5.197805082321748
18878. though it centers around	the brilliant and enigmatic figure of charles 12 the true hero	is not finally the king himself.	9.986520140169194
18879. hence the title of the book referring	to the soldiers and subjects of the king; on the fatal battlefield	of poltava to quote from the novel the wreath he twined for	himself slipped down upon his people.	6.120277221982742
18880. the charles men	consists not of a connected narrative but of a group of short stories	each depicting a special phase of the general subject.	10.056976558475618
18881. somewhat uneven	in interest for an average reader eight or ten of these are among	the finest of their kind in literature.	6.553433630895128
18882. they comprise a great variety	of scene and interest: grim episodes of war idyllic interludes superb	canvases of world-shaking events and delightfully humorous sketches	of odd characters.	5.953329010438817
18883. the general effect is tragic.	11.913118443611337
18884. almost nothing	is said of charles' spectacular victories the central theme being	the heroic loyalty of the swedish people to their idolized king in misfortune	and defeat.	7.291680485200391
18885. to carry out this exalted conception the	author has combined the vivid realism and imaginative power we have noticed	in his early poetry and carried them out on a grand scale.	7.355042969957854
18886. his	peculiar gift as had been suggested before is his intensity.	9.834148896278636
18887. george	meredith has said that fervor is the core of style.	8.963553512790957
18888. of few authors	is this more true than of heidenstam.	12.895847379491638
18889. the charles men has a tremendous	range of characters of common folk even more than of major	figures.	7.894532703238908
18890. the career of charles 12 is obviously very similar to that	of napoleon.	12.851048608786925
18891. his ideal was alexander of macedon as napoleon's	was julius caesar.	5.489277593037578
18892. his purpose however was not to establish an	empire but to assert the principle of divine justice.	12.215868171040139
18893. each aspired	to be a god in human form but with each it was a different kind of god.	8.796875546139505
18894. each failed catastrophically in an invasion of russia and each brought	ruin on the country that worshipped him.	9.844089899629623
18895. each is still glorified	as a national hero.	9.193807132044645
18896. the first half of the charles men	ending on the climax of the battle of poltava in 1709 is more dramatically	coherent than the second.	14.035673488342285
18897. after the collapse of that desperate	and ill-fated campaign the character of the king degenerated for a	time into a futility that was not merely pitiable but often ridiculous.	7.261120458933179
18898. like napoleon he was the worst of losers.	12.749280179795896
18899. there are however some	wonderful chapters at the beginning of the second part concerning	the reactions of the swedes in adversity.	10.197485044428308
18900. then more than ever before	did they show their fortitude and patient cheerfulness.	10.624528389062059
18901. this comes	out in when the bells ring which describes the rallying of the	peasants in southern sweden to repel an invasion by the danes.	6.156112269516297
18902. in the king's ride charles breaks out of a long period	of petulance and inertia regains his old self escapes from turkey	and finally reaches his own land after an absence of eighteen years.	7.66373902235384
18903. he finds it in utter misery and desolation.	10.083231465637732
18904. all his people ask for	is no more war.	11.4418120341996
18905. but he plunges into yet another this time with norway	and is killed in an assault on the fortress of fredrikshall being	only thirty-six years of age when he died.	7.5843126243169925
18906. he had become king at fifteen.	16.928187144975247
18907. then suddenly there was a tremendous revulsion of popular	feeling.	8.835061309666605
18908. from being a hated tyrant and madman he was now the symbol	of all that was noblest and best in the history of sweden.	10.592717367283203
18909. this is	brought out in the next to last chapter of the book a hero's	funeral written in the form of an impassioned prose poem.	9.083316087059355
18910. slowly	the procession of warriors and statesmen passes through the snow beside	the black water and into the brilliantly lighted cathedral the shrine	of so many precious memories.	7.258071825552662
18911. the guns are fired the hymns are	sung and the body of charles is carried down to the vault and laid beside	the tombs of his ancestors.	7.277412385950775
18912. as he had longed to be he became the	echo of a saga.	13.1888095876881
18913. heidenstam wrote four other works of fiction	about earlier figures revered in swedish memory.	6.445457072627249
18914. excellent in their	way they lack the wide appeal of the charles men and need	not detain us here.	9.99047393728934
18915. it is different with his volume the swedes	and their chieftains a history	intended for the general reader and particularly suited for high	school students.	8.115937423870978
18916. admirably written it is a perfect introduction to swedish	history for readers of other countries.	9.653747080961232

18920. the record	teems with romance and adventure.	11.55428287079168
18921. gustaf vasa is a superb example	and charles 10 the conqueror of denmark hardly less so.	5.3990293830770435
18922. of	gustavus adolphus and charles 12 it is unnecessary to speak.	9.034309825523442
18923. today the private detective will also investigate insurance claims or	handle divorce cases but his primary function remains what it has always	been to assist those who have money in their unending struggle with	those who have not.	6.772647822492416
18924. it is from this unpromising background that the	fictional private detective was recruited.	14.734414254715293
18925. the mythological	private eye differs from his counterpart in real life in two essential	ways.	8.76143696837147
18926. on the one hand he does not work for a large agency but	is almost always self-employed.	15.621813103876546
18927. as a free-lance investigator the fictional	detective is responsible to no one but himself and his client.	7.994590344943428
18928. for this reason he appears as an independent and self-reliant figure	whose rugged individualism need not be pressed into the mold of a	9 to 5 routine.	9.755861723726635
18929. on the other hand the fictional detective does not	break strikes or handle divorce cases; no client would ever think of	asking him to do such things.	7.786471770210377
18930. whatever his original assignment the	fictional private eye ends up by investigating and solving a crime usually	a murder.	8.918628127836707
18931. operating as a one man police force in fact if not in	name he is at once more independent and more dedicated than the police	themselves.	8.43091688469714
18932. he catches criminals not merely because he is paid to	do so but because he enjoys	his work because he firmly believes that murder must be punished.	9.913559474276441
18933. thus the fictional detective is much more than a simple businessman.	11.590880492147484
18934. he is first and foremost a defender of public morals a servant of	society.	12.579165842490525
18935. it is this curious blend of rugged individualism and	public service which accounts for the great appeal of the mythological	detective.	10.30339505700538
18936. by virtue of his self-reliance his individualism and	his freedom from external restraint the private eye is a perfect embodiment	of the middle class conception of liberty which amounts to doing	what you please and let the devil take the hindmost.	9.375142413461246
18937. at the same time	because the personal code of the detective coincides with the legal	dictates of his society because he likes to catch criminals he is	in middle class eyes a virtuous man.	6.991316999894017
18938. in this way the private detective	gets the best of two possible worlds.	16.647920507341794
18939. he is an individualist but	not an anarchist; he is a public servant but not a cop.	7.419585629824515
18940. in short the	fictional private eye is a specialized version of adam smith's	ideal entrepreneur the man whose private ambitions must always and everywhere	promote the public welfare.	9.036908829608988
18941. in the mystery story as in the	wealth of nations individualism and the social good are two sides	of the same benevolent coin.	7.988733387367815
18942. there is only one	catch to this idyllic arrangement: adam smith was wrong.	13.454581654753031
18943. not only	did the ideal entrepreneur not produce the greatest good for the greatest	number he ended by destroying himself by giving birth to monopoly	capitalism.	6.888931127758279
18944. the rise of the giant corporations in western europe	and the united states dates from the period 1880-1900.	11.890514745848916
18945. now although	the roots of the mystery story in serious literature go back as far	as balzac dickens and poe it was not until the closing decades	of the 19th century that the private detective became an established	figure in popular fiction.	7.1663587287090955
18946. sherlock holmes the ancestor of all private	eyes was born during the 1890s.	8.702680216672505
